Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

In keeping with the recent thread concerning more details on events:
Liquid Drano is free, and everyone is welcome.  It will be out of doors
somewhere in the san francisco bay area.

Why? We do the Liquid Air series of parties because we like to. they are
not elaborate productions, and all of the materials necessary are present
and taken care of.  Donations are never turned away, but neither is money
solicited.  What~is~ solicited is active participation.  We welcome 
everyone to these parties regardless of which category they think they
might fall into or describe themselves as; we do this because we believe
in inclusion.  We don't announce the location until the night of the party
(usually) because we prefer to avoid inflexible authorities, and because 
sometimes we've found great spaces the day of the event (i'm reminded of 
a certain tunnel :) ).
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

Unlurking to offer a possible answer to Michael's "arrest a friend" question. 
Often, the American Heart/Diabetes/Cancer/Horrible Disease Associations will 
have fundraisers where a person is "arrested" from their place of business 
and taken to "jail." The person then has to "post bail" by calling friends 
and asking them to donate money to get him/her out of jail. All of the money 
goes to the Association, and it's supposed to be pretty fun. Sometimes the 
people arrested are celebrities, which adds to the spirit of the fundraiser.

Hope that helps. Hope I'm right! Have a fantastic three-day weekend, 
everyone!!!

--Lynn

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: FREEDOM FYI; disclosure of terms
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu> says:

>All of you out there in computerland must remember that this is a RAVE, 

>not a concert.  The difference between the two is that it is underground, 

>so a lot of the information that is normally facilitated to people is not 

>given. 

I'm sorry, but "raves" stopped being "underground" a long time ago.  Hell,
there is even a Usenet newgroup for them, alt.rave :-)  You can find out
about raves by looking in several nationally-distributed magazines (XLR8R,
Urb, Slurp!, Reactor), they've been on TV numerous times (fictionally and
non-fictionally), they've been in the "New York Times" and "Rolling Stone."
I see flyers for upcoming raves in clothing and record stores all over.  In
LA I saw rave flyers in restaraunts in the Melrose area.  I've seen raves 
listed in the Village Voice's weekly entertainment calendar.  Most parties
that might call themselves "rave" in SF are held in clubs anyway, which 
strikes me as being quite aboveground as these clubs have permanent known 
addresses that anyone who has ever heard of them can just show up.

I think the difference between a "rave" and a "concert" is that "rave"
encourages active participation, whereas a "concert" is still much more
in the "watch-the-band-up-there-on-stage" producer(band)/consumer(concert-goer)
paradigm.  This is the thing to focus on to KEEP "rave" different from
"concert." :-)

Anyeay, the big mainstream parties such as Wicked, Basics, Cool World, Sharon,
etc. HAVE to be legal to happen, so what is the point in being so 
faux-secretive about them?  Might as well give the age requirements and if you 
can bring in food and water up front.

The renegades are a *slightly* different story -- of course organziers of 
things like the FMRs, the NMRs, Spiral Jive, etc don't want to give out 
location information in advance because the parties are being done illegally 
according to the strict letter of the law.  But still, the phone lines and
other announcements can still say if there are any age or food/water 
requirements.

Laura

All of you who wanted to know what breakbeat was, what hardcore was, how 
to tell the difference, what the heck "rotterdam" and "gabber" are, here 
is your chance!

The best way to learn these things is by hearing lots of examples, so come 
on out to "Liquid Draino" on Sunday night, July 3rd.  As usual for the 
Liquid * parties, it will start by midnight and will go until we decide by 
mutual consent to stop it.  So get there at the beginning 'cause if we have 
to re-locate or get tired you might not find us later.

This will be a free outdoor all ages party.  Bring food, water, blankets, 
toys, ear plugs, friends, pets, whatever you want EXCEPT FIREWORKS (but those 
little hand-held sparklers are cool if you are really careful).

You can get more info by calling (415) - 985 - 5244.  Bryce calls the 
party "Compressed Air" on the tape but it's the same party as "Liquid 
Draino," he changed the name because the second name sounded cooler :-).
Location info will be put on the voice mail the evening of the event, and 
you'll also be able to finger me for directions.

Laura

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Tony V Garcia writes:
 > Anyway, the big parties are always going to be expensive, because they 
 > have to rent a big space and pay the djs that get new music all the 
 > time.  So knowing that, I would not be concentrating on how MUCH it will 
 > cost (if you must know, always bring $20 to cover admission, then maybe 
 > an extra $5 for emergencies, plus however much other money for what-e-ver 

I'm not against $20 parties, as long as I get $20 worth...

The issue here is that promoters intentionally withhold information
that attendees badly need to help plan their night. And while some of
us who have been to a lot of parties can guess some of these things,
we shouldn't have to. Two friends and I drove all the way down to club
FX in San Jose from Sacramento and had to turn right around and head
back because there was no way for us to know the club was 21+. I
frequently drive people around who are under 21.

It's not too much to ask to have a promoter publish a few simple
things like cost, age limits, and water/confiscation policy.  The
bottom line is: if you won't do that, you don't care about your
participants, you only care about the money. Walks like a duck, looks
like a duck, etc. The vibe of such parties usually reflects this, in
my experience. Sometimes one lucks out, but not often. Find a caring
promoter, and you usually find a good party.

Sean


From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul  1 12:22:16 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09197; Fri, 1 Jul 94 12:22:16 PDT

	id AA08756; Fri, 1 Jul 94 12:00:31 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id LAA02962; Fri, 1 Jul 1994 11:45:12 -0700
Message-Id: <199407011845.LAA02962@netcom7.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 1994 11:50:08 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: RE: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

For those of you that have heard it before, sorry, but I just can't let his
one go by...

Charging $20 for a rave is no way to keep the scene alive and healthy. It's
a good way to keep *yourself* and *your djs* alive and healthy but, once
again, not so the scene.

Keeping the scene *healthy* would entail engaging people in a shared and
cooperative producer-producer, creator-creator relationship as opposed to a
producer-consumer relationship. There is mounting eveidence to support the
notion that this can be done at a very low cost to everyone involved, say
$3 for instance.

I don't mean to undermine the original efficacy of the rave approach which,
granted, introduced (re-introduced) this very concept, ie dancing
*participants* as opposed to headbanging, drone-like, front-facing concert
attendees !-); but one easily supplants the other...

And, from a budget standpoint, no amount of production values truly
necessitates a $20 price tag. But, just for fun, lets do some of the math
as it relates to the party in question. To be fair we'll estimate high...

Arena:                  $2500   (+no bar guarantee here; *huge* savings)
Security:               $1500
Sound Systems:          $2000
Visuals:                $1000
Laser:                  $1000
DJs:                    $6000
Food/Water:             $0500
Promotion:              $0500
Misc.:                  $1000

Total:                 $16000
Revenues: (2000@$20)   $40000

Profit:                $24000!


However this still misses the most important point which is that virtually
every line item (excluding arena & security) inflates in direct proportion
to the cost of admission!!!!

DJs charge $1000 cos it's a $20 party. They'd charge $500 if it were a $10
party, $300 if it were a $5 party etc. This party could stil be done at a
profit to everyone involved except *you* of course for $10. $5 would still
produce a profit. And, on a break even basis, this party could be done for
$3. 

One might contend that the promoter risks losing his/her shirt at this
point but, then again, imagine the appeal of a $3 Let Freedom Rave. I don't
think it's unreasonable to suggest that attendance could easily double were
the price $3 at which point it would once again be profitable!!! 

Now, as far as this myth of the holy big name dj shamans living in poverty
along the rugged frontiers of the newest music goes: Give Me a Break! I'm
not gonna point fingers but for the last month and a half I've been hearing
the biggest names playing the same old nightclub-oriented regressive house
sets over and over again. If I hear "it's your turn now" one more time I
think I'm gonna puke.

okay I guess I'm ranting now, however I think I made my point....

take it easy, and more importantly, keep it aliv..(gotcha!) no, 
keep it *real*
ethan

PS: I would *love* to be corrected by *someone* supplying the actual
numbers for this party :)



From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul  1 12:25:47 1994

hi folx,
recently, i got this in the mail and thought it might be of interest to y'all.
this is a free show put on by the sf mime troupe, and they DO talk, their
name notwithstanding :)
____________________________________________
 ESPACE    FROM   CYBERIA ... a virtual odyssey
 in the near future, a new world order chooses prisons over schools as radical
right-wing talk show host buck rimfire further inflates the hysteria with his
daily diatribe against all those who oppose hiw views. bu twhat secret does he
share with his arch-rival, the equally vitriolic black ultra-separatist sister
double melanin ? to escape the hostility and an uncertain future, young malcom
and zoe forge an actual friendship in a virtual land called `cyberia,' fighting
evil and oppresion as somar, the enchanter, and pyro-worrior karmakazia. in a
twist of fate, they are brought  face-to-face in the real world with a
surprising and near-tragic outcome. this all new MIME TROUPE production feature
an original musical score plus a talented cast of familiar faces.
_____________________

Date: Tue, 28 Jun 1994 01:41:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: "M. Lane Gilchrist" <gilchris@indigo.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re : Tribal Funk

Hello All!
    I spoke with someone who was coldcocked and robbed while walking alone up
the long trail to where the sound system was located. This person was
very lucky to weather this awful occurence unharmed (minus keys).
   This brings up the reminder to travel in packs when in the wilderness 
(urban or otherwise :) ). I remember being reminded of this on a  visit to
berkeley marina for a waycool afternoon/evening MESS party. One of our little
crewe (female) went to check out the local flora on a solo mission. A
concerned stranger/new friend brought us to our senses and I have
maintained a new level of awareness ever since.
   Any meanie better have on some heavy shielding in order to withstand a
multiple luv phaser volley :-D

Peaceout to y'all

Lane


--------------------------------------------------

From: Stevie Collins <stevie@soda.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: acid house
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 1994 18:50:52 -0700 (PDT)

> one more question...thinking about 1988 can anyone explain why "house" 
> people were takings yellow smileys and putting bullets through there head 
> and wearing these as fashion....(i am hoping someone will remember this)

Could be a reference to Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons(? Gibson? Don't
rememeber, and can't find my copy)'s work, _Watchmen_, in which the
first and last image is that of a smily face button which has had a
drop of blood smeared on it in just the right place so as to appear
liek a bullet wound.  Certainly a large percentage of people around in
1988 would have been aware of the fact that it had been used as such
in _Watchmen_ even it wasn't meant as a direct quote.

stevie

Lets Have A Free Rave    Saturday July 2nd
David . Das . Rucspin . U.S. Thomas . Tracy

Basically this is a spiral jive party
outdoors and free, kind of.

Y'all are familiar with the 24th and illinois space which gets busted
occasionally because many cars and people create a chaotic atmousphere
on the street. Well we got a guy who will let you in the gate and park
at the end of Army , and the party is further down than usuall. But the
guy will ask each person for $2 . He has reduced the bust probability 
by talking to the neighbors and finding out how we should do it to least
offend. He has been watching us for a while and now wants a piece of the 
action. He doesnt want to be paid to dissappear, so we think it is worth it
to let him provide pay parking. If you must sneak around please park wiseley
and don't hang out in the street.

415.281.8405   salutations, allen@ameba

Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

 From Lynn:
     -----Sheesh. Lighten up. It IS for a good cause, plus,the "arrestees" 

     work with the group to let them know when they'll be available to be 

     "arrested". 

     

     As for the bit about New Year's Executions: I don't know where you get 

     ideas like this, but go outside and take a walk, you've obviously been 

     staring at the walls of your cubicle/office for a little too long. 

     It's a beautiful day, so relax and enjoy!

lynn, i'm back from a lunchtime walk through noe valley per your  
recommendation - beautiful day indeed outside!

do you know anybody who has actually been arrested?  or subjected to a  
no-knock bust-down-the-door 5am search?  particularly for something he or she  
doesn't consider to be a crime, like posessing prohibited drugs?   or have you  
known somebody who has lived under fear/paranoia of such arrest?

the people i know who have been in situations like that aren't very "light"  
about it most of the time.

i think mock arrests or mock executions as an adult game (even for charity)  
can be likened to kids playing with toy guns.  in uncritical moments, i would  
doubtless play and laugh at these games (how *nice* that i could schedule my  
arrest for a convenient time).  but a more thoughtful take is that there's  
already enough of this stuff going on for real to need to augment and  
trivialize it with make-believe - even "for a good cause".

then again, if the mock arrests were made as shocking and harsh as the real  
ones, maybe they would be an excellent way to Wake People Up to what's going  
on in our society.  - bob
(sorry about the scarcely-rave-related bandwidth.  end-of-thread for me.)

Another reason I support the smaller parties: variety. Name DJs are
really good, but I like a lot of variety in whose sets I hear.

If it weren't for small-medium sized parties with good variety, I may
have never heard killer sets from:
        
        Susan
        Tamara
        Dave Synthesis
        Jon Drukman
        Ethan
        Laura
        M
        Tara
        Lee An
        Tomatsu
        DRC
        Kenneth Paul
        Bryce
        Jan Cooley

And who knows how many more I can't remember at this moment but whose
sets made me dance like a fiend :). I think I'd go to bigger parties
more often if they could mix more new talent with the the name DJs.
That would be really cool :).

Sean

In-Reply-To: <199407012111.OAA02724@soda.berkeley.edu> from "Laura La Gassa" at Jul 1, 94 02:11:52 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL20]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2374      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	Maybe there is a need to clarify the position of today's DJ's. In the 
	Bay area alone there is well up of 60+ DJ's. Ranging from Professional
	to Semi-Professional(No they havn't given up their day job yet or 
	they're a student) to Amateur(no pay, doesn't want to be payed, or 
	would like to be payed).

	I view the DJ as an artist. In so much as a graphic designer, script-
	writer, musician, actor/actress etc is an artist too. If these people
	view themselves as professional then I'm sure they want to get the best
	deal they can. Why sell themselves short? Why let the big corporation,
	employer, promoter makes loads of money off them? Surely they deserve a
	piece of the pie?

	I agree that $20 parties are steep. I wouldn't pay that much for a 
	party and if I did I'd damn well expect to entertained! Equating with
	music concerts, though, people will happily spend $15 - $30 or more to
	go to The Warfield, The Filmore, The Shoreline etc. to see some bands 
	play for a few hours. Is $20 so much to pay to stay up all night?

	Most DJ's operate a sliding scale based on the intended size of the
	party, the cover charge, and their personal feelings about the promoter
	and even to what the party is called or what the flier looks like - I 
	mean who really whats to play at a party called'Dawn of the E Heads'
	I think there are some ethics out there.  :)

	As to Wages. The figures quoted I think are somewhat inflated. I think
	if you half them you might get a more realistic amount. And of course 
	these are gross earnings. You must remember that professional DJ's run
	their own business - they're self- employed. Net earnings are much 
	different if you take into account the spend on vinyl per week. Most
	concientious DJ's buy a lot of records ($5 -$10 a pop).

	Even with all the griping, I think the diversity in the Bay Area is 
	enormous, more so than anywhere in the country. Small, medium, large 
	parties. Free, cheap, expensive. Acid Jazz, Techno, House, Garage etc.

	It's down to you where you want to go. If you want to go see Jeno-Garth
	and it costs $20 you know that in week or twos time you'll catch them 
	for $5, or for free at a FMP. What's the hurry?

	And if you don't like the way it is all I've got to say is this:

		IF YOU WANT SOMETHING DONE PROPERLY DO IT YOURSELF


	Markie !)

















































From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul  1 16:51:23 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA14278; Fri, 1 Jul 94 16:51:23 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA14271; Fri, 1 Jul 94 16:51:13 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id QAA25057 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Fri, 1 Jul 1994 16:51:50 -0700
Message-Id: <199407012351.QAA25057@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 1994 16:51:47 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Markie writes:

>	Even with all the griping, I think the diversity in the Bay Area is 
>	enormous, more so than anywhere in the country. Small, medium, large 
>	parties. Free, cheap, expensive. Acid Jazz, Techno, House, Garage etc.

When I left New York 6 months ago the musical selections were MUCH more
diverse than anything I've seen out here in San Francisco.

You could go to a party there and hear breaks, hardcore, electro, trance,
acid, progressive house, and old-school deep house ALL ON THE SAME FLOOR
ON THE SAME NIGHT.  Parties were like a tour through the realms of dance
music . . . acid jazz at sunrise . . . hip-hop sets . . . old school
techno from 1990/1991.  Dante would spin trance sets that would include
selections from Skinny Puppy and This Mortal Coil.  DJs from Europe and the 
West Coast visited quite often to give us a taste of their local scenes.  I 
have yet to encounter anything like that in SF.

Where is the hardcore?  Where is the breakbeat?  Where is the trance
that runs faster than about 140 bpm?  What about Laurent Garnier?
Damon Wild?  Miss DJAX?  Adam X?  Or anyone from the outside?

>	And if you don't like the way it is all I've got to say is this:
>
>		IF YOU WANT SOMETHING DONE PROPERLY DO IT YOURSELF

For sure.  And that is exactly why I am doing the small little bit that
I am, because I really want there to be more of a musical variety for 
people to choose from.  

I'm turning over a new leaf.  Enough of this.  Ethan has the "new acid" 
realm covered really well -- his tape that he just described contains some 
of the best of the recent acid/trance genre.  Get his tape, I love his 
taste in music (heee, since it's a lot like my own).  Liquid Air doesn't 
need two DJs who have nearly identical taste in music, though.  I'm putting 
my records where my mouth is and am going to pull out exactly what I miss.  
I may never work in this town again, ("we did that hardcore thing a few years 
ago and are over it") but so be it :-).  Come to Liquid Draino and get ready 
for rave-aerobics. :-)

Laura

	Hi. Thomas is out of town on July 9th. So we've decided to have a 
	guest at Wicked :O

	We will be featuring DJ Pierre (NYC).

	I'm sure all you audiophiles and house addicts will recognise him as
	one of original Chicago instigators of the sound we call 'Acid House'

	Working under many guises - Phuture
				    Phortune
				    Pierre's Phantasy Club

	he laid down the roots of acid on the Chicago Trax label.
	He is currrently joint in-house producer with George Morel at Strictly
	Rhythm Records as well as having produced records for Emotive Records
	and a host of remix work. He's also one hell of a DJ.

	Personally he's one of my total heros and is also responsible for the
	first house record I ever bought back in 1987 'Acid Tracks'.
	Other tracks you might know include 'We are Phuture', 'Fantasy Girl'
	and his current release on Strictly, 'Mental Breakdown'.

	
	See you in the land of green and purple on the 9th :)

	Markie  !)

> 
> Markie writes:
> 
> >	Even with all the griping, I think the diversity in the Bay Area is 
> >	enormous, more so than anywhere in the country. Small, medium, large 
> >	parties. Free, cheap, expensive. Acid Jazz, Techno, House, Garage etc.
> 
> When I left New York 6 months ago the musical selections were MUCH more
> diverse than anything I've seen out here in San Francisco.
> 
> You could go to a party there and hear breaks, hardcore, electro, trance,
> acid, progressive house, and old-school deep house ALL ON THE SAME FLOOR
> ON THE SAME NIGHT.  Parties were like a tour through the realms of dance
> music . . . acid jazz at sunrise . . . hip-hop sets . . . old school
> techno from 1990/1991.  Dante would spin trance sets that would include
> selections from Skinny Puppy and This Mortal Coil.  DJs from Europe and the 
> West Coast visited quite often to give us a taste of their local scenes.  I 
> have yet to encounter anything like that in SF.
> 
> Where is the hardcore?  Where is the breakbeat?  Where is the trance
> that runs faster than about 140 bpm?  What about Laurent Garnier?
> Damon Wild?  Miss DJAX?  Adam X?  Or anyone from the outside?


I don't think just becuase we don't see a wide range of music that was
popular years ago makes San Francisco (or LA) inferior to the New
York scene that Laura describes.

Personally, I would not want to hear many of those older styles at
a club.  I look at progressive dance music as a huge inverted 
whirlpool.  At the bottom, you have all the music of the past.  Great
music, yes, but older music.  As you ascend, the music becomes more
current, drawing on styles from the past.  Then, at the very top, at
the vortex, you have the music that is popular now.  I don't think
music at good clubs shifts from being housier or trancier, I think
it is all these things, all the time.  Lets face it, if a new track
comes out  that you can easily catagorize, then it probably is not
a good track.  The progressive dance music scene is so exciting! We
are evolving music at an incredible pace.  What other music scene
can you think of where a new sound is superseded by an even new
sound in less than 6 weeks?  Basically, I just like to hear the latest
evolution of dance tracks when I go out.  Becuase just when I think
that I have heard the best style that ever was or ever will be, I am
always suprised to hear the next thing, which is always better (at 
least for me).

Also, I don't think 20 dollars is completely unreasonable for an event.
If Let Freedom Rave has a nice location, a great sound system, good
DJ's, some lights, and some breakfast, and if it goes off all night,
then that is well worth 20 dollars for me.  No matter how much money
our promoters make, it will always be a fraction of what mainstream
promoters make.  Hey, I just payed nearly 30 dollars for Dead tickets,
and I KNOW I won't have half the fun I will have at LFR. Hey, it's
cheaper than church. And where else are you going to get that much fun
for 20 dollars?

-troy


From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul  1 21:53:46 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id VAA03872 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Fri, 1 Jul 1994 21:54:15 -0700

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 1994 21:54:12 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: variety and stagnation
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

In a reply to my last post Troyz said something about me implying that
NY was a better scene musically than LA.

Actually, from what little I've seen in LA, LA seems to be doing
pretty well.  There are breaks DJs (RAW), house, dub, and ambient
of all flavors, people who play varying hardnesses of trance
(Sondra Collins, Ron D. Core).  The few non West Coast Djs that
have come out this way seem to play in LA much more often than
in SF (but we got lucky with Pete Namlook).

As for breaks and hard trance being tired and old, how would anyone know
when it doesn't get played that much around here anyway and is quite
difficult to find in the stores?  There is stuff coming out that is
new and good and a bit of a change from groovy funky happy major key
house or slow minimalist warped acid under 130 bpm.

There is new music from the UK, all over Europe, and even from Australian 
labels like Juice that I've never heard in SF and I've never even heard 
those styles played here except for when someone like Alex gets a gig.

Laura

On Fri, 1 Jul 1994, Troy Sheets wrote:

> Also, I don't think 20 dollars is completely unreasonable for an event.
> If Let Freedom Rave has a nice location, a great sound system, good
> DJ's, some lights, and some breakfast, and if it goes off all night,
> then that is well worth 20 dollars for me.  No matter how much money
> our promoters make, it will always be a fraction of what mainstream
> promoters make.  Hey, I just payed nearly 30 dollars for Dead tickets,
> and I KNOW I won't have half the fun I will have at LFR. Hey, it's
> cheaper than church. And where else are you going to get that much fun
> for 20 dollars?
> 
> -troy 

        One point I was really trying to get across earlier today was that
I really believe that if people are going to base the worth of a party
solely on how much it is going to cost, then I think that person is
missing the point of the rave scene, which is supposed to promote inner
peace and peaceful coexistence with your neighbors.  I don't think I said
it in those words, but now I realize that was what I wanted to say. 

        Part of achieving inner peace, I have found, is to dispense with
needless worrying about things you have little control over.  A lot of the
messages that came back to me were along the lines of RI don't mind paying
$20 if I get my $20 worth, and it is on the right track.  I was just
concerned that people were focusing too much on the money aspect of it. 
$20 might be steep, but if you pick the right $20 parties, you'll get your
money's worth. 

        I think everyone gets soaked once or twice when searching for a
rave to go to.  So all I can say to people that are afraid of that
happening is donUt worry about it.  I think if you really ask around,
youUll find that everyone has been to a party where the promoter doesnUt
care.  I have been.  I went to enough parties and found which ones I
thought had people that cared enough, so I continue to support those
people as much as I can. 

        I have to go to bed now, so good night.  :)

dj fog

>For those of you that have heard it before, sorry, but I just can't let his
>one go by...
>
>Charging $20 for a rave is no way to keep the scene alive and healthy. It's
>a good way to keep *yourself* and *your djs* alive and healthy but, once
>again, not so the scene.
>
>Keeping the scene *healthy* would entail engaging people in a shared and
>cooperative producer-producer, creator-creator relationship as opposed to a
>producer-consumer relationship. There is mounting eveidence to support the
>notion that this can be done at a very low cost to everyone involved, say
>$3 for instance.

Is there nothing to be said for a person or persons using the money
generated through big *$20* events to further the scene or movement.  Like
Building a sound system, or starting a clothing company etc, to spread our
message.  This may sound defensive but i am asking you to be real.  i
believe if  we all started doing free or low cost parties only, it would
seriously impede the growth of the house nation.  We live in a
materialistic society, especially here in america.  To inflict change we
have to integrate within society, but in such a way as not to sell
ourselves out.  

>I don't mean to undermine the original efficacy of the rave approach which,
>granted, introduced (re-introduced) this very concept, ie dancing
>*participants* as opposed to headbanging, drone-like, front-facing concert
>attendees !-); but one easily supplants the other...
>
>And, from a budget standpoint, no amount of production values truly
>necessitates a $20 price tag. But, just for fun, lets do some of the math
>as it relates to the party in question. To be fair we'll estimate high...
 
Im sorry ethan but you have no idea what you are talking about, last years
Freedom cost $40,000  (forty  thousand ) to put on, that for an intake of
$43,000, a profit of $3,000 between 3 people for 2 months work.  How much
do you make in two months ethan. I am not saying that i have not made any
money from this scene, i have.  By putting on big paid parties i am in
essence asking you to support my beliefs and my actions and the direction i
am taking.  If any, or all of you do not support or believe in me, you do
not have to come.  Mabey i am a foolish dreamer, mabey not.  I believe that
a party is a direct result of the person or persons that are putting it on,
reflect on what you have learned in the last few years, i believe that
there is room for us all.

>Arena:                  $2500   (+no bar guarantee here; *huge* savings)
>Security:               $1500
>Sound Systems:          $2000
>Visuals:                $1000
>Laser:                  $1000
>DJs:                    $6000
>Food/Water:             $0500
>Promotion:              $0500
>Misc.:                  $1000
>
>Total:                 $16000
>Revenues: (2000@$20)   $40000
>
>Profit:                $24000!
>
>
>However this still misses the most important point which is that virtually
>every line item (excluding arena & security) inflates in direct proportion
>to the cost of admission!!!!
>
>DJs charge $1000 cos it's a $20 party. They'd charge $500 if it were a $10
>party, $300 if it were a $5 party etc. This party could stil be done at a
>profit to everyone involved except *you* of course for $10. $5 would still
>produce a profit. And, on a break even basis, this party could be done for
>$3. 

>One might contend that the promoter risks losing his/her shirt at this
>point but, then again, imagine the appeal of a $3 Let Freedom Rave. I don't
>think it's unreasonable to suggest that attendance could easily double were
>the price $3 at which point it would once again be profitable!!! 
>
>Now, as far as this myth of the holy big name dj shamans living in poverty
>along the rugged frontiers of the newest music goes: Give Me a Break! I'm

>the biggest names playing the same old nightclub-oriented regressive house
>sets over and over again. If I hear "it's your turn now" one more time I
>think I'm gonna puke.
>
>okay I guess I'm ranting now, however I think I made my point....

Spaced suggests:

>$5 b4 10 would be a helpful loophole for dem ole $20 buggers....    or am I 
>dreaming in the sunshine?  

I've seen it on flyers (not in so much SF though, I guess people are 
more honest here) and here's what happens:  you go before 10.  There is
a long line to let people in.  Why so slow?  "Oh, we have to check
carefully for security you know."  Time ticks by . . . suddenly it's
10, only about 50 people out of maybe 150 have gotten in at the
discount price, and everyone else has to pay in full.  Suprizingly
enough, SUDDENLY the line through security starts moving more
quickly.

But I still think it's a good idea, as long as the owner of the space
and the organizer of the party aren't slimy about it.

Laura

>I don't mean to undermine the original efficacy of the rave approach which,
>granted, introduced (re-introduced) this very concept, ie dancing
>*participants* as opposed to headbanging, drone-like, front-facing concert
>attendees !-); but one easily supplants the other...

This keeps being stated and I'm less and less convinced that this is
really a focal point for the "rave" difference.  Remember that sock-hops
and your lowest-common-denominator pop hip-hop Janet-Jackson-music dance
club all differ from concerts in this way --- but I think a Grateful
Dead concert is closer to what you mean than a pop dance club...

>
>And, from a budget standpoint, no amount of production values truly
>necessitates a $20 price tag. But, just for fun, lets do some of the math
>as it relates to the party in question. To be fair we'll estimate high...
>
>Arena:                  $2500   (+no bar guarantee here; *huge* savings)
>Security:               $1500
>Sound Systems:          $2000
>Visuals:                $1000
>Laser:                  $1000
>DJs:                    $6000
>Food/Water:             $0500
>Promotion:              $0500
>Misc.:                  $1000
>
>Total:                 $16000
>Revenues: (2000@$20)   $40000
>
>Profit:                $24000!

Yes, this is only possible because people are used to paying MORE than
$20 for concerts (note that Pearl Jam is suing Ticketmaster to keep the
prices of concerts to $19.95), which also cost more to produce than raves.

Abandoned warehouse versus Warfield Theater - imagine the cost savings.
And, due to the existing information system for rave attendance, you can
get by on the 25 cents per person promotion budget listed above, whereas
advertising for a 2000 person concert costs a LOT more than $500.

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

---

       /   Modem (510) 268-0102  info@tigerteam.org  /

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul  3 10:00:48 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12253; Sun, 3 Jul 94 10:00:48 PDT
Received: from netcom14.netcom.com by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12246; Sun, 3 Jul 94 10:00:36 PDT
Received: by netcom14.netcom.com (8.6.8.1/Netcom)
	id KAA03262; Sun, 3 Jul 1994 10:01:41 -0700
Date: Sun, 3 Jul 1994 10:01:41 -0700
From: child@netcom.com (Spaced-Out Funky Earthchild)
Message-Id: <199407031701.KAA03262@netcom14.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: communion's message of Sat, 2 Jul 1994 11:09:35 -0700 <199407021809.LAA05063@netcom.netcom.com>
Subject: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Martin says,
>believe if  we all started doing free or low cost parties only, it would
>seriously impede the growth of the house nation.  We live in a
>materialistic society, especially here in america.  To inflict change we
>have to integrate within society, but in such a way as not to sell
>ourselves out.  
 
And eye says,
Free and low cost parties have a right to exist as much as the $20 party.
The free parties may seriously impede the growth of Martin's definition of
"house nation" which I'm personally interpreting as, "free parties will
seriously impede my ability to make a big buck".  In my opinion, the "house
nation" will do what the "house nation" will do.

Just cuz one is living and thriving in this materialistic society
called America does not give one any excuse to be anything, much less greedy.
If one wants to be greedy, then go ahead and be greedy and s/he has my 
blessings too.  But charging $20 because one wants to "inflict change by
integrating within society but in such a way as to not sell ourselves out."
Sounds very funny to me!

eg.  Hey Tom & Jane, I see a society of totally decadent people who are doing 
little except for focusing on survival and satisfying their physical senses
ie. USA.  Let's go join em and make lots o dough so we can forget about 
spiritual evolution...... oh yeah, and remember not to sell out!  ..... NOT!

PURE LOVE IS FREE (I'm talking about a state of mind, not a party name)......
Let Freedom Rave is $20?

>Freedom cost $40,000  (forty  thousand ) to put on, that for an intake of
>$43,000, a profit of $3,000 between 3 people for 2 months work.  How much
Tho, I agree, if the truth is $3000 net profit for 3 people for 2 months work,
that's not much indeed, unless....
And I dunno which Freedom you're talking about because in '92 there were about
5000 people there which translates to gross intake of 100 Gs.

Big secret on what promoters do:  One gets an idea for a party, and then one
expends effort & energy to promote it (let others know about it) and set the 
whole event up and organize and pay all the people.  Basically the spark for
a rave begins in one person's head.  Now this spark will PERMEATE the whole
rave.  Ravers will come to the rave and pay an entrance fee, but what they are
really doing is sharing in the costs of the rave and thus, they are actually
paying money so the rave can happen.  The promoter *NEEDS* people to come to
his/her rave so he's not stuck with the entire pre-paid costs, which is the
risk that many promoters assume.  Ravers think, oh there's a party, I think
I'll go, but another way of looking at it is, oh there's a party, I think
I will contribute to it by financially offsetting bhe costs the promoter paid
by my fraction & I will give out tons of energy  by participating in the party.
There is a balance here.  In my view, an imbalance occurs when the ravers don't
want to offset the promoter's costs by their little fraction OR when the
promoter starts treating the entrance fee, not like a donation to defray costs,
but as a way of making big $$$.  Anyway, there is no right or wrong here,
just like in real life.  Because the BIG RAVE promoter's way of looking at it
is, what if few people comes to my rave and I lose $10K in prepaid costs in one
night?......Next time I throw a rave I've got to make some extra $$$ so I can
have some safety net in case next next time, I end up losing.  The 
hand-to=mouth raver's way of looking at it is, I can't go because it costs too
much unless I learn how to schmooz with the door people (ie. selling oneself
out?)  So I didn't go....but if I had  50Gs lying around or even an extra $100
bill lying around, I definitely would have gone.
Martin I love you & thank you for throwing Freedom so I could think about 
whether to go or not.  I spent about 2-3 hours just trying to make up my mind,
which was a rave in itself!  I hope Freedom went well for all parties involved,
and I hope it was about Freedom.

Space

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul  3 13:49:54 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA14113; Sun, 3 Jul 94 13:49:54 PDT
Received: from get.wired.com (wired.com) by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA13718; Sun, 3 Jul 94 13:15:12 PDT
Received: from localhost by get.wired.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id MAA27026; Sun, 3 Jul 1994 12:56:04 -0700
Date: Sun, 3 Jul 1994 12:56:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@wired.com>
Subject: Re: FREEDOMFYI; DI
To: Spaced-Out Funky Earthchild <child@netcom.com>
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <199407031701.KAA03262@netcom14.netcom.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407031259.A26485-0100000@get.wired.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

On Sun, 3 Jul 1994, Spaced-Out Funky Earthchild wrote:
> Martin says,
> >believe if  we all started doing free or low cost parties only, it would
> >seriously impede the growth of the house nation.  We live in a
> >materialistic society, especially here in america.  To inflict change we
> >have to integrate within society, but in such a way as not to sell
> >ourselves out.  
>  
> And eye says,
> Free and low cost parties have a right to exist as much as the $20 party.
> The free parties may seriously impede the growth of Martin's definition of
> "house nation" which I'm personally interpreting as, "free parties will
> seriously impede my ability to make a big buck".  In my opinion, the "house
> nation" will do what the "house nation" will do.

That's nothing but a personal attack on Martin.  If you can't hold a
conversation about this without casting people who hold opposing views
as money-grubbing big-time P.T.Barnum-esque Bill Graham wannabe's,
stop now.

> Just cuz one is living and thriving in this materialistic society
> called America does not give one any excuse to be anything, much less greedy.
> If one wants to be greedy, then go ahead and be greedy and s/he has my 
> blessings too.  But charging $20 because one wants to "inflict change by
> integrating within society but in such a way as to not sell ourselves out."
> Sounds very funny to me!

If promoters who charge $20 only make a couple thousand from a party
after spending three months working on it, it's not called being greedy,
it's called paying rent.  More often than not, large parties lose money.
The only parties that I've ever heard as being large cash cows were
Cyberfest, ToonTown (after they left King St.) and a couple of the
New Years' parties.  

What I interpret Martin as saying is that, yeah, small parties are great, 
but if you really do want to make a change in this world, and you think 
throwing parties like ours is a way to inflict that change (which I don't
disagree with at all), then large parties are a very good thing, if not
necessary. 

And if you don't think that large-party promoters care about their
patrons, you haven't met Martin.

> PURE LOVE IS FREE (I'm talking about a state of mind, not a party name)......
> Let Freedom Rave is $20?

Yes, because you can't rent out a large track for $3 per person, you can't
get enough security and sound for $3 per person, etc.  Some elements of
your costs are a function of the admission price, but many are not.  

> >Freedom cost $40,000  (forty  thousand ) to put on, that for an intake of
> >$43,000, a profit of $3,000 between 3 people for 2 months work.  How much
> Tho, I agree, if the truth is $3000 net profit for 3 people for 2 months work,
> that's not much indeed, unless....

Good, we agree here.

> And I dunno which Freedom you're talking about because in '92 there were about
> 5000 people there which translates to gross intake of 100 Gs.

I was there too, and I wouldn't say there were 5000 people there.  If you ask
me who's in a better position to judge attendance, you or Martin, you can
guess who I'm picking.  Finally, I'm sure a substantial portion of the
people there were either working or on the guest list, and guest list
bloat might be a problem.

In the rest of your letter you talk about how throwing parties should
be a collaborative process, and if promoters view themselves as showmen
or in the entertainment industry that's a bad thing, and I agree there.

	Brian


From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul  3 15:56:34 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15880; Sun, 3 Jul 94 15:56:34 PDT
Received: from ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15872; Sun, 3 Jul 94 15:56:24 PDT
Received: by ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU; id QAA00521; Sun, 3 Jul 1994 16:04:43 -0700
From: Adam Sah <asah@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199407032304.QAA00521@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: ongoing rave-finances comments, FREEDOM REPORT.
Date: Sun, 03 Jul 94 16:04:42 -0700
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Attached at the bottom is the last message I've received in the long chain
   of rave-finance email, esp. re:freedom.  My addition is to comment about
   this in light of a review of freedom.  Please don't flame me- I may have
   a jaded view or "missed something" but I'm not trying to offend.

Freedom:

   vibe: ecccch.  okay, seen better, but definitely there to be had.  Don't
   mean to detract from those who had thebesttimeoftheirlives, but it
   seemed like the point ("freedom", etc.) was kind of lost amid the
   tanning-shop made-up teenie boppers from the valley and their musclemen
   d00d gangstastylin guys.  I was wacthing the security folks pull
   junkbeer from cars.  Fortunately, people seemed to get along and more or
   less chill, so no complaints, but let's not compare this to sfrave's
   resort, the fmr's of a year ago (pre-r.s.)  or liquid air events.

   HOWEVER, much as I hate to say it, I can't complain about the $20 worth,
   the security folk were plentiful and reasonable, and didn't give me a
   hard time (ie. they did their jobs... professionally -- gasp!), the
   visuals were as interesting as stacks of alternating slide projectors
   get (but, to their credit, they did make sure to switch the slides a lot),
   the sound was quite rich, no problem trancing. the ambient tent was
   pretty good (although the music wasn't... spacey... enough for me) - it
   needed some more ventilation... too many _cigarette_ smokers (not enough...)
   but there was plenty of room, and the carpet was a nice touch.  Overall,
   the site was okay, although it didn't leave a lot of room to explore
   (security folk watching the hills... par for the course in bigger events)

So where did your $20 go and was it justified?

   overwhelmingly, yes.  Consider the bounty of helpers: security, ticket
   people, people to manage parking (which was amazingly well organized,
   even when the bubble appeared around midnight and they were reorganizing
   things on the fly to avoid a street spillover), lighting folks, etc.
   I won't go into the financial details- that's already been covered in
   previous email.  The point is that somebody went to a lot of effort to
   coordinate things, right up to the last minute, and for that- $20 is
   justified.

Now, you ask, I've had just as much fun paying $15, $10, $5, and $0.  What
   gives?  What gives is that you're paying a premium to rave suburban
   style- my _mother_ would probably sanction such an event, it was that
   well organized.  Granted, what's the likelihood that some crazy is going
   to try to set the place on fire etc. - but think about the gangs etc.
   At a big, well-publicized event like Freedom, you're partying with the
   highschoolers from around the area, and if you don't need that kind of
   cushion like they (their parents...) do, then don't go- save the $20.
   The Liquid Air folks pump in toons just as well as the Freedom folks do,
   and with the help of friends/family, we have the food, and the vibe and
   the blankets - and it's all donations or free.  There's no (real)
   precautions against a bust, there's no security folks to break up the
   fight that sucks you in when that wacked out, angel dusted jerk mistakes
   the gangsta for a punching bag ('course, there's no reason why that
   would happen, but if you don't tell the wackos or the gangstas about
   sfr events, they won't come, and it will all be a self-fulfilling
   prophesy, exclusion not being necessary since such folks seem to like to
   be among their own, and sfr definitely doesn't have the "proper" :-)
   density of the "in" crowd etc. etc.)

Btw, I had a pretty good time last night.  As usual, compliments to the
   folks who provided the info.  one thing: it's always cool to meet people
   on their first x-adventure, and hear them lose their cliquish,
   clothing-makes-the-person, i'm-in-you're-out attitudes, replaced with
   the girl who was laughing her ass off, rubbing my poncho and saying
   "people are GOOD... they really are."  To her, my best wishes - please
   hold onto that feeling by daylight.  Maybe then...

thoughts... peace... _harmony_

adam

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul  3 22:26:26 1994

Hello fellow Americans,

The folks at Le Chateau Co-op in Berkeley would like to announce a 4th of 
July Extravaganza the likes of which will probably not be seen for a while:)

CHATEAUPALOOZA: Burn All Your Flags!
Monday, July 4th
2 pm - 5 am

with (in this approximate order):

* Broun Fellinis (by the pool, w/ BBQ, clothing strictly optional)

* Larry Hunt & the Blue Flames (reggae/blues)

* The Grain (alt.metal)

* Sucklight (alt.weirdness)

* Dubtribe Sound System (alt.incredible live tribaldubfunkohousegrooves)

* Mother Earth Sound System DJs Scottie, Stonie & Whitsitt (alt.us)

* Chill Room by Harlan & Billy (alt.horizontalrelaxorama)


15 HOURS of grooves for ONLY 3 Dead Hemp-Growin' Presidents!!!

DIRECTIONS:
* Take 80 & exit Ashby Ave.
* Drive up Ashby towards the hills and make a LEFT on Telegraph
* Turn RIGHT at Parker and go up 2 blocks to Hillegass Ave.
* Chateau is on the corner, at 2545 Hillegass
* Enter on the side of the middle white house

Questions?  Leave a message at (510) 549-6260 or (415) 487-7681


Peace + respect,

			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE
			*************************
			>>>respect your mother<<<

communion writes:
 > Is there nothing to be said for a person or persons using the money
 > generated through big *$20* events to further the scene or movement.  Like
 > Building a sound system, or starting a clothing company etc, to spread our
 > message.

Free parties. Cheap parties. Social meetings. Donations to charity.
Helping beginners get started. Free fruit. Etc etc.

rich off expensive parties, keep good records and show them what
you're really doing.

 A short post about Liquid Draino:

 I got to the back-up location somewhat after midnight . Interesting mix
of more caustic music styles - the gabber was too hard for me , I decided
to stay holed up in my truck ater my nap instead of trying to come out
and dance to it! Otherwise , the music was perfect for a cold San Francisco
summer night.

 I'm going to bed ... 
	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul  4 16:42:16 1994

From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>

Subject: Liquid Drano cleans the pipes
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 4 Jul 1994 16:40:32 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1597      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

:)

Liquid Air went caustic (sort of) and did it up in an oft favored spot
on the SF waterfront on Sunday night.  We heard (and *danced*) for a good
four hours to tunes spun by Laura, Ernie Deakyne, and myself, with everything
from housey things to trancey things to acidy things to old techno anthems
to gabber and jungle madness. oh, yes...and breakbeat, too.  the smile
factor was very high, and we had quite a few visitors throughout the
night, and i met some new friends and some old friends.  one thing that
was way fun was when laura started off: there were less than 10 of us
when she started; suddenly, she looked up, and asked "where did all these
people come from?" cause there must have been 30 or more of us by then,
who seemed to appear quickly, and from nowhere.

although i helped organize this party (what little organization was required),
i still *love* these parties in general, and this last one was just great.
i was fully prepared to set up the sound system and play for a few of my
closest friends.  it was just amazingly wonderful to see so many people come
out for this little gathering.  it was also very nice when the party took
on a more intimate feeling after laura, myself and ernie has spun the first
round, and then each spun a shorter, second set of 4 or 5 tunes apiece.
people were still grooving out.  

i was also really happy to see that people were *not* put off by our
labelling this as a "hardcore" party.  i guess i take this as proof that
SF *can* handle hardcore, at least in small doses.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul  4 17:00:53 1994

        "Liquid Drano cleans the pipes" (Jul  4,  4:40pm)
References: <199407042340.AA02671@crl.crl.com>

Yowza!!  i got back from the last Grateful Dead show at Shoreline
(they're heading east for the remainder of the month) and found that
Susie had not only arranged to get me a ride with our friend Ann but
was also cooking up chocolate goodies and ice cream to send us on
our way!  (She was working the big 4th of July event down at the
waterfront today so didn't come down, wish you'd made it suze . . .)

We arrived a little before 1 and there was already a good crowd and
Laura was spinning up a storm.  Bryce kept us amused with oddities
and disasters from the Techno Closets of History.  Yes, it's true, the
sfravers actually *danced* to James Brown Is Dead, although Bryce
confessed to me later that around two-thirds of the way through he
remembered why we all got sick of that track!

I really liked Deaks' set too, lots of hard trance.  I must have missed
out on all the hardcore/gabber because not much was played (for the most
part, a good choice, although there are good tracks in those genres 
I find most of it aggro-paint-by-numbers clanging).  Bryce even came
back with the good mix of 'Dominator' and Deak did this great remix or
overlay of 'Planet Claire' that was both funny and sublime.  The wind
and chill were a bit much to take but everyone managed pretty well.

Thanks to everyone and see you in the future!

phred

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul  4 17:12:57 1994

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 4 Jul 1994 17:13:29 -0700

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Liquid Drano cleans the pipes
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

To add to Bryce's comments:

>four hours to tunes spun by Laura, Ernie Deakyne, and myself, with everything
>from housey things to trancey things to acidy things to old techno anthems

An interesting story of how I met Ernie -- DJ Deaks.  I hang out on vrave a 
lot, and he was there one day telling us about how he'd just spent a good 
amount of time in the UK, and had bought all these great records.  When Bryce 
found out that Lee An was going to be out of town, I recalled the conversation 
with Ernie and sent him some email.  He came up from Monterey, had killer 
sets, and HUGE smiles.  He also danced like a madman!  I didn't realize he 
was also on sfraves until last night :-)  Thanks for coming, Ernie!

The funny thing about the old hard techno anthems that Bryce was spinning was 
how into them everyone seemed.  It was like going back to 1991, when many of 
us first heard techno or started raving.  The funniest thing was that Cindy 
Kawakami knew EVERY track within about 2 bars of Bryce putting it down.  A big 
hug goes out to Cindy, Kia, and Sharona for dropping by -- they were at 
another party in San Jose, left it and came up to Liquid Draino, and then went 
BACK to San Jose.  They are the true hardcore women. :-)

>was way fun was when laura started off: there were less than 10 of us
>when she started; suddenly, she looked up, and asked "where did all these
>people come from?" cause there must have been 30 or more of us by then,

It was bizzare!  All day Brian had been saying "are you sure you want to 
do this, not many people will come" but we went out to set up with Bryce 
anyway.  Around midnight a few cars arrived, and John Martinko, Tamara, 
Brian S, Ethan, Maui, Sean, Greg, and a few others helped Bryce to get set 
up (it's amazing how quickly Bryce's sound system goes up, too!!!!).  So I 
started spinning, and didn't look up for about 3 or 4 records . . . and when 
I did look up I was shocked!

Another funny thing was that during my set, I noticed that everyone was 
focused on something although they were still dancing.  Unknown to me (my 
back was to it), there were two fires going on in Portrero Hill.  I guess 
they were started by fireworks up there or something.  They got put out 
pretty quickly, though.  It was just odd to feel that something was going 
on, and to have no idea what it was.

Anyway, big thanks to everyone who came, I'd guess there were about 50 or 
so.  I wish it hadn't been so cold -- but Bryce has some new location ideas 
that are a bit further south, so hopefully next time we won't all be freezing 
by 4:00 am.  As Bryce said, "it's time to find a new 'weak' spot." :-)

Laura

Brian writes:
>If you can't hold a
>conversation about this without casting people who hold opposing views
>as money-grubbing big-time P.T.Barnum-esque Bill Graham wannabe's,
>stop now.

I thought I should comment that, if Bill Graham were alive today, given
his feelings for PLUR-related activities (such as G. Dead concerts), he
would probably have bought a SOM warehouse as a full time Rave venue,
with nicer security apes than most clubs, free water and a special place
for flyers, venders, etc.  (Plus his downtown influence would probably
have resulted in less busts within the venue, etc.)

This is my direct experience of attending concerts that he produced,
and, during the same period, ones that he did not (usually in LA).  And
seeing some interviews with him.

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

I thought I'd come out of lurking mode to say that I had a great time at 
Liquid Drano last night!  Thanks lots to Laura and Bryce who spun some 
great sets (especially Bryce's ultracheesy stuff!  I LOVED it!) and to 
all the new people I met there...  I wish we could have stayed until the end
to hear Ernie spin too!

At my largest count, there were at least 50 people there.. I was surprised
at the turnout, especially since the first site didn't pan out.  I'd never
been to this one either, and even though it was cold it was still a great
spot, and very intimate!  

Thanks to Larry for the cinnamon candies and to everyone for the hugs and
smiles..  I met a lot of new people and made sure to give them blue,
purple, red, and/or green blo-pop tongues, too! It was definitely worth 
the trip from santa cruz to san jose to san francisco and back again.. :)  
I can't wait for the next event!

Now if only I could get Cindy's "meow mix theme sung to the tune of James
Brown is Dead" out of my head I could go to sleep...

-Kia

From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul  5 07:42:52 1994

From: janie@netcom.com (Janie Fogel)

Subject: freedom
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 1994 07:43:53 -0700 (PDT)

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I could sum up Freedom by saying that the total experience was far 
greater than the sum of its parts due to the fact that the vibe from 
the crowd was absolutely beautiful. 

We arrived at around 2:30 to a thorough but good natured search for
any fireworks and alcohol.  When we arrived at the site we found the
party to have criticle mass but not overly packed.  Tony played first 
and he was great.  I'm so pleased that he is back from where ever
he went to because he has always been a favorite of mine.  After Tony
i would say the music was good not great, but it didn't matter.  Almost 
everyone was dancing and happy, sharing the experience and talking with
one another.  I realize that the joining hands and making a circle is a
Martin trademark, but on Saturday everyone joined; even those sitting at
the time, and made acircle the circumference of the whole track, broke
hands and ran screaming to the dance area to Josh who played a really
good finishing set.  Where else but at a party can a group of people do 
something so completely goofy but with such honesty and good intentions
that it becomes something almost spiritual?

The party ended around 8:00, but the Ambient tent stayed open longer
with a Tofu scramble and loads of fresh fruit.  

Just as an aside I don't know why people are so down on Martin and/or
$20 parties.  We all have jobs to make a living and so do promoters.
Its really what you personally bring to a party that matters not
the fact that someone is trying to pay their rent from it.  There is
room in this scene for the $20.00 party just as much as the $3.00 
party -- they all have their place. 

janie


From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul  5 09:51:21 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28117; Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:21 PDT
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28110; Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:12 PDT
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-05/04/94)
	id AA12155; Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:59 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA00192; Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:58 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA10823; Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:55 PDT
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 94 09:51:55 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9407051651.AA10823@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Freedom Weekend
Cc: miga@well.sf.ca.us, choices@netcom.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Freedom definately exceeded my expectations.  We arrived after 2 and
established camp.  Amongst SFRavers that we either hung out with or saw
were P-ter & M Normal, Gil, Grey, Ethan, Bryce, Giamma, and Martin (who 
now after posting here is as much of an SFRaver as any of us).

At parties like this, I usually lay back for a couple of hours and wait for 
the drunks and gawkers to get tired and leave, but my first foray into the 
dance area was a pleasant surprise.  Everyone seemed happy and very much 
into the groove.  The sound was system was absolutely superb.  There were 
some nice projections against a couple of trucks on both sides of the DJ 
booth, supplemented by a bank of strobes.  They never got the lasers 
working, but there were enough visuals to make me happy.  The weather was 
perfect, little wind, clear sky, no dust.  After Tony's set, the quality
of the music waned a bit (for me), although Josh was pretty good as the 
finisher.  

As time wore on, the vibe continued to improve, especially as it got light 
out, with people smiling, introducing themselves to each other, sharing 
stuff and just being friendly.  Lot's of people climbed the hill to watch 
the sun come up.  Nothing beats outdoor parties.

The only (minor) downer was the appearence of a white stretch Limo on the
party grounds; this symbol of status and elitism was sorely out of place
here, but thankfully it didn't stuck around to long.

The finale alone was worth my $20 "donation".  It was during the last song 
when the circle started forming, growing and expanding until *all* 3 or 4 
hundred people who were left had joined hands with our backs were against 
the racetrack perimiter.  There was a moment of what-do-we-do-now 
hesitation, and then we ran back to the center screaming and jumping for
joy like a bunch of crazed idiots.  Then Josh gave us an encore for the 
final dance under the morning sun.  

A bunch of us hiked up the hill where we poked around at some petrified 
wood and fossilized seashells, wondering what kind of rave-related fossils 
archeologists might discover here 100 million years from now.  

All in all, I, and everyone I have spoken to so far, thought Freedom was 
a great party.  Thanx Martin.

sidenote: this was the only party I can remember where there were more
barechested women than men.  This probably says *something* about the 
freedom vibe that was in the air.  ;-)

*   *   *

The Sunset party started a little later than usual on Sunday at about 
3:30pm.  The Presidio location, amongst some bunkers protected us against 
the wind, but also gave us the option of a spectacular view of the ocean & 
GG Bridge for those who danced on the bunker's roof.  We helped Galen set 
up and a DJ named Monte started us off with some nice energetic house 
tunes.  There were about 30 - 40 of us dancing as the fog gave way to warm 
sunlight.  The Normals, Gil, Ann(thrax), Gregg, Robert, and Mark (ameba) 
were also there.  

Shortly after the music started, a ranger-type dweeb wandered near.  I saw
his jaw drop, before he vanished in a hurry.  We were soon surrounded by 
a variety of uniformed authorities in squad cars and on scooters.  
Negotiations ensued, and the party was allowed to go on until 7 at a 
temporarily decreased volume.  This was enough time for Phil Smart to 
deliver a killer set.  Although I was somewhat exhausted, it was impossible to not dance to the high energy trance/house he spun for us.

*  *  *

Monday nite, we were still too drained to drag our asses 6 blocks to the
Marina's fireworks display, but we managed to take in a pretty good show 
from the roof of our building.  Nationalism, like racism and organized 
religion is a force that mostly serves to divide humanity into warring 
factions.  But fireworks are cool so we focused on the general celebratory 
spirit of it and felt happy with the freedoms and choices that we *do* 
have, realizing that even in this seemingly imperfect world, it was still 
great to be alive.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

 
 



From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul  5 10:27:58 1994

Date: Tue, 5 Jul 94 13:28:35 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9407051728.AA02960@pilot.njin.net>
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: freedom
In-Reply-To: <199407051443.HAA14320@netcom12.netcom.com>
References: <199407051443.HAA14320@netcom12.netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Janie Fogel writes:
 > Just as an aside I don't know why people are so down on Martin and/or
 > $20 parties.

I know a lot of people enjoy $20 parties, but have a problem with $20
parties that:

Have rude or intrusive security.
Sell water at obscene prices.
Don't deliver $20 of party.
Get busted.
Appear to be $10 parties before you get there.
Have poor ventilation.
Won't let you bring food in.
Make overt attempts to kill other parties the same night.

I don't think the complaint is the price tag. I know lots of really
good vibe rave participants who don't go to $20 parties because they
can't afford it, and I hardly ever hear them complain. I've totally
ranted about $20 parties before. There are good ones out there.

My own complaint is that a lot of $20 parties fail the points above.
Those points aren't luxuries; they're basically treating human beings
like human beings.

How many parties have we been to with poor or no ventilation and no
fans? Do they allow smoking where the ventilation is bad? How much
work does it take to set up a couple of fans to blow air from cool
areas to warm? How much do the fans cost if you amortize the cost over
10 parties? Hint: I just bought two totally kick ass fans (with 5 year
warrantiess) for $38 each at Price Costco; look for them at parties I
attend. And yet I've gone to $15 and $20 parties that grossed in the
$10,000s with almost no ventilation and no fans.

I could go on and on. I think the thing is: we're tired of expensive
parties where the promoters are negligent or abuse the participants.
People are throwing their own parties because they're tired of paying
$20 only to get slapped in the face.

And at the same time, a lot of these bigtime promoters are promoting
love, community, peace, etc. etc.  If you talk the talk, then you
should walk the walk and treat your participants like you care. Don't
tell me your party is about brotherhood and then charge dehydrated
participants $2 for 12 ounces of water.

Sean

More Crotchety Summer Thoughts:

I am totally sick of this plateau magic age I have arrived
according to schedule relief at finding the perfect party squeeze
me new school aaaaahhhhh vibe that I keep hitting.  I am equally
sick of being told to keep anything anywhere going in anyway.
I am tired of expectations
I am irresponsible 
Stagnation

There has to be a better way to move people
and give me a jam


From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul  5 12:12:09 1994

Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id LAA07313; Tue, 5 Jul 1994 11:55:30 -0700
Message-Id: <199407051855.LAA07313@netcom13.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 1994 12:00:40 -0800
To: choices@netcom.com (communion)
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: RE: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings Friends!

I think an apology, of sorts, is in order. I have a habit of getting
carried away which, at times, is a good thing and yet, at others, not such
a good thing...I think I got a bit carried away in my recent analysis of
$20 parties and Freedom in particular.

Which is not to say, however, that I'm backing off from those points; they
are still entirely valid in a variety of contexts, however, I regret the
degree to which I allowed them to focus so intently on Freedom, especially
in light of Martin's recent disclosure of the financial breakdown for last
year's LFR. 

While I have to admit to no small amount of shock and just a hair of
disbelief that that party could have cost $40,000, I would have to agree
with Martin that, if you're trying to make your living throwing parties,
$3000 is not much compensation for three people over two months, in which
case, you all deserve our thanks for working so hard for so little. That
was, indeed, a fine party. :)

However Martin is not the only one throwing $20 parties. We have some very
recent and, unfortunately, horrifying examples of big name parties that,
IMO, really abused us, leaving me, in particular, a little trigger happy in
regards to the $20 party. I have no problem with us as a scene enabling
promoters and djs to make their living at it. But, make no mistake, this
implies a relationship and a *responsibility* on their part to deliver the
goods. And for $20 the goods better be good goods. 

Comparisons to BGP style mainstream concerts don't prove the point either.
If all we're measuring ourselves against is something that is obviously and
grossly inflated then our standards are far too low. Why shouldn't this
*movement*, if we're going to try and call it that, challenge, rather than
perpetuate, the hyperinflated material consumerism that is the hallmark of
american 'culture' if not western so-called civilization?

                                  * * *

One aspect of my initial post was that it was intended as a polemic; I knew
my estimates were low (despite calling them high); I was hoping to provoke
a response, which we got, on a number of fronts. And this, if you ask me,
is great news, long time coming too. The point being, that, as people in
community, the more we know about each other the better. Nothing makes me
happier than having someone tell me what their vision is and just how much
work they've put into it; it gives me a reason to support them. And, what
better place to do this than here on sfr?! If all we're using this net for
is just another place to hang a flier, we are indeed missing the point. So
I'm tickled pink to find myself in the midst of a real live discussion of
all the above and all of the below...

What has value? Who's worth supporting? Why? Where should this (house etc.)
go? Why? Who's getting the money? What's being done with it? Why? IMO,
these are essential questions if we have a future *together* as promoters,
as djs, as ravers....especially if we're gonna call this a *movement*. I
have yet to see a movement comprised of 2% producers and 98% consumers even
if the consumers are consuming a good product, well worth $20...

How about next year we do a net-organized, massively promoted (wired!),
free and fully permitted, national (worldwide!), march and Let Freedom Rave
on Washington DC! See just how much of a movement we've got...

Martin, you're the only person I know that could pull it off. You've got my
help if you want it :)

lots of love
ethan

                                  * * *

If your makin money many Americans, regardless of their beliefs, won't say
too much about what your'e doing to make it.  Even the the anti-drug folks
acknowledge that the dealers are  businessmen trying to make some cash.  Its
just the wrong drugs and the wrong people making the cash.  Profit is a
sheild.  It works for mega-corporations, TV evangelists,  just about anyone.
 California's #1 cash crop contributes mightly to our economy and that
doesn't go unnoticed.  During the CAMP years, production has quadrupled
according to some estimates.  Not exactly effective enforcement, but enough
to please the voters that want it - enforcement that is :-)  The powers that
be will squish you harder and faster for implementing that
let's-get-rid-of-money ideal than perhaps any other.  It scares 'em silly.
Its a classic dichotomy - change from within or revolt from outside.  I'm a
fan of the change from within using irresitible memes -- like a house virus.
 The music alone has this power because of its ability to unite across
cultures and sub-cultures wordlessly.  Many companies in the Bay Area,
particularly high tech/ creative ones,  do an amazing job of being
successful, making money, but still remaing true to what they were about in
the 60's. Our scene has definately benefited from this enviroment, as will
the future.

Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02331; Tue, 5 Jul 94 13:42:04 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA10671; Tue, 5 Jul 94 16:42:45 EDT
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 94 16:42:45 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9407052042.AA10671@pilot.njin.net>
To: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Cc: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: walk the walk, talk the talk
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407051246.A4674-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
References: <9407051728.AA02960@pilot.njin.net>
	<Pine.3.89.9407051246.A4674-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I have found that, in general, Basics, Gathering, and Community are
good bets and worth $20 when they are $20. Wicked is always a banging
party, but I express reservations about the vibe--the four I've been
to had some extremely happy people and some extremely rude people.
Bring friends to Wicked.

One Gathering I didn't go to because security and the door people were
pretty rude.  A Basics at the armory had doorpeople that treated me
well, but others told me they got extremely rude treatment.

A lot of spaces come with special liabilities:

I'd stay completely away from anything at Caesars or the Haze.
Security at these places is very rude and intrusive. If you like
flashlights in your face and having your bathroom stall kicked in
because they think you are doing drugs, by all means, patronize these
spaces.

Likewise, stay away from the King St. garage. It is too poorly
ventilated, the goons are too rude, there are no ins&outs to breathe,
and on top of the bad ventilation, promoters allow smoking in there.

Go to events at DV8 and the Trocadero. I haven't been to these spaces
myself (or if I did, it was before I learned their names), but people
keep ranting about them.

As far as bad parties go, I've been to too many of them, and have
tried (successfully) to just forget about specifics. 

DO attend smaller parties like: Spundae, F&F, Liquid Air, YSH, SPAZ,
New Moon Rave, etc. If you've ever wondered where the vibe is or why
the scene "is dead" you need only go to one of these for a massive
positive energy recharge.

:)

Sean

Well, as long as I'm spending the week soldifying my presence on regional
blacklists, might as well keep on going....

At 12:57 PM 7/5/94 -0700, Tony V Garcia wrote:

>We're all sick of promoters that don't deliver.  That is why I mostly 
>attend Wicked and Basics/Gathering/Vision parties.  I've always had the 
>positive environment presented to me.  I feel I've always gotten my 
>money's worth.  What about your experiences?

Hmmm. I don't know; the best recent example of a promoter not delivering
that I can think of is Wicked. The last Wicked I went to (5-6 weeks back at
19th and Alabama) was without doubt the worst value on the dollar I've
seen. The door price rose throughout the night from $13 to $15 while I was
there, and people I know report that it didn't stop til it hit $20. I've
already thrashed this party once so I won't go into all the gory details
but they're in the archives if you're curious... 

However, just what a poor value this party was, was further driven home by
a party in the same space a week later which doubled the number of big name
djs and viusal artists, used an additional room, actually did *something*
with the horrid hallways there and, believe it or not, cost
$10...unfortunately while this party may have been a better *value* it was
horrifying vibe-wise.

You had to ask. =)

Re: Basics/Gathering/Vision, in general I have always regarded these
parties as the yardstick with which to measure the biggies...

take it easy
ethan

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407051246.A4674-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU> from "Tony V Garcia" at Jul 5, 94 12:57:04 pm
