My mailer says that Tony V Garcia said:
> 
> We're all sick of promoters that don't deliver.  That is why I mostly 
> attend Wicked and Basics/Gathering/Vision parties.  I've always had the 
> positive environment presented to me.  I feel I've always gotten my 
> money's worth.  What about your experiences?
> 
well, without griping too loudly, i feel as if i've rarely, if ever,
gotten my money's worth at a Wicked or a Basics/Vision/Gathering/LFR.
I mind, somewhat, the high price.  I have, more than once, been treated
to a full body search and arbitrary confiscations by security.  At
certain events of the wicked persuasion, the price has been raised through-
out the night, from 13 to 15 to 20 dollars.  The sound at Wickeds (every
single one) has been abysmal.  The knock-me-over factor has been extremely
high at all Wickeds, and fairly high at all Martin events.  The clique
factor has been extremely high at all these events.  The quality of
mixing has been high, but the music has rarely if ever moved me to do
more than sway (the exception is Tony, who always seems to have two or
three tracks that I've found in obscure places and loved), and often
drives me right out of the room.  I attended several Martin parties where
the security was so in-your-face as to make life unbearable.  I have
attended many Wickeds and Martin parties where there were no in-and-outs,
despite being told at the door on the way in there were.  I have heard the
same DJs play at these parties for going on two years...one
notable exception was a Wicked that Christophe played at.  I have paid
money for a renegade sound system that has never appeared.  I have seen
more and better visuals at the Orb and Orbital shows, for less money than
some of Martin's parties.  I have heard more and better sound at the 
Orbital show than Martin has ever marshalled.  I have never felt *safe* at 
any of these parties.  I have generally enjoyed the chill rooms/areas at 
these parties when there has been a chill area. it was my observation the 
other day that i'd have to be heavily enhanced to enjoy LFR...i was right.  
folks around me who were enhanced had a great time; i, unenhanced, had 
a tolerable time, and really looked forward to  leaving. oh, it was very
nice to see and talk with friends, but my mind and spirit were elsewhere,
yearning for different music, better visuals, nicer people all around.
when i hear talk of $40,000 budgets, i imagine the ~series~ of events
that i could help organize.  so far, i've spent about $900 out of pocket
and helped organize over 13 events...total cost to the attendee for all
parties: $8 plus any donations they chose to make (we've only asked for
money at the door at two events, and one of those was a benefit).

and, when i hear that large parties are near essential to the health of
the "house nation", i'd take issue.  from what i've seen at large parties,
diversity in artistic expression is *not* present...look at the DJ list,
the visuals list, the sound providers list, the location list. unification?
not from what i've seen and felt. increased communication? not from what
i've experienced.  improved dialectic? barely.  this is the first serious
discussion on SFR involving Martin directly, and the Wicked posse some-
what directly; i've never had these discussions in person with the
promoters.

do some people have fun at these things? yes, unequivocally yes. me? nope.
i keep giving them a try to see if things will be different, and they
aren't.  it's why i keep helping to provide alternatives.

Why do i keep going from time to time?  several reasons: 1) people say of
me that i only go to parties that i help organize or spin at; it ain't
so;  2) i want to give these people a chance from time to time, to see
how they're doing, and if my perceptions of them were wrong; 3) my friends
want to go, and want me to go with them; and 4) i sometimes go to promote
parties i'm involved with. And, i don't just gripe about these parties.
I take action by helping to organize events. and, i have a good time at
other events besides Wickeds and Martin parties and ones i participate
in planning, so i'm not just a sourpuss.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

could have shut down the party and written Galen a ticket. Thats what happend
to us
a few months ago but the charges got dropped.

other side

uniformed police types and after looking through his backpack discovered a
bunch of LSD & MDMA. What makes it really bad is that they were arrested in
the Presidio which makes it a federal crime and subject to stiffer penalties.
I guess the moral is to BE CAREFUL when doing drugs in public, you never know
who might be watching.

Subject: something disturbing i saw at sunset
To: sfraves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Cc: Jason Davis <robdude@cats.ucsc.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407051416.A6331-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	i arrived at the sunset party around 5:30... i was delighted to
find mr. phil smart providing sounds the place was neat....presidio...had
never been there before, etc. after great dancing for about an hour i
decided to walk around and enjoy the location. i climbed a flight of
cement stairs to an interesting platform and saw a handful of friends
peering down below to the ground. i walked over to them and when i looked
down i felt that weird buzz i always feel when i see the authorities at a
party. the badges were handcuffing two guys and hauling them off. the
story that was passed to me was one i had heard before... a designated
undercover (narc) had fooled the boys into selling him e. the narc
appeared to me as a fashionable filipino male around 26-30 years of age.
he was dressed in a khaki vest with matching khaki hat, i believe he had a
blue and green flannel on under the vest...if this helps anyone...i do
believe i have seen him around before well the story goes on ...the boys
were searched..goods were seized...posession..tears...OH WHY DOES IT HAVE
TO BE LIKE THIS!!? this is exactly the thing that makes everyone say "FUCK
THE POLICE!" ...these boys have no intention of hurting or posing a threat
to anyone/anything, yet they are stripped of their dignity and thrown into
a squad car as if they have done something horribly wrong. as they were
loaded into the vehichle friend tracy gave them the number of a really
good attorney. 

		you two boys are in my prayers
			jason davis

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9407052323.AA16890@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, robdude@cats.ucsc.edu
Subject: Re: what happened at the techno-rave?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> what i need to know is the order of the line-up because i
> keep hearing mixed things about the dj who SPUN? after tony. someone
> please give me the low down and a description of the so called wishy washy
> set. 

The following is a general consensus of a small group of overanalyzers
us who went to freedom:

Simon came on after Tony, and started off pretty well actually.  High 
energy multilayered stuff.  But after a while, his set got kinda boring.  
I really haven't been crazy about Simon for over a year now - a lot 
of the songs he plays focus on the midrange frequencies, and although 
pretty energetic, seem rather souless and sterile without being 
trancey.   Spun followed, and played some funky tunes that were OK, but 
never really established much of a groove.  The set was enjoyable, but 
kinda low key, energy-wise.  Things definately picked up with Josh, 
though he didn't blow me away.  I felt that the music at the last
Gathering (Richmond) with a similar lineup was better.

Upon reflecting with friends about the music at Freedom, we agreed
that we'd rather hear mediocre sets on a great sound system (as was
the case here) than great sets on a shitty sound system.  Anyway, I
never go to parties looking for perfection, and the music was certainly
good enough for our needs, i.e. we had little trouble dancing our asses 
off. d:-)

- leg of eel

On Tue, 5 Jul 1994, ethan miller wrote:

> Greetings Friends!
> 
> However Martin is not the only one throwing $20 parties. We have some very
> recent and, unfortunately, horrifying examples of big name parties that,
> IMO, really abused us, leaving me, in particular, a little trigger happy in
> regards to the $20 party. I have no problem with us as a scene enabling
> promoters and djs to make their living at it. But, make no mistake, this
> implies a relationship and a *responsibility* on their part to deliver the
> goods. And for $20 the goods better be good goods. 

	Yes.
 
> Comparisons to BGP style mainstream concerts don't prove the point either.
> If all we're measuring ourselves against is something that is obviously and
> grossly inflated then our standards are far too low. Why shouldn't this
> *movement*, if we're going to try and call it that, challenge, rather than
> perpetuate, the hyperinflated material consumerism that is the hallmark of
> american 'culture' if not western so-called civilization?
 
	I agree with you, but it's going to take lots of people to do it. 
The fundamental problem here is we live in a society that promotes
materialism based on money.  Too many people have forgotten that money is
just something that we all agree on.  Money is something created by
people, so many people stress out on it and act like it is something 
real, when it is really mostly paper and electronic bits.  To invoke 
change on society, we must make our message big.  And unfortunately, in 
this society, if you are going to make something BIG, you need money.  
You can't go on forever throwing free big parties.  It's like the NRA 
when a gun control law is going to be passed, they pump millions of 
dollars into fighting that. I guess that is why I don't mind paying $20 
for certain parties (when I can afford to, that is).  I have really come 
to a personal realization that I don't care about money, even though 
that's hared to do sometimes, because I am a starving student.   
                                  * * * > 
> One aspect of my initial post was that it was intended as a polemic; I knew
> my estimates were low (despite calling them high); I was hoping to provoke
> a response, which we got, on a number of fronts. And this, if you ask me,
> is great news, long time coming too. The point being, that, as people in
> community, the more we know about each other the better. Nothing makes me
> happier than having someone tell me what their vision is and just how much
> work they've put into it; it gives me a reason to support them. And, what
> better place to do this than here on sfr?! If all we're using this net for
> is just another place to hang a flier, we are indeed missing the point. So
> I'm tickled pink to find myself in the midst of a real live discussion of
> all the above and all of the below...
> 
> What has value? Who's worth supporting? Why? Where should this (house etc.)
> go? Why? Who's getting the money? What's being done with it? Why? IMO,
> these are essential questions if we have a future *together* as promoters,
> as djs, as ravers....especially if we're gonna call this a *movement*. I
> have yet to see a movement comprised of 2% producers and 98% consumers even
> if the consumers are consuming a good product, well worth $20...
> 
	I'm totally happy about this too.  Just think that every time you 
say something on this net, over 900 people can recieve it.  The 
possibilities of sfr to help us define who we are as a rave scene and 
what message we want to say to the rest of the world are limitless..

> How about next year we do a net-organized, massively promoted (wired!),
> free and fully permitted, national (worldwide!), march and Let Freedom Rave
> on Washington DC! See just how much of a movement we've got...

	This sounds like the right type of idea, and I think it could be 
a good start.  Would we want to do DC or start here in Sacramento 
(wouldn't it be cool if Pete Wilson came to a rave and joined in the 
circle with the rest of us happy ravers?  hmm?)
 
> Martin, you're the only person I know that could pull it off. You've got my
> help if you want it :)

	Mine too, Martin :)  
 
> lots of love
> ethan
 
	PS Ethan, thanks to you and all who threw F&F II.  I was only 
able to stop by for a few minutes, because I had to work and drive from 
Santa Cruz, but when I came in, it looked like a really fun party.  I 
hope I can make it to the next one.

dj fog


From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul  5 16:36:17 1994

	id QAA15313; Tue, 5 Jul 1994 16:36:50 -0700

Date: Tue, 5 Jul 1994 16:36:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: a few more thoughts
To: SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407051617.A11370-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I just wanted to say one more thing about my response to ethan's 
article.  I really agree that we need to fight the materialism.  But I 
think we also need to realize that we live in a materialistic society, 
and trying to force change on people won't work as well as just letting 
it happen.  I really think it is already happening to a certain extent.  
But we can't get discouraged if we still see negative energy all around 
us.  It's just there, and if we let it be there, it will slowly 
dissapate, and it might not all happen in our lifetimes.  We will pass 
our message of peace and love without strings or credit cards on to our 
children, and we ought not to worry about whether or how they use that 
information.  

At one of the last parties I went to, I sat with some of my friends and 
we all came to an agreement that our revolution is hard to fight, because 
we don't really stress anything more than inner peace and acceptance of 
our neighbors and communication between everyone.  Even negative people 
can't fight our being positive.

My dear friend Sean Hall wrote in "Feel":

"New people are constantly being accepted into my tight-knit circle of 
friends.  Even people that don't seem to have the best attitude or 
friendliest disposition, seem tol let themselves go when they are 
surrounded by us.  It's as if we are showing them the way, and the 
greatest part is that we dont try to, it just comes naturally."(Feel, 
Vol. 2, Issue One, May 1994, page 4.)

I've experienced this, too.  I feel like I am showing people the way, 
especially negative people.  They can't fight you when you simply sit 
down and refuse to fight them back or be negative.  


HAVE FUN TODAY.  THAT'S WHY YOU'RE HERE.
dj fog

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 1994 17:09:34 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407051346.A4674-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU> from "Tony V Garcia" at Jul 5, 94 04:16:11 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2792      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


> The fundamental problem here is we live in a society that promotes
> materialism based on money.  Too many people have forgotten that money is
> just something that we all agree on.  Money is something created by
> people, so many people stress out on it and act like it is something 
> real, when it is really mostly paper and electronic bits.

With you so far.  Land ownership is the same way -- an invisible line that
says "I get to hurt you if you step over this."

> To invoke 
> change on society, we must make our message big.  And unfortunately, in 
> this society, if you are going to make something BIG, you need money.  

And by doing this, you become just another part of the system you are 
trying to leave behind.

"Changing the system from within" is a fallacy.  The system will only let
you in after you have changed yourself enough to conform to its rules --
or when you have changed consensus reality enough to make it adapt, or die.

Kurt Cobain wearing a "Fuck Corporate Rock" T-shirt on the cover of Rolling
Stone didn't weaken corporate rock, just like Clinton blowing sax on MTV
didn't change the drug laws, just like throwing $20 parties won't
weaken the wage-slavery combine.  They might be fun (which is why I don't
attack their existence) but I don't pretend that they're revolutionary.

> You can't go on forever throwing free big parties.

But you can go on throwing free (or cheap) small parties, which become
free (or cheap) bigger parties, or even several free (or cheap) small
parties.

> > How about next year we do a net-organized, massively promoted (wired!),
> > free and fully permitted, national (worldwide!), march and Let Freedom Rave
> > on Washington DC! See just how much of a movement we've got...
> 
> 	This sounds like the right type of idea, and I think it could be 
> a good start.  Would we want to do DC or start here in Sacramento 
> (wouldn't it be cool if Pete Wilson came to a rave and joined in the 
> circle with the rest of us happy ravers?  hmm?)

Sacto would be a good start -- get the car or bus-pools going and converge
the House Nation on the Capitol steps.  Now _that_ would be worth some
money and time to get happening, especially after the Brazilians showing
up for the World Cup proved that lots of happy partying people != disaster.

Speaking of which, the articles in the Merc about the "Brazilian Invasion"
were surprisingly sympathetic, even to the point of wondering whether the
US is too strict and puritanical.  The coolest anecdote was about a big
bunch of Brazilians partying their way down the street being stopped and
told by an officer that "You need a permit to parade down this street,"
to which someone replied, "We're Brazilians, man!  We don't need permits!"
and sambaed their way down the avenue.

// g

Hello,

In a positive way, I would like to ask to see the breakdown of the
$40,000 cost of the earlier rave.

This could produce the following results:

- It turns out that $40K is really the minimum cost for that event and
everyone gets a better feeling for $20 events, AND other potential
promoters have a better idea of costs, so they don't go broke
underestimating costs, OR
- It turns out that some of us say "gosh, you paid $5k for
such-and-such?  We did it once for only $1500." and the promoters find a
new way to save some money on costs,  OR
- (unlikely from someone in this astute group) when it is broken down,
$40k is seen to be an over estimate...

How about it?

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

for mere possession in the last 3 months.  I have heard that the bust
at the Sunset party was for possession only, also.

Sometimes I really feal helpless, becuase I think there is nothing we
can do to change this obviously flawed law.  If pot is still viewed 
as being an evil to society, then certianly drugs like acid or ecstasy
will be imposible to decriminalize.

I guess all I can do is warn people.  If you buy or injest a controlled
substance, you are committing a very serious crime.  So please, BE
CAREFUL, they are after us.  If stopping the drug problem means putting
all of us young, smart, loving people in jail, then that is what they will
do.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Jul  6 10:48:08 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20935; Wed, 6 Jul 94 10:48:08 PDT

	id KAA05941; Wed, 6 Jul 1994 10:49:04 -0700
Message-Id: <199407061749.KAA05941@netcom14.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 1994 10:54:15 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: RE: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Okay, undoubtedly *not* my last statement on the subject :) 

Just because last year's LFR cost $40,000 does not prove the assertion that
parties of this size must, or need to cost this much. Embarking on a profit
based endeavor creates a certain atmosphere. Embarking on a free or
break-even based endeavor creates a different (and I'm *not* saying better)
atmosphere. Believe me when I say that if the same party or, better, a
party of the same scale were attempted on a free, or break-even, basis it
would cost *dramatically* less, IMO, on the order of night and day.

For example:

Penelope's Web Site        $1200 (for the whole weekend!)
Plenty of Sound            $1500
DJs                        $0000 (Donated)
Visuals                    $0000 (Donated)
Security                   $0000 (Not an issue, different crowd)
Insurance                  $0000 (Not an issue, not required)
Promotion                  $0300 (30,000 2-sided b/w fliers)
Logistics                  $1000
Food/Water                 $1000
Misc.                      $1000

Total                      $6000

If 1000 people $6 each
If 2000 people $3 each
etc.

Feel free to add items I've forgotten. Hoewever the site quote is solid and
right from the source. At "Home" (a large party I threw) 6 pairs of the big
Community stacks cost $700. 6 alone would be adequate, 12 stacks would be
truly *plenty* of sound. Promotion costs are accurate as well. $1000 for
logistics seems generous....So unless there's some $35,000 item I'm
forgetting seems plenty feasible to me.

It's all about energy. If you *wanted* to make this happen, got other
people that wanted it to happen involved, they got their friends involved
and *everyone* promoted, here, in LA, in Seattle, on all the regional
'x'rave lists, it could easily be done...

F&F VIII perhaps...  :)

take it easy
ethan



From sfraves-owner  Wed Jul  6 10:48:26 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20952; Wed, 6 Jul 94 10:48:26 PDT
Received: from netcom14.netcom.com by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20942; Wed, 6 Jul 94 10:48:18 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom14.netcom.com (8.6.8.1/Netcom)
	id KAA05971; Wed, 6 Jul 1994 10:49:21 -0700
Message-Id: <199407061749.KAA05971@netcom14.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 1994 10:54:31 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves )
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Re: FREEDOMFYI; DI
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

At  4:14 PM 7/1/94 -40962758, Wicked wrote:

>Maybe there is a need to clarify the position of today's DJ's. In the 
>Bay area alone there is well up of 60+ DJ's. Ranging from Professional
>to Semi-Professional(No they havn't given up their day job yet or 
>they're a student) to Amateur(no pay, doesn't want to be payed, or 
>would like to be payed).

Yes, there is a need to clarify these positions. Nice to get a response
straight from the horses mouth, as it were. As an aside remember that the
word 'amateaur' comes from the root 'am' as in 'amore' and, translated,
means: someone motivated by love :)

>I view the DJ as an artist. In so much as a graphic designer, scriptwriter,
>musician, actor/actress etc is an artist too. If these peopleview >themselves
>as professional then I'm sure they want to get the best deal
>they can. Why sell themselves short? Why let the big corporation, employer,
>promoter makes loads of money off them? Surely they deserve a piece of 
>the pie?

In general agreed; I would not expect anyone to not try and optimize
whatever professional position they put themselves in. However I know for a
fact that both FTT and Cool World have paid DJs on the order of $1200 for a
2-hour set. Which, as we've noticed, results in bloated budgets which then
'necessitate' $20 price tags. I'm not going to suggest (again) that people
*shouldn't* have a profit motive in promoting raves but, like a farmer that
overplants his soil thereby depleting it's nutrients, $20 parties,
especially shitty ones, will wear out *your* market. Bottom line: I think
the whole shebang is inflated (especially in summer!) and that the scene
would really benefit from more promoters and djs making an obvious attempt
to demonstrate some good (financial) will (like the fmr) towards the people
that support them. Not to get too carried away on the subject, however, it
has been my experience that most of the so called "big name djs" have been
willing to play for free at free parties when asked to. Unfortunately they
haven't always followed thru, which is to say, actually showed up. 

>I agree that $20 parties are steep. I wouldn't pay that much for a party
>and if I did I'd damn well expect to entertained! 

Then why do you (Wicked) throw parties that, by your own admission, you
wouldn't attend?

>Equating with music concerts, though, people will happily spend $15 - $30
>or more to go to The Warfield, The Filmore, The Shoreline etc. to see some
>bands play for a few hours. Is $20 so much to pay to stay up all night?

I'll reprise a paragraph form an ealier post here: 

Comparisons to BGP style mainstream concerts don't prove the point either.
If all we're measuring ourselves against is something that is obviously and
grossly inflated then our standards are far too low. Why shouldn't we
challenge, rather than perpetuate, the hyperinflated material consumerism
that is the hallmark of american 'culture' if not western so-called
civilization? 

I think my idealism is getting in the way lately. I thought we were trying
to challenge some of the dominant paradigms. If we (you) just want to be an
another entre on the mainstream american platter then yes, I suppose $20 is
not a lot to pay for a nights 'entertainment'.

>As to Wages. The figures quoted I think are somewhat inflated. I think if
>you half them you might get a more realistic amount. 

Which figures are these? The ones I suggested or the $60K (Spun) and $100K
(Doc Martin) figures? As noted above, $1000 - $1200 for a 2-hour set can be
verified.

>And of course these >are gross earnings. You must remember that
>professional DJ's run their own business - they're self- employed. Net
>earnings are much different if you take into account the spend on vinyl per
>week. Most concientious DJ's buy a lot of records ($5 -$10 a pop).

Yes, being self employed has a lot of hidden overhead: dental, medical and
yes, vinyl. But, just out of curiosity, how much, on average, do you spend
on vinyl a week? I won't aim this directly at you, but if everyone's
spending so much on vinyl, I sure wish I was hearing some more new music. I
went to the Pure Space immediately prior to the Wicked at 19th and Alabama.
Garth played, then Jeno came on played no less than 4, and I think it was
more like 6, of the exact same songs. Two days later at Wicked they did the
they exact same thing. And, in actual point of fact, I've been hearing the
same sets from them for the last month and a half which, in case you hadn't
noticed, means I've been *supporting* them. My take: I haven't been getting
a lot for my money. For you to call this griping is, IMO, in very poor
taste.

>Even with all the griping, I think the diversity in the Bay Area is
>enormous, more so than anywhere in the country. Small, medium, large
>parties. Free, cheap, expensive. Acid Jazz, Techno, House, Garage etc.

I see the possibility here for a misinterpretation on my part of your vague
use of the word griping, so please clarify. But as long as we're on the
subject lets put the cards on the table and discuss some of the other
gripes with Wicked. I don't mean to attack you personally here and I can
easily see as how you might not want to be "The Voice of Wicked" but, to
some extent, you have you've thus identified yourself. So...

One of the main gripes I've heard about Wicked is that, in effect, you
operate as a cartel. Promoters have allegedly been "harassed" for not
replacing one Wicked DJ that was unable to play with another. Package
deals: Jeno won't play if Garth can't and vice versa are also reputed to be
a common occurrence. Given that these occurrences are true (are they?),
what right have you, as a collective, to try and exert that kind of
influence? We all try and get our friends gigs, but this takes it a bit far
I'd say. 

There's other people out there that would like a chance to play as well.

>     And if you don't like the way it is all I've got to say is this:
>
>           IF YOU WANT SOMETHING DONE PROPERLY DO IT YOURSELF

We are. So grab the rest of the boys and come on by sometime. You never
know, you might actually have a good time.  :)

take it easy
ethan



From sfraves-owner  Wed Jul  6 11:52:59 1994

In-Reply-To: nrg@netcom.com -- 07/06/94 11:01

hi y'all,
this  discussion raise some interesting points: supposing that rave kulture
'wants' to reach  a larger population, we need massives. do these massives
 have to be expensively run ? nrg seems to indicate that this is not
the case. so then why the higher priced raves at all ? by entering the
capitalist market, raves become part of that culture rather than challange
it and/or change it. and the rules of capilatist market will start to
dictate the nature and/or price of the party rather than the participants.
i don't see a way out of this. it is the old means/ends 'split'. it DOES
matter how we get there, the 'new' structure: the way there is part of
the new structure , post-capitalist/anarchist/whatever. or this is at
least one possiblity.
take care/shalom
ovid

bone-shaking bass that we can put out here.

gets out. ).

Community ConneXion: The NEXUS-Berkeley is having its first public
monthly meeting on July 10th, 12pm, the Sunday after the cypherpunks
meeting.

It will be upstairs at Kip's in Berkeley. It will be very
informal. We'll be able to snag a table to fit all of us, I think, and
from my experience at Kips on Sunday afternoons it should be quiet
enough. We'll probably have to get some food so they don't kick us
out. Shouldn't be a problem.

Items on the agenda: (not yet formalized/finalized.. suggestions welcomed)

	Privacy
		Privacy services
		Privacy emphasis
	Community
		building a local discussion group
		forum
		moo
	Organization
		Need to get more organized
		Find someone to help with that
		Issue of investors?
	NexusBucks
		Scheme
		goals

Directions:
	From I-80:
	Take the University Exit, go East on University until you
reach Shattuck. Turn right onto Shattuck. 3-4 blocks south turn left
onto Durant. Continue on Durant about 4-5 blocks, Kips is on the left
the block before Telegraph. Find parking. (It shouldn't be very
tough.. not like there will be an actual *lot*, but not tough..)

Summary:
	Nexus-Berkeley Meeting
	July 10th 12pm-? (maybe 4-5?)
	Kips in Berkeley
	
	I'd like to make this a regular thing, to have a meeting every
month the sunday after the cypherpunks meeting.

OKay, now that I am fully awake to write my post. I loved Liquid Drano. 
It was great listening to ultra-cheesy/hardcore/and hard trance. Bryce's 
sets were hilarious. It brought back so many memories. I loved Laura's 
set. Too bad SF sorta tamed her and she really didnt get into her 
hardcore set. Oh well. Next time. "I smell a blood of an english muffin."
It was great seeing everyone. Well, I guess I can be callled the hardcore
commuter: SF->SJ->SF->Los Gatos->SJ->SC->SF->work. *yawn* thinking about 
all that driving tires me. *phew*. Thanks to Bryce, Laura, etc. for 
putting on the party and to Hardcore Kia and Sharon for the "conversation"
up to SF.

 RE: The 25 watt restriction at the park: A few months ago , I bought
 a little electronics kit from Fry's - it's a stereo FM transmitter. I 
 originally bought it for my father-in-law , but maybe I could build
 and "test it out" at the picnic this August! 

  This is with the assumption that most folks have stereo headphones
 or earphones , and a portable FM receiver of some kind. If so , then
 folks could use their personal electronics to get the suffucient volume,
 while the PA speakers could be used more as DJ monitors , and as bass
 boost to complement the headphone/earphone signals.

 This assumes that I get going with that soldering iron ...


 ( How have other folks experiences with FM transmitters been? How about
   the bass? )
	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Hi all,
        Thank you Ethan for pulling the needed response from me and for
your kind and inspiring words.  It is nice to communicate with 900? people
@ 0nce and hear your comments, criticisims etc.  Most of you seemed to
enjoy Freedom as did most of the people not on the net. That makes me happy
to say the least.  Still i have heard that it was to far to travel from
some people.  One thing i believe is we have to learn to travel great
distances. Not only in the way of miles to a party or festival as the House
Movement ( your comments taken into consideration ethan ) expands within
america, but also in the distance we have to travel into the depths of
depths of our inner selves.  This is nessacary to in order to love and
accept ourselves first, the world will follow in due course.  This is
something i struggle with on a daily basis, somedays a lot, some a little. 

        I have put parties on for three years now, i have done them for
lots of different reasons over the years.....  For the love and happiness
that is created at them; for the boost to my ego; to satisfy my drive to be
the best at whatever i do; to create an enviornment where people are more
suseptable to achieve a higher state of consciousness; to bring people
together; for the money that can sometimes be made:  These are just some of
the reasons, but for the most part as i sit here now, reflecting, the main
reasons.  I think you would agree there are both good and bad reasons in
there.  You see, i am just a human being, i am no better or worse than any
of you.  I am just doing the best i can to make sense of whats going on
around me.  I see right, i see wrong, i see change.
On the subject of $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$, ken,
Freedom rave 93'

insurance                  400
lighting, strobes etc      550
bus                        500
trucks                     250
misc                     2,000??
                        ________
Total                   39,100

these figures are off the top of my head, and are kinda rough, ok?
i hope this answers some questions, even though i know there will always be
questions, but that is good.
peace and love  martin

Subject: Re: FREEDOMFYI;
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ovid muses:
> by entering the
> capitalist market, raves become part of that culture rather than 
> challange it and/or change it.

It is not clear to me whether raving, even as a "movement" is intended
to specifically challenge/change capatalism.  What is clear to me is that 
raving enables us to experience our ability to transcend our differences 
and come together in a spirit of energy, respect and caring for each other.

>... it DOES
> matter how we get there, the 'new' structure: the way there is part of
> the new structure...

I don't think I can completely agree with this.  There are many paths
to the same end; no one way is necessarily right for everybody.

At Freedom, when a few hundred of us held hands and experienced Unity,
Love and Silliness, it didn't matter who paid $20 or who was guested or 
who was Xing or what kind of music was played or who made money or how 
good the visuals were... It just happened because everyone there wanted 
it to and believed in the vision of what raving is supposed to be about.

I am hopeful that despite the variety of perceived flaws in our scene, 
those of us who continue to seek out the *positive* will continue to 
experience and perpetuate it in a variety of ways. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

> 
> Ovid muses:
> > by entering the
> > capitalist market, raves become part of that culture rather than 
> > challange it and/or change it.
> 
> It is not clear to me whether raving, even as a "movement" is intended
> to specifically challenge/change capatalism.

I'd put it this way: _I_ hope that raving as a movement will, among other
things, help to specifically challenge/change capitalism.  And I know I'm
not the only one that feels that way.  Maybe we aren't all expecting the
same ends from our movement?  But then is it really a movement?  Questions,
questions...

> >... it DOES
> > matter how we get there, the 'new' structure: the way there is part of
> > the new structure...
> 
> I don't think I can completely agree with this.  There are many paths
> to the same end; no one way is necessarily right for everybody.

You're both right.  Obviously there is not just one way, but if the way we
take is paved with corruption, the corruption will still be stuck in our
soles when we get there and we won't be able to get it out.

by the way, in case anyone was still wondering, liquid drain-o was dope.
Everything I would expect from an outdoor party and more.  And, I made an
accidental discovery from the fact that i didn't have enough oranges to give
everyone their own: the best thing you can give to someone is the ability to
give themselves!

peace,
stevie

stevie says:
>[...] if the way we
> take is paved with corruption,

What do you mean by "corruption"?  
- paying off a bum $2 to not report a trespass?
- taping and selling DJ sets of copyrighted material?
- paying a corrupt SFPD for a sound permit?
- putting friends on a guest list?

If we let debates over these kinds of philosophical issues stop us from 
coming together to share and perpetuate our message, there won't be much 
in the way of a rave scene, or a movement. 

> the corruption will still be stuck in our
> soles when we get there and we won't be able to get it out.

Maybe, maybe not.  When I step in shit, I can usually manage to eventually
get most, if not all of it off of my shoe.  Oh, you meant soul :-)  Well 
that can be cleansed also.  I believe in evolution - we humans will make
mistakes along the way to wherever we are going; the important thing (IMO)
is to keep moving in a positive direction.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Jul  7 11:47:20 1994

     id 0G7N000R Thu, 07 Jul 94 11:32:25 
Message-Id: <9407071132.0G7N000@sfnet.com>
Organization: SF NET San Francisco's Coffee House Connection
X-Mailer: TBBS/PIMP v3.08
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 94 11:32:25 
Subject: RAVE MOVEMENT?
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


In response to a recent comment on the meaning of the rave movement, I have
this to say.

I think raving in itself, and the music, has very little to say.  The music is
good music, technically, and it can give one a good happy feeling.  But it
doesn't get me thinking about unity and peace and stuff.  Unless I'm on
something.

I think the politics come from the promoters, and can come in any form.  You
could have a Rush Limbaugh rave, just as easily as a Greenpeace rave.  However,
generally the alternative (I hate to use that word) scene is where the raves
are at, be it pop alternative, or underground alternative.  And alternative is
generally about freedom, and open minded-ness.  Therefore, that's the general
political voice and backbone of raves.

However, how many raves have you been to that was overtly political, or even
just had something to say?  Although I had a good time at Let Freedom Rave, and
there were a lot of nice people there, and people who were into meeting new
friends, there were also a lot of people who were there just for the scene, or
just for the music, or just to be drugged up, or even just for a fight.  Peace
and unity wasn't on their minds.

                Jesus Chrysler

>    	Yes, and the earth is going to have a new ice age because of it!  
> It's true, I read it in the Enquirer.  I saw a picture of NY covered in 
> snow!  Really!  It's true, because I read it there!
My friend Timothy is throwing a party >4500' above sea level, as he 
believes that the polarity of the earth will reverse and everything will 
slide 2000 miles south.  I don't know what 4500' has to do with this, but 
the party should be.... interesting.  And plus it's happening on my 
birthday! :-)

Peace,
Matt
<(hcy)>

On Thu, 7 Jul 1994 jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com wrote:

> 
> In response to a recent comment on the meaning of the rave movement, I have
> this to say.
> 
> I think raving in itself, and the music, has very little to say.  The music is
> good music, technically, and it can give one a good happy feeling.  But it
> doesn't get me thinking about unity and peace and stuff.  Unless I'm on
> something.
> 
> I think the politics come from the promoters, and can come in any form.  You
> could have a Rush Limbaugh rave, just as easily as a Greenpeace rave.  However,
> generally the alternative (I hate to use that word) scene is where the raves
> are at, be it pop alternative, or underground alternative.  And alternative is
> generally about freedom, and open minded-ness.  Therefore, that's the general
> political voice and backbone of raves.
> 
> However, how many raves have you been to that was overtly political, or even
> just had something to say?  Although I had a good time at Let Freedom Rave, and
> there were a lot of nice people there, and people who were into meeting new
> friends, there were also a lot of people who were there just for the scene, or
> just for the music, or just to be drugged up, or even just for a fight.  Peace
> and unity wasn't on their minds.
> 
>                 Jesus Chrysler
> 
              to add a little perspective to all this talk about the 
social and political implications of the "rave scene"----we just got back 
from the rainbow gathering in wyoming.this gathering of several thousand 
people was completely free including camping, parking, food, drugs, in 
fact ,the use of money is totally unneccesary and obsolete!!!no permit 
was obtained for the use of this public land because the rainbow family 
do not recognize anyone's authority to issue a permit for land that is 
our's to begin with.noone is in charge, there are no security people, you 
are free to walk, climb, run ,swim, smoke ,and freek  anywhere that you 
feel like (with respect to others around you).the self governing nature 
of this gathering relies on a wisdom-system that evolves and mutates 
collectively---the rules are not handed down.of course the family have 
been working on this for over twenty years, but the end result is that 
they have created for themselves (and anyone else who wants to include 
themselves)a powerful force for personal and social change which does not 
concede an ounce of it's energy to the surrounding political and economic 
forces.pretty cool , huh?

From sfraves-owner  Thu Jul  7 15:38:54 1994

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 1994 15:39:27 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: BURNING MAN
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Is anyone here planning on going to the Burning Man Festival this Labor Day 
Weekend?  It's going to be up in the Black Rock Desert, about a 7 hour 
drive from SF (but not in the same location as last year).

Brian, Bryce, and I are up for it.  We're even thinking about bringing
MetroVision along if we can figure out a way to keep our records from
melting -- even in the shade in the daytime I suspect it will be too
hot for them.  If you have any  ideas . . . . 

If you are seriously planning on going let me know.  There is an
address to which you must send $30 to register, get directions, and
get some high desert camping/survival information.  I've got that address
somewhere, I'll have to dig it up.  So anyway, I figured that any
of us going could coordinate hauling/sharing supplies and rides.  If
you're not near the Bay Area and are going and would like to meet up
at the Festival, let me know and we can plan for a camping neighborhood
or something.

Of course, once I get there, the planning stops :-)  I fully realize
that chaos and cacophany rule.  I just don't want things to be so
chaotic during the packing/driving stage that we've forgotten something
once we're up there.

Laura

	I bought the same last year. It works, but I cannot set it correctly
	for stereo output (it has a lot of noise). Anyway, it can be a backup 
	for yours (and it is available for the future).

	What about having also a few boombox around ? They are not part of 
	the sound-system, and can contribute to the bass level.

	I would suggest (and if I have time I would do that) to go in the
	park one of this weekends before the party for checking the transmitter
	and finding the right frequency.

	
	Speaking of silent-raves, I found in July Wired (pg. 40) a description
	of the Interactor Vest, something you put on and connect to a sound 
	source to feel the vibrations of basses. They suggest to use it to
	play 'Mortal Kombat', I had another idea :)
	Anybody of you knows more about this toy ?
	
-- Raffaele

  This is regarding your letter about the person who said that they heard 
of people paying any where between $13 to $20 for the Wicked that was at 
19th and Alabama.  I'm sorry to say that I didn't go to that one, but i 
am usually seen at almost all of your parties at which I have always had 
a wonderful time.  As I understand, that night you had a person named 
chas running you door.  Well, I dont like to slam people but that is the 
same person that has sold bunk E to several of people that I know,  
stolen things from ameba, he is not allowed around here anymore.    

  With him at your door it is possible that he charged people more than 
he was asked to and kept the change for himself.  I am just telling you 
this as a friend, because i am tired of seeing you guys get slammed by 
other people in the scene saying that you charge $20 for a party.  I have 
never paid that much to go to one of your events but also, Chas was not 
at the door.  I advise you not to have that guy at your door and you 
won't have any problems with people getting charged $20.

See ya Saturday,

Tracy Ameba


--PAA20322.773620266/soda.berkeley.edu--

Come/Unity was great last night, back it its rightful place (1015).
Too bad it had to end at 3:30.  I picked up a few flyers but not as
much as usual.  What's up with the slow summer?  April and May were
packed with cool parties.  Actually there's still more than enough,
but I guess we're spoiled here.  Check out the new moon party and
Wicked this weekend, and Sunset or Mushroom Jazz or Elation after
that...

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

	Hey Markie, how's it goin'?  I don't get on the net much but i 
couldn't help but notice that in your reply to all the various complaints 
you said that someone said that they paid $20 for the Wicked party at 
19th and Alabama.
	Working here at Ameba I hear all sorts of things from the people 
that attend the various parties of the weekend.  I heard from a few 
out-of-towners that they were charged $20, which I thought was kind of 
wierd especially since every wicked that I have been to has always been 
$15 or less.
	Well by the end of the day at the store I learned that the 
infamous Chaz was working your door that night, which explains why people
were charged $20.  He used to work this same scam at Charter Oaks.  
Example: The Agreed amount of the party is $15, Chaz charges $20 and 
keeps $5 for himself, be careful he is very good at this and selling bunk 
E at your parties.
	I hope that you take my letter seriously, I speak from past 
experiences.  He has stolen from Ameba, therefore he is not allowed here 
anymore.
	Good luck in all that you do.  I'll be there Saturday.
Thanks for all the good times, Tracy Ameba

To: sfraves@techno
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Wicked: $15?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno

In my recent post regarding Wicked I did *not* mean to imply that Wicked
has routinely or historically charged $20. I have never paid more than $15
for a Wicked party. However people did claim to have paid that much ($20)
for the party at 19th & Alabama. Recent information on this list suggests
the possibility that Wicked may have been unaware that this was happening.
However as Wicked made no statement on the subject, and, in fact, may not
have known, there would be no way for anyone, like myself, to know whether
or not this was an anomaly, which is to say mistake, or simply a new
pricing arrangement.

take it easy
ethan

A side note about this event: apparently it has become a very public 
and popular kind of thing. Last year there were even TV stations 
covering it! So, just a warning that it's not nearly as private as it 
has been is years past...if that's what you're looking for you might 
be disappointed by the hordes at Burning Man (though the new location 
might be a help.

Subject: guitar player looking for DJ's a/or band for raves

Recently turned onto the rave techno scene. I've been playing guitar for 12
years and have played in several bands and played in most of the clubs in San
Francisco.
While at a rave last week I thought it would be interesting to hear some live
artists working with a DJ. My friend turned me on to Amourphous Androgenous,
Young American Primitive, Orb, etc. I WANT to play music like that! If anyone
is interested in experimenting I would be more than happy to drag my
equipment over, or you can bring you're rig to my practice studio in the city
(SF). I would like to play at some parties, I really get off playing in front
of groovy people, the more people the better I play.
zimmermanj@aol.com

Subject: Re: RAVE MOVEMENT?
To: jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com
Cc: sfraves@techno
In-Reply-To: <9407071132.0G7N000@sfnet.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407080007.A381-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno

On Thu, 7 Jul 1994 jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com wrote:

> 
> In response to a recent comment on the meaning of the rave movement, I have
> this to say.
> 
> I think raving in itself, and the music, has very little to say.  The music is
> good music, technically, and it can give one a good happy feeling.  But it
> doesn't get me thinking about unity and peace and stuff.  Unless I'm on
> something.

I believe the rave scene has taught me that if people can be this 
friendly and peaceful around each other at a rave, then there must be a 
way that people can be that way all the time, without drugs.  It's true, 
the music itself has really very little to say.  My opinion about house 
music is that when I am on something, I lose track of time dancing, 
partially because there's no words in it.  A lot of the sounds used in 
house music sound like they come from nature, but they're created 
electronically.  To me, it's almost contradictory, but it's beautiful.  I 
listen to songs sometimes and say "I've heard this song somewhere 
else--but it wasn't a house song."  Also, when I first started raving, I 
had heard stories about people getting into it too much, wanting to go 
out every night and take something.  So right from the beginning, I 
wanted to try to enjoy it afterwards after I came down.  My first rave 
was so fun.  Since I was told what raves were supposedly about (inner 
peace and cultural unity; love your neighbor), I found that happiness 
almost before I got there.  Since that time I have found the music to 
inspire me, and I don't need to be high.  I guess I am responding to your 
message, because I was concerned that you said the rave scene and the 
music doesn't get you thinking about unity and stuff.  I am curious, have 
you found yourself being more positive when not on something after going 
to a rave?
 
> 
> I think the politics come from the promoters, and can come in any form.  You
> could have a Rush Limbaugh rave, just as easily as a Greenpeace rave.  However,
> generally the alternative (I hate to use that word) scene is where the raves
> are at, be it pop alternative, or underground alternative.  And alternative is
> generally about freedom, and open minded-ness.  Therefore, that's the general
> political voice and backbone of raves.

Yuck, a Rush Limbaugh rave?  Was that the one where Morton Downey Jr was 
the promoter and the lineup of DJ's were David Duke and special guest 
from the Traditional Coalition?  
> 
> However, how many raves have you been to that was overtly political, or even
> just had something to say?  Although I had a good time at Let Freedom Rave, and
> there were a lot of nice people there, and people who were into meeting new
> friends, there were also a lot of people who were there just for the scene, or
> just for the music, or just to be drugged up, or even just for a fight.  Peace
> and unity wasn't on their minds.

I don't think raves are meant to be overtly political.  I think the 
message is simply that people dance, are happy together, and simply just 
exist in a large crowd without hurting each other or being violent.  The 
message is that people are so happy just existing, that nothing more 
needs to be said.  When I was agreeing with Ethan about a walk on 
Sacramento, I don't know how political I would personally like it to 
get.  I think just by keeping it alive, we are showing people around us 
that we are not a threat to society, unlike many other gatherings of 
large groups of people.  I mean, I heard cops were not trying to break up 
the last full moon, but they were in fact showing people the way.  I 
don't know if it's true or not, but I am hearing more and more about 
people saying how nice ravers are.  The word is getting around, and 
that's why I don't think we need to be totally political, except to fight 
to keep our scene alive.  I was part of the group of people that called 
the SF supervisors to protest the law about dancing after 2am if you're 
under 21.  I helped fight that, because it would suppress those people's 
right to dance.   


This is my definition of the rave scene:  Teaching people to exist 
alongside one another by being positive rather than negative.  

I'm curious.  What are other people's definitions?  What does the scene 
mean to you?  

dj fog

        Fri, 08 Jul 1994 09:10:00 GMT
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <A0F439B9@tigerteam.org>
Subject: Vinyl IDM-ish space mus
To: sfraves@techno
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 1994 09:10:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno


Hello,

I have the following Vinyl LPs left over from the days when I used to be
the only mail order retailer in the US for these titles (I'm no longer
doing any music retailing :-( ).

I'd like to trade them (individually) for DJ tapes, either IDM or not...
in fact, old stuff is perhaps preferable (91? 89?).  Or else for tapes
of old out of print techno or house.  (Which is not to say that I'd
refuse DJ tapes of the latest IDM/house/trip-hop/jungle/? ).

They are (all still sealed and all "reissues") :

Manuel Gottsching - E2-E4 (6 copies) - The million-selling hit of Summer
'89 "Sueno Latino" was a "cover" of this 60-minute long track.  In the
TEEX book, Dr. Patterson describes his favorite ambient albums, and says
this in his description of Steve Hillage's "Rainbow Dome Musick":

"Mix Manuel Gottsching's 'E2 = E4' with 'Rainbow Dome Music" and you'll
be very surprised at the end result.  Music to rebuild your head after a
heavy night".  So, all you need are two 1200's and the RDM LP and this one.

Richard Wahnfried - Time Actor (5 copies) - Richard Wahnfried is the
name that Klaus Schulze used for his collaboration albums.  This one
includes Arthur Brown ("I am the god of hellfire and I bring you
fire."), Vincent Crane (played keyboards on the original Fire), and Mike
Shrieve - percussionist for Santana.  There is a pretty weird "talk" by
Brown on this about the metaphysics of time...

Richard Wahnfried - Tonwelle (3 copies) - This is less Ambient and more
space-rock-ish.  Features Manuel Gottsching on guitar, Mike Shrieve on
percussion, and the artist-known-before-and-after-this-recording-as-Carlos
Santana :-) (but attributed to "Karl Wahnfried" in the liner notes).  Oh
yes, this is 18 minutes a side -- at 45 RPM (12").

Of course, there's Klaus Schulze on synths on both the Wahnfried LPs.

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

       /   Modem (510) 268-0102  info@tigerteam.org  /

Lee writes:
> Stevie writes:
>>
>> Ovid muses:
>> > by entering the
>> > capitalist market, raves become part of that culture rather than
>> > challange it and/or change it.
>>
>> It is not clear to me whether raving, even as a "movement" is intended
>> to specifically challenge/change capatalism.
>
>I'd put it this way: _I_ hope that raving as a movement will, among other
>things, help to specifically challenge/change capitalism.  And I know I'm
>not the only one that feels that way.  Maybe we aren't all expecting the
>same ends from our movement?  But then is it really a movement?  Questions,
>questions...

Well, it depends what you mean by capitalism.  I can't imagine anything
wrong with a free market system tempered by real anti-trust controls.
The problem comes from materialist and power junkies who distort the
system and use it for negative purposes.

Any other system (such as communism) really requires, in advance, that
EVERYBODY already has a positive vibe and community spirit, otherwise
you end up with all the same problems.

I think that it is really materialism and selfishness that you are
talking about changing.

"You better free your mind instead"

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Hey Guys,

I can understand the need to stop the crooks who charge extra $ for parties
only to pocket some of it for themselves.  I think it's wise to inform
everyone on the net as the best method to put and end to it.

I'm not sure, however, whether it's really necessary to name these people
for selling drugs.  People always will end up buying bunk anything and if
we were to run around and cry, so-and-so sold me shitty this or crappy
that, then we can't complain about cops visiting Wicked parties (or any
party for that matter) 'cause they heard people sell contraband there.

If you need to inform, take it offline...

- Steve

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9407082055.AA04690@pilot.njin.net>
To: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Cc: jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: RAVE MOVEMENT?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407080007.A381-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
References: <9407071132.0G7N000@sfnet.com>
	<Pine.3.89.9407080007.A381-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Tony V Garcia writes:
 > I don't think raves are meant to be overtly political.  I think the 
 > message is simply that people dance, are happy together, and simply just 
 > exist in a large crowd without hurting each other or being violent.  The 
 > message is that people are so happy just existing, that nothing more 
 > needs to be said.

That's one of the things I think makes the rave scene really unique.
Without a lot of overt communication, people at a party come to an
surprising level of understanding and empathy. Out of nowhere, a
feeling of consentual sharing and (often) love comes forth. I felt
this at parties long before being exposed to any sort of of rave
rhetoric or philosophy.

I don't think it comes from any sort of message directed from raves. I
think that it's something many of us hold dear inside and which
flourishes in the autonomy and acceptance of a good rave.

Not that messages are bad or anything. I think they help set the
stage--encourage the right mindset. Good caring promotion ties in here
too. Provide a good positive experience for your guests and it makes
it that much easier for them to enjoy themselves and let loose that
good stuff inside.

The whole experience: experienced people setting an example, promotion
that says "we want you to share in this", the pounding beats, eye
candy, disinhibiting psychoactives, and the consentual "vibe" that
builds. I don't think this says (or really needs to say) any
particular message. I think what it does is makes it possible for a
very special part of ourselves to migrate outward and touch other
people. It's just the good side of human nature, that very personal
identity deep inside that just wants to love and be loved.

And if that wasn't nice enough, I hear from a lot of people that the
experience has a lot of carryover into real life. Some people, once
shown the way, find it a little easier from then on to reach out to
others.

:)

Sean

For detailed information about Burning Man, write:

Burning Man Project
PO Box 420572
San Francisco, CA 94142-0572

It runs Sept 2 -5 this year.

They are requesting a $30 donation, to help cover costs of portapotties,
etc.  You can volunteer and whittle this fee down.

If you want to volunteer, or bring your performing act to the desert, call
415/985-7471.

A special screening of last year's broadcast press coverage and the Emmy-no
minated (!) PBS documentary "In Search of Ritual: The Burning Man" will be
whoops - was shown - on June 25.  

A concurrent event, Desert Siteworks, wil be held during the entire month of
September at the hot springs in Black Rock. Call William Binzen,
415-488-9864.

Desert Siteworks is a temporary community with collaboration, hard work and
harder play in an austere but gorgeous desert -- a nouveau/retro art
happening, high adventure and friendly hijinx.

Percussion, vocual, world beath, acoustic, electronic, neo-primitivist,
techno music. Scriopted and improvised structures adn actions trance
performance, dance and approa hes to ritual. Costuming and Bodypainting a
must.

Laura

ethan,
 when i first got on the net i learned that ideally it's main
purpose was to increase the communication within our *scene*. i also
learned that self promotion is frowned upon. the exception being promotion
of free parties. i have noticed you've done it more than once:  i.e. your
recent post/advertisement for your demo "acid test". i am not saying we
should limit the party info going through the net, i just think the info
could be stated without excessive use of adjectives and such. i feel that
the continuation of such posts could turn the net into an outlet to
increase popularity/exposure in the scene. 

love and cookie monsters....jason d.

On Fri, 8 Jul 1994, Robert Ernest wrote:

>  when i first got on the net i learned that ideally it's main
> purpose was to increase the communication within our *scene*. i also
> learned that self promotion is frowned upon. the exception being promotion
> of free parties. i have noticed you've done it more than once:  i.e. your
> recent post/advertisement for your demo "acid test". i am not saying we
> should limit the party info going through the net, i just think the info
> could be stated without excessive use of adjectives and such. i feel that
> the continuation of such posts could turn the net into an outlet to
> increase popularity/exposure in the scene. 
It's not necessarily self-promotion that I think it's frowned upon, it's 
*ego-centered* self-promotion.  It's not popularity or exposure that 
would be a problem, it's the *type* of popularity or exposure....

(this is not a flame, just an observation)

Peace,
Matt
<(hcy)>

well, in light of my recent post concerning what i disliked about
wickeds and martin's parties, i thought i would give some time to
things i liked about them.  wicked persists.  martin persists.
when martin says a party will be at a particular place with particular
performers, it's there, with those performers better than 90% of the
time.  for those of you who prefer, there are guaranteed to be hundreds
of people (if not thousands) in attendance; not precisely my preference,
but noted.  the sound at all of martin's parties i have attended has
been massive (with one exception, which was an anomaly in many ways).
i've never been to a martin party that was busted.  one has almost
certainly heard all of the DJs before, and consequently knows the
kind and quality of music to expect (again, not entirely my preference,
but noted as desirable by many).
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 1994 16:18:38 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: Robert Ernest <robdude@cats.ucsc.edu>, ethan miller <nrg@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Blatant Self Promo
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I certainly don't think that Ethan has crossed any line that should
be frowned uopn.  He certainly didn't say anything with "excessive
use of adjectives" and such -- here is his post:

> Hello everybody! 
> Just thought I'd let ya know that I'm playing SPAZ tonite. Party's located 
> at 60, 6th street in SF. More info at: 415.995.2366. Usually costs $3 and 
> well worth it. 2 rooms, live and djd music...Bring 21+ ID (or *something* 
> +) to keep the cops happy. I play from 12-2 but from what I've heard the 
> rest of the evening sounds killer as well so come down early. Party starts 
> at 9:00. Hope to see ya all there!  
> take it easy 
> ethan > > >

Here are the adjectives he used:  6th, 2, live, djd, 21+, killer.

I've been away from diagramming sentences for about 15 years now,
so I'm sure I got some wrong, but my point is that the only "hype"
adjective Ethan used was "killer" and he only used it once so
that's hardly excessive.

How else are people supposed to get the word out about small parties
if they aren't allowed to post to sfraves?  Ethan's post struck 
me clearly as a combination of information and invitation, not as
some money-hungry advertising thing -- especially since I KNOW that
DJs at SPAZ don't get paid.

What is so wrong in telling the community about upcoming gigs?  When
it's done personally and in good spirit then what is the problem?
Should Ethan, myself, Martin, and everyone else maintain private
copies of the entire sfraves list so that when we want to get the
word out about things we can without posting it to sfraves? 

It's not like Ethan posted every day for a week "buy my tape" or
"come to SPAZ" -- he did it just once each.  He is a high-profile
member of the sfraves community and so a lot of people really ARE
interested that he has a tape and that he will be spinning at SPAZ.
If DJ Deaks or Tamotsu or anyone else were to get a gig someplace
I'd hope they'd post it to sfraves so we could find them if we
wanted -- for profit party or not.

Laura

Subject: RE: RAVE MOVEMENT?
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

<my mail reader seems uninterested in quoting, unfortunately, so I will try to
paraphrase>

I'm not saying that dancing doesn't put me in a positive mood, and a good
mind-set.  But I get this feeling from *all* kinds of dancing, be it to hip hop
or rave or gothic or industrial.  Maybe in general the music is happier in the
rave scene, but Just being happy isn't really a statement.  It's nice, but it
isn't a statment.

And I feel that there is just as much negativity in the rave scene as there is
in other scenes.  Gangster wannabes go to raves, and annoying jock-types go to
raves, and teeny-bopper girls go to raves.  IMHO there may be a greater amount
of people who are into unity and group happiness, but there are probably more
of the other kinds of people at most raves.  *However*, I am speaking of the
typical rave scene, and *not* the more spur of the moment, and underground
raves.  But these are so few and far between, that one can't generalize about
the whole rave scene and think of just these.

                Jesus Chrysler

From sfraves-owner  Sat Jul  9 16:44:55 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA25869; Sat, 9 Jul 94 16:44:55 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA25858; Sat, 9 Jul 94 16:44:45 PDT
Received: (mmetz@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.9/PHILMAIL-1.10) id QAA16820; Sat, 9 Jul 1994 16:45:33 -0700
From: Mark Metz / Future Forum <mmetz@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199407092345.QAA16820@soda.berkeley.edu>
Subject: EDITIORIAL IN CLUBLIFE
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 1994 16:45:31 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL5]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2033      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	A couple of days ago at Ameba we received several copies of Mark 
Healey's new magazine 'Clublife' which had one of the stranges editorials 
that I have ever read, it goes as follows:

		DON'T BLAME SPEED.....	
	
	Much is often heard around San Francisco about how speed has 
destroyed the house scene.  Sure, it's not difficult for most people to 
bring to mind friends and aquintences who've crashed their lives into a 
wall of tweak.  Certainly, amphetamine use has become more conspicious 
and widespread, but to blame the end of good vibes in the house and 
techno scene on a drug?  First of all it reeks of the crass 
oversimplification that characterizes the popular media's attitude 
towards drugs- an attitude that those who are a little more well informed 
rightly complain about, but in this case seem to unthinkingly 
perpetuate.  There's a popular myth in our culture that drugs- and not 
people- are responsible for 'drug problems'.  It's an easy answer that 
takes the focus of attention away from the causes that are more 
difficult to quantify because they involve looking at out own behaviour 
and changing it.

	Speed didn't destroy our scene, if anyone 'destroyed' it we did.  
Speed use just grew to fill a vacuum, presenting itself as the next step 
in the logical progression from ecstacy abuse.  Infact, ecstacy when 
taken in large doses (more than 150mg or so, ie two hits of street 
quality ecstacy), produces an effect 'paradoxial' to it's usual emphatic 
qualities, an effect almost identical to that of amphetamine/......

	/What further complicates matters is that there are some people 
who can take amphetamines and use them to a positive effect in their lives.
/........

	/Even speed isn't always bad- not if you're learning, not if 
you're being creative, not if you're moving forward.


If anyone would like a copy of this publication to read for themselves we 
have a ton of them at ameba for free.  I think that this has to be one of 
the most uninformed of editorials that I have ever read.

(510)549-6260.  As Tracy posted, the New Moon weekend continues tonight at
the Chateau (in Berkeley, call above # for directions)  The startup time 
has slipped back to ~10 PM, to give us sound-system haulers a chance to
recuperate a few hours.  Call the # though -- if we start sooner they've 
got a great clothing-optional pool to swim and dance in before it gets 
cold.  This should blend nicely into tomorrow's Sunset party at the 
Berkeley marina :)

to spin up at Pt. Reyes and are planning to come to the Chateau) --

From: Gregory Harrison <73133.2775@compuserve.com>
To: SFRAVES <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: CYBERIA: The Book
Message-Id: <940710061142_73133.2775_FHF23-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I'm new to this list, so I'm not sure if anyone's talked of it yet, but did
anyone read a book called CYBERIA?  It has many mentions of S.F. and things
going on in the rave scene there.  

Cap'n Crunch, Jeno, Toon Town, Rose X... these are a few names in the book that
I recognized from discussions on SFRAVES.  I think the book attempted to be a
nonpartisan look into cyberculture and rave, but often I felt that it was a bit
limited in its scope, at least in its treatment of the rave scene.  I'm not
really familiar with rave in S.F. (i'm from L.A.) but I'd be interested in what
those from S.F. that have read it think.  

---greg h

We record DJ's live at raves.  Greg does the recording and I do cover art for
tapes which we distribute for free to people local and long distance.  There
are strict karmic guidelines that we follow to keep
everyone happy (DJ's, promoters, $$$).  This is a non-profit thing that we
do.  We're not really ready to go mainstream, we do this for fun.  We get off
on sharing the music of our scene with people who might otherwise might not
get a taste.  We do offer taping services with negotiable terms (free).  

Peace,

Greg and Cindy
House Archives

Wicked was Jeno,Garth,Pierre, and Markie. Pierre managed to play hard 
acid which was still "funky groovy" underneath the acid bleeps. It was 
Townsend on a Saturday Night which is always clubby yet fabulous. Wierdo 
ravers and drag queens, donovan visuals, smart bar, li'l chill space, 
line outside crowded dance floor, markie physically restrained security
from cutting of his record ....AND they turned it off with a scrAATch at
9:00am or so.  Courtney did more than anyone luv phaser set at broad sweep.
Geoff white between markie and security..you've seen it before...and it 
is still wonderful.

Had a great time!salutations, allen@ameba


From owner-sfraves Sun Jul 10 18:34:59 1994
Return-Path: <owner-sfraves>
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qNAGo-0003VNa; Sun, 10 Jul 94 18:34 WET DST
Sender: owner-sfraves
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com with smtp
	(Smail3.1.28.1 #12) id m0qNAGj-0003V2C; Sun, 10 Jul 94 18:34 WET DST
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id SAA29074; Sun, 10 Jul 1994 18:35:12 -0700
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 1994 18:35:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: "JMRTNKO, the real Sulu!" <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: wicked?
To: ezzevvravess <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9407101626.A15060-0100000@netcom2>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


First of all, i'd like to thank Bryce and Ethan and Laura and all for the 
Liquid Drano party. It was another arm-twist in my campaign to get my 
friend Hank (visiting from sh'kago) to move out here. He had a really 
good time for the week he was here. danke!

I personally would have rather gone to FreeFall, but the group we were 
with wanted to hit Wicked, so...We ended up getting there around 11:40 
hoping to get in before the price went up at midnight. I didn't really 
expect to succeed, but it sure seemed like the doorfolk were out to make 
sure it didn't happen. Carmen's backpack was dug, and I mean *dug* 
through for a full ten minutes while we had to wait on for her on the 
side. We rarely, if ever, have anything to hide, and if we did we 
wouldn't be so stupid as to put it in a backpack. They kindly 'offered' 
to hold her water bottle on the side so we could come up front and get it 
later, but of course it was gone. No big loss, but the manaical search 
through *every* container and pocket in her bag left her shaken for the 
next half-hour. That, and the passing of midnight in the middle of all 
this really pissed me off. Of course the misdirected search tactics 
completely missed one of the folks behind us who was certainly packing 
some...er...contraband. 

I can see it now: The Water-Bottle Riots of '94! Emotional crowd of 
brightly dressed San Franciscans storms doorpeople at club armed only 
with empty water-bottles and random pieces of fruit. Prisoners are 
dropped in front of a Coke machine in the middle of the desert with only 
a handful of bent Canadian coins and a well-worn and ripped one dollar bill.

Once inside, wicked was...well...the Townsend. Seemed just about the same 
as when we went for the CareFree/Wired deal two weeks earlier (note: CF 
charged $10 and allowed ins and outs, hint). The sound was louder, but 
certainly not better. Actually, let me rephrase that...THESE MOUNDS BUST 
POWDER, BUT SIR TINGLY NOT VETTE HAIR...WHAT?...FREEZE...HOUND...WAS... 
CHOWDER...WHAT?

THOUGH IT WAS NEVER <click> really totally enclosed, I do miss the little 
upstairs chill area they used to have there. Why is it closed off now?

For future reference, I suppose you can save this article and re-post it 
after each wicked (little 'w') that goes on at Townsend. After all, I 
really can't think of much that has changed since they started doing the 
big-club circuit. 

Maybe this is just more a reaction to the Townsend than wicked, but I 
fail to see how a party that gets rewound and replayed every other week 
or so is supposed to get anyone excited. I try not to have the 'been 
there - seen it - done it' attitude, but frankly three summers of this 
here and five more back in Detroit is about all I can take. When I first 
got here, I was taken by the creativity (or maybe the novelty) that 
Detroit had lost, but at the large-party scale it seemed to end with 1992.
One slide projected mandala or intellibeam or wailing diva thumper or 
brain blast drink or whatever seems pretty much like the other. I will at 
least credit the Basics/ComeUnity/Gathering/LFR hydra and wicked with 
being among the best purveyors of this model, but at least for me it's 
just become too formulaic.

One thing I've been wondering is why we need these frequent massives in 
the first place? Because we have to 'unite the world?' Hell, I have 
enough trouble keeping track of names, numbers and birthdays already much 
less actually keeping up friendships. I admit, i love seeing a couple 
thousand people together every once in a while, but in my experience and 
from reading many of the reviews posted here, the highlight of most 
evenings is when the crowd thins out to just a couple hundred and less. I 
rarely (if ever) see a massive with nearly everyone dancing or somehow 
interacting with the crowd as a whole. I have seen several smaller parties 
that have achieved this.

Oh, I don't know where this is going. I guess the massives do provide the 
function of spreading the 'rave' message further than the smaller and 
renegade parties do, but take a look at the message that is being sent. 
For $19.95, anyone can buy their way into a well-known, frequent, easily 
accessible party of consistent quality where you will be entertained in a 
consistent fashion for the regular amount of time until you tire of it. 
And all this for no more effort than sliding the twenty dollar bill over 
than counter. This method also sells a lot of laundry detergent, but I 
certainly wouldn't consider Tide (no matter how white my socks get) to be 
anything new, creative or revolutionary.

Eh, I'll shut up now. My week-long e-mail jones has been fed. john.

Precedence: bulk

jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com writes:

 > And I feel that there is just as much negativity in the rave scene
 > as there is in other scenes.  Gangster wannabes go to raves, and
 > annoying jock-types go to raves, and teeny-bopper girls go to
 > raves.  IMHO there may be a greater amount of people who are into
 > unity and group happiness, but there are probably more of the other
 > kinds of people at most raves.

I think it would be more fair to just say "people who bring negativity
to the scene" rather than listing stereotypes. I know plenty of people
who are in these groups who aren't negative at all. Take our own Bob
Ramstad, who is a "frat boy", and who has donated an enormous amount
of time, labor, and positive energy to the scene. Or how about Devin
and Stacy, both "teeny-boppers", whom I met this weekend at the NMR.
They were so nice that people were remarking how much they liked them
long after they left.

I'm not so much into PCness as seeing that people like this don't feel
unwanted. And if they read posts stereotyping them in a negative way,
they're going to feel unwanted and unappreciated. Wouldn't that be
awful?

Sean
