>From Mark Healey's "Clublife" magazine...

>Speed didn't destroy our scene, if anyone 'destroyed' it we did.
>Speed use just grew to fill a vacuum, presenting itself as the next
>step in the logical progression from ecstacy abuse.  Infact, ecstacy
>when taken in large doses (more than 150mg or so, ie two hits of
>street quality ecstacy), produces an effect 'paradoxial' to it's
>usual emphatic qualities, an effect almost identical to that of
>amphetamine/......

You know, I've never heard of anyone abusing MDMA in SanFran, not
once, even secondhand. I have personally seen people abuse themselves
with methylamphetamine and pot, and know of more than one person who
has abused heroin.

But E? Not that I know of. And I've seen plenty of it.

Sean

PS - I define "abusing oneself" to be when the net effect in someone's
life is substantially negative. Substantially meaning things like: you
blow off things in your life which pile up. You get depressed. You
spend all your money on drugs. You screw up a good relationship. Etc.

On Mon, 11 Jul 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
> >From Mark Healey's "Clublife" magazine...
> 
> >Speed didn't destroy our scene, if anyone 'destroyed' it we did.
> >Speed use just grew to fill a vacuum, presenting itself as the next
> >step in the logical progression from ecstacy abuse.  Infact, ecstacy
> >when taken in large doses (more than 150mg or so, ie two hits of
> >street quality ecstacy), produces an effect 'paradoxial' to it's
> >usual emphatic qualities, an effect almost identical to that of
> >amphetamine/......
> 
> You know, I've never heard of anyone abusing MDMA in SanFran, not
> once, even secondhand. I have personally seen people abuse themselves
> with methylamphetamine and pot, and know of more than one person who
> has abused heroin.

I've seen people take too much E - defining "too much" as often enough
to not get nearly as much benefit each time as if they spaced it out
more, and also to the point where they couldn't enjoy themselves unless
they were altered.  That's abuse, in my mind.  

> But E? Not that I know of. And I've seen plenty of it.
> 
> Sean
> 
> PS - I define "abusing oneself" to be when the net effect in someone's
> life is substantially negative. Substantially meaning things like: you
> blow off things in your life which pile up. You get depressed. You
> spend all your money on drugs. You screw up a good relationship. Etc.

Yup, that pretty much described them.  This is very rare, though, I
should point out, as most people when they start going down that path
do get negative feedback, like the opposite of cocaine.  But to say
it never happens isn't strictly true.

But compared to cocaine, cigarrette, alcohol, or even chocolate, E's
pretty benign.


	Brian

> pretty benign.
> 
i have to disagree here...but only in the matter of degree.  the FOAF i
mentioned in a prior post was left with no job, was homeless, had no
money, and was left with one friend who would help them.  it took this
person over a year to pull themselves out of the hole.  i remember 
conversations with this person where they would be hiding themselves in
a basement they were so paranoid about being "overheard" by roommates.
it's true they didn't have their nasal passages destroyed, nor die of
lung cancer, nor kill anyone driving while intoxicated...a few people
intervened ~before~ it got to that point.  let's make sure that no one
finds out what the long term effects of abuse are.

I went to the NMR this weekend. It was very nice!

Admission: free (1 1/2 hour drive, 1/2 mile walk up beach)
Water: free
Fruit, bread, OJ: free
Visuals: Pt. Reyes; once moved, just black lights
Vibe: very positive and friendly
Music: outstanding start to finish
Ins & Outs: yes
Searches: no
Lines: no
Clean Air: yes
Chill space: plenty
Toys/altar: yes, yes
Rude people/security: none
Sound system: very nice!
Tinnitus: no

you!

From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@techno
In-Reply-To: <9407110449.AA13424@pilot.njin.net>; from "Sean Casey" at Jul 11, 94 12:49 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-Id:  <9407102218.aa17888@cruzio.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

While MDMA has less potential for abuse and "destroying
people's lives" than methamphetamines do, such potential
*is* realized and I have on several occasions encountered
it in friends and acquaintances over the years.  To really
consider this subject seriously, look into Bruce Eisner's
text on Ecstasy, it's the standard in the field, either the
first or sefdond edition (Saunders' book is interesting, but
it tends to be rambly and long on interesting narratives
rether than based on as much useful info).

To cite just two areas:  people who, liking the E experience,
attempt to "stay there" by continuing to take E regularly 
have burned themselves out physically and psychologically,
needing extended periods for recuperation.  The most intense
E trippers I know have had to take extended times for re-
integrating themselves in their relationships, day-to-day 
lives, healtthy routines, etc., and for a few that I have
know over a 15 year period their E use *may* have been a 
factor in their suicide.  For others who have not integrated
the E experience it remains something that they do not bring
into their everyday life so there is more spiritual and/or
emotional disharmony in their interactions with others; these
are the folks that are groovy on E and more edgy, nervy or
even less capable of intimacy than they were before when they're
not on E.

Again, my experience over a 15 year period has been much like thos
in Adamson's (Metzner's) Gateway to the Heart book about MDMA:
that for the vast majority of E-takers it was a path, trail,
or autobahn lane to heart chakra interconnects--and I remAIN CON-
vinced that that is what it is for most ecstasy seekers.

Tahnk you, Mark and Sean, for opening up this important thread,
because I know that communication about our sacred and party
substances is important in the context of use and abuse of them
as tools of consciousness!

Ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com

Precedence: bulk

Hi Brian and others--

Well, I said my bit about E in the post I just
sent to sfr, and while I agree with most of whAT
I've seen (including your sage comments Brian B.),
I must take issue with:

>But compared to cocaine, cigarrette, alcohol, or even chocolate, E's
pretty benign.

As an Italian American who has had alcohol (wine) all
of my life since birth and a kid growing up with cocoa
products, even the universe of statistics does not tell
me that these substances are more harmful if a similar-
ly large population were exposed to E.  I think that
comparisons are frequently judgments that we have no
need or ability to raise.  Let me give a real virulent
example: heroin-using former students of mine have frequently
used the old "you have your drug, I have mine" approach
when conversing about their addiction.  That's, as Uncle
Bill Burroughs puts it (I guess I think of him as the 
consummate authority in this realm) junk talk pure and 
simple!  Comparisons and judgments too often lead us into
circular arguments, finger-pointing and enabling rather
than empowering. So : )  !!!

Ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Discover the difference between doing and being and become!
ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins  HarperSanFrancisco

We need to make this the jump-off point for finding a TAZ, I guess. I 
repeatedly hear of folks being interested in doing this sort of thing on 
a weekly basis, and then they just seem to go away (YSH sez "Grrrrr...!!)

Does anyone else have folks mention that they would like to be involved 
in having parties, only to sort of drift away and out of touch?  

I think that when someone exhibits interest in having their space be a 
possible happening-place, we ought to double-team them in a really nice 
way. A couple of us could call them and go visit, and then maybe a couple 
of other folks, etc.-- maybe we could keep them interested long enough 
to overcome initial doubts. Also, that way no one need spend all their 
time courting a potential ally, with no help from the rest of us.

Does this sound helpful, or is it just one more been-there done-that?

Thanx

Maui :)

  I wasn't actually planning to go raving this weekend, but when I saw 
someone post for "Remembrance" in Santa Cruz, I just had to go.  So I 
gathered up some friends and we made the hour drive to Davenport around 
11pm.  When we got to the site, Greyhound Rock, there were a TON of 
cars... Unfortunatley, there was no music! It was just in the process of 
being busted :(  I was realy disapointed since I wanted to hear Spun, 
Wool and Harry Who spin.  

  As if the party getting busted was bad enough...  They NEVER updated 
the info line giving a new location or appologies for the bust.  I can 
understand when the promoters can't get to a phone, but come on, it's 
simply rude not to change the message.

  So we drove around the Santa Cruz mountains till about 3am when we 
saw a decent amount of cars at Bonny Doon.  There were about 80 people 
there, drinking beer, and hardly any of them were dancing.  The people 
were friendly, but the vibe was non-existant.  Plus, the music was all 
about a year old and the DJ couldn't match beats at ALL! 

  I have respect for the DJ because it was his sound system and he 
organized everything and as far as I know was the only DJ for the whole 
night.  So basicaly he was just throwing a party to do some 
self-promotion and get some practice spinning live.  Which is fine, but 
it would be nice to get some GOOD DJ's to go on afterwards.

  Anyways... I expected more because the last time I went to an outdoor 
party in SC it was AWESOME!  But this time things didnt work out, and now 
I'm getting sick to top things off...  ::sigh::

  On a positive note: I hope you all come out to the next Liquid Air 
party this Saturday...  As far as I know, its still happening, so bring 
your friends, your smiles, your warm clothes and some telescopes so we 
can all check out the comet colliding with Jupiter!! ;)

Peace out...

-Ernie

Hi Folx--

I'm sorry that Ernie who came down for Remembrance
unfortunately did not stay connected to the folx
when Remembrance reconvened after being busted by
the CHP at Greyhound Rock. We stayed and found the
*real* party again!

It was a truly awesome (if somewhat dusty) small
party with the best djing I've *ever* heard Wool
do (especially the work before the generator needed   
regeneration)! The combined energy of those who were
there from the San Jose and the Santa Cruz families
made for a powerful dance vibe for us kicking up 
the dust (somewhat like the arena at Golden Gate
Park).  Imagine  a sacred glen near an abandoned barn 
and farmhouse of the turn of the century, the trees
holding back the wisps of fog, the hills on the 
inland side of highway one echoing the rhythms,
Santa Cruz and San Jose (and a few City folk) homies
dancing together, communing on blankets around small
lamplights, gathering and munching blackberries between
sets in the early a.m. light and you have this picture.

As summer progresses, let's have more of these parties 
at such sites; our ancestors knew many of them, we're just
re-discovering them!

Peace and love,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Discover the difference between doing and being and become!
ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins  HarperSanFrancisco

On Mon, 11 Jul 1994, Sean Casey wrote:

> I went to the NMR this weekend. It was very nice!

Yeah, I figured it would be. We went to the one up there a few months ago 
and it was very nice. Carmen and Hank and I were up in Marin that night, 
but Carmen had to be awake and functioning the next morning in Santa 
Cruz. We had to pass on it this month. See you there next time though.

> Tinnitus: no

eh?

Don't think my previous criticism included these smaller events. It's not 
really directed at the big events either. The target was the formula that 
has evolved and has been choking the life out of many events here and 
that seems to go completely counter to the lip service of 'change and 
growth.' I also want to keep the scene alive, but not if it means 
a future of unending, expensive and degrading life-support.

Thankfully, other events and people have been appearing to provide 
something other than the meat-and-potatoes. But I hope that they too will 
be aware of the trap of stagnation. A new formula is just as bad as the 
old one. 

I guess as Markie said, I could do it myself, and back in Detroit, I 
already have. While I have great stories and memories from each event, 
being a promoter isn't really my calling, so to speak. It's hard 
work and I tip my hat to anyone who tries to do it, but I need my energy 
and time for other things. If I can someday find a way to tie my outlet 
into these smaller events, I will, but for now I have to remain just an 
attendee. sigh.

jmar.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Tinnitus and being shredded
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407102315.A27231-0100000@netcom2>
References: <9407110517.AA13918@pilot.njin.net>
	<Pine.3.89.9407102315.A27231-0100000@netcom2>

Precedence: bulk

"JMRTNKO, the real Chekov!" writes:
 > > I went to the NMR this weekend. It was very nice!

 > > Tinnitus: no

> eh?

Tinnitus is what happens when the sound is WAY TOO LOUD and you don't
a handy pair of 24+ db reduction earplugs to make everything sound
nice and muffled. The next day or three one's ears ring. It is a sign
of hearing damage.

Try this test: Don't go to an event for three weeks. Find an ultra
quiet environment and listen. Do your ears ring? Permanent hearing
damage.

What a lot of promoters haven't figured out is: louder isn't better.
Louder sounds like shit, reverberates too much indoors, and causes the
smarter participants to wear earplugs, which means it sounds even
shittier.

What I'd like to see them do at big events is:

      Raise the high speakers above the crowd (and point them down) so
      that speaker-worshipers don't block the sound. Treble beams out
      narrowly; it won't go around someone standing in front of a bin.
      (Try it.) All that money you spent on the mid-high bins is
      actually spent on the few people standing in front of the
      speakers.

      Remove at least 1/2 of the sound system. SHREDDER 60,000 WATTS.
      You walk in and it sounds like you're standing between two train
      locomotives at full throttle. The pattern recognition in your
      brain goes into overdrive trying to find a beat in the clipped
      off waveforms and the multiple bass echoes and fails. You've
      been mugg^H^H^H^Hshredded.

      Use a limiter and set it so that the amps don't clip and the
      volume is below earplug level.

The first one is a little hard. You gotta stack the bass bins and
stack a mid-high on top. Might even need a sandbag or something to aim
it down.

The second will probably save anywhere from $500 to $2000.

A good stereo compressor/limiter is about $500.

And the whole thing would sound better. You'd be getting reviews like:
"It sounded really good!" and "I met God." And you could smile about
it later knowing no one's hearing was damaged. :)

Sean

From owner-sfraves Mon Jul 11 02:30:44 1994
Return-Path: <owner-sfraves>
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qNHhE-0003Wla; Mon, 11 Jul 94 02:30 WET DST
Sender: owner-sfraves
Received: from netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com with smtp
	(Smail3.1.28.1 #12) id m0qNHh9-0003WcC; Mon, 11 Jul 94 02:30 WET DST
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id CAA25640; Mon, 11 Jul 1994 02:31:11 -0700
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 02:31:11 -0700
Message-Id: <199407110931.CAA25640@netcom12.netcom.com>
X-Sender: ambient@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: Re: EDITIORIAL IN CLUBLIFE
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>        Speed didn't destroy our scene, if anyone 'destroyed' it we did.
>Speed use just grew to fill a vacuum, presenting itself as the next step
>in the logical progression from ecstacy abuse.  Infact, ecstacy when
>taken in large doses (more than 150mg or so, ie two hits of street
>quality ecstacy), produces an effect 'paradoxial' to it's usual emphatic
>qualities, an effect almost identical to that of amphetamine/......
>

This is a bit of an overstatement. I'd say "street quality" E, if indeed
MDMA, is more around 100mg. He seems to be arguing that doing a couple of
E's is the same as doing speed, and that people started doing it for that
reason. First of all, while high doses do increase amphetamine-like side
effects (teeth grinding, etc.), they don't obviate the entactogenic effect;
and I think 150mg is a bit to low of a dose to cause serious amphetamine
like side effects. Secondly, who would waste $40 or more on E if they
really wanted speed, which is much cheaper and more widely available?

I have seen E abuse, but what I've seen is a different pattern than
amphetamine abuse. I've rarely seen anyone doing it as frequently and with
increasing dosage as I've seen people do with speed. Rather, I see people
start relying on it to free them from insecurities and to make them more
open. Instead of using the experience as an example of how change sober
behavior it becomes a crutch. I've even known people in relationships where
"when we're on E I love her, but when we're not I can't stand her."

What I find rather scary is the use I've seen around some colleges - it
almost seems like it sometimes replaces alcohol as a "pick-up" drug.

My opinion is that an increase in speed use ocurred (among other factors)
because of a lack of quality E, its relative low cost, and a tendancy among
users to look for peer support by getting their friends to do it as well.

As far as effects on the scene, speed is a big ego-inflating I-me drug,
where as much of what is good about this scene is the we-us atmosphere...

>        /What further complicates matters is that there are some people
>who can take amphetamines and use them to a positive effect in their lives.

Or can achieve positive effects in their lives despite speed use.

>        /Even speed isn't always bad- not if you're learning, not if
>you're being creative, not if you're moving forward.

No, it doesn't necessarily turn people into paranoid, aggressive,
spaced-out tweakers, but I've seen personalities change in that direction
quite a bit more than I've seen anyone giving it credit for making their
lives better.

Joe


----------(Joe Rice)-------------------------( welcome to the church )---------
-----(ambient@netcom.com)--------------------(of what's happening now)---------

	id CAA02327; Mon, 11 Jul 1994 02:39:15 -0700

Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 02:39:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: A drive thru rave...
To: SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@techno>, centauri@cats.ucsc.edu
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407110218.A6879-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it was a thriller, folks.  people standing on the side of the road, 
biting their fingernails, literally glued to their watches.  would the 
party be able to go off before the sun came up?  it was a race against 
time.  suddenly, the music started.  then stopped.  then started.  then 
stopped.  then stopped, oops, i mean started again.  ?

the music it was fun.  the first dj spun a fun set.  but where was spun?  
i looked all over the place for him.  i looked in the old abandoned house 
for him.  i asked all over the place for him.  i began to get a complex 
about myself.  did he have prior engagements, or was he simply not at the 
party to avoid my presence?  

it all worked out in the end, though.  everyone parked their cars in the 
eucalyptus trees and danced.  someone told me wool was spinning.  

anyway, all in all, i had fun.  when i left, i drove through the crowd to 
get back on the freeway, since that was the only way i could go.  it was 
embarrassing, since i felt like i was a party pooper, but it did help 
make my experience at remembrance into a plural and process-oriented noun!


From owner-sfraves Mon Jul 11 05:09:34 1994
Return-Path: <owner-sfraves>

	id m0qNKAw-0003V2a; Mon, 11 Jul 94 05:09 WET DST

Received: from techno by taz.hyperreal.com with smtp
	(Smail3.1.28.1 #12) id m0qNKAr-0003UzC; Mon, 11 Jul 94 05:09 WET DST
Received: from netcom.com (netcom3.netcom.com) by techno (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19463; Mon, 11 Jul 94 05:01:54 PDT
Received: by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id FAA26156; Mon, 11 Jul 1994 05:03:07 -0700
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 05:03:07 -0700
From: resonate@netcom.com (resonate)
Message-Id: <199407111203.FAA26156@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno
Subject: hearing
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	The only events I have been to where the sound was not damaging
	have been SFRave events. I find that almost 100% of all concerts
	and rave type events I have ever been to have poorly run overly loud
	sound. The sound "engineers" at these shows are probably long gone
	for concert deafness and couldn't effectively set up and run
	sound anyways.

	If you *always* wear 24db+ earplugs then you will find that your
	mind adjusts to this level of volume reduction and that the sound
	is *great*. Its just like your eyes adjusting to dim light in a room.
	You will be able to pick out the components of the sound and enjoy
	it much more if you have earplugs on.

	For those of you who *never* wear earplugs- it will take you several
	sessions to get used to the reduced level and have your mind adjust
	but it is worth it.

	Anyone who doesn't wear earplugs at events *does* have hearing
	damage and it *will* get worse throughout your life. If you get
	tinnitus (ringing) you will be in tremendous agony and it is
	*incurable*.

	Wear earplugs.

From owner-sfraves Mon Jul 11 08:55:02 1994
Return-Path: <owner-sfraves>
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qNNh8-0003X5a; Mon, 11 Jul 94 08:55 WET DST

hey g n c,

what did you think of wicked, assuming you showed up. i was very

trying to convince my friends to go to the new moon thing in 
berkeley, which i had read about and morgan said he was going
to hit when i saw him there. i actually came home at about
4:oo and listened to a simon tape i have...that was good music.
i think garth has lost it or something. and the crowd...seemed like
a bunch of raver wannabe's. very strange. i am curious to know
what you guys thought/did. looked for you for a while, then figured
you weren't there.

am seeing this as a sign that it is time to give the scene a good
long break. if you are online and see any discussion of the event,
please forward it to me. it seemed like i saw quite a few other folks
like me wondering "what the hell is going on here...this isn't wicked
in any way". 

carter

>
>	The only events I have been to where the sound was not damaging
>	have been SFRave events.

        It usually hasn't been a problem for me at outdoor events, I just
        don't get that close to the speakers.  Indoors, I use earplugs.

>       I find that almost 100% of all concerts and rave type events I
>       have ever been to have poorly run overly loud sound.

        The larger outdoor concerts rarely get that loud, the neighboring
        communities won't let them  (Shoreline, for example).

>	If you *always* wear 24db+ earplugs then you will find that your
>	mind adjusts to this level of volume reduction and that the sound
>	is *great*.

        Where do you get earplugs that block sound evenly over the frequency
        range?  All the ones I know of block lows a little, midrange a bit
        more, and highs totally.  If all you listen for is the booming beat,
        you won't miss anything with earplugs, especially since you really
        feel that more than hear it, but if you actually want to hear the
        highs, you need to find a place where the music isn't so loud that
        you need them.
                         &andy
                         KC1IP/6
                         the tie-dyed side of the force

> 	Anyone who doesn't wear earplugs at events *does* have hearing
> 	damage and it *will* get worse throughout your life. If you get
> 	tinnitus (ringing) you will be in tremendous agony and it is
> 	*incurable*.

I have it.  It sucks.  Don't get it.  Please.

...and I've been wearing earplugs since I was about 19.

Besides, earplugs don't cut out the body-shaking BOOM BOOM BOOM of the bass,
just that ear-roasting sizzle of overdriven mixers or 808 hi-hats treble-
boosted by producers who can't hear either because their ears are roasted too.

// g

PS: Even worse than raves are rock/punk/guitar shows -- guitar distortion
is in the perfect range to munch your cochlea triple-quick.  If you're
*lucky* you'll just end up half-deaf, unable to hear any treble at all
so you can't make out consonants when people talk.

PPS: There is absoultely no known cure.  Read this again -- THERE IS 
ABSOLUTELY NO KNOWN CURE.  Stays with you to the grave, and gets worse
as you age.  I got wise before it got too bad, but there is no such thing
as silence for me anymore.

Subject: Prevention of Hearing Loss
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

to amplify the recent warnings from others:  yes, the sound is loud enough at  
most events to cause permanent hearing loss from just being there.  speaker  
tweekers are at much greater risk.  protection is a MUST.

in addition to handing out blow pops and fruit, how about handing out earplugs,  
especially at those events where the sound is certainly above the damage  
threshhold?

some notes:

- one source of inexpensive, disposable earplugs is Lab Safety Supply, 800  
356-0783.  most brands are fifteen to twenty cents per pair in quantity of 200  
pair.  my favorite type (so far) is "Flents Quiet! please Foam Earplugs".  Lab  
Safety also sells a little "Foam Earplug Sampler" kit for $8.00.

- yes, foam earplugs are pretty nonlinear in their attenuation.  i find that if  
i insert them only a little way into the ear canal (maybe 1/3 to 1/2 of the  
intended depth) the attenuation is still sufficient for rave use and it is more  
linear (the highs are not so terribly muted).  before use the plugs can be  
trimmed down in length a bit with a serrated knife so they don't stick out so  
far.

- psychedelics can be analgesic.  a speaker tweeker who ordinarly would feel  
pain might not feel discomfort at all while dosed.  



following is some text from the MDMA Frequently Asked Questions document.  it  
could well be extended to include hearing loss at concerts or raves as a result  
of 1) not feeling pain and 2) not remembering or caring about the possibility  
of hearing loss.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Behavioral Safety Concerns
--------------------------
     As noted, a primary psychological effect of MDMA is to make the user feel  
"safe", at peace with the world, pleasantly reconciled to things as they are,  
and things however they will be.  This can remarkably diminish one's ability to  
make sound judgements during the session.   Examples:

- It becomes easy to want to prolong the MDMA state by taking more and more of  
the drug (or of other drugs), beyond what you would judge wise or worthwhile  
when not under its influence.

- It becomes easier to have unsafe sex.  You may "forget," judge that the risk  
of infection is very small, or feel that infection wouldn't be such a terrible  
thing after all.  If you think you might have sex while on MDMA, it may help  
you and your partner to stay safe if you lay out safer sex supplies before  
dosing in a place you'll be sure to see them later, and agree beforehand that  
you'll use them if the occasion arises.

     Another danger stems from MDMA's lessening of the awareness of pain  
(whether through chemical analgesia, or through psychological analgesia).   
Combined with the extra energy the drug gives, it becomes easy to sustain  
bruises, blisters, or other bodily damage from extensive dancing, hiking,  
climbing, etc., without noticing it until after the damage is done.

     Under MDMA, it may seem "right" to make immediate changes in relationships  
(increasing or decreasing commitment) of all kinds.  The fresh points of view  
appreciated during an MDMA session are one of the drug's most prized benefits,  
but it is probably unwise to actually make lasting relationship changes until  
you have a chance to see how you would feel about them after the drug and its  
afterglow wear off.  - rnj

thing is, I can still hear the 14kHz+ whine of some CRTs. Oh well :).

causes the insides of your ears to tickle/hurt) . God knows what she
was feeling. I was too freaked to do anything about it.

From: Bryce Ryan <brycer@crl.com>

Subject: Re: hearing
To: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 17:32:35 -0700 (PDT)

In-Reply-To: <9407112344.AA17510@pilot.njin.net> from "Sean Casey" at Jul 11, 94 07:44:20 pm

Precedence: bulk

I can't tell you all enough how happy i am that this discussion is 
taking place.  As a sound person, the single most frequent comment 
and request i receive when working with the equipment is: "Can you
make it any louder?"  It's really quite a difficult issue for me, in
a way, because i want to give people what they want.  However, i like
my hearing, and am exposed to much higher SPLs for longer periods of
time than almost anyone else in the rave "scene", so i almost always
answer "NO".

i have seen many a DJ who turns everything up to distortion levels
(and beyond), and still wants it turned up, up, up, and up, because
they are (whether they know it or not) deaf.  i have warned folks
here before about permanent hearing loss.  What most folks don't
realize is that most of damaging sound energy comes from the mids and
the highs...having a flat frequency response curve on the sound
system produces deafening levels in the mids and especially the highs.
This is because the smaller the speaker, the more efficient they are
(the magnets move smaller distances, and are smaller, so the same
amount of electrical energy produces higher SPLs at higher frequencies).
If sound people put most of the system's energy into the bass bins,
and EQ'd their systems properly (and listened to them), there'd be
far less problems with "too much sound".  it's also a square law kind
of thing...twice the energy can produce 4 times the SPL.

it is precisely this problem of improperly tuned and monitored systems
that causes most of my problems when listening to the so-called wailing
diva school of house music.  an improperly tuned system reinforces the
mids and highs far too much.  since the sound of the human voice, 
especially alto and soprano voices falls mostly in the 1KHz-5KHz range,
when these are reinforced by an improperly tuned sound system, the
"diva's" voice reaches 6-12dB over the rest of the system, which goes
from being a sound on the edge of painfully loud to well beyond that
level...and my ears feel it.  i *like* hearing the human voice on
sound systems, but if every time it's played on a big system, my ears
lose a little more hearing, and hurt me, i develop an aversion reaction
to the sound.

as a representative of both Sound Vision and Metro Vision, i'd like to
take this opportunity to tell you all that if you're at an event where
we are doing the sound (ethan or i), and the sound is too loud for you,
or in some way unpleasant, *please* let us know immediately, and we'll
take care of it.  we love our hearing, and we love yours.  we'd like
to be offering sound services for a long time, and we'd like to preserve
ours and your hearing.  we take this stuff very seriously.  also, if you
do events, and want advice or counsel on proper setup and tuning of the
system you are using, please feel free to contact us...we want to make
sure the community at large retains the ears by which we hear each other's
unique voices.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

From: resonate@netcom.com (resonate)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: shower w/ raincoat on
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Okay a number of common things have been said about earplugs:

	1) Wearing earplugs doesn't sound good. The sound is muffled and
	   and I just don't get that *loud* feeling.

	The mind and ear are a trainable duo. If you *always* wear earplugs
	and you *pay attention* to the music you listen to then your senses
	will adjust to the shift in EQ and *compensate* and it will sound
	just fine. The only exception to this rule is if you are so deaf
	already that all of the relevant damagable frequency reception 
	in your ears is gone- then earplugs will do nothing for you unless
	you are at an event with damaging sound in different frequencies-
	like a missile launch or an SRL show or an atomic blast.

	2) I like to take off my earplugs once in a while because I want
	   that *loud* sensation.

	See #1. If you take them off then you lose the tuning your brain
	has been working on to adjust to the EQ.

	3) Which frequences to earplugs really knock out? How many dbspl
	   do they remove?

	dbspl = decibels sound pressure level. I prefer the generic
	flourescent green thrify earplugs. These are made by the Super301
	company in the South Bay. They take down *30dbspl* of sound. There
	is no concert you can attend that has sound loud enough to damage
	your hearing if you have 30db earplugs in. 

	They knock out mostly high and mid frequences. The bass shines
	through and of course you body feels it. Again your mind WILL
	compensate for the EQ shift if you *listen*. IF YOU *LISTEN*!!!!!

	4) I'm a DJ and I can't mix with earplugs in.

	If you truly consider yourself an artist you will make sure you
	have the right tool for the job: good ears. Learn do deal with 
	earplugs. Don't be a Pete Townshend and suffer for 50% of your
	life in great pain every time you hear music. 

	If any of you have any questions that need more exact frequency
	measurements- I can provide them.

	Oh and you can substitute the word "condom" for "earplug" and
	reread the whole schpiel and its still valid.

	-resonate, weird blinking lights, voltage control records, the blue^3



From brian  Mon Jul 11 18:06:10 1994

Subject: Custom and normal earplug experiences
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 18:06:00 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9407111702.W29800-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com> from "Brian Behlendorf" at Jul 11, 94 05:03:15 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2197      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> I have tried earplugs, but the non-linearity of them makes it sound like
> someone turned off the main speakers, leaving just the subs on.

You get used to it after about two events, in my experience.  I play drums
and all amplified musical instruments with them in, and don't like the
sound without them now.

> A friend I once knew (who was a musician) had custom, form-fitted
> earplugs made.  Does anyone know if these provide more linear noise
> reduction? 

There are many kinds of custom earplugs.  The ones I had were designed to
block as much noise as possible and damn the linearity.  They did about
35 dB, I think.

One model I recall was nearly linear but only provided about 10 dB of
reduction.  For speaker-tweeking, this will not be enough.  For most
other situations, if you don't already have ear damage, it might be, but
I wouldn't risk it.

Keep in mind that no earplug can block bass: the sound waves are simply
too long, and much of the perception is physical anyway.  The more
protection you get, the more bassy the sound gets.

> (custom earplugs cost 100.00, a small price to pay for hearing, I guess)

Custom earplugs don't block much more noise much better than store-bought
ones.  The best kind are the standard E.A.R. yellow or beige foam ones,
which will knock off 30 dB if used properly.  There exists a brand of blaze-
orange foam ones with the advantage of having a slick and non-icky surface
but I don't remember the brand name and they're more expensive.  E.A.R. were
about 29c a pair at the Payless last I checked.

Of course, the custom fit more nicely and don't itch after prolonged use.

Handy Hint:  If you forget earplugs, go to the bathroom and get either
two squares of micro-thin institutional TP or one square of normal TP.
Fold it over itself until you get about a 2/3 inch on a side square.
Saturate it with water (under the tap), and push it over the opening of
your ear canal so it forms a vacuum seal -- don't shove it way into your ear
canal.

This will get you as much protection (if done properly) as any earplug,
at the cost of feeling somewhat gooshy and tending to dry and pop out every
hour or so.  Way better than tinnitus, tho.

// g

I don't know. How many "jock-types, and country hicks at Let Freedom Rave 
do you think actually joined the circle with a clear and happy mind, 
thinking about unity?"  Hopefully, all of them.  However, that question 
is one without an answer for me, since there is no one definition of a 
"jock-type" or a "hick".  Certainly there are many people that could fit 
the description by sight, but I don't judge people by the way they look, 
so I could care less about that.  As for whether everyone joined the 
circle thinking about unity and with a clear and happy mind, I can't 
answer that one unless everyone that was in the circle took part in a 
poll that asked "were you thinking about cultural unity and happiness 
when you joined in the circle at Let Freedom Rave on the 2nd-3rd of 
july."  And I don't care, either.  Hopefully people that aren't thinking 
of it will.  If not, as long as they don't interfere with other peoples 
right to dance in peace, let them do what they want.  


dj fog

From brian  Mon Jul 11 20:36:32 1994

Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id UAA06436; Mon, 11 Jul 1994 20:36:32 -0700

  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Mon, 11 Jul 1994 20:34:11 -0700
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 19:53:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Minuk <davidmin@crl.com>
Subject: Earplugs II: The Return of Hearing
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.87.9407111937.A26345-0100000@crl.crl.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I use earplugs I purchased at a sporting goods store.  They are metal 
cylinders held in a latex insert.  They don't stop much sound until there 
is a sudden change in sound level.  So you can still hear fine and you 
get some protection ( though probably not as much as foam).  I have been 
using them for around ten years and have had good results.  My ears don't 
ring after a concert.  (I don't wear them for raves, because I can 
usually find a safe spot, whereas at someplace like the Kennel Club, 
there's no escape from noise).  They're less than ten bucks.  I've only 
had to buy 2 pairs so far (got to buy another one, lost my last pair :-().
They were recommended to me by a musician, but I d on't know if they're 
FDA approved for rave hearing protection ;-).  They are better at 
stopping sudden noises such as you might find at rock concert than the 
constantly loud levels heard at raves, but the fact that they 
don't muffle the sound and are comfortable makes them tops in my book.
I don't know the brand name, we used to call them Sonic earplugs but they 
had a different name on my second pair.
(Longwinded, rambling hearing story follows)
For many years, I used to be able to close my ears.  This was a blessing, 
because I was able to sleep no matter what the ambient noise level was. 
By placing my head in a certain position, my ears would close, and I 
could sleep.  One day, I was suddenly attacked by dizzy spells.  This 
disturbed me considerably, because I had not experienced this before, and 
I had no other symptoms of illness.  It did have the benefit of occuring 
when I tilted my head a certain way, creating a cheap thrill rush.  So I 
went to the doctor and told him how when I turn my head a certain way 
everything starts spinning around and around and around.  He said don't 
tilt your head that way. (rimshot).  But seriously folks, he wanted to 
look in my ears.  He tried but couldn't. Totally clogged with years of 
goo!  He asked me if I ever had my ears cleaned, I said no.  I didn't 
know this is something you had to do regularly, maybe I don't watch 
enough TV commercials.  So he stuck a squirt gun thing in my ear and 
whoosh! out came tons of gunk.  He told me that the dizziness was probably 
caused by an allergic reaction to dust.  I think it was caused by a rave 
I went to the previous weekend.  It was a Vision in a very dusty Livermore 
warehouse (hack hack thanks, Martin...).  I got over the dizziness, 
but my whole perception of sound changed.  Now I could hear sounds that I 
hadn't for years, like those great 909 hi-hats!  And birds tweeting!  It 
was amazing.  I used to be totally into the bass because it was all I 
could hear.  But my hearing was much more sensitive now.  Unfortunately, 
it robbed me of sleep but eventually I adjusted.  I wish I could still 
close my ears though.  The moral of the story is, well there's none I 
suppose.  OK, how about get your ears cleaned  out, you may be suprised 
at the difference.  And oh yeah, wear earplugs, 'cause hearing is great.

David

 Someone finally mentioned my favorite style of ear protection - wet
paper tissue:

> On Mon, 11 Jul 1994, JUMP IN THE FIRE wrote:
> 
> > 
> > Handy Hint:  If you forget earplugs, go to the bathroom and get either
> > two squares of micro-thin institutional TP or one square of normal TP.
> > Fold it over itself until you get about a 2/3 inch on a side square.
> > Saturate it with water (under the tap), and push it over the opening of
> > your ear canal so it forms a vacuum seal -- don't shove it way into your ear
> > canal.
> > 
> > This will get you as much protection (if done properly) as any earplug,
> > at the cost of feeling somewhat gooshy and tending to dry and pop out every
> > hour or so.  Way better than tinnitus, tho.
> > 
 To which Tony Garcia added:
> Be careful, however, about sticking it in too far.  otherwise you will 
> end up at the doctors office like i did saying "well, i kinda stuck it in 
> too far"!  
> 
  The way I shape the wet tissue varies from JITF's method in that I 
 make it an oblong shape instead of square. I insert them into my ears 
 such that the main body of the tissue rolls lie in the curve just 
 outside my ear canal . Then , I adjust the amount of insertion into the
 ear canal to tailor the degree of attenuation. The part of the roll
 that is outside the canal acts as an anchor to keep the earplugs from 
 flying out , and also act as handles to make removal easier.

  If no institutional TP is available , regular TP works good , as does 
 cocktail napkins - just get 'em wet!

  If you have trouble getting used to the mid/treble attenuation of 
 commercial earplugs , you might give wet tissue a try. It's my preference,
 after trying the foam ones and the expensive latex/metal ones ( HOWEVER,
 if the sound system is godawfully LOUD , the latex/metal ones are the 
 best - keeps a better portion of the high end than the foam ones or the
 earplugs that look like silicon putty. ).

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

 As an offshoot of the hearing protection thread -

 About once every 4 or 6 months , I'll be sitting around , not doing
much , when a weird little thing happens to my hearing. The hearing in 
one of my ears will cut out , and something that sounds like a pure
sinusoidal tone rings delicately in that ear for about 4 seconds . Then
my regular hearing returns as the "test tone" fades away.

 I've had this since I was a teen ( correlation to my first rock
concert experiences? ). I've heard of way worst cases of tintinnitus ,
some poor folks hear tones and whistles all the time - so I'm not
complaining. I'm just wondering if it's happened to anyone else.

 It's the weirdess thing - as if some technician somewhere to doing the
remote biannual check on my sound sensors! << "the gov't put a circuit
in my head" >>.

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

I thought this guy's experience would add an additional perspective on
the recent Wicked...

Ken

included message follows:
==========================================================================

>
>Last night I went to my first "rave", from a listing on sfraves-calendar,
>clan of Wicked in SF.  I was shocked!
>
>1. There was no variety to the music at all!  The only change was that
>the baseline would occasional stop and start again.
>2. There were no trippy, colorful clothes - most everyone looked like they
>were trying to emulate boring mainstream fashion ala grunge and jeans.
>3. There were no interesting drugs - the drug of choice was clearly
>nicotine and I got a whole carton of second-hand smoke.
>4. It was predominantly couples dancing together (it IS the 90's, but..)
>5. The music had absolutely no positive social content - the only
>discernable spoken sample was a voice saying "Annihilate Intruders" - it
>felt really creepy like the military-industrial complex was sponsoring it.
>6. It was expensive ($15 for a few hours of generic dance beat???)
>
>Somebody please tell me that there are Raves not like this!?  Somewhere
>with interesting and conscious music and people, less fricking cigarette
>smoke, and maybe a single person or two?
>
>Ben Discoe
>    "I do VR for a living"

( I posted this to alt.rave last week )


 There's a comic book artist who's work I've been collecting over
the years named Matt Howarth. Not only do I like his style and 
imagination , but he often has personal music reviews at the end of
some of his comics. Since his tastes run similar to mine ( pre-new age 
space/synth music , some industrial , some avant-garde misc. stuff , and
more recently techno ) , I've always enjoyed reading his reviews. 

 Matt Howarth has also incorporated "real-life" musicians as characters
in his stories. The list includes This Heat , Nash The Slash , Conrad
Schnitzler,and Dave Brock & Hawkwind. Which practice leads to the tie-in
with this newsgroup.

 Coming in Sept. , one of Matt Howarth's comics , "Savage Henry", issue #2 , 
from Iconografix Comics , will have Moby as a "guest". Here's the plot 
synopsis from a recent comics catalog:

 *Savage Henry meets techno rave musician "Moby" as they share a dream of
of highly amusing proportions in "Going Interactive." They go fishing, 
ride dinosaurs, sit on the beach as melting ice cream cones, talk with
penguins, go flying, play detective and spy catcher - and then realize
that they are prisoners of their own shared dream! A mysterious presence 
wants them to have fun, wear hats, and not ask questions.*

 I thought some of you folks might want to know ...

		Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
tomorrow's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12:15ish to 1:15ish 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Precedence: bulk


	Well,

	  I guess I was at a completely different wicked than everyone
	else this weekend.  Although I do agree the $15 entrance fee
	to be quite high, I had an enormously great time.  I arrived
	inside after being searched by the entrance nazis.  They
	confiscated all of the fruit and water that me and my friends
	brought.  Major downer, but since this was a once in a 3 month
	outing for me I decided to not let the night rest on one thing.
	I had reservations about going to Townsend for a Wicked, I
	usually do not enjoy that venue because of its sound quality
	and I usually overheat easily in there.  But on this particular
	evening staying cool after dancing for several hours was no
	problem.  The sound system was ok, but not spectacular.  I
	was wearing my my favorite sunflower shirt and boots and brought
	along my favorite toy (flashing bike light).  My toy as usual
	got lots of attention and allowed me to meet lots of new
	smiling faces.

	  In all I had a terrific evening and if I never go to a
	rave again this was a good one to end raving on.  I do not
	know what you all are crying about.  You only get out of
	a rave what you put in, I guess I put in tons and got out
	tons.  Those of you who did not enjoy yourself need to
	put something into this scene instead of complaining about
	it or it will just die.  Keep in mind I am a 29 yr old
	professional and my 20 odd friends range in age from 23
	to 33 from all walks of life and we all just had a fabulous
	time.

	Keep the peace & safe journey,

	Ron.

> much , when a weird little thing happens to my hearing. The hearing in 
> one of my ears will cut out , and something that sounds like a pure
> sinusoidal tone rings delicately in that ear for about 4 seconds . Then
> my regular hearing returns as the "test tone" fades away.
>

Yes. This happens to me every now and again. Did you hit your head as
a child (wild guess)? Maybe it's your ear-bones finding a nice 
natural harmonic with your surroundings for awhile.

as a veteran of the LA metal scene (Troubador back in '86 or so), i can
  attest to the benefits of earplugz, tho, i've heard one interesting
    theory about ear damage:

  if you are CONSTANTLY exposed to loud sounds (at least once per 24hour
    period), you are in danger of having hearing damage... but, if you only
      subject yerself to loud volume levels on an infrequent basis (like
        once or twice a month) then your ears will probably not suffer
          any damage at all, unless the volume's 200 db or something like
            that.  issit true or not that yer ears have a sort of 'shielding'
              effect, for short-term exposure to loudness, kinda like the
                adjustment your eyes make for bright light?????

whadyasay? huh?

Dave Scruton

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 1994 10:23:46 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <199407120534.WAA04604@netcom14.netcom.com> from "Larry Ching" at Jul 11, 94 10:34:41 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1175      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>  About once every 4 or 6 months , I'll be sitting around , not doing
> much , when a weird little thing happens to my hearing. The hearing in 
> one of my ears will cut out , and something that sounds like a pure
> sinusoidal tone rings delicately in that ear for about 4 seconds . Then
> my regular hearing returns as the "test tone" fades away.
> 
>  I've had this since I was a teen ( correlation to my first rock
> concert experiences? ). I've heard of way worst cases of tintinnitus ,
> some poor folks hear tones and whistles all the time - so I'm not
> complaining. I'm just wondering if it's happened to anyone else.

Yep.  Each of those tones is one of the little cilia in your cochlea
dying.  "Aaaaaargh!"  Everyone loses some hearing as they age -- loud
sounds accelerate the process.  I get that sensation every couple of
weeks.

Interestingly, this means you can "burn out" certain frequencies.  I used
to be incredibly annoyed by the 14.75 KHz (or whatever) of free-running
standard-resolution video monitors, which I'm always around at work.  Now
I can't hear them at all -- constant exposure has zorched my ability to
hear that particular frequency.

// g

> Interestingly, this means you can "burn out" certain frequencies.  I used
> to be incredibly annoyed by the 14.75 KHz (or whatever) of free-running
> standard-resolution video monitors, which I'm always around at work.  Now
> I can't hear them at all -- constant exposure has zorched my ability to
> hear that particular frequency.
> 
> // g

Also interesting is that the impression of "loudness" that you feel is based
on an average over the sound spectrum.  In general this works, but it means
that you can totally blast out your hearing if you are listening to a single
frequency (say a sine wave from an oscillator for some sort of test) even 
though you feel no significant pain from the loudness.
Rodney

Brian, let me know if your address has changed...

Date: 11 Jul 1994 17:39:09 U
From: "BrianB" <brianb@mni.com>
Subject: Hearing

You used to be able to get custom-fitted musician's ear-plugs (I forget the
brand name) at the Haight Ashbury Free Clinic for about $50 (they're usually
about $100). These block sound evenly over the entire frequency spectrum- rather
than cutting out the highs leaving a dull <thud thud thud>. *WAY* better than
foam, at any thickness. They're very musical and transparent, and offer about 20dBs
of attenuation. Well worth the money.

Brian Benitez

Troy, let me know if your address has changed from tsheets@scf.usc.edu

From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu>
Subject: wicked (one more review)
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 1994 22:07:02 -0700 (PDT)

This is what I expected from Wicked:  I thought it would be kind
of bad early in the night, and get a little better towards morning.
Instead, it was really bad early in the night, and it got really
good in the morning.

	When we arrived at 4am the place was packed.  I immediately
saw what my 15 dollars was paying for:  Excellent visual 
projections (anyone want to send me their name/number?), about
92 intellabeams, and a mediocore sound system.  Unfortunately,
it also bought a neon pink-and-glass-block bar (gag!) and
San Francisco's "Coolest" club goers.  The bar I could live with,
the "cool" club goers I could not.  The dance floor was swamped
with expensive clothes and cheap pick-up lines.  Beer was spilt
everywhere.  There were way to many people on the dance floor
to actually dance, and about half of them were just standing
around talking.  Now, don't get me wrong.  I really enjoy some
showiness at clubs.  I like dressing up in some cool clothes too,
but I don't make it my mission in life to look cool, like many of 
these people do.  For some reason, the sound did not seem all that
loud.  I could here the conversations around me a lot better than
Pierre's spinning.  
	But, as I expected, around 5am people started leaving.  Around
six o'clock it felt like someone in a back room through a giant knife-
switch (give my party life!) ,and hey! I found myself at a good house
party.  By 7am there was just enough people on the dance floor to
create some vibe and to have room to twirl around a little (well,
not literally (:   ).  Even the music seemed louder. Either they
turned it up in the morning or there were just fewer bodies to
absorb it.  At 8:30, the dj (sorry, havn't matched names/faces yet
to sf djs) was forcibly removed from the 1200s, and we left
happy.
	I suggest if you want to experience Wicked, that you arrive at
5am.  This way, you will just catch the tail end of the drinking 
crowd, and have about 3 hours of a cool house crowd.  
	Anyone want to tell us about the Ameba party?

-troy

	Kate (from England) posted to this list a few months ago asking to
hook up w/people in the US when she and her 2 friends, Mark and Rich,
would be touring the states this summer.  I live near Seattle, and just 
finished spending a week with Mark and Rich while they were up here 
checking out the Seattle and Vancouver scene.  They asked me to post 
the following message:

____________________________________________________________________________

	3 English ambient/techno/alternative heads (2 guys, one girl) 
	are touring the US and are looking for places to land our 
	Volkswagen spaceship, crash, chill, shower, and see the sights
	with similarly groovy people.	We're gonna be in California
	in August, and would love to meet people and do the west coast
	party thing!  

	We're friendly, approachable, really well-behaved and won't bite!
	Please reply to our friend Andrew, as he will forward us 
	info when we call him!
____________________________________________________________________________
	

	Please send any info re- places for my friends to park their van,
events, people who'd like to meet them, etc., to this e-mail address.
My friends in Seattle and I have hung around them a lot in the past week,
and they really are nice people who are looking forward to experiencing
the SF scene! ; )

	Peace,
	
		Andrew

	Two comments:

	To Larry:  Along with the steady *riiiiiiing* that I get with the
tinnitus, I also occasionally get the pure sinusodal tone, too and often
wondered what it was.  I guess I've got the same question -- does anyone
know what this is? (fluid rolling around in your inner ear?)

	AboutWickedPost:  My first rave was the Wicked about six weeks or so
ago (also at Townsend), and although I had an absolutely fabulous time, I
had some similar complaints as the guy on alt.raves.  I felt the music was a 
little too simple (?).  I guess I like more going on at the same time with the
beat/bass/etc.  I actually *liked* the fact that everyone there was dressed to
dance.  Rather than being faced with a room full of fashion kings/queens, I
was pleasantly surprised with a lot of really down to earth, smiling faces :-).
Does anyone have any recommendations on parties with better music?  No insult
to the folks that run the show.  I'll still go to the next one :-).

/steve

(For some reaosn majordomo thought this was an admin request... hmm...)

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 94 10:35:44 PDT
Subject: Any takers for GG PARK?

As much fun as In The Light was, I'm not going to be able to organize 
another Golden Gate Park party this year.  However, I have the date of 
Sept. 3rd reserved for us.  Anyone who would like to take the lead on this 
can count on my help with the paperwork.  A few notes:

- The Park Permit costs $400.
- A $500 refundable security deposit is also required.
- The SFPD sound permit costs $30.
- No soliciting is permitted at the site, although we can probably get a
  waiver for this if we do a benefit of some sort.
- Amplified sound must end at 6pm.
- The renovations to the Band Shell are complete and will provide a more 
  interesting backdrop & better acoustics than previous parties there.
- Sept. 3 is Labor Day weekend, the same weekend as Burning Man.
- I managed to collect about $200 in donations for In The Light.  Some
  people have already stated that they would donate some $ for another park
  party, but it is not clear how much can be expected in this regard.
- There are plenty of volunteers on sfraves willing to help setup/cleanup 
  etc.

I'd love to see another park party, so if anyone is interested in organizing
one, or knows someone who is, please let me know. :)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

At 04:26 PM 7/12/94 GMT, KEN STUART wrote:
>Sean writes:
>>I went to the NMR this weekend. It was very nice!
>>
>>Toys/altar: yes, yes
>      ^^^^^
>
>Do raves in NYC have altars?  My guess is no; I may be very wrong but I
>would think that this is an SF thing rather than a rave thing...


When Liz Roberts, Laura, WILL-E & I were trying to put together a rave here 
in the NYC area, Liz mentioned setting up a table to use as a sort of altar 
(I remember her using a different term, but the idea is the same).  I loved 
the idea, and had never seen one before at a party in NY.  

When Will-e and I traveled to your sf land I saw one (I think it was at the 
Blue Cube party), and was impressed that someone went out of their way to 
add that level of spirituality to the party; it was there also that I saw 
not one but two people burning sage (at Launch Pad), which WILL-E has done 
at home before, but which I've never seen at a NYC party.

So I'd say it's a sf or west-coast thing.

Phil Z



From brian  Tue Jul 12 12:16:47 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id MAA15319; Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:16:47 -0700
Received: from mothra.nts.uci.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA15313; Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:16:40 -0700
Received: by mothra.nts.uci.edu id AA18536
  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:16:31 -0700
Received: by mothra.nts.uci.edu id AA18526
  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:16:28 -0700
From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
Message-Id: <199407121916.AA18526@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Subject: Dont Be A Dopey.. o/~
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 94 12:16:27 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

For a long time i've thought that the whole
"You do things your way, i do them mine" thing was totally right on,
but then i realized i was just too egotistical about how
important i thought a lot of issues are just too damn important
to let any viewpoint hold,
things like racism...
i try Real hard to say "let them think their way, and you think yours"
when listening to a bunch of KKK members on Geraldo
and i think i can do it better than most of my friends, but overall...
its just too much of a thing that is not just affecting
their own persons, but is somethign that affects others

Now, as to an "I do my drug, you do your drug" idea...

Considering how your body is pretty much made up of chemicals
and the way your brain interacts is pretty much based
upon the chemicals that happen to be in it at the time
Chemicals seem to be an important thing 

As an important thing, we should look at the chemicals that people take
and what affects they have...

I think that too many people in drug cultures try to deny the 
negative effects of their drug of choice
Mainstream America was doing a damn good job of placing all the
blame on every other drug that wasnt supported by a large lobby
and it's just now that we are starting to deal with all the problems
that nicotine and alcohol and hopefully soon caffeine cause

In the same respect, lots of users of LSD or E or whatever say
"See? Our drugs arent like that!"
(in reference to things like physical/sexual confrontations and abuse
that tend to happen a lot by people under the influence of alcohol)

The big question is: Are the people the problem or the drugs?

I mean, i think that a lot of the people attracted to LSD for its
abilities to open peoples minds are going to get that otu of it

people attracted to LSD because its a fun toy and makes you feel funky
will get that out of it

I spent a whole nite in Los Angeles watching people in a park wandering
around aimlessly just talking to themselves and the little
people that they were seeing

They didnt seem happy to me, they didnt seem to be having some
great educational experience either, they were just homeless people
looking for some way to get their minds off their problem
and found a REAL cheap one that lasts for the whole nite

It's not the typical picture i have in my mind, from experience, of
an LSD user, but its one that is probably the strongest

It just points out the important thing that:

ANYTHING CAN BE ABUSED
~~~~~~~~

some people have addictive personalities, and it doesnt matter
what they do, until they change their personality enough,
they will get addicted
to heroin, to alcohol, to MDMA, to watching TV all day
all of these can be done to a point where 
they do nothing with their lives,
do not interact with other people,
have no job, contribute nothing to anything, etc etc etc

WITH ALL THIS IN MIND:

How can anyone say, "My drug is better than your drug!"

Well, i dont think anyone should say that, but they should
provide lots of INFORMATION about drugs,
about the statistics, and better yet about real stories

I have NEVER talk to someone about Speed without them saying that
they hate it and how stupid it is
Does that mean they dont do it again? No, it doesnt. I see that as a problem.
(Of course i also grew up aroudn smokers who said the same thing...
and none of them ever attempted to quit)

with everything, people get really fucked up, on whatever
and they go to far for their own good, and say
"I'm never going to drink (or whatever, thats just the most common) again!"
only to go and abuse themselves later

And percentagewise it would be real hard to find out which drugs
are the most problematic
because the percentage of the population that uses alcohol
and the percentage that uses psychadelics are not even close

NONETHELESS, we should do our best to provide information
and to find information about things like:
Rape, Domestic Violence, etc etc 
and see what drugs are related to those

and use that as caveats, 

Its NOT the drug that is the problem in these cases
its the fucked up way that WE as a society
are letting people be brought up

letting them think its okay to hit their spouse, OR
not giving them the means to express themselves another way

letting them think that certain sections of society are objects of desire
and not letting them interact with them as Subjects of their own control
which makes things non-ideal for either side

if you throw chemicals into someone's system, depending on what it does
and depending on them, these leanings can get increased or decreases
some chemicals are obviously more likely to increase
and some more likely to decrease
but it kinda depends on what they are acting on

my point?
theres not enough information about anything
theres CERTAINLY not enough negative stories
about psychedlics/empathnogens that arent media-hype 
some kid thought she could fly and jumped off a roof type things

personally, i think, ideally, any chemical can be used to 
learn, either because it fucks you up and you learn to deal with that
or through some other means that is immediately less harmful

but thats ideally
and it think that the ideal type people doing that
would be ideal becuase they have enough information
to really know what they are doing

until then, we need to look around and get information
look at all the people in the spotlight using heroin 
to solve their problems and when that doenst work, a shotgun

look at our friends or former friends in a state of
amphetamine-induced paranoia too scared to talk to you

look at our friends who are involved in horrid relationships
that eat at their lives until a half an hour after
they pop a little capsule in their mouth

and look at all the things that happen that are good
when under whatever influence
and learn that too

 ,
dana

"Don't look for opportunity in the distance,
recognize it and embrace it right where you are."

From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul 12 12:47:05 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id MAA15582; Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:47:05 -0700
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA15574; Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:46:35 -0700
