	id MAA27064; Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:47:13 -0700
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 1994 12:47:13 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199407121947.MAA27064@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Rainbow and rave report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

                         Rainbow Gathering report
                         ========================

                    (c) by John Draper (Cap'n Crunch)

   Well,  I'm BACK,  after traveling slighly less than 5000 miles in 
a period of almost 2 1/2 weeks.    Thus explains my long term absence.
But,  from the chatter in the Raves mailing lists,  I wasn't missed.

   I had actually not planned to go to Rainbow Gathering,  but it sort
of turned out that I was in a unique position to go,  so I jumped on the 
opportunity.

   It all started when my friend Aaron who origionally lived in Iowa,
wanted me to drive him there to pick up the rest of his stuff.    Figuring
that I have to start work soon,   this was our only opportunity to do this,
so our decision to drive to Iowa was a "Spur of the moment" thing.   So
on the 22nd of June with little fanfare,  we pack up the car and head east.

   About 40 hours later,  after continious driving,  we arrive in Iowa City,
A College town.    While Aaron was dealing with his stuff,  I head over to
the University Computing center where I can get on the Internet and check
my Email.   Few people even knew I was gone.

   At that time,  I learned my friend from Pennsylvania was heading west and
was to pass within 50 miles of Lake Okoboji in North West Iowa (Our next
destination),  so we arrange to meet there a few days later.    Andy,  our
friend from Pa.   was heading out West to Wyoming to attend the Rainbow
Gathering,  so it was then that we made the decision to go.    

   On the way,  we visited Yellowstone park,   and took long hikes through
the wilderness,  enjoying the more remote parts of the park.    For me,  it
was really GREAT because I haven't gone on such a long trip in several years
and needed the break.     We met some people who had been to the Gathering
earlier in the week,  who warned us of some potentual health hazards and to
avoid drinking from some of the natural water sources in the area,  because
some of the land was used for cattle grazing.   We also get word that more
than 10,000 people were already there,  and the event hadn't even started
yet,   but most of the encampments were already set up,  and that it was
spread out over an area about 5 miles in diameter along several ridges
and valleys,  with a huge meadow (About 1 mile by 1 1/2 miles in size)
with some large and very small forest "Islands" providing ideal camp
environments with plenty of dried firewood easy to gather for the fires.

   After several days at Yellowstone park,  we head south to the site of the 
rainbow gathering and easily find the nearest city "Big Piney" along the
route where we take the cut-off to the national park.    After driving
about 10 miles on paved road,  and another 20 miles on dirt roads,  we
finally make it to the huge parking area late in the evening and decided
to set up camp in the parking area and hike into the main Rainbow area
in the morning.

   We learned that it was about a 2 1/2 mile hike to what they called the
"Center Circle".    Andy,  with his two daughtors Lindon and Heather wanted
to camp near Kid Village (Another half mile in),  so we lug all our camping
gear up to that point.    Along the way we stop at the "Ganji testing station"
for treats and coffee and casually make our way,  visiting all the camps
along the way.    Everyone greeted us with "Welcome home brothers and sisters"
as we headed down the long pathway into the main Gathering area.   The place was
so spread out.   Hundreds of people scatterred out over this huge "Bowl" like
meadow,  the air so clear that everything looks so close until you realize that
these tiny little things out there are people.    Far out on the other side
of the main area is the Teepee area.   These huge teepees,  along with the
Wyoming mountains in the background certainly convinced me that I had taken
a trip back in time to the days of the old west.   Camps were set on the edges
of the tree lines.    Kid Village was in this little "Inlet" of trees,  and
CALM was located at the tip of a tree penninsula.  

   Aaron met some of his friends from Iowa,  and insists that we hike another
mile back to a camp called "Turtle Soup".  which eventually became our home
for a week.    Along the way,  we visit Sun Dog camp,   North West camp, 
MIA/POW camp,  and way in the back,  we finally make it to Turtle Soup.
I figure that we were about 4 miles from the parking area at this point.

    The Turtle Soup camp is mostly folks from Michigan,  and probably (in my
opinion) was the hippest camp at the Gathering.

    A little about the environment....   I figure we were at about 8000 feet
elivation.  On our first night,  it was BELOW FREEZING,  and I had ice crystals
all over my sleeping bag in the morning.    But as soon as the sum comes up,
the temperature rapidly rises to well above 80 degrees.   The sun is fiercly
hot in the day,  very windy,  and extremely dry.   Most days I was there,
it was partly cloudy,  and when the sun gets blocked by clouds,  the temperature
drops down to 50 degrees within minutes.

    Later that afternoon,  a fire started,  but luckely,  it was quickly put out
before it got out of hand.   It turned out that some bozo built a fire too 
close to an adjacent tree,  and without a rock base,  and the roots caught
fire and spread quickly to the rest of the tree.    Quick thinking on the
part of bystanders quickly chopped down the tree to isolate it from
the others,  and the fiew was doused.   Naturally, we were warned that
fire conditions were very high due to the windy weather.   That evening, 
we had a council meeting and gathering to make sure that everyone knew about 
the fire danger,  and what to do if there was a fire.  IE:  Get out of the
trees and out into the meadow.

     The rangers were very impressed with how fast we reacted to the fire,  
and how quickly we set up the bucket brigade to put it out.   By the time the
fire fighters arrived,  we were mopping up the fire,  putting out the "hot
spots". 

    The water sources come from spring water,   but it had to be filtered, 
and was un-drinkable unless filtered.    Turtle Soup had our own water 
filtering pump,  and we took turns pumping our own drinking water through 
the filter.

Later that afternnon,  after the fire,  I go out and explore the vast area
and visit the camps.    With only 3 hours of daylight,  I didn't have much
exploration time after having to help deal with the fire,   but I manage to
make it back to Turtle Soup to get my flashlight before wandering out to
all the fires scatterred around this vast area.

Most of the encampments were in the forest,  bordering the meadows.   Some
areas just had little Islands of trees in the vast meadows,  and others in
huge groves of trees.    Finding my way around at night was quite challanging,
but I finally figured out that it was really not possible to just pick out
some camp and head out there at night.    I quickly learned that it was much 
easier to just sequentially go from camp to camp,  visiting each one,  and
hanging out by their fire before striking out to visit another one.

On the 2nd full day ( I think it was Sunday) in the early afternoon,  
I decided to dose up and hang out by my camp and do my yoga.   About
the time I was "peaking" I hear a faint shout "Fire Fire" from far away,
but no reaction from anyone close by.    About 5 monutes later,  everyone
was shouting "Fire Fire".    By that time,  I could smell the smoke,  and
quickly grabbed my fanny pack (With my car keys),  and vacated our tent
area and headed towards the main Turtle Soup camp.

By the time I made it to the camp,  it was diserted,  and a ranger directed
me in the opposite direction (Towards the Krishna camp).    I was totally
disorentated,  going off in a direction TOWARDS the trees and in the opposite
direction to the opean meadow where I would seek safety.    I don't know how
close the fire was,   but I could hear it,  and the smoke was really getting
thick.    Eventually,  a person named Dan assisted me down to the open meadow,
and we made it along the river (Away from the trees).    Once out in the meadow,
I realized how bad the prediciment I was in.    Flames were shooting up
hundreds of feet in the air,  and the wind was blowing the flames everywhere.

I tried to skirt the fire by going in the opposite direction,  always trying
to stay behind the fire,   running like crazy along the river.   I never
stopped running until I actually reached the river and came across the Krishnas
doing their "Hera Krisha" chants.    I just wanted to get away from them as
quickly as possible,  so made my way along the river for several more miles
until I was far enough away from the fire (And Krishnas) to feel somewhat safe.

By that time,  I noticed the wind had changed direction,  blowing the fire
AWAY from me,  so thinking I was somewhat safe,  took the opportunity to
skinny dip in the river to cool off,  get my bearings and figure out where
I was.   I must have covered about 7 - 8 miles (About two ridges from the
main circle),  and after meeting some other people,  learned just how far
I had traveled.    I never saw any forest rangers anymore,   but teamed with
several other Rainbow folks,  picking my way back to the main circle which
was estimated to be about 4 miles away from where I had fled the fire.

On the way back,   I saw that the fire fighters had started to drop fire
retardent on the fire,   but by the time I returned back to camp,   most
of the fire was put out and rumors were that it was ALMOST under control.

I also learned happily that Turtle Soup survived the fire,  but the Aloha
camp got burned out.   The fire was located near the Serenity kitchen.

   Announcements were made for volunteers to help mop
up the hot spots,  so 4 bucket brigades were immediately formed,  and about
4000 Rainbow folks (including myself) joined in the mopping operation.

The wind played a great part in helping to contain the fire,  as it changed
directions three times,  whipping the fire opon itself towards the areas
it had previously burned,  thus resulting in only about 8 achers of forest
burned.   We were REALLY LUCKEY.

Aaron,  my freind was caught in the parking lot when the fire started,  and
wasn't allowed back to the camp until long after most of the fire was put
out.    There was only a very small number of professional fire fighters
available to focus on this fire,  because of many larger fires in Wyoming
and Glenwood Springs Colo.  

Later on,  the local fire investigaters learned the fire was arson,  and
just before I left the Gathering,  we learned that the bastard was caught.

I arrive back at camp at about 2 am,  totally tired and fried out.   Then
thinking back,  and with some maps of the area,  tried to figure out where,
and how far I had traveled.   I'm not so sure,   but after tallying up the
distances,  I think it must be in the range of about 45 miles or so of
walking (And running),  when I considered I went to the parking lot TWICE
after helping fight the fire,  and on two of the bucket brigades,  each of
which was about a mile long.

That evening of the fire,  someone commented "The fire is out",  and I rebuffed
and said "NOT LIKELY".    That mopping operation took several more days to
insure that "root fires" wouldn't flare up again.

That evening,  EVERYONE was on FIRE WATCH...

The next day,   I focued on doing more of my yoga,   teaching other Rainbow
family members how to identify "Energy blockages" and remove them through yoga
and thai chi like exercises.    

That next evening,   I went night exploring again,   hopping from camp to camp,
telling stores of my travels to Russia and other interesting things.    My
wanderings brought me far and wide until Sunrise (2nd day without sleep,  and
35 more miles walked,  hiked or wandered).  Instead of trying to sleep at night
(When it was the coldsest),  I used that time to keep active (And warm).   Then,
I would meditate out in the meadow (When it was the warmest).

Most of the evenings,  I would dance my ass off in the drum circles,  grooving
on the flames of the fire as a natural source of visual eye candy,  tripping
on the lights of the fire and the stars in the sky.    Unfortunately,   the
circles didn't offer much room to dance without getting roasted near the fire,
and buring off physical energy dancing like crazy.    Somehow I managed to
kick around for several hours before I got so hot that I had to cool off.
Some of the best drumming I've heard in a long time...

Late one afternoon it rained,  right about the time we were to gather out in
"Main circle",   but nature had other pland for us,  and provided us with a
spectacular rainbow,  lightning,  thunder.  and her awsome power.    I stayed
sheltered in "Everyone's Kitchen" trying to stay out of the way.    Eventually,
I made it over to Kid Village to visit with Andy before going back to Turtle
Soup..

That evening,  the weather was surprisingly warm,   but pushing that "Warm front"
was a "Cold front" and long after I wrapped myself in blankets,   the weather
got colder and colder.    Not having a warm sleeping blanket,   I wrapped around
anything I could find.     I did manage to stay somewhat warm,    but was 
surprised to find it snowing in the morning.    Shortly after that,   later on
in late morning,  yet another awsome Rainbow was hanging in the sky....  This
one was from snow,  and a lot more intense.    But that evening,   thanx to the
warmer evening before it got cold,   I slept for the first time since I arrived.
In fact,   after staying for more than 6 days,  I think I only slept TWICE.

Living out there for a week made me realize how little technology means,  as
I totally lost touch with the rest of the world.    I called no one,  nor even
cared what happens in the real world.    The only high tech thingie I had was
a flashlight.  It was GREAT!!    Wandering around in the great hills,  large
meadows,   and seeing the teepees.  No cars,  electric lights,  amplified sound,
radios,   or anything to even remind me that I'm in the 20th century.   

The stars were awsome,  at 8000 feet,  there was little air between me and outer
space,  no pollution to dirty up the air,   no bright electric lights were
intruding on my sky gazing.    Eventually,  my lousey night vision improved,
but I still needed a flashlight to nagigate the trails.

One day,  Aaron and me decide to head out even further to a place he discovered
called "Granola Funk".   It was an "Out of the way" camp,   very nice people,
and spent several hours with them,  hanging out,  telling stories,  and keeping
warm by the fire.   

We also visited the "Lost Hippies" camp,  "Fairy camp",  and a number of others
in that area,   but couldn't get to the Pizza Kitchen or sweat lodges.    

Living at Rainbow gathering was like living in a utopean world,  where barter
replaced money.    This was an experience I'll never forget...

Zippy Rave
==========

Our 2nd to last evening,  we get word of a Rave to take place in the parking
lot area.    When I hear the word "Rave" my ears perk up and I take immediate
notice.    Raving is my favorite passtime,  and I really like dancing until the
sun comes up.    So,  I head over to the main access trail waiting for some
people coming from the parking lot to tell me if a rave is really happening.

I had assumed that I would be able to hear it,   but as I walked along to access
path,  I could barely hear anything.    Some people were pointing in a direction
opposite to Bus Village (Where it as alleged to be).     As I headed down to the
area (Still not hearing the music) I realize why...    It was in this huge deep
revine.   I could hear the generator but not the music.     Once I got close
enough,  I could hear this amazing acid trance music like what you get from
Germany,   and it didn't take me long to get down there and start dancing.

WOW!! What energy... And how bright electric lights were,  compared to camp
fires.   It didn't take long for me to get acquainted with the Zippies,  and
I danced my ass off all night.    At one point,  just as the sun was coming up,
I realized that I was the only person dancing for about a half hour...   

Eventually,   I noticed a fire,  and most people (including the Zippies) were
huddled around the fire.    I quickly joined them and got told some amazing
stories about the Zippy movement.    Pretty heady stuff...    I would say at
the peak,  about 50 - 70 people were at this small family rave.... Most had a
lot of fun,  and the rave disn't in any way,  interfere with the reat of the
Rainbow gathering.  In fact,  It was almost invisible,  and one had to make
a concerted effort to find it.    You couldn't find it my listening for the
"Thud Thud" sounds,   thats phore shore...

We were assures that the Zippies were to do a live presentation the next day,
but the Zippies were to be heading out to San Francisco,  and couldn't stay
one more night.

The next day,  we managed to get our car up to the "Secret access road",  about
100 feet from our camp.  We assured the rangers that we would only be there long
enough to load our camp gear and leave by sunset....    Aasron takes the car
into town to get gas (town's only gas station closes early).

I attend the last circle,  and tearfully said my goodbys to all these wonderful
Rainbow brothers and sisters,  and make a vow to definately make it next time.

On the way home
===============

   We left LATE at night,  around 10 pm or so,  and headed back to civilization,
and the rest of the world regrettably.    While traveling through Salt Lake City,
I stop and get a newspaper and read an awfully inaccurate article about the 
Gathering that made me want to vomit.    Cristopher Smith was the reporter,   
but his article contained som many inaccuracys that it is hard
to believe that he even visited tha Main Circle.   Here is what "the Salt Lake
City Tribune" said about the Family....

Headline:   RainBow family may say Utah is the place for 95 reunion

It opens with:   Utah,  are you ready for the Rainbow Family.....   It goes on
  to mention that the Rqainbow members are considering Utah.     Hmmm!   Don't
  recall that,  but I wasn't at ALL the council meetings.    That might have
  been discussed.
  
  Apparently,  this Ron Jablonski,  spokesman for the Forest service incident
  command center was quoting this to the press.
  
They go on to mention...  "Family members caused 4 fires...,  the largest
  scorched 8 acres near the Kiddy Village or Serenity camp.    "Forest service
  crews were assisted by Family members in controlling the fires,  although the
  Family members were not equipped to be on the fire line".
  
I personally feel that the forest service didn't give enough credit to the
Family on how quickly the fire was dispatched.   I urge all you Brothers and
Sisters to please write to the Salt Lake City Tribune and please set this
poor un-informed weenee straight.

We stay overnight in Reno (Where the hotels are really cheap),  and go swimming
at Pyrimid lake to cool off from the 100+ degree heat.    Shortly after 6 pm,
we cross the California border... Aaron asleep,  and me driving the last leg
into Mill Valley.....

For those that cannot make it,    and for those that can,   I hope to see you
all next year,   and that I can be better prepared....

Peace...
CC

Hello, I'm new to the sfraves list.  It looks great so far.

  I'm trying to track down some way to contact Crash Worship.  About a year 
ago, I toured with them for two weeks as their sound engineer.  Since then, 
I've been busy trying to stabilize student loans and all that Real World sort 
of stuff and I've lost track of them.

  I didn't see an ad for Crash Worship in San Francisco until the *day after* 
the show.  Talk about timing!  Did anyone see the show?  (Sorry if it's been 
discussed to death already.)  On the tour, we had a show every day except for 
a few long distance travel days so I saw more then ten shows in 14 days -- 
there's some stories there...

  An email address or the snail mail address of their record label would be 
great.

  I've just moved to the Bay Area this past March leaving behind Albany, New
York.  I'm a Unix sysadmin working for NASA Ames at the NAS facility.  We've 
got some really nice computer toys (two Cray Y-MPs, a Thinking Machines CM-5, 
an
Intel Paragon, piles of Silicon Graphics workstations, etc.) so I'm happy here 
workwise, but the nightlife in or around Mountain View for someone like myself 
is either non-existent or strictly word of mouth.  I don't mean to be elitist, 
but the Edge on a Saturday night is a depressing place to be.

  We plan to move to San Francisco inside the next year or so, but I don't 
have a handle on the area yet.  So in general, any suggestions of places to go 
and things to do, areas to check out for apartments, etc. would be useful.

  If you feel this is inappropriate material for sfrave, feel free to email me 
directly.


Rodney

<rpeck@nas.nasa.gov>

	Some guy approached me and said 
	"we really like your Weird Blinking Lights music. would you like
	 to play at a massive Zippy rave?"

	I said, "thank for the offer but i'm really not to into that scene
		but I hope it goes well for you."

	he said "but this could mean a lot of MONEY for you."

	i then launched off on that this whole cyberzippyraver
	all about people just like him and that i would never lend my
	share my resources with such pathetic greed and weakness and that
	I would have nothing to do with him.

	he wouldnt relent. he followed me around and kept saying "money!
	it could mean money"

	i came fairly close to decking the guy. he was physically in my space
	and couldn't believe that i could turn down his "hip" offer.
	to me this is what this whole thing, as well as all other currently
	documented "hip" things are about. greed and trend. 

	i hope they keep their evil and filth away from our city. they would
	do much better in LA

Ah, I'm pleased to see a Crash Worship helper on our group!  Sorry you 
missed the show, I enjoyed it muchly.  The only discussion on sfraves was 
my notice urging people to check'm out, and a reply from someone who was 
glad she took my advice.  The best place to find discussion of CW is on
rec.music.industrial.  I think most ravers would enjoy CW, but it's not 
the same as a rave by any means, though they  aren't Industrial 
either, IMHO. I see a few ravers at CW shows, but not many.  I'd be 
intrigued to find out if there is more of a connection in other cities.
 
There is a good thread about about the 
SF show on r.m.i.  It's also probably the best place to find 
out  how to get in contact with them, as I already saw a similar request 
on that newsgroup.  I saw that they are now booked by the Rave agency, which 
I believe is local.  Rave with a capital R, that's their name.  I hope 
that there can be discussion of CW on this group, so if anyone wants me 
to either e-mail or post the CW review thread, let me know.  I would love 
to hear your stories, I've heard so many crazy rumors.  Welcome to the 
Bay Area, and remember, Mountain View isn't THAT far from SF.

seems to be a lot of confusion and misinformation going around about the 
whole zippy thing.i'll relate the info i have and people can interprete 
this however they see fit-------
the "zippies" are anybody.the word means "zen-inspired professional pagan".
if you think that you might describe yourself this way , then you're a zippy.
if you don't like labels, that's cool too.
currently, there is a group of people who have been travelling across 
america as the "zippy pronoia tour". this tour started in london from the 
megatripolis club and wound it's way via the rainbow gathering to san 
francisco.some of them are sleeping on our floor.others are scattered 
throughout s,f, on other peoples floors.some of them are from england , 
some are americans who joined up along the way.
this is a diverse group of people {new people are joining every day).
the organizing principle of the pronoia tour is chaos.
there isn't actually anyone "in charge" , and at this point i'm sure many 
people have tried to claim that they are the "organizers" but i can 
assure you that this is impossible.
the grand canyon thing is happening and people are encouraged to bring 
their own sound systems.

planet 6 sound

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199407130550.WAA00881@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: concerning *e*
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Jus' wanted to add an imho to the discussion on ecstacy:

psychologically speaking, i think it rewires your personality somehow.  it
is a subtle effect, but real, i think.

i honestly believe that doses of e, appropriately administered, would transform
the world.  i've already encountered two different communities that have been
transformed, or perhaps created, by e.  

i've also known people who would steal and grovel for their next hit.  

what comes down to i think is that it makes you feel truly and genuinely 
happy...there have been a few times when (under its influence) some problem
or piece of static in my life would change.  it was as if the e transformed
my mentality concerning that aspect of my life.  and when the drug wore off,
and the feeling went away, there would be no more problem....i mean, it 
wouldn't look like a problem anymore.  it would look like something that
had been bugging me, wanting my attention, wanting my love.

that post about Adolf Hitler & speed keeps going around and around in my
mind...creepy!  (who was it that told us all about Hitler's daily injections
of meth?  and suggested that the Holocaust was a direct result of speed?
or maybe i read that somewhere else...sorry!)

the people that i know who would steal and grovel for their next e experi-
ence were just going through a crazy period in their lives and got over it
eventually.  as far as i'm concerned, they were looking for a way to feel
some love.  

one last thing:  i don't really care if e does some kind of irreparable
damage physically... it used to worry me some, but not any more.  the
benefits make up for all that.  the chance to feel like an angel for an
hour or two was worth it!

peace, love & buckets of e to you all!!!

-anthrax

I wouldn't be so hard on the Zippies.  There are some good folks involved
and it's clear that Megatripolis is a very happening thing in the ferment
of the UK club scene.  But nevertheless, their spokespeople have a chronic
problem reining in their hype.  crunch, bless 'im, gave us a great and
realistic view of what they are doing in his Rainbow Gathering report.

Quite frankly, I think that the arrival of Mark Heley and the Wicked
crew and others from the UK in the early 1990s in SF, and more recently
the visitation by the DIY crew last year and the forthcoming transplantation
of the Third Floor crew (Digit, EFX, Buck) to the UK for a while have and
will have far greater implications for the development of a GOOD scene
with global interconnections.  And you know what, we're part of that 
with our mailing lists and vrave.  I'm glad the Zippies are participating
in these same tides of change.  But instead of preaching how house and
techno are going to change the global zeitgeist, I'd rather get on wit
the business and fun of doing it.  And letting the quality of our scene
and music speak for themselves.

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9407131710.AA28712@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: concerning *e*
Cc: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Anthrax shares:
>...there have been a few times when (under its influence) some problem
>or piece of static in my life would change. it was as if the e transformed
>my mentality concerning that aspect of my life. and when the drug wore off,
>and the feeling went away, there would be no more problem....i mean, it 
>wouldn't look like a problem anymore.  it would look like something that
>had been bugging me, wanting my attention, wanting my love.
 
Ann, what I find so encouraging about your observation is how you clearly
see that your experience doesn't make the "problem" go away, but instead
gives you a more positive perspective on it.  The key here is that the
"problem" still demands you attention.  In other words, you do not use mdma 
as an escape.  In fact, you might even be more likely to take action now
that your perspective on it is a more positive one.
 
Unfortunately, I have known people who use mdma simply as just another
feel-good high; as a way to more easily avoid difficult issues in their
lives; a way to happily continue along a path to nowhere; a path of both
self-avoidance and the avoidance of many difficult aspects of the world
around them.  
 
So much seems to depend on how a person is predisposed to begin with.  Many
people seek to explore, to grow, to reach out - but are held back by deep
psychological pain.  I've seen such people have their lives transformed
by the liberating nature of the mdma experience.  There seem to be others 
who are more predesposed to hiding from the responsibilities and challenges 
that normally come with living a varied and growth-oriented life.  For such 
people, mdma seems to do little more than perpetuate a lifestyle that, IMO, 
rarely leads to happiness for themselves and does little to benefit the 
world that supports them.
 
Fortunately, I think most, or a sizeable minority of people are curious 
about what the world has to offer and what kind of role they can have in
it.  Most people want to be able to love themselves and others around them,
but have been trained by society (sometimes justifiably) to distrust 
instead.  But humans as a species tend to be curious and want to understand 
things.  And because such positive predispositions seen to be buried within 
so many of us, I generally agree with your assessment that
 
"...doses of e, appropriately administered, would transform the world."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Precedence: bulk


Here's a quick rundown of what's around...

In San Francisco --

Tweekin' Records (on Haight near Steiner), 415-626-6995
	good selection of house and acid jazz 12" and CDs

BPM Music Factory (1141 Polk, between Post and Sutter), 415-567-0BPM
	good selection of house 12" and CDs and DJ mix tapes

Gaia Mantra (on Valencia near 16th), email mantra@netcom.com
	good selection of techno and trance 12"s, a few CDs

Record Rack (corner of 18th Street and Sanchez), 415-552-4990
	good selection of commerical house and club music, 12" and CDs

Star Alley
	good selection of commercial hip-hop and house 12" and CDs

Ameba (on Haight, west of Cole)
Housewares (on Haight, east of Masonic)
	Both are clothing stores that carry some CDs and DJ mix tapes



In the East Bay...

Primal Records (2420 Parker, at Telegraph), 510-548-8511
	good selection of house and tribal 12"s -- the current hot place
	for DJs to shop right now.  Some CDs also.

Mod Lang (on University, about a block from campus)
	small dance section, but since everyone shops at Primal, Primal
	will often be sold out of titles that Mod Lang will still have in stock.

Alex and Klea will happily recommend trance/acid/ambient music for you

I wanted to add a note from my own personal experience, it just 
wasn't one I saw expressed yet.

I used meth every weekend (and only then) for about 2 1/2 months during 
the summer in Santa Cruz, that being one of the only times that lovely 
town has enough employment. I can honestly say that it did no perceptible 
harm whatsoever. I worked like a fiend and had the fortitude I needed to 
survive two tourism-based jobs, and I even enjoyed the experience. It was 
a little hard to eat, but that wasn't much trouble. I didn't sleep for 
two or three days, but heck, I can do that w/o help anyway.

I should also point out that I wasn't smoking it-- I don't know if that's 
relevant or not.

My first E experience left me feeling oddly depressed for a few days, but 
I think that might have been the absence of the person I had been with 
while on it. It hasn't recurred subsequently.

Peace.

Maui

There is a solution to Sean's dilemma:

* Go to SPAZ -- it gets over around 2am, right?  We're going to start 
	around midnight.

* At 2am call (415)-985-5244 to check the directions.

* JUST to be safe, check "the usual spot" on your way out of town.

* Join us after SPAZ at Liquid Air, and bring everyone!  

Laura

From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 1994 11:32:25 PST

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Burning Man news article
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was sent to me by Gigi, a net-aquaintence of mine.  Enjoy.

Laura

***********************************************************************


PAGANS AND PATRIOTS

by Gigi Bisson
Contributing Writer, Metro
Copyright 1993. Distributed with permission of author.

We're going to singe, parch, smoulder, simmer, deep fry, and burn to a crisp
in one of the world's largest frying pans.  We're traveling East to find the
West.  A lonely and lawless frontier, so uncharted and undesirable that you
can do whatever you damn well please.  

 Along with a flock of techno pagans, nature-lovers, hippies, full-moon
crazies, performance artists and ravers from the Silicon Valley, San
Francisco, and Los Angeles we made the eight-hour pilgrimage to the northwest
Nevada desert.  My travel partner, partly for shock value, partly for reality
check,  announces our plans to strangers.

"We're going to the Black Rock desert to watch a group of people burn a
40-foot tall wooden man. You heard of it?" he asks waitresses and gas
attendants.

"Are they a bunch of satanists?"
"Sounds like that horror movie, 'The Wicker Man.'"
"Is that some sort of religious festival?"  

We didn't even mention the 30-foot fiberglass dachsund head, stolen from a
Doggie Diner restaurant in San Francsco, hauled out there on a flatbed truck
and crowned with a ring of glowing neon.  The man was wierd enough. The very
idea of building a magnificent four-story effigy and burning it to a crisp. 

An hour out of Reno, we climb over the Sierras. The land dries up and
flattens out, turns from green to gold to brown to beige. In Gerlach,
 outpost of bars, slot machines and taxidermy shops, we stop for ice.
  Stuffed bighorn sheep, coyote, fox and mountain lion line the highway.   I
glance at the official Burning Man topographic map.  Like the Cancer scare on
a cigarettes pack, a rectangle in the corner reads: 

"WARNING: Black Rock Desert may be hazardous to your health. Vehicles may
become mired in unconsolidated terrain.  Should you stray from the path,
remember: Help is NOT around the corner.  People have died here." 

"Do not rely on your odometer or compass. All objects -- humans, cars, our
encampment -- drastically diminish in the scale of the desert.  Lights array
themselves in random and confusing patterns.  Any point may be four, 40 or
should you happen to fix on a star, 400 billion miles distant."

The Black Rock Desert, a prehistoric lakebed that forms the largest flat
expanse in North America stretches to our right. In the distance, spectacular
plumes of dust rise twenty feet above the surface and streak East across the
playa like jet exhaust.   We see a tiny black-lettered cardboard sign:

"BURNING MAN ---->"

They say if you were placed in a dark, silent room and all stimulation was
removed, you would begin to hallucinate within an hour. It's the principle
behind a flotation tank. It's principle behind the desert.  

A black van ahead of us skirts the horizon, disappears into a mirage of heat
haze, hovers and then shrinks into a black sphere that floats above the sand.


Dust plumes streak across the hard-packed white alkaline dust lined with a
fine lacework of cracks. As far as the eye can see. Nothing. Not even a
tumbleweed. Then barren violet mountains in the distance.  We floor it, and
streak across the desert at 70 miles per hour. 

Suddenly, we see BLACK ROCK TRAUMA CENTER, an egg-shaped aluminum trailer,
with bones, kerosene lamps and feathers dangling from the door. A sign warns
that broadcast media will be taping this event. A craggy hippie in a cowboy
hat asks us for our $40 registration fee and directs us on the last part of
our journey. 

"Stake everything down. We had 40 mph winds yesterday. And at night, watch
out for the acid heads driving 90 miles an hour without headlights on, man,"
he says.

 The camp shimmers in the distance. Desert Navigational Locators, a series of
eight sculptures made by William Binzen of rusting potato mashers and
institutional egg beaters, form gateways marking a compass of four
directions. This inner circle is surrounded by an outer circle of vans, land
yachts, Airstream trailers, candy-colored nylon domes and Port-o-Potties. 

A hollow conch-shaped mud sculpture by Pepe Lauzan rises dramatically to the
South, the neon-haloed Dog Head marks the West. And on an axis exactly 15
degrees North of due East, the Burning Man lies in state, with the largest
blank canvas in North America behind him.  Up close and personal, he's a puny
framework of plywood, glued and stapled together.  Like Cher or Madonna, the
icon seems larger in photographs.

Invite 1,000 of America's most helplessly urban people on a  camping trip to
America's most forbidding wilderness, and this is what you get. Sweltering in
black leather with no words like "dehydration" or "sunstroke" in their
vocabulary, staggering barefoot, swigging cappuccino.  Women dance topless
and men wear skirts, oblivious to the threat of sunburn.

They transform Nevada desert into California beach. Just add water. An
"Arabian shiek" wearing a cloak fashioned from designer sheets pedals
aimlessly on a mountain bike.  People circle listlessly in ATVs, dune
buggies, tricycles, skateboards, rollerskates, scooters. A guy skims across
the playa in a deranged landsailer: a four-wheeled plastic horse with a
windsail. Four guys in turbans slumber in a striped tent with a bank of
panels to run the solar refrigerator. 

It's soon apparent that the well-intentioned schedule in the brochure is part
mirage as well. A vaguely African head made of chicken wire, scrap lumber and
copper sheeting marks the center of town.  The "cafe" turns out to be a
Monkey Bean Espresso truck.  A press truck holds a Macintosh computer, a
laser printer, a Xerox photocopier.  A truck topped with antennas and loaded
with high tech equipment forms the pirate radio station, but when we tune
into 89.9 FM, nothing but irritating feedback hum materializes.

The temporal community gathers around a message board near the
satellite-dish-topped Greyhound bus in the center. In the early days, the
bedrock of support came from the Cacaphony Society, a group of anarchic
performance artists and costumers.  Louis Brill, a Cacaphony member,
overlapped the event into another group, YLEM (pronounced eye-lem) an
organization of artists using science and technology that includes Dr.
Clifford Pickover of the IBM Thomas Watson Research Laboratory, and Roger
Malina of the Center for Extreme Ultraviolet Astrophysics on its board of
advisors. 

Flyers are posted for other organizations that now converge here, each with
its own interpretation of the desert. A nature group called Outdoors
Unlimited, a group of conservationationists known as the Desert Survivors, an
Activist BBS. (If you accept the "Official Version " of anything, you are a
danger to yourself and humanity. Call for the latest on FBI, CIA, KGB, DEA,
KKK, FOIA, INS, IRS, JFK, MLK.")  A want ad bluntly advertises the desires of
at least one of the ravers and Deadheads present: "I'm looking for some
'Shrooms. Anybody want to sell some?" 

In the afternoon heat, thermals rise and cause dust devils -- swirling
dervishes of dust that spiral like tiny tornados across the sand.  Winds of
40 miles per hour suddenly rip tarps and shade awnings.  It's miserable. You
can't even keep the dirt out of your beer.  

Every third resident of Black Rock seems to be making a documentary.  I've
been out of the car for less than half an hour when a man thrusts a mike into
my face.

"I'm just looking for the definitive statement on what this all means," he
asks. 

I'm too drained by the stifling heat to mumble something about a strange
succession of mirrors.

We are the burning man. Everything becomes performance art. We suspend
disblief when we walk into the theater.  A tent called The Oasis sports an
indoor recirculating water fountain decorated with plastic snakes.  I tour
the Christmas Tent, strewn with tinsel and garlands. The hostess invites me
to visit later for eggnog, caroling and fruitcake.  Chrismas Muzak is piped
throughout the village and a guy in a red and green kilt and a Santa in a
cotton beard pass out candy canes.  

When the sun sinks into gold, crimson and orange, and a huge yellow moon
rises, the playa cools and settles into a surrealistic neon Las Vegas
carnival.  Various sculptures are ignited and sacrificed.   The doghead is
rimmed with stagelights, the generators hum, and it's transformed into a
stage alive with a halo of neon.  

Dozens of people line up, and tug of war-style, raise the man. Suddenly, his
hollow body is outlined in a dazzling skeleton of glowing blue neon framed in
a fuselage that seems, in the mirage of light, to be a wire-framed,
computer-generated graphic.  His head, a faceless kite-shaped Japanese paper
lantern, is aglow with blue.  Standing on the low horizon, he takes on a
prodigous proportion.  With the aid of technology, a lone man in the
wilderness is suddenly visible for miles.  

A Lost In Space fashion show features "shapes that time forgot."  A throbbing
circle of drummers, people playing tubas, horns, pots and pans forms, and the
costumed dance one by one. An alien, a teradactyl skeleton, a grim reaper or
two, dance in the center, ringed with popping flashbulbs.  

Recognizing the succession of mirrors, someone yells: "Hey, let's get the
video guys in here." Suddenly, a dozen videographers, including the PBS crew,
a super 8 camera, and a guy with a bizarre handmade video camera encased in
an aluminum box, bob in the circle, filming each other.

Time for the "Fire Tree" sculpture/performance: A bonfire is lit inside the
mud-covered shell.  Flames shoot out of the top, which looks like a hollow
glove stretched skyward.  The crowd whoops and chants, drumming, and
spinning. While standing near the center of the mud volcano, one of the
sculptors is nearly sacrificed as the tree colapses on to itself and flames
shoot out of its cracked molten fingers. 

People gather and stare into a neon crop circle, 50 feet in diameter of
glowing red, blue and green broadcasting to some distant UFO in the night
sky. A confused dog stumbles on the circle and is electrified, but not
sacrificed.

At midnight, a rave begins a half mile north of camp.  Follow the strobe
light. The night turns to Burning Jam.  

The Burning Man is the creation of Larry Harvey, who specifically disavows
any spiritual meaning, yet speaks fervently about the Man.  Eight years ago,
Harvey was looking for a way to cheer himself up after a relationship broke
up.  On a whim, he decided to burn a wooden man on the San Francisco beach
during summer solstice.  He called his friend, carpenter Jerry James, and
they knocked together an eight-foot-tall figure, gathered a dozen friends on
the beach, and burned it.  The sight of the man, arms blazing against the
night sky was far more moving than they anticipated.  Each year the Man grew
larger. By the fifth year, the police arrived in time to stop the burning,
and nearly caused a riot.   

They moved the Man away from the law, to the Black Rock Desert.  "Life seems
infinitely precious against that cosmically vast waste," Harvey says.
 "Everything that is, is more intensely so." 

 The Burning Man finally broke even last year, and Harvey reputedly hopes to
eventually make a living off the festival.  He talks of adding to the
spectacle next year, including Laser lights and a Tesla coil generating
man-made lightning. 

"We're primal technology. The ritual is derived directly from technical
requirements, and the logic of engineering the Man," Harvey says.  Last year,
he was invited to exhibit a slide show of the Burning Man at Cyberarts in Los
Angeles.  "A lot of cyberpeople come here,"  he says. 

The growth is a point of contention among the old timers, including Binzen,
who feels the festival has grown dangerously large.  Now the Bureau of Land
Management is demanding $2 per head as rent.  

In response, Binzen started Desert Siteworks, a more personal,
invitation-only performance work that focuses on ritual and art.   "As you
get more deeply into ritual, you relate to the movements of the desert,
working with desert navigation, creating alignments and time-based
performances," he says, talking of car lights creating patterns on the playa,
processions of candles, Stonehenge-like arrangements of sculpture mapped to
the heavens, and sand drawings that work as a matrix that helps us understand
how we fit into the cosmos.

***

The rising sun emerges from the Man's outspread legs. As the day progresses,
it traverses his spine, and exits through the top of his head. Sunday begins
with the Ancient Rite of the Java Cow.  When all the cups have been filled at
the Miraculous and Ever-Flowing Udder, the Cow addresses the crowd with her
ritual greeting: " Do you want cream and sugar with your coffee?" and the
congregation responds as one: "No we want it black."  

We hear of a hot spring, and with vague directions, head East past the Man,
toward the imposing Black Rock on the horizon, speeding away from the
anarchic urban madness and back into nowhere.  Ten, maybe 20 miles away,
across the railroad tracks, we sink into Trego Hot Springs, a warm creek
surrounded with vibrant green grass.  Naked bodies slick with sulphurous
black mud crackle in the sun.  

Remnants from Desert Siteworks litter the springs -- a semicircle of
descending railroad ties called "Woodhenge," and posts topped with sculptural
faces.  We continue on to Bordello Springs, a pristine pool surrounded by a
lone clump of trees and lush asparagus ferns.  

Here, the lawless soak together.  A man dressed in khaki unbuckles his gun
holster and slips in.  A guy from Boulder Creek with two pierced nipples
tells me about the loaded shotgun he found a few yards away.  "I'm thinking
of burning it with the man tonight. Or maybe I'll keep it," he says.  A group
of model rocketeers describe a 15-foot rocket, mislaunched this morning, that
shot back into the playa.  It's now buried eight feet under, and they're
trying to figure out how to extract $2,000 worth of metal from the hardpan
alkali.   A couple of guys called Desert Rats swagger in, one carrying an
automatic rifle.  A guy from Oregon asks if he can fire it, and suddenly, the
desert quiet is punctured with Ramboesque gunfire. 

By the time we head out, angry clouds gather on the mountains.  Thunder
rumbles. Racing toward the camp, racing against the dwindling light, we're
suddenly adrift in a horizonless white ocean.  Clouds hide the stars.  My
compass points West, but we forget how far South we drove.

This is the widest unpatrolled highway in North America.  It's nothing
compared to the 3,500,000 square miles of arridity that make up the Sahara,
but the 1,000 square mile Black Rock Desert ranks as one of top 30 deserts on
earth. Explored by John Charles Fremont in the 1840s on his way to the Santa
Clara Valley, and crossed by the historic Applegate-Lassen Trail, the route
of the 49ers, some sections are apparently littered at 50-foot intervals with
 the graves of infants who died when pioneer wagon trains lost in the winter
snows.  The warning rattles my brain: "People have died here."

 For an hour we race around in circles, heading toward hazy encampments that
appear and disappear on the horizon.  Finally, a flare shoots up in the
Southwest, and race toward it, knowing that the man will burst into flames
any minute now.  Finally, we see it, a blue haze, and the man begins to grow.
 

We screech to a halt behind the man. The crowd has swelled and tripled, and
white lights creep toward him from all directions as locals risk the night
drive to witness the spectacle. 

The crowd writhes to the steady drumbeat in evening gowns, tuxedos, feathered
Mardi Gras costumes, masks, Cyalume light sticks, LEDs and bare skin. Last
year, Brewster Kahle, a WAIS, inc. employee, exchanged wedding vows with his
wife
 while the man burned.

One by one, people volunteer to strip off their shirts and a woman in a
feathered headdress douses them with alcohol and torches their bodies.  A man
and woman rise and shoot flaming arrows into the man's loins.  The drumming
rises, the crowd whoops and hollers in an inebriated frenzy.  It's every bit
as tribal, pagan and halucinatory as Mardi Gras, Carnival, a Grateful Dead
concert. Torchbearers touch the man with flares and WHOOOSH! he's human
effigy flambe. 

Loaded with cheap fireworks, and popping neon tubes, the man starts to
explode. He colapses on his back, and a flurry of sparks drift in the sky.
 People begin jumping over the Man, and a woman slips and falls into the
embers, her dress bursting into flames. 

Lightening ripples like a Tesla coil cranked by a speed-crazed organ grinder,
bright as daylight. The Man is upstaged by a circle of raw electricity.  Rain
pelts us, turning the dust into tenacious clay and a dust storm whips up,
dumps baby powder from the heavens and blots the scene with a whiteout.
 Nature bats last.

"You're gonna turn white," a man standing by a truck covered with CB antennas
says.  A local, he owns a ranch and opal mine to the north.  "There are
probably police infiltrators in this crowd," he says. "The FBI and DEA's
probably here." He tells tales of drug-laden airplanes landing in the dead of
night, yuppies making cattle drives across the desert just like the one in
the movie City Slickers, fights with the BLM over mineral rights.  "They'd
just as soon git rid of all of us," he says. "If this rain keeps up, you
won't even git out with four-wheel drive. I've walked out of this desert
before," he says.  "You better go."

We follow an exodus out of the desert, through the blinding dust,
hydroplaning on the slick mud. I look in the mirror and I'm Betelgeuse -- a
ghost with dust white skin and hair.  As we escape the whirling anarchic
madness, I still ask why. 

Struggling to explain the question of the Man, I talked to my friend Diego, a
student of things mystical.  "Somewhere, back in their common consciousness,
they remember Lugh, the the summer horned god, child of light," Diego says.
"He dies so we may live."  In pre-Christian cultures, a man woven of straw
with loaves of bread inside was burned and the bread then fed to the village.
The druids also sacrificed humans who were burned alive so the crop would be
fruitful the next year.  "The Burning Man also sybolizes the death of love,"
he says.  "In their act of love, he is consumed." 

 Throughout history, old forms of religion are superseded by new, and the new
forms use the most modern technology available to them to propagate. If so,
what is the crop we are promised when the Neon God burns? Commemorative
T-shirts? Video footage? Software?

Or perhaps just an escape. I keep remembering what the rocket man said while
I was soaking in the hot springs. "You know, a lot of different people are
out here at Black Rock this weekend," he said in a Nevada drawl. "You have
the rocketeers.  You have the racketeers. You have the Desert Survivors.  You
have the Desert Rats.  You have the Burning Man people.  And we have
something in common.  We all like fire."

Im sort of suprised to hear all of this negative talk
about the zippies...  Of course I know nothing about
them, and maybe everything is all true...

But it reminds me a lot of how my freinds who arent
into "the house scene" talk about raves/ravers.
If we expect others not involved with house parties etc.
to let us all party ANd at the same time, not bash
our heads, shouldnt we let those zippies do their thing...?

and not bash them ?

Of course this isnt "their city" so maybe they should
all go home, 
But then I only know three or four people who were born in
sf...  So I guess everyone else I know that lives there
would have to go home too.....hmmmmmm.

Just kidding, but really, my non "raver" freinds sound
a lot like these posts about how lame the zippies are...

In-Reply-To: <m0qO93M-0003V0C@taz.hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9407131231.A15912-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Actually, if you have the time, I'd recommend digging through many of the 
primarily used stores in the city. Techno and house are spread a little 
wider than you'd initially think. 

Streetlight on Market has a large 12" and LP section (new/used) and I ran 
a couple Plastikman and CJ Bolland singles among others, with the import 
of Quoth, a Seefeel promo, and an old Ink! copy of SevHeads "Dead Eyes 
Opened." Lots of white labels and test pressings, but unfortunately, no 
turntable to try them out. They also sell brand new cds with printing 
errors on the disc art for less than normal used prices. They play just 
fine and are even guaranteed to do so. On the nostalgia wave I picked up 
RSW's In Dub and Soundclash for $3.95 each. Lost both of these in the 
"great cd swipe of 91" and kept fogetting to re-buy them. They have some 
interesting new stuff as well but all the techno is located in the 
R&B/Soul section. Wierd.

Record Finder around the corner from Tower on Market has a small used
12"/techno section in the back. Nabbed a HartHouse comp and a Juno 
Reactor single there. Also picked up my Scanner and B12 cds used there.

There are many more in the city and East Bay, but these are the ones I 
hit most frequently, being only a short trip down Market. Happy digging!

jmar! flipflipflipflipflipflipflip yes! flipflipflipflip...

KEN STUART <KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org> asked me to post this on the net.  
I got it out of "Feel", the newsletter produced by Martin and the gang.  
I really liked it, and I think you will, too.  
---------- Forwarded message ---------- 
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 1994 11:14:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
To: KEN STUART <KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org>
Cc: deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu
Subject: Some Signs & Symptoms of Inner Peace

Yes, there is a list of this in "Feel".  Here it is:

1.  Tendency to think and act spontaneously rather than from fears based 
on past experiences.

2.  An unmistakable ability to enjoy each moment.

3.  Loss of interest in judging other people.

4.  Loss of interest in judging self.

5.  Loss of interest in interpreting actions.

6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

7.  Loss of ability to worry.  (this is a very serious symptom)

8.  Frequent, overwhelming episodes of appreciation.  

9.  Contented feeling of connectedness with others and nature.

10.  Frequent attacks of smiling through the eyes of from the heart.  

11.  Increasing tendency to let things happen rather than make them 
happen.  

12.  Increase susceptibility to love extended by others as well as the 
uncontrollable urge to extend it.  

enjoy!
dj fog

PS, I would also like to add that inner peace doesn't cost $20, $25, $10, 
$5, $3, or even 25 cents.  Inner peace is free, because it comes from 
within yourself.  But because it comes from within, you have to make it 
happen for you.

>        Two comments:
>
>        To Larry:  Along with the steady *riiiiiiing* that I get with the
>tinnitus, I also occasionally get the pure sinusodal tone, too and often
>wondered what it was.  I guess I've got the same question -- does anyone
>know what this is? (fluid rolling around in your inner ear?)
>

Your ear is actually producing that tone (at the frequency you are about
to lose some sensitivity to), if someone stuck a mic near the outside of
your ear 
when you heard the tone, they could pick it up .

i agree with susie about the zippy "movement."  the fact that they a re
trying to publicize their thang is a bad sign.  publicizing just brings
it to the attention of the authorities, necessitating such measures as
security, much more subterfuge for those who wish to indulge in mind
candy, etc.  in my experience, keeping parties hidden from view of the
general populace, which doesn't much approve of what we do for whatever
reasons, is a key element for success.  im trying to keep an open mind,
of course, but....if the zippies are primarily motivated by greed, then
i don't want to have anything to do with them.

-anthrax

I don't sense that the Zippies are motivated by greed.  In fact, to the
extent that there are self-identified Zippies at all (and I'd be surprised
if more than a few dozen people actually describe themselves that way),
they seem to be motivated by the desire to get attention.

The whole thing seems like an elaborate prank to me, the only difference
between this and, say, the Merry Pranksters of the Kesey/Babbs/Cassidy
era is that the Zippies don't want to admit that's what they are doing.

I'm all for pranksterism, don't get me wrong.  But this all reminds me
of the apocryphal story, perhaps originally from the French Revolution,
where someone at a sidewalk cafe sees a crowd rushing up the avenue
and yells, "Wait for me, I am your leader!"

ACLU, the League of Women Voters, or the Rainbow people.  The
oppressors are strong, we need to stick together and not quibble
over reletively minor differences.

The druids also sacrificed humans who were burned alive so the crop would be
fruitful the next year.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Just to clarify, this is actualy debated among scholars and mystics.  Some
say they did, some say they didn't.  Those that say they did also add that
those burned were criminals convicted of heinous crimes, as Druids were
not just mystics but historians, lawyers, judges, jailers, and possibly
executioners all rolled into one.

-Winston

In the list of "Signs and Symptoms of Inner
Peace" I would exclude just one:

 
6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

because the spiritual leaders with inner 
peace that I admire had a *lot* of interest
in conflict:

Gautama Buddha

Jesus the Christ

Mohandas K. Gandhi

Etc.

I would substitute:

6.  Loss of interest in editing minutiae such
as obvious typos on email


Ciao,
Will

I wanted to add a note from my own personal experience, it just
wasn't one I saw expressed yet.

I used meth every weekend (and only then) for about 2 1/2 months during
the summer in Santa Cruz, that being one of the only times that lovely
town has enough employment. I can honestly say that it did no perceptible
harm whatsoever. I worked like a fiend and had the fortitude I needed to
survive two tourism-based jobs, and I even enjoyed the experience. It was
a little hard to eat, but that wasn't much trouble. I didn't sleep for
two or three days, but heck, I can do that w/o help anyway.

I should also point out that I wasn't smoking it-- I don't know if that's
relevant or not.

My first E experience left me feeling oddly depressed for a few days, but
I think that might have been the absence of the person I had been with
while on it. It hasn't recurred subsequently.

Peace.

Maui
============================================================================

Different bodies, different habits, different effects.  This should always
be taken as a granted.

I know plenty of people who use it recreationaly or for work on an
occasional basis with little or no side effects at all.

BUT....

I have enough experience and wisdom on this matter to say:

If you use it consistently for extended periods of time, and especialy if
you use it I.V., you WILL have medium to BIG problems, I guarantee.

I have never seen official studies but have seen more than enough
not-coincidental cases of users developin skin infections and sores
to make a corelation.

I have seen people who I know to be psychologicly "normal" (if there is
such a thing ;-) go way out after heavy use.  Of course they go back
to being there old selves after about 3 days to a month of abstinence.
I have also seen people who were a little psychologicly abnormal go even
further out on the abnormality spectrum.  This includes a recent case
of my mother-in-laws now ex-boyfriend, normaly a very humble and non-
violent person who is now in jail for hitting her and then hitting a
police officer over the head with another police officer's baton.  Prior
to this he told me that "they" were transmitting "programs" to his
brain at night-time through some sort of frequency similar to TV and FM,
that his sores and skin legions were caused by iritations from implants
that "they" had implanted - including the one he retrieved and saved
that he showed me that I believe was a hair folicle, and hundereds of
other paranoid stories.  He became loud, beligerant, obnoxious, and
paranoid of everybody and everything.  I could type pages of these stories
about him and a whole bunch of others I have known in the last 10 years.

I do know one person who has been a heavy user for 10 years has no
dicernable pysical or psycholical effects and never gets sick.  I
often joke with him that germs and virus can't live in his chemical-
laden body.  But, his problem is simple yet profound.  He parties and
raves so much that he's often late or just sleeps all day through work
during his one day after four days recovery and he can't hold a job.

I don't believe that there's been enought time to see if nuerolgical or
other damage occurs long term from this kind of use.

They say speed was the demise of the Haight-Ashbury scene or the greater
hippy scene in general.  I don't know if you can realy pin-point that one
thing but blames a funny thing.  People like to say it's not the drugs
it's the people who abuse them but you can also truthfully say the people
wouldn't have done that/been like that if it weren't for the drugs.  Or 
that the drugs wouldn't have done that to the people if the people weren't
using them.

Anyway, be forwarned.  Out of the many people I have known, none of them
have used heavily and not had medium-big problems in their lives that
they would not have had, had they not been using heavily.

These are just some personal observations and experiences that I feel
are important to those less familiar to know.  And I should also add
that these are moderate to heavy users and I'm not some sort of crusader
because I've seen friends/family ruin their lives.  I even occasionaly
indulge myself.

-Winston

California and Arizona areas that have reported swirving in their
cars because the passenger seats of their cars were possessed by the
"Angel Gabriel" saying that he will return on this Saturday (the
second coming?).  The friend who told me this claimed that it had
happened to her (she sounded VERY serious) and the cop who pulled her
over immediately let her off because she was the 8th person that day
to report it happening!

people who are attempting to be and look like a punker.
hmm?

I think it is a bit unfair to call the Zippies greedy. This is not 
readily apparent to me from their publicity. i can understand a certain 
degree of skepiticsm regaring the matter but would also say that we 
should reserve judgement until we know a bit more. I know that one of 
the orignal zippies Fraser Clark is actually pretty cool. He has 
published a magazine called "Encyclopedia Psycedelica" since the mid 
'70's and also put out a colcool cd called "Shamanarchy In the UK". Two 
personal friends of mine have hung out/interviewd Fraser and have said 
that he seems to be reputable and knowledgable in various areas.

Just cuz there was a big thing in Wired (and other mags) doesn't mean 
there media mavens.

Ronan

Topic  82 [wired]:  the Zippies
#149 of 149: John Bagby (cubensis)      Mon Jul 11 '94 (18:15)    74 lines

 KESEY PASSES MANTLE TO ZIPPIES

 Independence Day, 1994
 Boulder, Colorado

 The Zippy Pronoia Tour to US stayed in Boulder a little longer
 than intended,  causing speculation at their planned destination-
 the Rainbow Gathering in western  Wyoming.  By invitation from the
 Naropa Institute, the Zippies hosted a late-night  4th of July
 rave at the Boulder Theater, keeping them in Colorado an extra few
 days.   It was worth it.

 The Zippy event began after a performance by Ken Kesey and the
 Merry Pranksters, in  honor of Allen Ginsberg's 70th birthday and
 Naropa's 20th Anniversary.  A stunned  and revved-up crowd came
 together on stage to dance to the ambient sounds of the  Zippy
 group Universal Sound.

 Around three a.m., Kesey pulled from his parking space to find a
 crowd of Zippies  blocking his white Cadillac convertible.  A
 bespeckled Zippy stepped toward the car  and said: "Ken Kesey, the
 Zippy Pronoia Tour hereby kidnaps you for transport to the
 Rainbow Gathering-- a prank worthy of your pronoia.  Will you come
 along  peacefully?"

 Kesey paused and frowned as his posse of pranksters roared at the
 suggestion.  "I've  bitten the ankle of the beast," replied Kesey
 to the befuddled Zippies,  "Don't ask  me to bite where you want
 to bite."

 "What about inspiring the next generation?"  The Zippies asked.

 "I've done that movie... it's your turn." Kesey pronounced,
 roaring off in the Cadillac.

 The Zippies scratched their heads for a few moments, then piled
 into  their vehicles and called the Associated Press via cellular
 on the road to the  Rainbow Gathering.

 The mantle has been passed.
 _________________________________________________

 ZIPPIES SYNERGIZE WITH NATIONAL RAINBOW GATHERING
 July 6, 1994
 Big Piney, Wyoming

 The Zippy Pronoia Tour to U rumbled through the Wyoming
 wilderness to arrive at the  annual national rendezvous of the
 American Rainbow Family.  Late from a last-minute gig in Boulder
 with Ken Kesey and Allen Ginsberg, the Zippies had a good excuse
 for tardiness.

 Although the Rainbow Gathering had reached it's climax a few days
 before, the Zippies rallied some of the core 6000 Rainbows who
 remained to throw the first-ever rave at a Rainbow Gathering.
 During the last five years in Britain, the Zippies gained momentum
 and strength by  achieving "festi-rave crossover" between the UK
 rave and nomadic festival subcultures. The formula worked even
 better in America.  The hippy-ish Rainbows generally shun
 technology, but were drawn by the siren's call of the Zippy sound
 system set up by the main parking field.  The ambient Zippy set,
 mixed with tribal  drumming and vocals, kept the strange mix of
 dancers ecstatic through to sunrise.

 The Zippies joined the main circle of the Rainbow Council, ate
 some organic  vegetarian food, and huddled together with the
 American hippies during the cold  Wyoming nights.  A debate over
 the uses of technology and the purpose of media hype  continued
 around the campfires, from the original Rainbow/Zippy discussions
 begun in cyberspace in the spring.

 ________
 Just wait until we  connect on the dance floor with our west coast
 co-conspirators.

Will writes:
>In the list of "Signs and Symptoms of Inner
>Peace" I would exclude just one:
>
>
>6.  Loss of interest in conflict.
>
>because the spiritual leaders with inner
>peace that I admire had a *lot* of interest
>in conflict:
>
>Gautama Buddha
>
>Jesus the Christ
>
>Mohandas K. Gandhi
>
>Etc.

Actually none of those people had any *interest* in conflict.

Their only interest was the love inside themselves and everyone else.

However, they did not *shun* conflict if it became necessary to
accomplish their mission.   To shun or exclude anything is to give it
importance...

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Will--

I believe when they say "loss of interest in conflict" they are referring 
to people who look for a conflict to throw themselves into, or resort to 
negative things to solve their own frustrations.  One example of this 
might be a parent that comes home from work tired and stressed and yells 
at their children because they had a bad day at work.  Clearly there are 
many valid reasons to have a conflict.  But even Gandhi and the others 
you mentioned stressed non-violent conflict.  

So perhaps I would change that to "loss of interest in violent conflict", 
but that might be creating too hard of a dividing line.  Anyone is free 
to cut/copy/paste to their liking.  

dj fog

"Did you know that the Rice Krispies highest on the bowl dry first (when 
they sit in the sink for, say, a week)?  It's because they're closer to 
the Sun."
		---George Carlin

> on us?  A strange related bit of information I  heard from a friend
> in LA is that there have been dozens of people in the southern
> California and Arizona areas that have reported swirving in their
> cars because the passenger seats of their cars were possessed by the
> "Angel Gabriel" saying that he will return on this Saturday (the
> second coming?).  The friend who told me this claimed that it had
> happened to her (she sounded VERY serious) and the cop who pulled her
> over immediately let her off because she was the 8th person that day
> to report it happening!

Well, a fellow here in town named Tim is throwing a party above 4000' so 
that a select group of groovers won't sink into the ocean like the rest 
of the west coast.  He's *guaranteeing* that he'll be beamed up that 
night.  How's that for promotion.  That's one hell of a visual, and "come 
to this party or drown" is a good tactic... :-)  This is my theory: He 
has somehow turned into memetic flypaper.  If you encounter him, he will 
lecture to you for hours on end about a massive all-inclusive conspiracy 
theory.  The only way to get out of listening to it is to walk with him 
as he explains the thing, find someone else, spend 15 minutes in a 
three-way discussion, then slip off, leaving the unsuspecting third party 
to handle him.  I'm quite convinced that he's been talking about it 
nonstop since the dead show :-)

Actuallky the whole "Some Signs & Symptoms of Inner
Peace" is a disgusting mishmash of P.C. spirituality-
babble.  Christ, Buddhsa, Gandhi, etc., *were* interested
in coinflict, interpreting actions, not just letting
things happens--to name just a few that contradict this
contempo-Pollyanna list of New Age dicta.  The aim is to 
roll over--smile, don't worry, think and act spontaneously,
etc., which funnily enough I don't find as parts of the
work or teachings of Christ, Gandhi, Buddha and spirits like
them that I've studied and admired.

It draws hairs to say they were interested in "resolving
conflicts"  (plus that sounds too ombudsmanlike for these
guides). I much prefer what one of them said--and the others
echoed in various ways--that "you shall know them by their
works," so let's look carefully at the content, results and
sources of our sayings and not be so concerned about holding
to how right our list is. Another one of the three said that
there are no teachings to ultimately grasp hold of, there is
only the way, and a third said that his three greatest
obstacles were, first his favorite the British government,
second the intransigent Indian people, and third and greatest
he himself!

ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com

From sfraves-owner  Thu Jul 14 12:23:37 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id MAA27182; Thu, 14 Jul 1994 12:23:37 -0700
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA27177; Thu, 14 Jul 1994 12:23:32 -0700
Received: from cruzio.com by scruz.net (8.3/1.34)
	id MAA06201; Thu, 14 Jul 1994 12:23:28 -0700
Subject: Zippies and Stereotypes
To: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 94 12:19:31 PDT
From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9407141822.AA28316@pilot.njin.net>; from "Sean Casey" at Jul 14, 94 2:22 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-ID:  <9407141219.aa20917@cruzio.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sean writes:

>The name "Zippies", however, is profoundly stupid sounding to me.
Whoever coined that term did a great disservice to those people s/he
were trying to categorize.

As I understand from reading and hearing the Zippies, it's
a name they apply to themselves.  We're not stereotyping
if we call people what they call themselves.  And  *that's*
the central point about stereotypes, to relate these two
current threads: if I call myself an Italian American it's
not good to call me a wop or dago or greaser or whatever.
If you look at me and call me an old fart, that compounds
the problem because not only is that not what I call myself
but you have abstracted one part--physical age in this
case--and applied it, disparagingly at that--to *all* of
me.  Thus the problem with "jock,"  "bubble gummer,"
"redneck," etc.  And there's a third troublesome area
with stereotyping and that's identification itself:
in reporting in the media even if terms like "white,"
"Mexican American," "black" or "African American" are
used they can be inflammatory because by abstracting merely
one aspect of a person's identity we reinforce already
culturally established notiions, that is, notions our own
culture has in a thousand ways already established about
categories, usually unconsciously and sometimes consciously.

Ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Once the truth is told, you never need to pretend again.
ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins  HarperSanFrancisco

Ok... so I guess all the people who were against my classifying people, anre
trying to tell me that they've never classified people, is that right?  Well I
personally find this hard to believe.  However, the fact remains that there are
people who dress like "ravers", but the furthest thing from their mind is peace
and unity.  You can't tell me that there aren't people who go to a rave  solely
for the sake of picking up chicks/guys and/or getting soused.

We've gotten way off the topic...

I agree that the underground parties tend not to attract this kind of folk, and
there for are conducive to a happy-go-lucky, peaceful and united kind of vibe. 
If that's the message of raves in general, then I'm all for it.  I like to feel
that way too, you know!  It just saddens me and can be difficult to feel that
way, when you're at a club/rave and there's some slimeball hitting on every
girl in a halter top there!

Subject: Re: Some Signs & Symptoms of P.C.ness
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
> Actuallky the whole "Some Signs & Symptoms of Inner
> Peace" is a disgusting mishmash of P.C. spirituality-
> babble.  

Will, I think "disgusting" is a bit harsh.  I feel that it would be naive 
to view SS&SIP as a set of guidelines for how the human race should be.  
Such ideas work better (for me) as a description of a (sorely neglected) 
place in our psyche  where we can let go of our preprogrammed tendencies
to focuse on our differences and on the things that separate and create 
turmoil among us.  Raving is largely about letting go of the analytical 
planned-action judgmental pragmatic focus of our energies.  We may not be 
able to live our lives according to SS&SIP, but periodic shared immersions 
into these concepts, as one of many perspectives on life, would probably
be of some benefit to everyone.  I too cringe at the sound of Dogma
barking, but there are other ways of listening to these kinds of things.

Peace, er Action, or whatever works for you,

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi Folx--

Lee suggested my use of the word "disgusting" was 
"a bit harsh," and I agree. I must say that I also
agree that in general these kinds of lists are handy
to peruse from time to time as touchstones for our own
guidance.  I disagree with the general tenor of the
11 "Signs & Symptoms," however, in that for me they
don't jibe with my own sense of the feng shuy of
higher spirituality.  They definitely come from that
current school of thought that separates inner peace
from activism, moral indignation and creating the new
dualism of bliss/blitz vs. nonviolent resistance.  I'll
happily choose the latter every time if (as the list
makes clear) and when I see the former.  Actually I
like the unity and simplicity of "Do unto to others as
you would have them do unto you" the best!

ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Once the truth is told, you never need to pretend again.
ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins  HarperSanFrancisco

hi j.c.--
 
No, the point *isn't* that we don't classify people;
it's to try to do it with intelligence and sensitivity!
 
Since the following is what you're concerned about, let's
hear you talking about:
 
> It just saddens me and can be difficult to feel that
way, when you're at a club/rave and there's some slimeball hitting on every
girl in a halter top there,
 
*That's* a *long* way from the kind of stereotyping and
namecalling that you were doing earlier!  Thank you!

From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>

Message-ID:  <9407141542.aa03961@cruzio.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lee--
 
I didn't think your piece was bad writing(you seemed to indicate that
it wasn't clear or showed some other negative influence from computer
programming work.  If someone indicated that to you in private e-mail,
maybe that person has a reading problem.  I see these forums, like sfr,
as crucibles where we worrk out our concerns and issues through as open
communication as possible.  They're radically different from any medium
we've had before because of their use of cyberspace's virtual presence.
 
Someone recently put down Doug Rushkoff's "Cyberia," and it *is* an
uneven book in terms of depth of coverage and timeliness.  But one
of the nice things he does in one chapter in the book is present and
discuss some of the unique communicatioons situations that e-mail
and the internet pose.  If someone else knows some good sources or
points about this, please come out with them.  I believe a lot of
our "flame wars," "sysop pulling the plug," and general lack of under-
standing of each other in cyberspace are related to the everyday
communications conflicts we have but *some* are unique to this medium!
 
ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Once the truth is told, you never need to pretend again.
ILLUMINATIONS   Paul & Collins  HarperSanFrancisco
