Tonight's Mushroom Jazz anniversary has just about all of the DJs who
have spun there...  Tomorrow, Liquid * is back with an all-star SFR
lineup :).  Saturday, we bid farewell to Malachy with a special 
Come-Unity...anyone have more details on Malachy?  And finally, the boat
party on Sunday should be cool...so I ought to be busy this weekend.

P.S. - note the new address for svbscribing and unsvbscribing - 
        majordomo@hyperreal.com.

> Actually I
> like the unity and simplicity of "Do unto to others as
> you would have them do unto you" the best!

I don't like it because it's not true.  (True for me: I don't believe
in Universal Truth (tm).)


I don't want other people to treat me the way they want to treat each
other -- generally with bizarre politeness ritual, groundless
suspicion mixed with naivete, and overt hostility to difference.

I don't want other people to treat me the way I treat them, because I
am not presumptuous enough to set myself up as an example.

I want people to do WHATEVER THE HELL THEY WANT.  I'll tell you if I
have a problem, and then we'll work it out.


Do what thou Wilt shall be the Whole of the Law.
Love is the Law, Love under Will.

// g

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I've been on this list pretty much since it started and I think I need
to point out that historicly Wicked is THE commonly acknowledged rageing
party of parties.  It's only lately that the classic media phenomena of
a very vocal (or in this case of e-mail, textual) minority expresses
they're opinions so much that it starts to seem like a commonly held
consensus of everyone.  This, I think happens a lot around here with
other topics and ideas too and I think it's important to keep in mind
that we are an entity of 900 different people.  If 5 people mail you
and tell you they think you suck it may seem like "everyone" thinks
you suck but keep in mind that's just 5 out of 900 people!

-Winston

>From what I've heard, the comet was broken into smaller pieces by 
gravitational flux the last time it passed by Jupiter.  Consequently, 
there are several (a dozen?) smaller pieces due to impact and varying 
times.  I'm under the impression that it should be sometime over the 
weekend; accuracy is quite variable.  But we (on Earth) should be able 
to view the impact site within 8 hours of its occurrence.  Does anyone 
know what position in the night sky Jupiter occupies currently?  It 
seemed to me that it was somewhere a little bit east of due south when 
looking about 50 degrees up at 11:00-midnight...

Mercury beausoleil.

	>>Greg

To: winston@lurnix.com (Mark Guthrie)
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 1994 17:54:41 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9407132318.AA05936@cassy.lurnix.com> from "Mark Guthrie" at Jul 13, 94 04:17:45 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL5]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1702      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   I'm glad to see that it only took you 2 and a half months to figure 
out that speed isn't the greatest things in the world to be involved in.  
That is if you have quit.  

   I was once hooked on the crap, weighed only ninety pounds, ate little 
and slept hardly at all.  I remember how it felt when i lost it, so to speak.
Now over a year latter, I am clean off speed  and  I have absolutly no 
reason to pollute my body with that poison.  Consider yourself lucky that 
you didn't end up strung out, with no money and no home.

  Quitting wasn't very hard and once you get past the three week bummer 
then everything really starts to look up.  You finally feel like a  human 
being and healthy and realize that, yes indeed there is more to life 
than finding the next line.

  Since ending this chapter in my life I have picked up record s in place 
of the straw and my life is a lot better as a result.  


  For someone who is wanting to stop the best thing to do is eat alot, 
take lots of baths, and take tyrosine, that will keep you from getting 
depressed (this cause a lot of people who are trying to quit from quitting).
Just think of how you are going to feel, when you want to go to sleep and 
you can and when your health finally returns to normal you'll be glad 
that you stopped.

As for partying, I have much more fun when I go out to partys, it is alot 
easier to make friends when you are not tweaking (inflating your ego).
most people that I know that still use this drug spend a lot of time 
talking but not listening and learning but when you are on speed you know 
everything; right?

I just wish that people would learn to slow down a bit and really enjoy life.

Tracy Ameba

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 94 10:13:15 PDT
From: winston@lurnix.lurnix.com (Mark Guthrie)
Subject: re: twentynothings

Anthrax writes:

i agree with susie about the zippy "movement."  the fact that they a re
trying to publicize their thang is a bad sign.  publicizing just brings
it to the attention of the authorities, necessitating such measures as
security, much more subterfuge for those who wish to indulge in mind
candy, etc.  in my experience, keeping parties hidden from view of the
general populace, which doesn't much approve of what we do for whatever
reasons, is a key element for success.

And I say:

I see these points but don't necesarily agree.  "They" (who seem to be a
rather nebulous entity) are just having fun throwing raves and traveling
around to see our country.  What's so wrong with that?  And since they
are a pretty nebulous group it could be said that anyone who attends
they're events is initiated as one of them ala "You will be assimilated.
Resistence is futile." {Oh shit, they've assimilated the Captain (Crunch)
already.  Can they be stopped?}  I think everyone is taking to seriously
and reading in all sorts of conspiracies and motives.  Were realy very
much the same.  How is our fairly public and advertised GG Park events
any different?  Were trying to show the public that were not so bad and
that were just into having fun and unity.

Anthrax also says:

 im trying to keep an open mind,
of course, but....if the zippies are primarily motivated by greed, then
i don't want to have anything to do with them.

And I'd like to emphasize:

This is how rumors start.  A couple people form express the (in my opinion)
premature and unfair view that they're greedy after reading something on
the net or having one personal experience with one person "claiming" to
be "affiliated" with them and then someone sees the above sentance and 
then when the conversation comes up sometime someone else says "Oh, I've
been hearing from multiple sources on the net that they're greedy".  And
then that person tells others in the next conversation "Oh, they're a
bunch of greedy fucks.", etc.  Let's keep this in perspective and keep
in mind that as far as I know only a couple of people out of 900 or so
have expressed that they think the zippies are greedy.  And I haven't
seen anyone else claim this in any magazines (Wired, etc.) or any where
else on the net.

I appologise for using you as the example, Ann, and I want to point out
that the above sentence does say "if" because she's not saying they're
greedy, shes just responding to what others have said but when people
see things like that in print a lot it starts to become credible 
because it starts to seem like a commonly expressed view.

-Winston

This is kind of uncomfortable for me, but here goes:

Malachy borrowed Susan's $5,000 video projector, and has told her he 
would track it down. He hasn't called at all. Everett Zero has it, and he
has made excuses instead of delivering. He says, "Oh, you can get it *if 
I'm awake*", which is pretty lame. It is Susan's and my opinion that both 
of these folks have been very remiss in their dealings with us. Heck, 
it's been a *very* long time since we've seen the projector-- we really 
just kept thinking we'd give everyone involved some time to get it 
together. But instead of getting it together, they have flaked off and 
made bad excuses. 

I just thought that the list ought to know what's going on before we have 
that big we-love-Malachy fest this weekend. I know someone on the list knows 
how it feels... we're just lucky we weren't in physical danger like that 
person was.

Maui

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: tsheets@VNET.IBM.COM
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 94 15:02:04 PDT
Subject: re: Jupiter

I had a Piracitam-enhanced dream about 4 days ago that I did not think
much about until I started reading about these wierd things going on
as we approach the Jupiter-asteroid day.

First, let me note that when I take Piracitam, by dreams can be ultra-vivid,
making them seem like visions instead of dreams.  Usually, I only
have positive, wonderful dreams on it, but...

Okay, I was in a van, driving down a beach.  In the van with me was
most of my immediate and much of my extended family.  This was a beach
by a large city (like Santa Monica).  I looked up into the sky, and I saw
some cosmic body, it looked a lot like another earth.  I can clearly recall
seeing green land masses and blue oceans.  Suddenly, things started to
feel wrong.  About a mile ahead of us a jumbo jet crashes into the
beach in a burst of fire and light.  The ground shakes a little.
Everyone in the car is silent, looking at each other, but we all seem
to feel the same thing.  Not a feeling of death, but instead a feeling
that each of us, all the ones we love, and the entire world as we know
it was about to be obliterated, and there was nothing anyone could do about
it.  There was not time to scream, there was not time think.  The ground
shook a bit more, and I awoke.

...And on that note, have a fun weekend, everyone!!!

-troy

On Thu, 14 Jul 1994, Greg Richards wrote:

> 
> >From what I've heard, the comet was broken into smaller pieces by 
> gravitational flux the last time it passed by Jupiter.  Consequently, 
> there are several (a dozen?) smaller pieces due to impact and varying 
> times.  I'm under the impression that it should be sometime over the 
> weekend; accuracy is quite variable.  But we (on Earth) should be able 
> to view the impact site within 8 hours of its occurrence.  Does anyone 
> know what position in the night sky Jupiter occupies currently?  It 
> seemed to me that it was somewhere a little bit east of due south when 
> looking about 50 degrees up at 11:00-midnight...


Greg et al:

Jupiter is currently visible at approximately 5 degrees Scorpio, which can
be found by estimating where the sun is currently (assuming it has set of
course) then adding about 120 degrees. For example, if it is midnight, the
sun is roughly 90 degrees below the horizon, or "at 6 o'clock" (not the 
time - the position relative to you if your position was the center of 
a clock). Every 30 degrees equals one hour on the clock, so Jupiter 
would be found "2 o'clock high" or at 30 degrees above the western horizon.


The first collision is expected on Saturday night with the largest 
fragment crashing into the Great One on Wednesday.  In any event, I 
expect the best views will come from the Hubble Telescope, which 
photographed the comet on it's next pass following it's being shattered. 
I have a pretty amazing JPG or GIF image made from composite Hubble 
photos of the same.  They're most remarkable, and I'd be happy to put 
them into the sfraves archives if someone will send me some data on where 
to upload and how.  I have full net capability with all of the basic 
protocols.

BTW, if anyone is looking for somewhere to go tomorrow (Friday) e-mail me
and I'll try comp you in at 1015 so long as my guest list holds out. 
There's a Tatoo Show upstairs in the Gallery and Zendada is in the
basement.  I'm still waiting for info on the dj lineup in the main room,
but will post again when I know it.

From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)

Subject: Her Karma Ran Over His
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM

Will writes:
>I disagree with the general tenor of the
>11 "Signs & Symptoms," however, in that for me they
>don't jibe with my own sense of the feng shuy of
>higher spirituality.  They definitely come from that
>current school of thought that separates inner peace
>from activism,

Well, this "current school of thought" is not really current, in fact it
is the oldest recorded thought, period.

The basic problem of activism is that it comes from the ego of "I know
what is best for everyone".

"Higher spirituality" consists of removing yourself from the limited,
closed-in perspective of your own ego, so that you can resume the
natural state of a higher perspective.

The "signs and symptoms" are simply a sign post of how you are doing in
that endeavor.

Christ, Buddha and Gandhi were all coming from that non-ego/self-less
perspective, and what they did was in the best interests of everyone.

Note that Christ refused to take part in any revolution against the
Romans, despite the oppression going on.  Not exactly an activist.

Buddha renounced his position as crown prince - a very influential
position - in order to seek enlightenment.

>moral indignation

requires an "us" and "them" perspective.

>and creating the new
>dualism of bliss/blitz vs. nonviolent resistance. I'll happily choose
>the latter every time if (as the list makes clear) and when I see the
>former.

I don't see any inconsistency between bliss and nonviolent resistance,
especially when you consider that Gandhi did both.

If someone really feels there is an inconsistency, that would mean that
they come to raves, which are generally blissful and non-political, only
to distribute flyers and/or recruit people for causes...

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

g sez:
>I don't want other people to treat me the way they want to treat each
other -- generally with bizarre politeness ritual, groundless
suspicion mixed with naivete, and overt hostility to difference.
                                              
That's *hardly* what "Do unto others as you would have them do
unto you," says, means or even by the most bizarre stretch of
the imagination can be construed to be interpreted as.  And yet
g has a point: countless millions of Christians and Buddhists
over the centuries have interpreted the owrds of *their Leaders*
to mean what he cavils against!  So, in a way, his concern is a
real one: even though the Buddha and the Christ did not intend
such spiritual gymnastics, at least some of those who read their 
words afterwards turned them into that.

g also sez:
>I don't want other people to treat me the way I treat them, because I
am not presumptuous enough to set myself up as an example.


Even without re-reading the line, we can see that it definitely
does *not* say this! Maybe too much Crowley has impeded reading
comprehension here!

finally g sez:
>I want people to do WHATEVER THE HELL THEY WANT.  I'll tell you if I
have a problem, and then we'll work it out.
 
 
Do what thou Wilt shall be the Whole of the Law.
Love is the Law, Love under Will.

So you *are* a follower of Aleister Crowley, g, when you
say that!  I can probably cite chapter and verse; here,
I'll pull out my copy of 777....

ciao,
Will

Ken sez--

>Well, this "current school of thought" is not really current, in fact it
is the oldest recorded thought, period.

It's *one* thing to demonstrate that something is true,
Ken, and another to just baldly state it as you do here.

If you're interested I'd like you to relate these 11
Signs and Symptoms to "the oldest recorded thought"
somehow.  I doubt tHat you can.

Both Jesus and Gandhi (and possibly Buddha) were
killed because they *were* activists, real threats
to the political status quo of their times.  Check
*your* sources on that!

Going to raves, indeed, frequently *is* a very
spiritual experience of the highest order.  It
can be demonstrated from some of the truly giving,
ego-less moments we'vw all shared there and on sfraves    
as well!  But it's not the kind of mindless bliss
that that list suggests, rather it's a truly mindful
state.

Finally, Ken sex--

I don't see any inconsistency between bliss and nonviolent resistance,
especially when you consider that Gandhi did both.
 
If someone really feels there is an inconsistency, that would mean that
they come to raves, which are generally blissful and non-political, only
to distribute flyers and/or recruit people for causes...


Well, never having flyered at a rave, I haven't thought about
whether that is an inconsistency or not, but I don't think it
is.

And my point was, in fact, that bliss and n-v resistance are
a unitary state--but I saw nothing in the list that suggested
that the conflict that n-v resistance engages is is okay, in
fact it says just the opposite!

Good discussion!  I think a lot of us are going beyond
waving our own private banners with this one--and that's
encouraging!

ciao,
Will

Though I am not involved in the actual events to date, I feel it 
important that I help clear up what I hope was a simple misunderstanding, as 
opposed to being a malicious campaign directed at damaging the 
reputation of someone whom I very much respect.  I am hesitant to even 
include the text of the original post due to the fact that it smells 
like a cattle pasture,"but here goes:"
 
On Thu, 14 Jul 1994, Maui-Your Sister's House wrote:
> This is kind of uncomfortable for me, but here goes:
> 
> Malachy borrowed Susan's $5,000 video projector, and has told her he 
> would track it down. He hasn't called at all. Everett Zero has it, and he
> has made excuses instead of delivering. He says, "Oh, you can get it *if 
> I'm awake*", which is pretty lame. It is Susan's and my opinion that both 
> of these folks have been very remiss in their dealings with us. Heck, 
> it's been a *very* long time since we've seen the projector-- we really 
> just kept thinking we'd give everyone involved some time to get it 
> together. But instead of getting it together, they have flaked off and 
> made bad excuses. 
> 
> I just thought that the list ought to know what's going on before we have 
> that big we-love-Malachy fest this weekend. I know someone on the list knows 
> how it feels... we're just lucky we weren't in physical danger like that 
> person was.
> 
> Maui

This is the second time I've seen posts regarding the projector.  The
first time, I mentioned to Everett the next day what I'd read, and he
explained that the projector had been dropped off by someone, whose
identity he did not know, at a place he was working in Santa Cruz.  It 
was apparently disfunctional at the time (why else would it have been 
abandoned for a year at a repair shop?).  In spite of his attempts to 
locate the owner, it remained a mystery until recently.  I do know that 
he had been in contact with Susan very recently, explaining the 
situation to her, including the fact that the owner of the place where it 
is in S.Cruz is on holiday, and I know that he offered to ride there with 
her to pick it up when the guy returns.  

To begin with, I know few places that one can abandon equipment for a year
and then show back up indignant and malicious toward the people who
*could* very easily declare it their own by that point.  (Have you ever
been in a repair shop that didn't post a notice re: at what point it was
their gear if you didn't resolve it???) Second, Everett is the one and
only person who has been able and willing to show up consistently, do what
he says, and miraculously repair old, worn-out, beat-up equipment used in
the operation of the sound and lightshow at 1015.  That is why I feel so
indignant.  I firmly believe him to be a man of his word, and resent the
tone and content of the original post.  Thirdly, it's pretty chicken-shit
to attack someone publicly in an arena that they do not participate in...
meaning: Everett does not have a sfraves connection , nor a computer,
which is why I am responding in his behalf.

At the very least, I would suggest some public apologies.  I suspect that 
Malachy's accident must have closely followed dropping off of the 
projector, so being a bitch to him is pretty irresponsible.  And as 
Everett seems to have made the effort to track down and help return what 
may-have-once-been a $5000, three gun projector (approx ten years ago I'm 
told), I find the malicious diatribe above to be the worst example of 
netiquette.

I guess I need to clarify here.  There are several reasons I don't want 
people to "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you" -- at
least not near me.

1) All relationships are not symmetrical, where each person gives and takes
in the same way.
2) A world where everyone was like me would be both scary and boring.  I
don't want that.
3) I don't want to be constantly subjected to everyone else's idea of
a good time, either.  I do not enjoy many of the traditional rituals of
handshake, small talk, male bonding through sports, etc.
4) Let's say I'm really horny.  If I "did unto others etc." I'd be in jail
on rape charges, or in the hospital with major contusions.
5) Not to mention...

> >I don't want other people to treat me the way I treat them, because I
> am not presumptuous enough to set myself up as an example.
> 
> Even without re-reading the line, we can see that it definitely
> does *not* say this! Maybe too much Crowley has impeded reading
> comprehension here!

Um...what?  If I am treating others the way *I* want to be treated, I am
using myself as the desired model for human interaction -- and I don't
even believe that myself, much less want you to believe it.

Because of this, "Do unto..." is the most selfish philosophy possible.

> >I want people to do WHATEVER THE HELL THEY WANT.  I'll tell you if I
> >have a problem, and then we'll work it out.
>
> >Do what thou Wilt shall be the Whole of the Law.
> >Love is the Law, Love under Will.
> 
> So you *are* a follower of Aleister Crowley, g, when you
> say that!  I can probably cite chapter and verse; here,
> I'll pull out my copy of 777....

Oh, *please*.  You're stereotyping as badly as the people we deride
here on the list for being closed-minded.  If I quoted H. L. Mencken,
would that make me a misogynist and fascist like him?  If I quoted
Thomas Jefferson ("That government is best which governs least"),
would that make me a supporter of the Three-Fifths Compromise?  If I
quoted Martin Luther King, would that make me black, or a minister?

If I quoted Nirvana in my .sig, would that make me a suicidal junkie
with bowel trouble?

If anyone still cares, I'm not a Thelemite, Taoist, SubGenius,
Buddhist, Zoroastrian, Hindu, Druid, Satanist, or anything else -- or
I'm all of them, if you count thinking "they're right sometimes"
as being a member of some club.  Crowley was a fuckup and a
junkie, but I don't have to be like him, and neither do you.  What he
was, was smart enough to see through the smoke and mirrors of most
'morality', even the 'nice' kind.

Don't forget to floss!

// g

Fixed, morris...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 1994 19:36:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Vernon Morris <morris@indigo.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Comet Shoemaker-Levy

Regarding the cometary impacts on Jupiter, most likely, the bulk of the
 US populace will see nothing unusual about Jupiter from 16-22 July.
  Even astronomers with telescopes and detectors of every possible
wavelength directed toward Jupiter may see nothing unusual either, although
a faint fireball or two and distortions of the planet's cloud decks as seen
 in the infrared are supposedly possible.  Actually, there are some nice
simulations of some model predictions available from MOSAIC.  These are 
probably the most exciting things that anyone will see from this event.  I
(may be mistaken... but) think there are some satellites in
the area which will also be collecting radiative emissions from the event 
via CCD and/or IR spectroscopy.   

You can point out Venus during the early evening as a reasonably bright
object in the western sky but I  do not think Jupiter will be visible.  
Generally one needs a telescope (or so Galileo said...).  

VooDoo

hi, my name is john, and i'm new to sfraves.
i'm in boston now, but i'm moving to sf at the end of august.
i'm also known as handi.
call me whichever you like.


this post sparked my interest, because one time after having a very pleasant
day on mushrooms, that evening when i went to bed...i smoked out...
and my dreams were very very very vivid.  i still remember.  this is what
i remembered:

i remembered these childhood storybooks that my brother and i used to have.
the characters were called fred and scott, and fred was supposed to be
my alter ego and scott was my brother's (fred is my middle name, scott is
my brother's name...see the connection?  i think it was one of those computer
generated story books that came out in the mid to late 70s.)  anyways, these
characters were these kind of dog looking like people with fred as the
big brother that could do no wrong and scott was the little brother that
looked up to big brother and thought he was so awesome.  big brother took
care of little brother.  very nice things...

anyways, when i went to bed, i had vivid visions of these 2 characters
jumping up and down in these poses and sort of doing these superhero
moves....like they were conquering evil.

anyways, after i had this vision, i really wondered if any of these books
ever existed at all.  because i can sort of remember them after the vision
and remember thinking of them in the past, but i'm really not sure they ever
existed.


the reason i spouted all of this was that i remember by friend had given
me piracetum when we ate the mushrooms.

but i have no idea if this is related....
(i don't know how piracetum works, if you need to build it up in your body
before it takes effect, whatever)...

but that's my related story.

-John

>What's so wrong with that?  And since they
>are a pretty nebulous group it could be said that anyone who attends
>they're events is initiated as one of them ala "You will be assimilated.
>Resistence is futile." {Oh shit, they've assimilated the Captain (Crunch)
>already.  Can they be stopped?} 

Ahem... I wouldn't say that...    I met them in Wyoming,  told them about
my involvement in the rave scene and got noticed dancing my ass off
(trying to keep warm).

They were at my place this evening here in Mill Valley,  and I have to
admit,  they are a very interesting lot of people.   We talked about a lot
of interesting things,  and I was invited to speak at their Jupiter Bash
party this Sat evening.    They seem to have a LOT of support,   and
are VERY interested in setting up a "Home base" here in SF area.    They
are in close ties with the SPAZ group,   and seem to be genuinely interested
in keeping the rave scene alive.

Their music "Acid Techno trance" is slightly faster in tempo (145+ BPM)
but whort of the 160+ BPM "Hardcore".    I really like the music I've heard
from Universal Sound,  both at a private birthday party (Oh!  Happy birthday
Foster) at Foster's place last Tuesday evening.

So,  I see no reason to want to stop them,   instead we all should just try
and figure out what they are about.    They don't seem to be "Money grabbing"
types,   and I doubt if they would charge $20 for one of their gigs.

I think for those SFRavers who are skeptical,  they should try and attend 
their Jupiter Bash party this Sat and see for themselves.

Peace
CC

I was at WIcked last weekend and had a swell time.  Sure, there was a long
line to get in and it was heck-a cold outside...Sure, there were so many
people it was very hard to dance....but I did notice that the midrange
and tweeters were placed above the crowd such that it wasn't unbearable.
The sound was better than at that 19th and Alabama spot by a mile.  To me,
it seemed like the vibe was also better here than there.  Actually, 
I experienced the best vibe within about a 10 foot radius of the DJ booth.
It sort of peeked around 6am, as people cleared out of this 10 foot area,
leaving just about a square foot more room for each person and then all these
smiles just came out and it was great.  

As for the music...Sure, nothing mind-blowing, but everyone was still into
it around the "hot spot" giving out whoops and cheers when they felt that
surge of energy you feel when the DJ brings the energy up a notch with
just the right transition.

One thing that I saw that really sucked was the parking around 3rd st.  
Apparently they have a new policy on street cleaning on that street not
just tuesday and thursday, but EVERY day from 2am to 6am.  so basically a
whole bunch of people had to pay $20 tickets for missing the new sticker
on those signs... beware.

walrus@quack.kfu.com

hi g// and other folx--

As a professional writer, editor and teacher of 34 years,
I must say it makes me feel good to see you clarifying
yourself, carrying on real discourse and not falling into
that all-too-American syndrome (imnduced largely by our
mass media that just wants us to roll over and buy) of
being just pissed off by real discussion of importaNT ISSUES.

I'm not going to reply to any of the good points you raise
now; it's 1;15 a.m., and I'm sure others will, too, but
we are all showing how and why Internet newsgroups are the
cutting edge of the information explosion: we're actually
having some real dialogue, not just passively accepting
what's put out there, which is what we're mainly "educated"
and trained for in our consumerist culture.

Early on as a teacher I learned the easiest way to make
students *hate* writing is to do what still too many
teachers do: bleed over papers with a red pencil, 
paying attention to spelling, mechanics and usage but
seldom interacting with the content.  Such red-pencil 
editing is the *last* step in the writing process, not 
the first and only one, as too many students experience    
throughout their education. And it only reinforces wha
the media tells us subliminally: your ideas don't
matter and if you think like other people rather than
for yourself you will be healthy wealthy and wise.
Bullshit!

Every now and then (and I expect it any mnute now on
sfr) some people get mad about these thread that have
*nothing* to do with raves, raving and rave culture.
Bullshit again!

ciao,
Will

P.S. My "follower" line to you, g, about Crowley
I admit was provocative bait, so forgive if you
can another admirer of The Great Beast when he
saw some wonderful sentiments that, no matter what
I may say, still fire and illumine the spirit
albeit not in the same way as they did once.


-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Creation, after all, is only play.

On Thu, 14 Jul 1994 jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com wrote:

> 
> 
>  > > that, but when I talk about "punkers", and refer to the 
>  > stereotype, I refer to
>  > > people who are attempting to be and look like a punker.
>  > > hmm?
>  > > 
>  > > Jesus Chrysler
>  > > 
>  > Why classify?
> 
> Because it's very easy to classify someone when they want to be classified, no?
>  Some people try to fill those stereotypes, and do a damn good job, so that
> they're very easy to classify.

Perhaps I need to make myself clearer.  What I am trying to say is why be 
so concerned with what other people are doing?  Unless those punkers you 
are referring to are doing something specific to you to interfere with 
your space, then why expend the energy even talking about them?  What 
someone looks like or the stereotype they fill often has very little to 
do with the person inside.  This is why I say "why classify?"  
Classification requires too much energy for me.  Maybe you could give me 
some good reasons why I should classify people.

> > would track it down. He hasn't called at all. Everett Zero has it, and he
> > has made excuses instead of delivering. He says, "Oh, you can get it *if 
> > I'm awake*", which is pretty lame. It is Susan's and my opinion that both 
> > of these folks have been very remiss in their dealings with us. Heck, 
> > it's been a *very* long time since we've seen the projector-- we really 
> > just kept thinking we'd give everyone involved some time to get it 
> > together. But instead of getting it together, they have flaked off and 
> > made bad excuses. 
> > 
> > I just thought that the list ought to know what's going on before we have 
> > that big we-love-Malachy fest this weekend. I know someone on the list 
> > who knows how it feels... we're just lucky we weren't in physical danger 
> > like that person was.
> > 
> > Maui
> 
> This is the second time I've seen posts regarding the projector.  The
> first time, I mentioned to Everett the next day what I'd read, and he
> explained that the projector had been dropped off by someone, whose
> identity he did not know, at a place he was working in Santa Cruz.  It 
> was apparently disfunctional at the time (why else would it have been 
> abandoned for a year at a repair shop?).  In spite of his attempts to 
> locate the owner, it remained a mystery until recently.  I do know that 
> he had been in contact with Susan very recently, explaining the 
> situation to her, including the fact that the owner of the place where it 
> is in S.Cruz is on holiday, and I know that he offered to ride there with 
> her to pick it up when the guy returns.  
> 
> To begin with, I know few places that one can abandon equipment for a year
> and then show back up indignant and malicious toward the people who
> *could* very easily declare it their own by that point.  (Have you ever
> been in a repair shop that didn't post a notice re: at what point it was
> their gear if you didn't resolve it???) Second, Everett is the one and
> only person who has been able and willing to show up consistently, do what
> he says, and miraculously repair old, worn-out, beat-up equipment used in
> the operation of the sound and lightshow at 1015.  That is why I feel so
> indignant.  I firmly believe him to be a man of his word, and resent the
> tone and content of the original post.  Thirdly, it's pretty chicken-shit
> to attack someone publicly in an arena that they do not participate in...
> meaning: Everett does not have a sfraves connection , nor a computer,
> which is why I am responding in his behalf.
> 
> At the very least, I would suggest some public apologies.  I suspect that 
> Malachy's accident must have closely followed dropping off of the 
> projector, so being a bitch to him is pretty irresponsible.  And as 
> Everett seems to have made the effort to track down and help return what 
> may-have-once-been a $5000, three gun projector (approx ten years ago I'm 
> told), I find the malicious diatribe above to be the worst example of 
> netiquette.

Kerry, in response to your comments on "the projector thing" --

susan here:

fact: i did not "drop off" my beloved video projector at some two-bit chop
shop in santa cruz a year ago. i don't even know where the fucking place
is (can *somebody* please tell me -- i'll be there within hours). what i
*did* do was entrust something i could ill afford to lose to someone i
barely knew (malachy) on the basis of good vibe alone, and am now reaping
the usual and customary benefits of such an action. silly me.

fact: when my projector "once-was" a $5000 machine (in *perfect* working
order) was approximately two years ago (it was *one* year *new* at that
time) when i turned it over to the "patriarch" of the house scene.

fact: when i finally was able to get in touch with malachy, last month,
(i didn't want to push it until then, because i knew he had far bigger
things to worry about, so i hesitated to contact him until i had exhausted
all other options) he said he would look into it and get back to me in a 
week or so -- again, i took him at his word -- he did'nt.

fact finale: when i ultimately traced the projector to everett, we set up
several appointments, which fell through for reasons which were out of 
his control, except for the one where he simply chose to sleep in while i 
waited by the phone all day for him to call. for this he apologised, and 
i heartily accepted his apology, being eternally grateful for the tender
loving care i know he has given the projector since it was dumped on his
doorstep by goddess-knows-who goddess-knows-when. i have expressed this 
gratitude to him every time we have spoken, and told him that when this
was all over i wanted to treat him to the dinner of his dreams, or whatever
special treat he could think of, to repay him for his kindness. talking 
to him, he does not seem like the type of person who would willfully blow 
someone off, but i have left him numerous messages since our last 
conversation, all saying something to the effect of "i'm totally flexible 
as to when we go to santa cruz, but please just call and let me know 
what's up", and i haven't heard a word from him, and i'm just kind of 
freaking 'cause he's my only connection to my projector. so, when maui 
offered to post a message regarding the situation, i told her to go for it.

yes, we are frustrated.

we are both relatively new to sf but old to the scene, and we've never 
encountered a situation like this before. we both believe in giving 
people the benefit of the doubt, and i think the fact that we have put so 
much trust in people we barely know is testament to this, but if you were 
us, how would you feel? it's gotten to the point where we can only 
believe in what we see -- and one thing we don't see is our projector.

we were both under the impression that everett *was* on the net and both 
posts were made in the hope that he would see them, in the (unlikely) 
event that he has not gotten my numerous messages. i assure you that 
nothing was meant to be said behind anyone's back. to be sure, i would 
welcome any communication from everett. i want nothing more. i'm sure one 
phone call from him would clear up any misunderstandings, and if you 
could persuade him to *make* that phone call i'd be forever in your debt! 
                                                  respectfully,
                                                  susan

ps: regarding the condition of the projector, it was in positively 
flawless condition last time i saw it, but i would gladly reimburse 
everett, parts and labor, for any work he has done on Betsy. the offer of 
dinner still holds and, kerry, you're welcome to join us.
                                                  peace.

From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <271433C0@tigerteam.org>
Subject: There IS No Contradicti
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 1994 06:07:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Will writes:
>Ken sez--
>
>>Well, this "current school of thought" is not really current, in fact it
>is the oldest recorded thought, period.
>
>It's *one* thing to demonstrate that something is true,
>Ken, and another to just baldly state it as you do here.
>If you're interested I'd like you to relate these 11
>Signs and Symptoms to "the oldest recorded thought"
>somehow.  I doubt tHat you can.

It comes froms the Vedas, estimated to have been written roughly about
10,000 years ago.

It would take some hours of research to rigorously demostrate this. I'll
seen what I can dig up that might be less rigorous...

>Both Jesus and Gandhi (and possibly Buddha) were
>killed because they *were* activists, real threats
>to the political status quo of their times.  Check
>*your* sources on that!

No, I just mentioned in the last message that Jesus refused to be an
activist.  In fact, that was why he was killed.  As long as everyone is
distracted by the Judaea vs. Rome, Clinton vs. Bush, etc. then the
status quo is NOT threatened.  What is threatening to the status quo is
that Jesus and Gandhi asked people not to be selfish, to love/help your
neighbor.  Gandhi was killed AFTER his non-violent campaign caused the
British to give India its independance.  He was killed because he THEN
started advocating that Hindus and Moslems love each other and get along.

The whole idea of being ego-less and self-less is very threatening to
both individuals and the status quo.

>
>Going to raves, indeed, frequently *is* a very
>spiritual experience of the highest order.  It
>can be demonstrated from some of the truly giving,
>ego-less moments we'vw all shared there and on sfraves
>as well!  But it's not the kind of mindless bliss
>that that list suggests, rather it's a truly mindful
>state.

Okay, could you list what on the list strikes you as "mindless"?
This could be semantics, really.  In order to be truly mindful, ie in
the sense of aware, you have to turn off your "mind", ie the chatterbox
in your head...

>
>And my point was, in fact, that bliss and n-v resistance are
>a unitary state--but I saw nothing in the list that suggested
>that the conflict that n-v resistance engages is is okay, in
>fact it says just the opposite!

I re-read the list after reading this point and, really, the only one
that refers to this whole discussion is that same one:

6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

Whereas Tony posted that the problem is in the term here "conflict", I
think that the crucial word is "interest".

In the ego-less state one has no interest in conflict.  If, however,
circumstances dictate that conflict is the necessary and proper course
of action, then conflict is not shied away from.  To shy away from
something, is actually to be interested in it, in that one is interested
in avoiding it.  If one neither embraces nor avoids something, one is
not interested in it.

Indeed, someone who was interested in conflict would have no reason to
resort to "non-violence".

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

her.  I can't remember exactly what she said or did to him, but instead 
of telling him to fuck off, she sat down with him and explained to him 
why his behavior toward her, point by point, was inappropriate.  Instead 
of completely turning him away, she gave him the opportunity to look at 
himself.  Jesus, I get upset, too when I see people treating raves like a 
meat rack, too, but after this experience, I now have hope that this can 
start to change.

Susan, Maui, and sfravers, 

Thanks for your sweetness and patience during my earlier fiery diatribe.  
I have nothing involved here other than my appreciation for Everett's 
having made my work once again a joyful non-stressful experience, yet I 
very much appreciate Susan's well-spoken response.  I have spoken to 
Everett this evening, and am confident that the matter will be resolved 
as soon as the owner of the studio returns from his vacation. (Everett is 
of the opinion that it should be any day now.) 

To my knowledge, Ev has never had net access.  He recently lost the Haight
Street space where he lived and worked, and is currently staying with a
friend while doing what he can to help keep 1015's technical environment
functioning. This has been fiscally difficult as we are still under siege
from the City of San Francisco and the Irish-Catholic dominated Police Dept
which seems to be working in collusion with the Catholic Church's efforts to
develop the real estate next-door to us.  If it weren't for his efforts, 
I can assure you that your next visit to the club would have been at best 
disappointing.

Sorry for the flaming response, but glad it all is working out.  Please 
contact me if you lose touch with Ev'again.  BTW, I couldn't recommend a 
better tech should the proj need help.  Having been a club tech for 18 
years, I've had more than my share of 3-beam projectors and can tell you 
that they tend to be problematic, but generally have small part failures 
that only require lengthy diagnostics (as opposed to expensive Japanese 
parts).  Hope it's that or better... maybe we'll laff about it all over a 
nice meal soon.  Peace....................................Kerry

Ken sez--
 
It will take him "hours of research to rigorously demonstrate"
that the Signs & Symptoms list comes from the Vedas!
 
THIS I'll gladly wait to see! As a student of the Vedas myself,
it's hard for me to see how things like #5, 6, 7 and 11 come
from the Vedas.
 
Then he says that "Jesus was killed because he refused to be
an activist...(to be) distracted by the Judaea vs. Rome" thing.
 
Wrong!  Remember when he said "Render unto Caesar the things that
are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's"? THIS really
set the (then P.C.) Herod-Pontius Pilate crowd off because they
could see how these kinds of teachings were a real threat to their
status quo collusion of the religious leadership in Judaea with
the Roman colonial government.  When given the chance to kill
Jesus or the most heinous criminal, it's not surprising they had
Jesus the "rabble-rouser" killed!
 
Ken also asks if I "could list on the list what strikes you as
'mindless'?"
 
I did that in my first post responding to this list.  Let me say
again that the discussion about how the "ego-less state one has no
interest in conflict" has become so convoluted and dualistic that
it has lost any meaning. Conflict is an integral part of life, of
growth, spiritual, mental, physical or any other kind I can think of.
 
Finally, Ken lists Clinton and Smeal his idea of who the P.C. ones
are.  Well, P.C. is relative to your point of view.  If you like
Rush Limbaugh, he'd be your P.C. point man; or if you're against
his type of politics you's sneer at his P.C. right-wing perspective.
In New Age circles I've seen lists like this list held up before
as guides for right livelihood, not people like the
two above!
 
ciao,Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
Creation, after all, is only play.
ILLUMINATIen C.n C.S   Paul Gary Max Coliollins HarHarperSanFrancisco

let's faceit, folx, EVERYONE makes some sort of stereotyped, cubbyholed,
  categorical assumption about EVERYONE ELSE he/she sees, hears, hears about,
    or reads about, as soon as there is any sensory input whatsoever,
      round the clock, asleep/awake/whatever...
your brain is always working, always trying to hook things together, trying
  to make some sense of what your eyes see.

most people dress/look the way they ARE.  nowadays, with so many hundreds of
  types of races/creeds/lifestyles/etc all squnched together in urban areas,
    there's not enough time for your brain to fully assimilate ALL THE FACTS
      regarding any one person of interest, especially when passing peeple
        on the street.  that's all there is, pure and simple; so naturally,
          the brain lumps each person into some sort of category which each
            of us has pre-prepared for that type of person.
one of my personal foibles is always lumping pinstriped-suit peeple into the
  conformist-stiff-old-and-greedy category, which is absolutely silly. we all
    have one or more 'pet peeve' type of person out there who, we think, is
      not doing everything they should to be the wonderful person that we
        think they should be... SO, the ol' brain goes to work and that
          person's attributes suddenly all FIT into the category we have for
            that type.

needless to say, with 5 billion people, there's gotta be some repeats, or
  darn near-misses, of groups of people who act, think, look, etc. alike.

  still, we're all different, we still don't even know if we all see the same
    color when we look at a flower...

   if you think yer immune to this categorizing, take a good look at everyone
    you see on a busy street, and listen to your mind.  it'll be making all
     sorts of conclusions about EVERYONE you see.  your internal detail
      filter usually turns off the screed, but if you listen real hard, it's
       all there...

   so, maybe instead of altering human nature, it's just a matter of 
    thinking a bit more about what your subconscious says before you talk
     or act, so you can give yourself a bit more time to form some sound
      conclusions about the other people you form opinions on.

am i talking crap or whut??

Dave Scruton
Fractallonomy

SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com sez:
> 
> let's faceit, folx, EVERYONE makes some sort of stereotyped, cubbyholed,
>   categorical assumption about EVERYONE ELSE he/she sees, hears, hears about,
>     or reads about, as soon as there is any sensory input whatsoever,
>       round the clock, asleep/awake/whatever...
> your brain is always working, always trying to hook things together, trying
>   to make some sense of what your eyes see.

[some stuff deleted]

>    if you think yer immune to this categorizing, take a good look at everyone
>     you see on a busy street, and listen to your mind.  it'll be making all
>      sorts of conclusions about EVERYONE you see.  your internal detail
>       filter usually turns off the screed, but if you listen real hard, it's
>        all there...
> 
>    so, maybe instead of altering human nature, it's just a matter of 
>     thinking a bit more about what your subconscious says before you talk
>      or act, so you can give yourself a bit more time to form some sound
>       conclusions about the other people you form opinions on.
> 
> am i talking crap or whut??

No, not crap.:)  I read somewhere, maybe a psychology text or
something similar, that one of the main motives behind stereotyping is 
to define the unknown.  The brain needs to have a definition for things
and a classification to help figure out where to store information.
The problem with stereotyping is when a person doesn't let go of
his/her preconceptions when given an opportunity to explore the real
thing.  This leads to a very limited understanding of ones environment.

We classify much more than people it is something that we do to just 
about all of our experiences.  I have stereotyped every plant that looks
even remotely similar to poison oak as being dangerous.  I have done this 
for my own safety because I am extremely allergic to poison oak.  But 
when I found out that one of these plants wasn't dangerous and
actually produces sweet fruit I enjoyed that fruit.

Take care.
-- 
Candice			pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu


    I'm nothing now, but I'm something compared to what I used to be.

Subject: Ethics, Freedom, and Bad People

One fine summer day, some people said:

>  > Now imagine if everyone in the world thought that way.  Imagine how far
>  > we could go.
>  >  
>  > OKAY!!! For starters: Napoleon, Hitler, Alexander the Great
>  > and guys like that!
> Jesus Christ, the Inquisition, the Crusades, witch burnings, the war
> on homosexuals...

These people personally caused very little trouble.  The horror comes
when other people sacrifice their own Will to that of another, and the
power of the individual becomes the power of millions.

Anyone who practices "Do what thou etc." will not be suckered by
subterfuges like organized religion and patriotism -- they are simply
tricky ways other people have come up with to try and get you to do
what _they_ want instead of what _you_ want.

Note that all the above "evil" people or groups were pushers of either
religion or the state.  Both offer the illusion of comfort and safety
in return for freedom; your Will, or, as some put it, your soul.

"Those who are willing to give up essential liberty to gain a measure of
 temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety."   -Ben Franklin

// g

Subject: Re: yer ID, please!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 1994 14:00:07 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <01HEQD3XLHF600B3J6@EDEN1.HAC.COM> from "SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com" at Jul 15, 94 10:40:03 am

Precedence: bulk


>    so, maybe instead of altering human nature, it's just a matter of 
>     thinking a bit more about what your subconscious says before you talk
>      or act, so you can give yourself a bit more time to form some sound
>       conclusions about the other people you form opinions on.
> 
> am i talking crap or whut??

No, you're absolutely right.  Any time we recognize anything, we are
'stereotyping'.  It's like the old saying, "If it walks like a duck, 
quacks like a duck, ..." then I probably won't bother to dissect it just
to find out if it _really_ is a duck or not.

Harmful stereotyping happens when (as you pointed out) your initial
judgement based on first contact keeps you from learning based on
further contact.

If I say "All purple people are stupid", I'm stereotyping.  If I say
"All purple people are _not_ stupid", then I'm still stereotyping
because I've never seen a purple person -- though the assumption may
be more reasonable.  I have no idea whether purple people are smart or
not, and I don't really care, because it doesn't matter to me.  Same with
O.J. Simpson and U.S. foreign policy -- I have absolutely no data except
what newspapers and the government told me, so what business do I have
deciding others' lives, even if my opinion _did_ matter?

It's amazing how much time I have to do stuff and have fun once I started
mostly ignoring popular culture and other spectacles.

// g

Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA25830; Fri, 15 Jul 1994 15:03:55 -0700
Received: from cruzio.com by scruz.net (8.3/1.34)
	id PAA00690; Fri, 15 Jul 1994 15:03:36 -0700
Subject: Discrimination vs. Discriminating
To: Candice <pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu>
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 94 12:49:30 PDT
From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199407151823.LAA17124@hulk.sfsu.edu>; from "Candice" at Jul 15, 94 11:23 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-ID:  <9407151249.aa26516@cruzio.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We're doing well in making fine distinctions, folx,
because what SCRUTON@JOYCE and then Candice are
talking about in their recent addition to the dis-
cussion on stereotyping is the important notion of
discrimination, which is the practice of prejudicial
categorization, and discriminating, which is judicial
or finely discerning differentiation.  Sounds simple
but it isn't; to some they seem the same but they aren't.
The diff?  Basically, our application ofr our experience,
observation, perception and interpretation.

SCRUTON@@JOYCE: 

>
> let's faceit, folx, EVERYONE makes some sort of stereotyped, cubbyholed,
>   categorical assumption about EVERYONE ELSE he/she sees, hears, hears about,
>     or reads about, as soon as there is any sensory input whatsoever,
>       round the clock, asleep/awake/whatever...
> your brain is always working, always trying to hook things together, trying
>   to make some sense of what your eyes see.
 
[some stuff deleted]
 
>    if you think yer immune to this categorizing, take a good look at everyone
>     you see on a busy street, and listen to your mind.  it'll be making all
>      sorts of conclusions about EVERYONE you see.  your internal detail
>       filter usually turns off the screed, but if you listen real hard, it's
>        all there...
>
>    so, maybe instead of altering human nature, it's just a matter of
>     thinking a bit more about what your subconscious says before you talk
>      or act, so you can give yourself a bit more time to form some sound
>       conclusions about the other people you form opinions on.
>
> am i talking crap or whut??

Candice comments:


 
>No, not crap.:)  I read somewhere, maybe a psychology text or
>something similar, that one of the main motives behind stereotyping is
>to define the unknown.  The brain needs to have a definition for things
>and a classification to help figure out where to store information.
>The problem with stereotyping is when a person doesn't let go of
>his/her preconceptions when given an opportunity to explore the real
>thing.  This leads to a very limited understanding of ones environment.
 
>We classify much more than people it is something that we do to just
>out about all of our experiences.  I have stereotyped every plant that looks
>even remotely similar to poison oak as being dangerous.  I have done this
>for my own safety because I am extremely allergic to poison oak.  But
>when I found out that one of these plants wasn't dangerous and
>actually produces sweet fruit I enjoyed that fruit.

mother Earth sound system DJ's scottie and whitsitt (plus several 
friends) will be contributing an ambient/dub reggae/live trip out
to Divine's chill room tonight (Friday). for info:
510/247/2474
415/267/6193
************

on rave ethics: as far as I can see, the only "universal ethic" of raving 
is to respect everyone for the common purpose of dancing.  Everything thing 
else (spirituality, politics, etc.) comes from individuals and is 
variable depending on who you ask. I, personally, tend to bring alot of 
this sort of thing in to our m.e.s.s. parties, but that's just our sound 
system, *not* raves in general.
as for "Do unto others...": don't deny yourself in favor of others, and 
don't deny others in favor of yourself.  or, Do what you want, but don't 
hurt anyone. I believe that provides for balance, IMHO.

love,
whitsitt

p.s. Just in case that comet does obliterate us all on Saturday night, 
thank you all for a wonderful time.  The parties have been real nice... :)

From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 15 20:51:52 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

	id UAA05706; Fri, 15 Jul 1994 20:44:05 -0700
Received: by tigerteam.org (WILDUUCP! v1.10d)
        Sat, 16 Jul 1994 02:54:00 GMT
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <06681E76@tigerteam.org>
Subject: Re: Some Signs & Sympto
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 1994 02:54:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

>Ken sez--
>
>It will take him "hours of research to rigorously demonstrate"
>that the Signs & Symptoms list comes from the Vedas!
>
>THIS I'll gladly wait to see! As a student of the Vedas myself,
>it's hard for me to see how things like #5, 6, 7 and 11 come
>from the Vedas.

I don't yet have the time to find my Upanishads to rigorously document
this, so I'll just go from general memory.

>5.  Loss of interest in interpreting actions. [of others]

What others do is irrelevant, everything of value is within yourself, so
all that you need to do is focus on the love within yourself (atman).

All actions of others are due to karma [perhaps messages on
hyperreal.com are due to hyperkarma :-) :-)].  Their karma, in turn, is
due to their actions.  Escaping this vicious circle is only through
focusing on the love within yourself.

>6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

Same answer as for 5.

>7.  Loss of ability to worry.  (this is a very serious symptom)

When you are focused on the love within yourself, what possibly could
there be to worry about?  If you say "but what if" or "but what about",
then that consists of a lack of focus.

11.  Increasing tendency to let things happen rather than make them
happen.

This is the more esoteric one (perhaps that is why it is at the end).
The mystics all describe that when they let go of their own petty
desires, and aligned themselves with the love within, then things happen
of their own accord, without their own puny intervention.  When they
aligned themselves with the love within (atman), they automatically
aligned themselves with the world (brahman, Gaia) and being aligned with
the world, things in the world happened in alignment with them in return.

>
>Then he says that "Jesus was killed because he refused to be
>an activist...(to be) distracted by the Judaea vs. Rome" thing.
>
>Wrong!  Remember when he said "Render unto Caesar the things that
>are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's"? THIS really
>set the (then P.C.) Herod-Pontius Pilate crowd off because they
>could see how these kinds of teachings were a real threat to their
>status quo collusion of the religious leadership in Judaea with
>the Roman colonial government.  When given the chance to kill
>Jesus or the most heinous criminal, it's not surprising they had
>Jesus the "rabble-rouser" killed!

Yes.  This paragraph is more evidence in support of my position :-).  I
was going to put in this paragraph, but I didn't want to make the post
too long.

>Remember when he said "Render unto Caesar the things that
>are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's"?

The previous sentence is "Whose face is on this coin?" "Caesar's".

The meaning of this is (in the context of the taxation without
representation of 2000 years ago) that there is no point in contesting
worthless material things.  The "things that are God's" are the
spiritual things - Peace, Love, Unity, Respect.  Elsewhere Jesus says
"my two commandments are Love God and Love Your Neighbor".  So, it's
PLUR for God and PLUR for your "neighbor".  (How you interpret "God" is
your own personal choice.)

The other jews were upset that he refused to lead a activist rebellion
against Rome, so when the high-priests (jewish establishment) made the
Romans arrest him, no one came to his aid other than his disciples.

Then Pontius Pilate asked him "Are you the King of Jews", he answered in
such a seemingly vague way that, after some further questions, Pilate
announced that he could find no crime.

>Ken also asks if I "could list on the list what strikes you as
>'mindless'?"
>
>I did that in my first post responding to this list.  Let me say
>again that the discussion about how the "ego-less state one has no
>interest in conflict" has become so convoluted and dualistic that
>it has lost any meaning. Conflict is an integral part of life, of
>growth, spiritual, mental, physical or any other kind I can think of.
>
>Finally, Ken lists Clinton and Smeal his idea of who the P.C. ones
>are.  Well, P.C. is relative to your point of view.

NOT!  Whereas you definitely COULD use P.C. to describe those things
that right-wing republicans automatically assume are true, it just isn't
done.  Useage in the 90's refers to left-wing liberal rigidity and lack
of a sense of humor about their objectives; it especially refers to
where institutions try to prevent speech that says anything about a
specific group of people (cf the concurrent 'stereotyping' thread on
sfraves :-) :-) ).

>In New Age circles I've seen lists like this list held up before
>as guides for right livelihood, not people like the
>two above!

NOT!  Please excuse the stereotyping :-) but New Age overwhelming
consists of people who have the same PC speech taboos described above
and are VERY MUCH in favor of activism for left-wing liberal causes.

The Signs and Symptoms is very much at odds with the New Age - which is
one reason why it fits raving so well :-) :-).

New Agers are ALWAYS interpeting EVERYTHING :-).  They're ALWAYS
WORRYING :-).  They're ALWAYS acting due to fears based on past
experiences.   And they're ALWAYS judging their self. :-)

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Received: from epikt.agames.com by agames.agames.com (8.6.9/3.14+gl) id BAA00280; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 01:06:28 -0700
Received: by epikt.agames.com (8.6.9/3.14+gl) id BAA22426; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 01:05:59 -0700
Subject: Uncle Grigsby's Philosophy Korner
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 1994 01:05:59 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To:  <9407151308.aa27346@cruzio.com> from "William Penna" at Jul 15, 94 01:08:17 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2471      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



I challenge anyone to come up with a more concise and useful definition
for the following terms:

Q: What is a "right"?
A: An expectation that someone else will behave in a certain way.

Q: What is a "moral"?
A: My justification for demanding a "right".

> >How about people can do whatever they want as long as they don't infringe
> >on the rights of their fellow humans and respect each other--a basic
> >tenant of humanism.

The concept of a "right" rests on a foundation of morals, without
which it is simply an expectation.  Since I do not believe in absolute
morals, I therefore do not believe in any sort of privilege given to
a certain set of expectations called "rights" over simple preferences.

It would, therefore, be meaningless for me to claim any authority other
than my own for my "rights", whatever I consider those to be.  I do
not expect others to cater to my whims, and I do not wish to cater to
theirs -- however, there are organizations called "governments" which
find it good business practice to impose the whims of some group on 
everyone else, whether those whims be sodomy laws, liability laws,
the concept of "trespass", universal health care, the concept of the
automobile as the ideal form of transportation, or subsidies for 
overpopulation of the biosphere.

If "my rights stop where your rights start", who gets to draw those lines?
Maybe it should be you rather than someone else.  After all, there is no
one better qualified than yourself to judge.

Some may object that such a philosophy, if applied, would result in
people running amok in the streets, killing or kidnapping and torturing
them for no reason at all, fighting each other out of blind hatred, ...

in other words, just like the present except you don't have to worry 
about drug busts, police raids, a trillion-dollar machine 
that props up dictators across the globe with your money, or timber
companies being paid to run roads into old-growth so they can send 
virgin pulp to Japan, ...

and who knows?  Maybe if more people took responsibility for their own
actions, and had the freedom to do so, we would fulfill our basic needs
of love, food, and shelter _first_ instead of last -- and then we could
explore the mysteries of our chaotic existence from a position of
ultimate strength instead of weakness and dependency on those who use
our energies to maintain the status quo.

"...and then I shall be free to pursue truth in one body and soul."
	-Rimbaud

// g

enough of the drug to supply doses to more than 450,000 people. (eat em up yum!
yum!)

California this decade.
>The invesigation began in Sacramento six months ago...
>The drug, a stimulant and hullucinogen, is most commonly used by teenagers and
young adults and is supposed to heighted sexual sensations.

and is popular in the Castro and Haight Ashbury district of SF.
>Undercover drug agents began tracking the supply from raves in 
Sacramento through five or six levels of drug dealers in Marin and Contra
Consta counties, and in the Haight Ashbury district.

  Another great night! And a great start to what I hope will be a much 
better weekend then last. Anyways, Liquid * proved once again that 
strange music can bring people together.  We had the usual SF-Raves crowd 
and their friends, plus the beer drinkers from down the beach.  With the 
exception of a few shady characters, the drunks danced among everyone 
else and added quite a few extra bodies to the party.

  Many many thanks to Laura for finding such a good spot. Although you 
may not have to worry about the homeless charging you for parking, you 
might have to worry about the drunks pulling the plug out of your 
generator. Other then that, a wonderful and slightly warmer spot then 
24th and Il.

  It was great to finally hear Lee and Tamara, both who spinned smooth as 
silk. Unfortunatley because of some generator problems Bryce was unable 
to make DAT's of the whole evening.... sigh... perhaps some other time.

  Finally, I had a great time and my friend, Drew, also had a wonderful 
time.  Was real nice to look up from the mixer and see so many people 
going bezerk!  Hope to see some of you at Come-Unity... Anyways, I just 
got home and am starting to slur my text, so I better get some rest.. 

-=*Ernie (deaks@netcom.com)

 p.s.

  I finally got to Costco and stocked up on blanks, and also finally 
finished BOTH sides of my tape.. So for all those people who have been 
waiting so long (especialy RobertJ) I will be sending the tapes out on 
Monday and Tuesday and I might bring some up tommorow if I meet any of 
you at C-U...

  X Ta Zzzzzzzzzzzzzzz..... ...  ..    .       .




From sfraves-owner  Sat Jul 16 06:51:27 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) id GAA04251; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 06:51:27 -0700
Received: from netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with ESMTP id GAA04246; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 06:51:23 -0700
Received: by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id GAA12418; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 06:51:45 -0700
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199407161351.GAA12418@netcom12.netcom.com>
Subject: Multicultural Liquid *
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 1994 06:51:45 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 6181      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 After SPAZ , Raffaela & I drove to Liquid *. A nice site , like 24th
and Illinois in that it's located in an industrial area and is next
to the bay. We got there at about 12:45AM , and Lee Ahn was spinning
some nice music.

 It turned out that the isolated partying possibilities of the area
was known to other folks as well. A "kegger" party was occuring about 
a quarter mile away from us, and the attendees of both parties were 
using the same parking lot. Isolated individuals from the kegger came
over to check us out , some of those danced with us for a space.

 The first negative intrusion of "keggers" occured during Lee Ahn's set.
Four of them came down and stood to the side between the DJ table and
the generator. They lit a bottle rocket , made some mocking attempts
at duplicating our dancing , and started a mini-mosh-pit between 
themselves( stomping on someone's shirt in the meanwhile.). I think 
they also decided to test the flamablity of their plastic
beer cups. I made a hasty intervention when they started to mess with the
power cord running from the generator - seems they had almost tripped 
on it, and were wondering what it was.

 As they finally decided to leave , one of them decided it would be 
'fun' to diconnect our power cord - to our consternation. As they left,
there was an exchange of words between them , Bryce , and Laura 

 I don't know about anyone else , but it took about an hour before
I got my "good vibe" feelings back. Return they did though , thanks to 
Ernie's music.

 Then the "keggers" came back , about seven of them this time , one of
them a gal in a blanket. From what I could tell , the same asshole who 
cut our power decided that throwing pebbles at us would also be "fun" -
I don't think he hit anyone before he stopped. Four of them came down
to us again , at the other side of the DJ setup this time. They did a 
little moshing/bumper car stuff again , hung around some more, then
left to go back to their party. As they left , Mr. Asshole tossed one 
last pebble at us again ( he missed again , I think ).

 Well , this spoiled my "vibe" for sure. I started patrolling around ,
trying to make sure that nothing bad started. About 45 minutes after the 
last "invasion" , I think I saw three of our obnoxious neighbors drive
off , Mr. Asshole among the three. 

 It seemed that the other party was composed of a variety of individuals 
with an apparent age and intoxication spread which was much wider than
the first assumption of "high schoolers". One of them , a short-haird
guy in his late twenties or early thirties , whith a vauge "cop" feel
to him , stood on the ridge over our party , just listening to
Laura's set. I talked to him a bit , invited him to dance , but he just
wanted to listen. Later , he left in an RV with three other folks from 
his party.

 Great music by Laura!


 I think the keggers/SFRavers relationship turn to something most
positive in two stages. The first stage was the arrival of Matt , a 
thoroughly plastered fellow "from Coyote Point , dude". He had gotten 
a cigarette from one of our folks , and was negotiating the profoundly
complicated task of getting it lit. I tried to oblige , but the cigarette
just wouldn't light. It was then I noticed that he had put it in his
mouth backward - filters don't burn well. He got another cigarette , and
successfully got it going. It was then that some more Liguid * folks walked
up to us and offered the fellow a smoking bomber of a joint , which he did
not seem displeased to see. Matt , the happy drunk , soon joined us down
in the dance area.

 He had mentioned that the keg was empty , and his friends were going to 
be carrying it by any time . As I stood on the plateau above our party,
I did see three folks with a squat shiny object. Through some impulse (
maybe I wanted to make things "better" ) , I decided to go talk to them.
Maybe I was encouraged that one of them was a gal. 

 One of them did a semi-apology for having "a lot of drunks", I took that
in the best light, and kept on chatting. I wanted to tell them that Matt
was with us - a guy in no shape to drive or maybe even walk alone. So,
Matt's friends decided to check him and us out .

 "Is this a pay admission thing?"

 "Oh no , we're , like , a club - we just wanted to have a LATE party ."

 So , they came down to join us and find Matt - bringing the empty keg
and their little boom-box. I left and rejoined the party a few times ,
as I was watching the parking lot , since they were expecting some folks
in an RV to come back and pick up the keg and them. I wanted to tell 
their drivers where they had ended up. Of course , this would have been
unecessary - I could hear them whooping from the parking lot. The times
I returned to the party , the keggers seemed to be at a happier level -
and , accordingly , the SFRavers around them. The funniest part was when 
they used their Maglites as strobes!

 Poor Matt fell over some stuff near the DJ table  ,but seemed none the 
worst for it . At that , our visitors decided to leave us - to grins 
( many of relief ) all around.

 There's a story ( probably apocryphal ) about a primitive self-help
treatment for a troubled mind. The patient is supposed to lug a huge rock
up to the highest local point, and then toss the heavy damn thing away.
The physical feeling of relief is supposed to transfer to a mental
relief. Well , I felt just like that fabled primitive when those guys 
left - just like I had heaved a great big problem away off a cliff! I was
bouncing like a rubber ball! Wheeeee!

 I don't know if it was a concious thing by Laura , or just my carefree
mood , but the music seemed to jump up another positive notch at the
same time. 

 After doing some more working out , it was time for me to call it quits.
Raffaela and I left during Ernie's set - I hope Liquid * closed safely
and joyfully!

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

( PS - Thanks to Laura for finding the new location. Thanks again to her
  and the rest of the DJs for the great music! And thanks to Bryce for 
  the sound system! )


( PPS - Nice to meet the SFRavers I know , and some new ones! Now , I'm
        going to bed! )

 > scene back when they started having raves there.  Personally, I 
 > don't consider
 > any event held in a club -- no matter how well-done -- to be a rave. 

I could see this as being very true.  It all depends on how one defines a
"rave".  For me, generally it's just the music.  But maybe I haven't
experienced enough of what you would call "raves" to distinguish.  I have only
been to 1 rave outside the bay area, and when I think about it, it was
definitely a different vibe:  Garden of Eden in Boulder, Colorado.  It was
pretty commercial, but the vibe was very positive, since it was away from the
big city types, and it attracted a lot of earthy-type ravers (and
high-schoolers too, but they were OK).  Well, now that I have more freedom to
choose the raves I go to, having not been as well connected as I am now, I
mopst certainly will go to more of what you call "raves" as ooposed to thge club thangs.

Well, a lot of the time, these people who I'm talking about *are* bothering me.

do it to surrounding people.  I've been elbowed and pushed around many a time
by a drunken jock or gangster who's looking for a fight.  Am I supposed to keep
my eyes closed when I see others making fun of the people around them, or
purposely trying to be an asshole for the sole purpose of being a downer for
everyone else?

On Sat, 16 Jul 1994, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> I was watching CNN (to check out the comet collision thingie) and saw our
> very own Brian Behlendorf (representing Wired Magazine) who got his very
> own 15 second video-byte during an report on pornography on the
> internet. Something about a case at Lawrence Livermore Nat'l Labs where an
> employee got suspended for putting up nudie pictures on what appeared to be
> the web. He said something about "in any community there will be a red
> light district".... :-)

Actually it was "In any community of 20 million people, you're going to 
have a red light district.  It's to be expected".   So they reshowed it
this morning?  Cool, I actually haven't seen it yet (only have the 
transcript :)

Basically they called Wired magazine the morning that story broke asking 
for a demonstration of the internet and how easy or hard it is to 
download images.  No one else wanted to do it, as the whole fact that this
story was considered important seemed stupid to us, but Hakim Bey 
notwithstanding I thought maybe we could help put things in perspectve.  
KTVU also interviewed me on the same subject a little later, and 
supposedly was a lot better about it (although the KTVU reporter wanted 
us to show him "the front screen to the Internet.  You know, when you log 
in".  Sigh!)

And after all this, my parents wanted to know why CNN would consider me 
an expert on net pornography :)

	Brian

On Sat, 16 Jul 1994 jesus.chrysler@sfnet.com wrote:

> 
> 
>  > why be 
>  > so concerned with what other people are doing?  Unless those punkers 
>  > you 
>  > are referring to are doing something specific to you to interfere 
>  > with 
>  > your space, then why expend the energy even talking about them?  
> 
> Well, a lot of the time, these people who I'm talking about *are* bothering me.
>  And if they're not doing something to me directly, like I've said before, they
> do it to surrounding people.  I've been elbowed and pushed around many a time
> by a drunken jock or gangster who's looking for a fight.  Am I supposed to keep
> my eyes closed when I see others making fun of the people around them, or
> purposely trying to be an asshole for the sole purpose of being a downer for
> everyone else?
> 
I don't know what to say for you.  I've seen those same type of people, 
and they have bothered me in the past, and they still do now, but I have 
found that when I ignore those kind of people, I simply do not see them 
anymore.  I don't feel I should be concerned with what they are doing, 
because they cannot change unless they want to.  So being concerned with 
those people, in my eyes, is worthless.  I am a much more peaceful person 
inside now that I "pay little attention to pop culture" as someone said.  
Jesus, I think if you just try to see this situation my way (I have done 
so for your point of view), I think you could get something out of it, 
and you could end up enjoying raves so much more.
