Hi Folx--

I must agree with Darren Atherton and nToy V Garcia
in regard to the seemingly interminable and endless           
escalation of argumemnts over the Signs & Symbols of
Inner Peace.  It started innocently enough with a couple
of us having a different view of one or two of its points,
and it looks like unless I end it here the posts will get
longer and longer, and increasingly self-justifying. I
must say I agree with Darren Atherton and Tony V Gracia:

> Actually I thought the original post was as beautiful and sweet as the music
> we listen to all week..
>
> I wish there were more posts like it..

>
>> Thank you.  It almost seems like we're just arguing it into the ground
>> now, which is too bad, but I am glad to see that at least one person
>> takes it at face value and not much more.
 

The music and parties I've enjoyed this week have just
reinforced my notion of how great a world there is out
there, and how rave culture is a small but beautiful part
of it: the Italian and Brazilian World Cup Games and party 
celebrations in S.F. on Wednesday that--especially in the
case of the Brazilians--show how people can really party;
and Babatunde Olatunji and the Drums of Passion last night .
at Palookaville that showed how much live energy love we can 
all share when our heart chakras are open to each other
through the vibrationalhealing of music!

I look forward to tonight's events--from ComeUnity to the
Zippies--to top off and lead into what should be a truly
insane tomorrow when Italy and Brazil meet!  If you haven't
been to the afterparties of events like these, go--they are
like block parties in Rio during Carnaval!

ciao,
Will

P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?
     Will you ever answer any of my private posts to you?

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
The earth becomes heaven when you release your fear.
ILLUMINATIONS  Stephen C.Paul & Gary Max Collins  HarperSanFrancisco  1991

Even though I worried for our safety when 6 tall drunk guys turned
up to mosh at Liquid *, I had a GREAT time overall.

HUGE THANKS to Bryce, without who's soundsystem we'd be nothing :-)
        to Tamara, Lee, and Deaks for the good music
        to Larry for patrolling and watching out for the rest of us
        to all the people who showed up post-SPAZ or wherever they were
        to Samir and Adam for bringing their "renegade-virgin" friends
        to everyone for coming, dancing, sharing food and water, helping
                to haul gear and pick up trash

One thing that really stood out for me was that I got to play a bunch
of records I've been hoarding . . . or afraid to play . . . 150 to 160
bpm techno tracks.  I felt it went over well and have disproved to myself
my old theory that San Francisco hates the harder and faster stuff.  So
I won't bitch about that any more :-) :-)  What was even cooler though
was that from Tamara's old-style acid and funky set to Lee's house to
Deaks' progressive to my fast trance to Bryce's homage to Ritchie
Hawtin people really showed a lot of appreciation for what was played.
You all are just the greatest!

Laura

From: stevec@cafe.berkeley.edu (Steve Collins)

Subject: Liquid *
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yet another great Liquid Everything party.  Everytime I go to one I feel more
and more a part of our little family.  It's really good to try and get back to
these small, tribal communities which will help each other and support each
other, especially in times of need.

I don't know what else I can say about the party specifically that hasn't been
said before.  I do want to bring up one point, though: I realize that there
were, in fact, one or two people from the other party who were being mean.
But the point at which there was the most animosity is when the main power
cord became loosed from the generator.  I would like to ask: did anyone SEE
the other party people purposely and with malicious intent pull the power
cord?  Maybe they just tripped on it and pulled it loose, and then,
realizing what they'd done, instinctively ran, having been brought up in a
hostile and unforgiving society (assuming we'd try kick their asses because
they interrupted our party).

Maybe that's not what happened, and maybe some would argue it's not
particularly likely, but you never can tell.  I would rather give them the
benefit of the doubt (I'd already given them some bagels, what the heck :) )

My one regret was that my good friend Laurel, who is not a regular raver 
(yet), was all ready to go with me but then decided she was too tired.  Too
bad, becauce she would have had a lot of fun, and she's also an incredibly
powerful presence whom I'm sure we all would have benefited from.  Oh well,
I'll make sure she gets to the next one, and see if we can get her to join
our family!

Particular thanks go out to all the DJ's for great music (I think Laura's
and my musical appreciation brainwaves must be on the same frequency), Deaks
for the Japanese twix things (that was deaks right?  I can't understand how
I've been raving all this time and I'm _still_ horrible with names), Marie
for the tasty apple, and eternal thanks to Brian, Bryce, and the Cap'n for
offering spiritual leadership.  I shouldn't even single out these people
though because _everyone_'s presence is important equally.

thanks to all,
stevie

p.s. my personal apologies for the fact that the earth did not in fact start
spinning in the oppostie direction during the night.  Oh well, better luck
next time.

Hi all,

Liquid Air was my second party to attend from SFR and again I really enjoyed
myself.
Although as mentioned before a "kegger group" was not too far away and some
interresting individuals would come stumbling by, until the time I left all
was lots of fun.  
Thanks to Bryce for putting the event together and Laura being an incredible
source of positive energy they managed to make this another evening to
remember.  Again I did not get to listen to Laura's set (last time I got
there too late and this time I was too tired to wait until 3:00am for her
set.)  Laura hopefully next time.

Getting back to Good Liquid...
The analogy here is very simple.  SFR was the good Liquid VS the Kegger
being, well... the not so good Liquid.. ??..
What I'm getting to is that I was very impressed by the warm, friendly,
sincere and very mature attitude the SFRs have as a group.  Their "Liquid" of
choice was water or juice mixed with lots of high energy adrenalin,
incredibly good music and a sence of peace with themselves and nature.  A
very big contrast to the OTHER group.  Keep up the good work, Bryce, Laura,
Brian and everyone else involved.
I'm planning to go to Free Fall tonight, in about 2 minutes, cause it sounds
like the music could be very good.  Lets check it out.

Until next time...thanks a lot all.

Denis

I've told a lot of you this personally, but I wanted to make a general an-
nouncement to all those who have met me, been nice to me, taken care of me, or
just helped provide a good vibe during my time near SF -

I'm pretty much decided that after I (I hope) receive my degree in December,
I'm moving back to my home, Illinois.  I have learned much from my travels
here, but it's time I go back to my blood realtives, my heritage, my climate,
my culture, at least for a while before i go traveling off somewhere else.
I'm especially excited to be reunited with some old friends whose intellects
and creativities all resonate really well with each other and mine.  We're
hoping that together we can accomplish some really powerful and exciting
things.

Don't think of me as leaving for good though; think of me as SFRaves's
ambassador to Chicago!  I intend to share the knowledge I have gained here.
My brain is already working on how we can get some more renegades going
there (there probably are some already, but I don't know about them).  It's
hard in a state that has so little waterfront property that seemingly every
inch of it is owned and patrolled, but we'll figure something out.  Also,
I'm thinking of trying to bring raves to Waukegan, my actual home town.
It's a podunk town, but but there are definitely a few people there who are
just as eager to shatter dominant paradigms as I am but haven't had the
opportunities that I've been so blessed to have.

I'll definitely be staying in touch with sfraves via email to get everyone's
help and input to achieve these goals.

So as you can see, I'm pretty excited about the whole thing.  But on the
other hand I'm going to get as much out of my last 5 months in SF as I can!

Here's to you all, and thanks again.

love, 
stevie

Precedence: bulk

 
 As to the disconnection of the power cord - as they were leaving , they
trailed the power cord ( this I determine via body language and by their
heads looking down towards the ground ). Then , the main group made a 
sudden and obvious fade up the hill as the one guy bent down to the ground.
The power did not cut off until after he was rising back up to a standing
posture. By these signs , I think it was a deliberate decision by at 
least one of them to disconnect our power cord. 

 ------------------------

 In a large part , I feel the nonviolent and forgiving/tolerating stance
of the Liquid * participants truly prevented a deadly inflation of the
problems we had with the other party. We saw that one of their games 
was "I push you , you push me" - as an actual physical game , and as 
a psychological one ( Their "push" was to invade our "space" , be obnoxious,
and mess with our equipment ). Since we didn't "push" back , they didn't 
get a chance to prove how tough they were.

 Even then , it took that one "rotten apple" among them to really crank
up our tensions ( the guy who disconnected our power and tossed pebbles
at us ). If he hadn't left the site entirely , the evening may have turned 
out differently. Maybe his own pals had gotten tired of his shit.

 As it turned out , good vibes and nonviolence wins again! :-/ ( For a 
contrast, refer to the bad raver/gang problem that happened at Candlestick
Park months ago. Luckily , we got some "regular dudes" instead of 
gangsters last night. ).

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Subject: Endless Arguments Over
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Sun, 17 Jul 1994 05:46:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Will writes:
>
>P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?

This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes to
on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.

I find e-mail a superior verbal communication to either the telephone or
in person.  E-mail allows you to sit down when YOU have time to
comfortably think about what you are reading.  On the phone or in
person, two things happen:

(1) I can't fully relate all that I'd like to say about the topic
because it takes a moment or two to collect my thoughts.
(2) I find that in 80% of cases, the conversation veers into a different
direction before an interesting aspect is discussed.

Now, there is, of course, the non-verbal aspects which are very much
enhanced in person.  But, I'm married :-) and I find that the other
non-verbal aspects, ie raving, happen just being in the room with
everyone.

So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with a
specific e-mail address :-) ?

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

From sfraves-owner  Sat Jul 16 23:26:48 1994

Received: from nbn.nbn.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.5/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA02568; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 23:26:43 -0700
Received: from cyberden.com (uucp@localhost) by nbn.nbn.com (8.6.4/8.6.4) with UUCP id XAA14881 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 16 Jul 1994 23:26:16 -0700
Message-Id: <199407170626.XAA14881@nbn.nbn.com>
Date: 17 Jul 1994 01:03:09 GMT
From: Jake@cyberden.com (Jake)
Organization: The CyberDen - 415.472.5527
Reply-To: Jake@cyberden.com
Subject: Re: Yes, Virginia, there ARE parties greater than raves!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was in Los Gatos with some friends (including several Brazilians) after
Brazil beat the US.  The news said there were two or three thousand
"revelers."  The scene was strikingly rave-like (a "revel"?)-- throngs of
people, some drummers, an occasional horn player, and lots of happy people
spinning, dancing and looking for the slightest excuse to sing "OLE ole ole
ole... Bra-ziiiil... Bra-ziiiil"

There were nationalistic overtones, but also "OLE... U-S-A..." too, which I
thought was nice, and something I found hard imagining Americans doing had
they won.

Another comment:  there were about a billion cops from several counties.  At
about one AM they proceeded to try to shut the party down, forbidding entry
into bars, and streets; hasselling drummers and dancing groups.  This
confused the Brazilian tourists quite a bit. It was a good example of the
insecurity of authority figures presented with a lot of people having fun.

You should have seen the motorcycle cops being surrounded by lauging dancing
people (my friends too) trying to get the cop to smile as we took group
pictures with him while he and his partners tried to break up our "dance
cell" using sirens and divide-and-conquer techniques.  Love and happiness won
out and they just made their escape temporarily, although many were freaked
out at the inappropriate seeming show of force.

It seems to me that by, in their minds, trying to prevent violence or
misconduct, the hard-handed behavior of the cops were actually creating
animosity, resentment and the nucleus for opposition.  Same old story really.

Why do people dislike it when other people are having a lot of fun?  I don't
know, but I've found it to be a depressing and widespread human trait since
partying in high school and college...

My point-- the World Cup celebrations really are rave-like, including their
eliciting of unreasonning negativity by uptight authority figures who equate
a little abandon with criminal behavior.  A legacy of (N.) America's
Quaker/Pilrim/Protestant work-good-go-to-heaven, and
play-bad-wanton-irresponsible-go-to-hell moral foundation, perhaps. : )

Here's to a little tolerance and post-judice instead of paranoid prevention
and prejuduce.  Let us revel!

j a k e

--
The CyberDen - Worldwide Alternative Music & Entertainment Network
415-472-5527 - Labels, Zines, Multimedia, Bands, Artists, Cultures
cyberden.com - Telnet and anonymous FTP -> Info: info@cyberden.com

Fritzit says:

>What we read was something to the effect of "look for the guy
>in the yellow and blue sweats who will give you something" or
>something like that.  I didn't have to read much into it . . .

Well, that was DJ Deaks describing himself so he could meet people
because he's new to SFRaves.  He was giving away these awesome
almond cookie sticks that were dipped in chocolate.

You DID read too much into it.  Remember, rave doesn't ALWAYS
equal drugs, and people who are giving things away sometimes
really ARE generous and begnin and just want to share chocolate.

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 17 12:26:26 1994

	id m0qPbqu-0003V1C; Sun, 17 Jul 94 12:26 PDT

From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Sun, 17 Jul 1994 12:26:20 PST
In-Reply-To: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
       "Endless Arguments Over" (Jul 17,  5:46am)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Endless Arguments Over
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ken writes:

>Will writes:
>>
>>P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?
>
>This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes to
>on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.
>
>I find e-mail a superior verbal communication to either the telephone or
>in person.  E-mail allows you to sit down when YOU have time to
>comfortably think about what you are reading.  On the phone or in
>person, two things happen:

But what does this have to do with going raving?  Will SPECIFICALLY
asked if you ever go raving, and you didn't answer his question even 
though you claim that talking over email is so much less prone to errors 
than other forms.  If so, then how can it be when you've completely missed 
his simple and direct yes or no question? :-)   

Do you ever go raving, i.e. going out and actually HEARING the music you 
keep asking me about, dancing around, soaking up the atmosphere, and getting 
some hugs and smiles?

People can try to verbally describe music until they are blue in the
face or until their fingers fall off from typing, but until you've
gone and heard lots of examples yourself and heard for yourself how
a DJ works and how the dancers respond, it's not the same as email.

>So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with a
>specific e-mail address :-) ?

Direct human contact with those whom we endlessly debate often gives
rise to greater understanding.  It also allows you to meet people 
with whom you'd otherwise not exchange email and in that way extend
your connections with the community.

Two years ago when ne-raves was first getting started there were 
endless stupid flame wars.  I then decided to throw a big party at
my house before a big rave so that the "email addresses" from the
list could meet face to face.  The result was phenomenal.  ne-raves
was transformed from a lot of sterile semantic debate into a huge
love-fest.  Once the initial euphoria wore off, a feeling of
family solidarity remained for quite some time.  To this day ne-ravers
go out of their way for each other to offer rides to parties, to 
offer crash space after parties, to cooperate to have picnics, 
dinner parties, nights out in cafes or restaraunts, and to even throw
raves.  None of this started happening until people actually met 
face to face. The transformation really was amazing.  (There are still
endless stupid flame wars, and I really think that this is due to
the fact that email is a very PROTECTIVE medium -- it allows you to
say things to people you never would in person because there is no
raw physical humanity for you to go face to face with.)

Here in SF, too, I've seen similar things on a smaller scale.  I distinctly 
recall a lot of bickery email going around before the Friends and Family
party at Komotion.  Two of the three combatants (and you were the third)
met in person at the party.  I made sure they got introduced.  The result
was smiles and hugs and declarations of new-found feelings of friendship.

Nothing beats first-hand experience, be it of music, of that ephermeral
quality known as "vibe," or of another person.

Laura


From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 17 13:04:39 1994

Date: Sun, 17 Jul 94 16:04:32 -0400
From: Bob Ramstad <boccibob@media.mit.edu>
Message-Id: <9407172004.AA12714@media.mit.edu>
To: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org
Cc: SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Subject: in person vs email
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ken sez:

> This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes
> to on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.

> So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with
> a specific e-mail address :-) ?

well, personally, i've found that sfraves became 10000% more rewarding
once i started regularly physically interacting with the people on the
list.  ymmv.

maybe it's some facet of insecurity or curiosity that drives it, but i
basically found myself really needing to meet these people.

i also wanted to be involved in the group, and the reality is that one
ongoing major activity of the group is actually throwing raves.  i
happen to be of the opinion that it's probably the most important
thing that this group does.  we HAVE provided an alternative scene
which, more importantly than just being different, we have
specifically tailored to be something which we enjoy immensely.

so, in the context of sfraves, i think that it's really important for
people on the list to interact IRL.  some great friendships have come
of it, and i think that the more loving connections between people,
the better.

in the greater context of the net, and as someone who has been on the
net for eight years, it appears to me that the longer you spend on the
net, the more you realize how important really meeting the person is.
(i'm not the only one who thinks this, btw, it's something which many
researchers in teleconferencing / virtual reality are thinking about.)

of course, these are all my opinions.  you'll probably only truly
value them if you've met me before :-)

i miss you guys!
Bob

My mailer says that Steve Collins said:
> 
> I do want to bring up one point, though: I realize that there
> were, in fact, one or two people from the other party who were being mean.
> But the point at which there was the most animosity is when the main power
> cord became loosed from the generator.  I would like to ask: did anyone SEE
> the other party people purposely and with malicious intent pull the power
> cord?  Maybe they just tripped on it and pulled it loose, and then,
> realizing what they'd done, instinctively ran, having been brought up in a
> hostile and unforgiving society (assuming we'd try kick their asses because
> they interrupted our party).
> 
I personally saw someone in a white sweatshirt and jeans, about 5'9"
brown medium length hair slightly stumble over the cord, then pick
it up, and follow it to the generator.  he then went over to his friends.
they wandered about for a bit, then went up a path to the top of the rise. 
this individual was the last in the group.  he, as he passed by the
generator, fished around the ground again to find the power cable, followed
it to the generator, and pulled the plug.  Definitely with a purpose.  He
then ran up to the top of the rise, laughing and nudging his friends, who
also laughed and twittered.  As i was walking toward the generator, i sent
some harsh words in their direction, including the stratightforward 
question: "don't you have anything better to do?"  the reply was, "No!"
to which laura responded, "well, go do it somewhere else."  end of exchange.
after that, we simply kept a watchful eye on them to ensure no further
mischief.

that incident, as well as the throwing of bagels and pebbles and lighting
of firecrackers amidst the dancers were clearly not mindless mistakes.  to my
knowledge, no lasting physical damage was done to anyone.  however, these
acts of "mischief" were, to me, intentional.

my response to these actions was primarily watchfulness.  lots of people
continued to dance, and the djs played on through all of this, including
several visits by our neighbors.  larry mentioned that he spoke with some
of these folks.  i don't think there was any malice on anyone's part, ours
or theirs.  for my part, i did not want them messing with the equipment
(since it's mine or my responsibility), nor physically harming anyone 
(even unintentionally).  it seems that once we established that as a ground
rule of sorts, we got along much better.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Michael Kellner <mkellner@apple.com>
Subject: Re: Liquid *
To: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Date: Sun, 17 Jul 94 15:41:28 PDT
Cc: stevec@cafe.berkeley.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
> 
>  In a large part , I feel the nonviolent and forgiving/tolerating stance
> of the Liquid * participants truly prevented a deadly inflation of the
> problems we had with the other party.

I found the mix of cultures quite interesting. Yes, there were some
bad apples in the bunch, but I think a lot of the keggers were curious
as to what we were doing. There is not way they could have "raved"
quite like we did - can you imagine dancing with a belly full of
beer, ech!!

There was a definite "sphere of influence" that the sf-ravers put
around our party. What with moving our dancing bodies between the
potential trouble-makers and the equipment, a buffer zone was made
and the "invaders" were kept at bay.

When the group left, the music definitely seemed happier (on purpose?)
and I felt the group accomplished something by standing our ground and
keeping everything peaceful.
 
>  As it turned out , good vibes and nonviolence wins again! :-/ 

Yes, it did. I want to thank everyone involved. Liquid * was my 
second rave (after July 4 Liquid Draino). I made some good friends
and had a terrific time. Thank you all - see you again soon.

-Mike

  The SPAZ/Zippie party was definetley one of the best parties I've been 
to all summer.   There were essentialy three rooms, the front 
entrance/bongo lounge ... The main dance area, and the chill space down 
below.  The vibe was plain and simple: DANCE DANCE DANCE.  With the 
exception of the ambient area, I never saw anyone NOT dancing!

  The atmosphere was this weird sort of techno-psychedlia.  They had 
some great black light art and lots of other wierd stuff painted on the 
walls, not to mention the video projections and the other assorted 
effects.  I was under the impression that the building the party was in 
was the 'zippies' HQ.  Does anyone know what the deal is with that 
location?  I really hope they decide to throw some more parties there.

  Now to the subject of this post... Does anyone have any mix tapes of 
that super super intense hardcore acid they were playing around 2-3am.  I 
thought I had heard it all, but that stuff was phenomenal.  The ripping 
analog bass lines grabbed  hold of my entire body and sent me stomping 
like a mad man! I need to hear some more of that stuff :)

Peace out...

-Ernie

Date: Sun, 17 Jul 1994 17:41:08 -0700
From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Message-Id: <199407180041.AA10269@quack.kfu.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Zippy/SPAZ was nuts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I must agree that this was a very very high energy gathering of people and
also in what looked like someone's flat.  The music was intensely fast and
everyone was going WHACK-o.  I think it was around 3am that they started
doing LIVE techno with about 3 guys and a bunch of keyboards all piped through
the mixer so that the DJ could fill in his own stuff too.  THAT sent the crowd
into this frenzy... I wish I could have joined the pit of people but my body
just couldn't do it.  (one of the reasons why I couldn't get out to Liquid *
unfortunately) And the location was really quite a trip with spirals painted
on the walls and floor.  There was some guy behind the DJ doing some video
editing which I couldn't quite understand, but it seemed to add to this aura
of "technology" with all the keyboards, turntables, computers and tv screens
crammed into what looked like the kitchen.

Speaking of the Los Gatos world cup celebrations, I was there after Brazil
beat the U.S. and I felt that high energy-togetherness thing that was all
over the place, which definitely showed that there are a lot of people out
there who have that rave-desire, but haven't taken steps to find out.  But
what I also noticed was that it was dangerous.  People were throwing lit
fireworks into the crowd, causing a fast movement of many bodies in several
directions (almost like a riot) and then just kept-on chanting and even
started slam dancing pretty hardcore in the large crowd (prolly only because
it was a crowd).  Ok, I never saw anyone get hurt, but there sure was a lot
of potential for it.  

Luckily, the police were there to click their flashlights on and off.  WI felt
so much at ease!
:)

Tony V Garcia writes:
 > Could you tell us less cultured folks what the Oceana Project is?  

It was a project to build a nation on a huge floating island. The
constitution was really neat; no "consentual crimes" were possible.
No protecting you from yourself, etc. Quite an enlightened document.

The project was going on for quite a while, and then at one point they
decided they just couldn't raise ther money, and it was ended.

Sean

On 17 Jul 1994, Jake wrote about the World Cup:

> about one AM they proceeded to try to shut the party down, forbidding entry
> into bars, and streets; hasselling drummers and dancing groups.  This
> confused the Brazilian tourists quite a bit. It was a good example of the
> insecurity of authority figures presented with a lot of people having fun.

Here in Washington D.C. tonight the Brazillians we're partying all over the
place having fun and driving up and down M St in Georgetown waving flags
and dancing on the top of their cars. Even tho i was going for Italy who'd
id got a chance play Nigeria, The party was so much fun i ran up and down
the streets huging various people and high fiving a many more.
   And the cops didn't stop the party, and actually in another part of town
closed off a road so people could celebrate
> 
> My point-- the World Cup celebrations really are rave-like, including their
> eliciting of unreasonning negativity by uptight authority figures who equate
> a little abandon with criminal behavior.  A legacy of (N.) America's
> Quaker/Pilrim/Protestant work-good-go-to-heaven, and
> play-bad-wanton-irresponsible-go-to-hell moral foundation, perhaps. : )
> 
  Id venture to say that the World Cup although its competition and all
is basically all about fun. I've had a lot of fun taking part in the 
different celebrations i have been part with, either Nigerians, or
Saudi Arabians or Italians, or Brazilians (or even Americans ;) and
going to the games. The World Cup was as amazing as attending a rave.
  Raves and the World Cup tap into the same vein of: "Look life can
suck but here we can create are little utopia and just dance, cheer,
hug, run around act crazy, but by all means have fun!" And it definately
was like that for me Im really gonna miss all the Cup has brought with
it over the past month :)

> Here's to a little tolerance and post-judice instead of paranoid prevention
> and prejuduce.  Let us revel!
> 
I'm with that!

doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

Laura writes:
>Ken writes:
>>Will writes:
>>>
>>>P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?
>>
>>This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes to
>>on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.
>
>But what does this have to do with going raving?  Will SPECIFICALLY
>asked if you ever go raving, and you didn't answer his question even
>though you claim that talking over email is so much less prone to errors
>than other forms.  If so, then how can it be when you've completely missed
>his simple and direct yes or no question? :-)

Because this is such a ridiculous question that the only result of the
question can be the thought -- why did this person ask this question?

(Can you imagine posting to someone on alt.cult-movies "Do you ever go
to see movies?" or to someone on alt.soccer "Do you ever watch soccer?")

The only plausible reason has to do with:

>Here in SF, too, I've seen similar things on a smaller scale. I distinctly
>recall a lot of bickery email going around before the Friends and Family
>party at Komotion.  Two of the three combatants (and you were the third)
>met in person at the party.  I made sure they got introduced.  The result
>was smiles and hugs and declarations of new-found feelings of friendship.

But you see there is a BIG problem with this.  All that has happened is
that you've moved someone from within the "them" circle to the "us"
circle.  What we need is to do this with EVERYONE - ie eliminate the
"them" circle.  As I mentioned to you in private e-mail (I hope you
received that), what set me off was that the supposed "narc" was treated
with prejudice as "them".  What was stupid on my part was to treat the
person who did that, as "them" :-).

The idea that we're supposed to be introduced and then never take
exception to false statements :-) :-) seems pretty silly to me.

>>So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with a
>>specific e-mail address :-) ?
>
>Direct human contact with those whom we endlessly debate often gives
>rise to greater understanding.

Greater understanding of what?  I have friends I see every week (as a
group) and I know less about them than I know of many people I converse
with on e-mail - because of what I said before about the usual
meandering nature of conversations.

> It also allows you to meet people
>with whom you'd otherwise not exchange email and in that way extend
>your connections with the community.

Ah, but this is the opposite of my question.  If I go to a rave, meet
someone, and say "How can I contact you later?", that person might say
"Do you have e-mail?".  This has nothing to do with meeting people we
know on e-mail previously.

> I then decided to throw a big party at
>my house before a big rave so that the "email addresses" from the
>list could meet face to face.  The result was phenomenal.  ne-raves
>was transformed from a lot of sterile semantic debate into a huge
>love-fest.  To this day ne-ravers
>go out of their way for each other to offer rides to parties, to
>offer crash space after parties, to cooperate to have picnics,
>dinner parties, nights out in cafes or restaraunts, and to even throw
>raves.

But again, this also works in reverse, otherwise there would be no rave
scene at all.  Someone throws a rave, people discover that there are
other people like them who are willing to take a chance in order to
experience the love vibe, they exchange phone numbers (and/or e-mail
addresses), meet at cafes or for lunch, etc.

>Nothing beats first-hand experience, be it of music, of that ephermeral
>quality known as "vibe," or of another person.

But this is just what I said in the part of my post that you deleted in
your response.

And we all do all of those things.  But I feel that we should interact
with EVERYONE on e-mail (or elsewhere) as if they were a close friend.
I'm unlikely to ever rave with Tony in Miami or Sigi in Australia or
Chrome in Amsterdam -- should I treat them differently??

Interestingly, the question at the top came at the end of a thread where
the OTHER person was advocating the place of "conflict" and THEN feels
the need to meet in person because we've been having this e-mail conflict.
:-) amazingly ironic :-).

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

PS Anyone know the exact time of the full moon this week?

Larry says:

> with an apparent age and intoxication spread which was much wider than
> the first assumption of "high schoolers". One of them , a short-haird
> guy in his late twenties or early thirties , whith a vauge "cop" feel
> to him , stood on the ridge over our party , just listening to
> Laura's set. I talked to him a bit , invited him to dance , but he just
> wanted to listen. Later , he left in an RV with three other folks from 
> his party.
> 
>  Great music by Laura!
> 
> 
>  I think the keggers/SFRavers relationship turn to something most
> positive in two stages. The first stage was the arrival of Matt , a 
> thoroughly plastered fellow "from Coyote Point , dude". He had gotten 
> a cigarette from one of our folks , and was negotiating the profoundly
> complicated task of getting it lit. I tried to oblige , but the cigarette
> just wouldn't light. It was then I noticed that he had put it in his
> mouth backward - filters don't burn well. He got another cigarette , and
> successfully got it going. It was then that some more Liguid * folks walked
> up to us and offered the fellow a smoking bomber of a joint , which he did
> not seem displeased to see. Matt , the happy drunk , soon joined us down
> in the dance area.

Actually, it *was* quite funny. I had gone up there(since I had just
finished off my left ankle in the "track" next to the right speaker.).
to smoke and enjoy the lovely music and people below, when Matt came up
and sat next to me. It was obvious he wanted to bum a smoke, but thought
it was decent to make small talk first. So he said, "Where are you from, 
duuuude ?". I said, "India". He was a bit puzzled, "India,dude ? I 
live right over there---------> where those lights are.."...

I had just come to the party, and didnt know that he wasn't part of it..

In any case, it was a great party, and thanks to you all...
my only regret is that Laura's music refused to let my legs stay still,
and my ankle was forced to 'enjoy' in silent, joyous protest.:)

On Sat., we went to 177 Townsend..but were put off by the $15/- cover..
and landed up at the uppity jazz place on 2nd near Brannan.:p
Like someone else had suggested, why not advertise the cover charge on
the answering machine, as well? I can't see it doing any harm.,.

..And to make the weeekend perfect, Brazil won!!!!!
There weren't enuf of us Brazil fans in Ireland's 32( spoiled the
'vibe' for the Italian(Irish-turned-Italian fans, tho:)), tho..and the line
outside Bahia was 100+ strong at 1030(2 hours before kickoff):(...


> 
Looking forward to the next party..:)

regarding the amusing case of ignorance on the part of the TV reporter
  when talking to Brian, i think it's GOOD that there's still a bit of
    mystery regarding the Net; it probably keeps some of the most
      seriously clueless peeple outta harm's way; kindof like not wanting
        peeple on the freeway who don't know what a steering wheel is...
    (am i being elitist?)

oceania was an idea ahead of it's time, (kinda sea-quest-ish...) which
  was to create an ocean-borne nation, which was immune from international
    lawz.  the list is still alive, but it's been merged with some
      libertarian list at MIT, i think...
Dave Scruton

>>The party was so much fun i ran up and down
>>the streets huging various people and high fiving a many more.

...huge-ing or hugging? :)

Either way, its pretty cool-- and I'd venture to guess that its a lot
different than, say, when the 49er's win the SuperBowl.  I'm generalizing of
course, but Americans "party" like the "Drunken kegger people" more so than
I've found in other cultures.

Some friends & I partied pretty heavily/regularly in college, and we'd always
get newcomers who thought our group were real "party animals."  Often they'd
want to thrash or harass someone, or be an asshole, to fit in with us.  The
stone thrower at Liquid reminds me of the type ("Hey I'm drunk let's fuck w/
something/somebody"). Is there just one in every crowd, or just one in every
American crowd?

I guess I'm belaboring the point because it fits into my diatribe of
excessive rule making and repressive type behavior modification usually
bakefire (like w/ drinking age limits, Catholic girls, drugs, and generally
partying).  I won't go into it now :)

Hey, just revel, man.

j a k e

Subject: a night of emusic
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Saturday night- we braved the big parties, avoided the zippies, and set up
the Weird Blinking Lights scientific sound lounge and it was AWESOME!

big thanx to BRYCE for providing the Metrovision Speakers. I have never
seen anyone as relaxed as he was- we could tell our sound was perfect because
he slept the *entire time*- the truest compliment for an ambient band.

The room looked awesome thanx to the decorative skills of WBL Arteests
peet seraphim and john "mandibles" tapeworm.

caliban spun everything from the Mahrahi Yogi to the the lunar landing tapes
overlaid with brian eno.

this was a first for live performance in SF by the famed WBL engineer
Doctor David van Brink (click the 7.0 text in the "monitors" portion of
your mac control panel). he did a traditional tape music of analog synth
piece. rocky jammed on the Nyles and analogs, and i had a small portion
of my analog arsenal.

we will next perform on aug 13 at FFIII at a time TBA.

hear you all there...

-rsn8

Subject: Jupiter Did It: What a Weekend!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 18 Jul 94 21:11:06 PDT
From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-ID:  <9407182111.aa01804@cruzio.com>

Hi Folx--

What a fabulous weekend this was!  I'm sure the *Jupiter Effect*
is doing it's thing!  The only regret I'd have, if I had regrets,
is that I didn't make it to the Come/Unity as I had intended be-
cause I was having so much fun, using so much energy, communing
with so many good friends, and dancing my arse off at their great
party!

My weekend was framed by zippy-related activities:
the truly excellent small rave on Stevenson Alley
that featured great spaces (chill room, drum area,
dance area with great altar and good sound and
visuals) and *mainly and finally* what ended up to be
more than six hours (!) of dj Goa Gil's Best DAT-ing
that had us all levitating from time to time!  The
zippies really showed that they can do it (I especially
liked pincus the parallel universe teuton at the door
and statuesque on the dance floor for at least an hour
near the end).
 
Going to a cafe full of Italians and Italian-Americans
to watch the World Cup Finals was extraordinary! The
spirit flowing around the huge TV--the highs and eventually
lows--was something we rarely experience in this country!
I had seen both matches on Wednesday in the semi-finals
and danced in the streets with Italia fans in the afternoon
in North Beach and endlessly with the Brasil fans in front
of Bahia off of Market, but the partying that the Brazilians
put on Sunday rivalled *any* rave soul and spirit I've ever
felt!  Wow!
 
Then today, Monday, I went by Crash Palace and saw the Cap'n
crunching in the adventures of his with the zippies and my
English friend Keith a poem of his for the pronoid cultural
anarchic CD-ROM they are making!  Anyone can put in anything:
song, writing, painting, dance, drama, you name it--it will be
a totally inclusive work of art.  And the ol' revived Kennel
Club looks great as the new Crash Palace!

I look forward to being of any help this weekend when our 
own Andrew of Epic Productions here in Santa Cruz puts on
the next zippy event!  If anyone needs crash space or other
requirements, please e-mail or phone me!  Looking forward
to seeing you-all!  Epic has put on some great parties here
so far--and this one promises to be spectacular.

End of superlatives!

ciao,
Will

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
The earth becomes heaven when you release your fear.
ILLUMINATIONS  Stephen C.Paul & Gary Max Collins  HarperSanFrancisco  1991

Sean sez--

> I said the Zippies had a silly name. And at SPAZ I found out they were
> real people and totally into our vibe and really nice. So I apologize
> to the Zippies and I pledge to try and not be so stuck up as to focus
> on a name when I should be trying to connect with _people_.  I am such
>a stuck-up dumbass sometimes.

Well, we *all* are!  That's really good of you to flgellate
yourself in public, Sean, but as the zippies are cultural
agents-provacateurs they open themselves for radical inter-
pretations.  I told some of them at the party on Stevenson
Saturday that they should contact Bill Griffith, the artist
who does Zippy the Pinhead comix, because Zippy is pronoid,
too, in a very existential, zen and idiot-savant sort of way.
I mean, we have to unite with our potential allies. In one
of his strips Zippy visits the Santa Cruz Beach and Boardwalk
because he heard it was one of the great sacred sitesf the
world.

I mean, how right can you be?

ciao, Will

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 17 Jul 1994 18:15:31 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: matt@tribe.tribe.com (Matt Stevens)
Subject: Fraser Clarke wants to stay in SF!

I had an interesting conversation with Fraser Clarke, impromptu-spokesman
for the Zippies, last night at their Jupiter Bash.  He was saying that he
feels as if SF is a newfound home, and that he wants to do something here
on the same scale as Megatripolis; he phrased it as wanting to bring
together the young and old, in groups of 3000 people or more, on a weekly
basis.  He says he plans to have a learning center similar to the Parallel
University, and is hoping to use the University angle as a way around
police harassment.  It will be very interesting to see what he pulls off!

As far as the show last night is concerned; it was wonderful!  Having raved
in most of the major rave-aware cities on the west coast I have to say the
vibe last night was unique.  Everyone there was there to dance, and the
music played just kept us dancing!  Hot, hard and sweaty; combine that with
people who love to dance and you've got the formula for a good party.

Congrats to SPAZ and all envolved for a really well done show.
--
matt

On Tue, 19 Jul 1994, Spaced-Out Funky Earthchild wrote:
> >like the damage to stop here. Before I learned what it was, I thought I 
> >was receiving some strange radio frequency. The ignorance of youth. 
> 
> Yo, how do YOU know that you're not listening to some alien or internal
> frequency?  Is that what a few Ph.Ds told doctors who then told you is 
> hearing damage?  
> 
> Did you know that if you listen carefully, the human soul can hear 7 to 10
> internally generated frequecies?  I haven't tried listening - someone told
> me that.  According to some people's description, some of them sound like
> a birds's sweet voice, small finger cymbals, buzzing of bees, the sounds of
> crowds in large gathering places, drums, etc. depending on which one you are
> focusing on.
> 
> Hearing damage?  Maybe, but maybe maybe not....

Sorry to dump this one into sfraves, space, but I thought some other 
folks might like to hear these factoids.

Actually, we designed a promo piece for an HMO a few years ago that was 
sprinkled with some interesting medical tidbits.

TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS, EAR, HUMAN

Quoted from memory, but all the figures are true...

"An adult human can hear frequencies of up to 20,000 Hz. Children can 
usually hear up to 40,000 Hz. Adult hearing extends down to 16 Hz. Any 
lower and you would be able to hear your muscles moving."

"The human ear is sensitive to energies down to one quadrillionth of a 
watt. If the ear were only slightly more sensitive, you would be able 
hear molecular collisions as backgound noise."

jmar! shhhhh!

Recently , apost from  "JMRTNKO, the real Chekov!" <martinko@netcom.com>
contained some info about the frequency limits of human hearing:
 
> 
> Quoted from memory, but all the figures are true...
> 
> "An adult human can hear frequencies of up to 20,000 Hz. Children can 
> usually hear up to 40,000 Hz. Adult hearing extends down to 16 Hz. Any 
> lower and you would be able to hear your muscles moving."
> 

 FM radio is specified to transmit sounds up to 15Khz. This was considered
good enough in the days when it was invented. In any case , most adults are
doing good to be hearing up to 15,000 Hz. To be considered "high fidelity",
audio equipment should be able to process frequencies cleanly up to 
20,000 Hz. 

 Of course , maybe I'm prejudiced - I've just tested myself with an audio
generator and a MDR-V6 headphone , and my hearing dropped off at 15,285 Hz.
I think I tried a similar experiment in my teen years , and I think I was
able to hear stuff up to 18,000 Hz. ( but I may have been hearing the
distortion in my test equipment ).

		Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

PS - That "test tone" that I occasionally hear - that I've mentioned in
 a previous post - seems to be at about 3664 Hz. I used the audio generator
 to attempt a duplication of the tone , as I remembered it.

 A quiz ( that I don't know the answer to ) - what musical note is 3664 Hz ?

From: meclay@netcom.com (Michael E. Clay)
Message-Id: <199407200723.AAA13617@netcom4.netcom.com>
Subject: Zippies, raves & cyberspace
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 20 Jul 1994 00:22:58 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

  Just thinking about the great gathering with the Zippies & SPAZ this past
  weekend. What a musical blowout - the music & visuals started good and
  improved all night. There was such a vibe leading to an ecstatically
  dancing early morning crowd - this was a good one! I'll assume that the
  gathering of the Z's in S. Cruz this weekend will be one happening
  place to be - starting at 4 outside and moving inside later in the 
  evening... the Zippies are in town and from all indications they like us
  and we like them - both sides have a lot in common.   

  I just met Will P. and Cap'n C. for the first time in the flesh and I for
  one find it nice to meet the people behind the "computer speak". What
  exciting times we live in! With even more options for interactions than
  ever before!!! 

  One great thing about the scene is its overall acceptance of and ability
  to appeal to people of all types - skin color, dress style, and age take
  a back seat to being with others and sharing the move groove.. This time
  around we have it a little better. In the 60's there was a paranoid 
  sense of not "trusting anyone over 30". Now; although not yet perfect; we
  find the willingness to accept anyone who can accept themselves, find
  an inner groove and share a bit of a smile. It's taking us back to tribal
  roots where after the work was done- people made music and celebrated.
  Think about it.. in tribal cultures the old and young took part in a
  united village celebration - the moon, the crops, the weather and change
  of seasons brought people together to make music and dance. And now the
  rave brings back some of this natural joy - and giving some of us a 
  chance to take at least a small step toward Pronoia. Maybe someone is
  trying to do something nice for us after all ! :-) (-: We meet and greet!

  Now at the risk of making this a little long a (reasonably short) file
  some of you might find of interest:




	----- Begin Forwarded Messages -----

Date: Fri,  8 Jul 94 10:54:59 PDT

In response to a number of requests (most of them from Brian Smith), I'm
posting a radio piece I did for "Fresh Air" a couple of days ago on the
language of the info age.

geoff nunberg

			  The Dactyls of October
			       Geoff Nunberg
	  Language Commentary for "Fresh Air," NPR, July 6, 1994


	I've been looking over the new magazines like Wired and Mondo 2000.
Cyberzines, they call themselves, the Vanity Fair or Interview of the
information age. As best I can figure the information age runs from 18 to
25. Or at least the magazines have a rather MTV cast to them. Jazzy fonts
on colored backgrounds, text running over the pictures. It's all very
engaging, but a little hard to read for someone of my decade and diopter. I
find myself yearning for the austere simplicity of the black-and-white
screen on my antique Mac. But maybe that's the point of these magazines, to
drive us all on line. Cyberquislings, boring from within.
	There's clearly something big afoot. There are echoes of the
sixties, with all its talk of revolution -- how the technology is going to
lead to universal empowerment and the end of hierarchy. You might think
nothing had changed in the last 30 years, except that now the relevant
technology is software engineering instead of pharmacology. It's not
surprising to find Timothy Leary on the editorial board of Mondo 2000,
having decided to drop in again now that things are once more getting
interesting.
	But the language of the age has nothing to do with the 60s. It's
cyberspeak, all those compounds patched together from the truncated
syllables of other words. Cyberspace, internet, ethernet, hypertext,
vaporware, ubicomp, nanotech, infobahn. You think of the fighter planes in
the old comic strips: pocketa, pocketa, pocketa, pocketa. I have heard the
future, and it speaks in dactyls. It's a rhythm we've heard before, but not
at Woodstock. This is the music of October, 1917. It's the way the
Bolsheviks consolidated their words, as ruthlessly as they consolidated
everything else: comintern for Communist International, agitprop for
agitation-propaganda, komsomol, Komkultur, sovnarkom. The words
had a willful ugliness, as George Orwell put it, as if to signal a break
with bourgeois aesthetics. It was was the language of technological
efficiency, literally telegraphic, the clipped syntax used for
communication by wire.
	The resemblances to cyberspeak are more than accidental. For one
thing, current computers constrain the shape of words in some of the same
ways that the telegraph did. There are the programming languages that won't
accept expressions with extra spaces in them, the operating systems won't
let you use more than eight letters for a filename, so that all your files
wound up with titles like TaxInfo.txt. And when cyberspeak picks up the
pattern, it's as if to say, this is how we're going to talk when we let
machines be a party in the conversation.
	But there are indirect historical connections, as well. The
terminology of Soviet Communism was the model for Orwell's Newspeak -- words
like doublethink and Minipax, not to mention the name Newspeak itself. And
that in turn was the idiom that William Gibson transformed to make the
language of cyberpunk, which took newspeak from gray to noir. It was Gibson
who coinedCyberspace. It's the sort of word that Big Brother would have
used if he'd been a radio evangelist in Raymond Chandler's LA.
	Of course the new cyberspeak doesn't have the dark, oppressive
overtones of its predecessors. It's upbeat and hopeful. But then there was
a brief moment when the Russian revolution was light and gay. It was the
time of the Constructivist avant-garde, with their collectives, their
paeans to bridges and machines, their new forms of theater -- not to mention
the typographical experiments that are the direct progenitors of the
graphics in Wired and the rest.
	I'll grant you the comparison has its limits. The digital
revolution has produced some interesting creative works, but it has yet to turn
out a Malevitch or a Mayakovsky. For that matter, we should feel a little
embarrased about calling this a revolution at all, at least by contrast
what happened in October of 1917. It's more like a virtual revolution,
where everybody gets to lead the charge on the Winter Palace and nobody
actually has to be carried off on a litter. Still, it's a great time to be
young and on-line, and maybe November will come in little milder this time
around.



	----- End Forwarded Messages -----

well,

(log (base 2) (3664 / 440)) * 12 = 36.69 notes above A440 (in equal
temperament) = 2/3 the way between A and Bb, above the C 3 octaves above
middle C.

stevie

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
            JUPITER COMET IMPACT IMAGES AVAILABLE FROM NSSDC

The National Space Science Data Center (NSSDC) at NASA's Goddard Space Flight 
Center is pleased to announces the availability of the latest Comet 
P/Shoemaker-Levy 9 impact images taken by the Hubble Space Telescope, Keck 
telescope, Calar Alto, European Southern, La Palma, MSSSO, etc.

The images can be obtained using the World Wide Web (WWW). The URL is 

is http://www.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/COMET.HTML.

The impacts have caused plumes 1000's of kilometers high, and have resulted in 
atmospheric features which are still visible after a few days.  The impacts 
will continue until July 22 and the NSSDC will endeavor to bring you the latest 
images.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Since the announcement was made at 1:00am on Tuesday, July 19, we have 
been overwhelmed with the accesses to our WWW server.  So far we have logged 
over 25,000 requests even though our server was down for extended periods 
today!

I thank you all for your patience and many, many note to support.  Please stay 
with us as we push the limits of the net over the next four days!  In the 
meanwhile, you will be happy to know that our service is back up and running 
at full steam.  We have split the load on two very capable machines and on 
last check neither were breaking into a sweat at a peak of 2000 access per 
hour!

Cheers !


Syed S. Towheed
Systems Programmer
Hughes STX Corp.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
National Space Science Data Center			    
NASA Goddard Space Flight Center			       
Greenbelt, MD 20771, USA
		    
http://www.gsfc.nasa.gov/nssdc/nssdc_home.html
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Syed S. Towheed >>>>>>>>

when some dj's turn their treble way up, often late into the night, I too 
use wadded up wet toilet paper or paper napkin earplugs which are very
effective and allow me to dance without the treble pain.  They are as effective
to me as regular earplugs and sometimes, I have to reduce the thickness of
the toilet paper to allow more sound to come in.

Very cheap, disposable and effective.  Viva toilet paper!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 20 Jul 1994 17:25:50 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ravnbird@crl.com (Denis)
Subject: resonate/WBL & Ambient Music

SPAZ/Free Fall last Saturday.  I agree 100% with "a night of emusic" that
resonate posted on July 18 ... it was AWESOME.  Everyone involved did a
great job, from the incredible decor "I loved those space dronettes", to
the great gear setup, keyboard and all.  The sound system was also very
good...but... this is where I start to get irritated.
You have incredible, inspiring and intelligent mind twisting ambient music
(I'm sure those performers: resonate, caliban...put their heart and soul
into it) but as a listener I barely could get into it because of
distraction from the dance beat and baseline from the main floor
downstairs.  I do understand that this is not an isolated problem (sound
transmission in chill-out rooms).  For instance resonate says "we will next
perform on aug. 13 at FFIII at a time TBA."  The last FFII had a wonderfull
selection of ambient djs but an even worst sound transmission problem not
to mention the foot path to enter and to exit the club was right through
the ambient space.  If I'm not mistaken, I hear FFIII is going to take
place in the same location "Komotion".
Well, what is a Girl/Boy to do?
>From my professional background I know that when one brings up a complaint
one should also offer a solution.  Well... I don't have one.  I thought by
bringing up The Issue maybe a NETstorming session could occur and some
small progress could be achieved.  Maybe I'm too much of a sound purist but
then again I think any ambient dj would agree that the purpose of a chill
out room is to create an atmosphere where the music transport you into
another world where the dream is not interupted by annoying sounds. ---By
the way I do not totally agree with "...we could tell our sound was perfect
because he (Bryce) slept the *entire time* the truest compliment for an
ambient band".  I personnaly feel that ambient music should create a state
of "dream" not "sleep" where a dj (band, performer) could somehow control
your "journey" by the sound being generated or created.
I guess my frustration comes from really getting excited by the ambient
music I heard on Saturday (it was very, very good...it was great!) but I
just could not EXPERIENCE it. I kept on goin back downstairs out of
frustration. (Then again the MAD techno/trance music was absolutely fun to
dance to).
Like I said, I don't have a solution. 
-Maybe somehow organising ambient nights only with those performers could
draw an interresting crowd and create a wonderful peaceful atmosphere.  
-Maybe looking for venues where ambient and dance spaces are further apart
and better insulated.
???

ravnBird (Denis)

	Sound isolation is a problem only if you deem that the context must
	always include it.

	After spending a large amount of my time in perfectly built studios
	I find that the setup and maintainence of a soundsystem in a loud
	environment, while not ideal, is a welcome challenge. Since the
	context of SFRaves events or most other events includes loud music
	outside- well we'll work within it.

	I'm very glad you liked our music- that show as kind of a "warm up"
	for us since all three of us haven't done live audio in SF proper
	until that show- we've done shows without the entire team and have
	been doing lights/graphics/projections for years (remember the
	digital countdown clock at Psychadelic Apocalypse?).

	We do plan to do a an afternoon show at Gaia Mantra records- so
	sound purists should be satisfied.

	Our decoration and artwork is done by Pete Lasell (flint@soda.berkeley
	.edu) and John Daniels (tapeworm@netcom.com). Pete has done our
	current poster. The Traditional Synthetic Cuisine CD artwork was
	done by me but the next one will be done by Pete. The CD is 
	available at Gaia Maintra Records at 511 Valencia/16th and at
	Rasputin's Records in Berkeley. 

	Thanks again to all who attended- we'll be bringing MUCH MORE 
	sound into the world as time continues to flow.

________________________________________________________________________________
	sound is the sum of all ingredients that are used in its creation
			(((((((((((resonate)))))))))))
________________________________________________________________________________

For those ambient-ethno-acid-trance folx out there here is my recent 
playlist.I formerly hosted a show called "No Commerical Potential" on 
WZBC 90.3 FM, Boston and have been involved with Full/New Moon parties in 
L.A. and S.F. as well as the last Friends & Family and will be appearing 
at various venues in the near future.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Astralasia * Whatever Happened To Utopia * (Magick Eye)
Zion Train * Natural Wonders of the World In Dub * (Zion Train)
Loop Guru * Duniya * (Nation)
Eat Static * Implant * (Planet Dog)
Sun Electric * Aahh! * (R&S)
Various Artists * Tox Uthat v.2 * (Silent)
Various Artists * Depth Charge * (Submerge)
Jorge Reyes * El Costumbre * (Extreme)
Autechre * Bass Cadet EP rmxs * (Warp/TVT)
Path Plaeasant * Sound Information * (Path)
Vulva * Mini Space Vulveltte EP * (Reflective)
DHSS * Hutch Burn 12" * (Brute)
Michael Mantra * Sonic Alter * (Silent)
Peter Namlook * Air 2 * (FAX)
Psychick TV * Peak Hour * (TOPY)
Orbital * Diversions * (FFRR)
Deep Space Network * Big Rooms * (Source)
Pauline Oliveros * Crone Music *(Lovely)

"We see emerging piecemeal and with the greatest ambiguity the seeds of a 
new noise. A NOISE OF FESTIVAL AND FREEDOM. It may create the conditions 
for a major discontinuity extending far beyond its field. It may be the 
essential element in the emergence of a TRULY NEW SOCIETY."

						-- Jacques Attali

My mailer says that Denis said:
> 
> You have incredible, inspiring and intelligent mind twisting ambient music
> (I'm sure those performers: resonate, caliban...put their heart and soul
> into it) 
>
me, too...for an early set.

> but as a listener I barely could get into it because of
> distraction from the dance beat and baseline from the main floor
> downstairs.  I do understand that this is not an isolated problem (sound
> transmission in chill-out rooms).  
>
true enough.  however, the alternative was to pump up the volume so loud,
and put enough bass bins in the chill space to turn it into a "main" room.
frankly, that space cannot handle enough power to overcome the downstairs
system.  imagine a 100W stereo competing with a 1500W stereo.  you heard
the results.  i apologize for the sound not being to your liking.  do you
have a suggestion as to how we can overcome the bleed through?

> For instance resonate says "we will next
> perform on aug. 13 at FFIII at a time TBA."  The last FFII had a wonderfull
> selection of ambient djs but an even worst sound transmission problem not
> to mention the foot path to enter and to exit the club was right through
> the ambient space.  If I'm not mistaken, I hear FFIII is going to take
> place in the same location "Komotion".
>
also true, as will F&F^4.  F&F^4 is one that I am helping to organize
as a party with ambient music in the main room.  that may alleviate some
of your concerns.  But, back to F&F^3...do you have a suggestion as to how
we can overcome the bleed through, yet still provide adequate ventilation
to the dance floor and still have easy access between the two? do come help
us set up these parties...we need your suggestions and assistance.

> then again I think any ambient dj would agree that the purpose of a chill
> out room is to create an atmosphere where the music transport you into
> another world where the dream is not interupted by annoying sounds. 
>
as an ambient DJ, i disagree with this as an absolute statement.  many people
use a chill room to do that...chill from dancing hard.  any soundscape is
incidental, often.  i once spun ambient in the same room as a 2.5KW system...
it gave me a new appreciation of the dj's art...trying to find spaces in
the dance beat.

> ---By
> the way I do not totally agree with "...we could tell our sound was perfect
> because he (Bryce) slept the *entire time* the truest compliment for an
> ambient band".  I personnaly feel that ambient music should create a state
> of "dream" not "sleep" where a dj (band, performer) could somehow control
> your "journey" by the sound being generated or created.
>
well, as the person referred to in the quote, i'd like to publically clear
something up.  at no time was i really asleep...i actually had my eyes
closed and was listening the the entire soundscape provided to me...dance
beats as well as ambient sounds.  and, i got up several times to move 
around, and to go downstairs to dance and visit with friends.  the spirit
that steve intended his statement is still accurate, and true to your
feel for ambient...i *was* transported. i believe (correct me here if i'm
wrong, steve) that steve was also referring to the quality of the sound.
i deal with sound on a regular basis (SoundVision, and MetroVision...which
had parts at last Saturday's gig-under-discussion); when i don't fiddle
with systems, i'm happy, and i judge the sound quality good; hence, my
relaxing was a compliment to WBL's use of the sound system.

> -Maybe somehow organising ambient nights only with those performers could
> draw an interresting crowd and create a wonderful peaceful atmosphere.  
>
come to F&F^4, at least.  also, i hear that Noc Noc on Mondays (?) is
ambient.  Dalvah used to have ambient nights, too.  however, both of those
venues are also bars. on the ravey side, New Moon parties have been ~very~
ambient...do check them out.

> -Maybe looking for venues where ambient and dance spaces are further apart
> and better insulated.
> 
if you come across any, do let the list know, as well as sfraves-planners...
we'd *LOVE* to use them.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

Concerning sound isolation for chill rooms:

One unfortunate consequence of generating thousands of watts of very low
and  near subsonic frequencies is that they are *very hard* to escape. I
remember (a couple years back) *feeling* a toon town literally 4-5 blocks
away :) 

This problem is compounded by the general lack of available and, more
importantly, *affordable* spaces. Though, in truth, even the most expensive
spaces fail in this regard: richmond civic prolly one of the best in terms
of multiple rooms, but you'll still never escape the bass. Fashion center,
concourse, trocadero, caesars, townsend etc, fail as well. The best
solution to this I've ever seen was when imagination used both townsend *&*
king street; that was one *hell* of a chill room (all of king street).

But, to get to the point, in general, I think we're faced with having to
make the best possible use of spaces that meet many, if not all, of our
needs, the alternative being to do nothing (no music in chill room) at all.
I think that even given the constraints and problems currently under
discussion, both performers and the variety of other participants would
still prefer doing it as opposed to not. In the case of komotion we do have
plans to improve this situation. Unfortunately, these will not be realised
in time for the coming party, but rest assured that we are aware of and
concerned about the problem and will continue to address it to the best of
our ability. Anyone out there with experience in this area, we certainly
welcome your suggestions!

take it easy
ethan

Komotion makes for a pretty good TAZ, but it's just not very good for
having a main system and an ambient system. The front hall isn't very
big, has bad acoustics, and gets a lot of bleedover from the main
system. I'm surprised the last F&F worked out as well as it did,
considering the obstacles to overcome. It was also nice that the
ambient didn't try to compete with the sound level....it's hard to
chill when the chill room is really loud!

It'd be nice to further isolate the main room from the front hall, but
then it'd get way too hot. I'm trying to devise ways to get more cool
air into the main room, so maybe next party won't be so humid :).

Sean

Date: Wed, 20 Jul 1994 22:28:14 -0800

From: ravnbird@crl.com (Denis)
Subject: resonate says...

<Sound isolation is a problem only if you deem that the context must
 always include it.>

You bet I do!  
For instance, If I would go to a gallery to view some original art and
someone had spray painted some graffiti on it, I would be totally
devastated.  They are both artists in their own right, but definitely not
together.
You, as an artist have a perception of what you want your public to hear
and I'm sure you do not want some stray sound from another "performer" to
alter your original idea of what you want to project as a final sound
scape.
Yes, I do understand that the setting associated with "ambient" or "chill"
rooms in clubs or rave parties is beyond your control and you do need that
setting to expose your artform.  I don't want to picture myself as an
egocentric so I'm sure I could indeed sit through an entire set even in
that context (maybe with some mind altering substance though).
I'm delighted to hear that you (your group) will perform at Gaia Mantra.  I
think that it will be the perfect space for it....oh but the street
noise...sorry I just had to:)
Looking forward to experiencing the true you!  
Do post the date and time...I can't wait.

Denis    ravnbird@crl.com

Subject: Re:  resonate says... [ravnbird@crl.com]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


If I wanted there to be *no* interference with our sound we would make it so.
I don't mind the interference. It sort of creates a space where the mind can
tune into the ambient and tune out the beats. I have no problems doing this
and in fact the sensation that there is sound going on around me that I am
not tuned into is a pleasant one- sort of like being happily asleep in a room
filled with people. After having your attention focused on beats you will
usually find that the mind will happily wander and unfocus and enjoy
non-beat oriented music- or what i like to call ZERO BPM sound.

I'm working on a string of saturday afternoon shows which will feature
better acoustic surroundings.

-steve rsn8

Subject: What is ambience?
To: ravnbird@crl.com
Date: Thu, 21 Jul 94 14:19:14 PDT
From: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Message-ID:  <9407211419.aa20122@cruzio.com>

resonate sez:

<Sound isolation is a problem only if you deem that the context must
 always include it.>

Denis sez:
 
>You bet I do!
>For instance, If I would go to a gallery to view some original art and
>someone had spray painted some graffiti on it, I would be totally
>devastated.  They are both artists in their own right, but definitely not
>together.

I sez:

Let's go back to basics (no pun intended) and consider what
ambient rooms, music, art, etc., is. I agree with resonate
that sound isolation is not a rquisite part of ambient art,
and in fact can be seen (or heard?) as quite extraneous to
an artist spraypainting another artist's work in a gallery
as being antithetical to ambient art as a misinderstanding of
ambience's concept.  The context--club, rave or party with its
main dance area's sound--is indeed an integral if background
part of ambience. At 90% of the raves I've attended over the 
years there has *not* been total or even major sound isolation.

Denis sez:

>Yes, I do understand that the setting associated with "ambient" or "chill"
>rooms in clubs or rave parties is beyond your control and you do need that

The fact that the setting is beyond the control of the ambient artist
is the whole point, wheteher it was Brian Eno's Music for Airports
which was one of the progenitors of this art form many years ago or
Adam Douglas's use of nature sounds mixed with techno bleeps in his
great Earthrise on the Silent label or the SPAZ folx downstairs at
last Saturday's Stevenson Street party where the upstairs thumping
was ever present, IM not so HO!

ciao,
Willi

-- 
Will Penna               408.423 8907         wpenna@cruzio.com
You too withhold the very things you complain are missing from the world.
ILLUMINATIONS  Stephen C.Paul & Gary Max Collins  HarperSanFrancisco  1991

To: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On sound isolation/interference: One thing to think about is John Cage's 
"4:33", where the pianist sits and does nothing for the allotted time.  
The background noise in the concert hall becomes the piece.

The constant droning of the main room can be both irritating and helpful 
in an ambient room, depending on the elaborateness of the environment you 
are trying to create.  When there's too much bleed from the main system, 
I tend to stray away from creating all-immersive environments and play a 
more abstract, noisy, bleepy set.

a piece of peace,
::Matthew J. Corwine                         Online Editor, XLR8R Magazine::

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 21 Jul 94 16:34:26 PDT

Precedence: bulk


I can't think of much to say about the listings for this weekend, so
I'll ramble on about tonight.  The full moon parties haven't been starting
till about 3 or 4 in the morning, so if you want to get warmed up,
you might want to check out one of the many weeklies.  Soul Purpose
usually has good acid jazz DJs from the Mushroom Jazz crew, plus good
local live bands.   Lift probably has the deepest house on Thursdays; 
Jeno, Graeme and Spun are at Pure Space, with more of an SF sound;
Flour, if it's on this week, is more mellow at Deco.  For the South
Bay, Inspirations and Shake Yo Buddha both got some recommendations
a while back; I dunno if they're still happening.  I haven't heard much
about Universal Groove or Better Living thru Chemistry, so somebody
check them out and give us a report!  Finally, I'm still holding out
for Your Sisters' House to come back...


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, July 21st - the full moon?

Friday, July 22nd - Dig!
        the Broun Fellinis, Last 2 Serve and DJs Charlotte, George, Kevin
        DNA, 375 11th St.  10pm-4am, 21+, $6.

Saturday, July 23rd - Mind Body & Soul
        DJs: Frank Nitty, Spinner, Ghost, Dave Alga, Darwin Chamber
        $10  (415) 905-5700  (510) 287-9392

Saturday, July 23rd - Go Figure
        DJ's Taj  John Mac  Raphael  Simon  and guests
        $5 all ages     (415) 974-9464

Saturday, July 30th - Anthem of the Sun
        Jeno  Garth  Josh  DJ Dan  Simon  Carlos  Ghost  Tony
          Greed  Rick Preston  Tony Fader
        408.951.7315  415.605.5946  510.716.3727

Saturday, August 6th - Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Saturday, August 13th - Friends & Family III
        acid.house.ambience.techno.trance@komotion
        details to follow...

Saturday, August 13th - Inertia
        Jeno  Pete Avila  Thomas  Christophe  Marcel  Dutch
        Proceeds benefit Bay Area Women Against Rape
        415.281.9888

Saturday, August 20th - "RADIO!RADIO!"
        an SFR picnic at Sunnyvale Baylands Park.
        Audio augmentation via micro FM stereo transmitter. Bring your FM 
          portables!
