-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Lift - Digit, David Harness & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - San Jose Oasis, 200 N 1st St. 9pm-2am, 21+, $5.  
        journees@netcom.com  408.236.2102  415.267.6974
Pure Space - 10pm-4am, 21+, $5. DNA Lounge, 375 11th @ Harrison. 415.267.0640
Shake Yo Buddha - acid jazz, rare groove, hip-hop, soul, funk, reggae.  
        369 S 1st St, San Jose.  9:30pm-2am. 21+, $5.  408.236.3787
Flour - Dani & Mark Farina - Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 415.441.4007.
        (every other Thursday)
Better Living Through Chemistry -
        18+ w/id, $5 w/can of food, $7 w/o.  415.615.8559
        [7/21 - Thomas(US), Andre, Markie]
Kit Kat - 6th & Harrison (the End-Up) - 21+, $5 w/invite
Soul Purpose - live acid jazz and DJs - $5, 21+, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison. 
        415.905.8811    415.882.1178
Casa de Samba - samba house, latin jazz, bossa nova w/Thomas, Manuel & guests
        10pm-3am, 1st & 3rd Thursday each month. 415.435.7577

------------------------------ F r i d a y ----------------------------------

Life/Twirl - Sound Factory - 525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300   21+
Deep - Nikki Rivera, Jason Hayes, Lewis. 6th & Harrison (the End-Up)
Raw - Neon Leon, Jan Cooley, David Harness & guests - 540 Howard - 415.243.8181
Ooga Booga - 2600 Watt Ave (upstairs @ country club lanes) - 916.484.4006
Apocalypse - 415.979.8411
SPAZ (Semi-Permanent Autonomous Zone), 2 sound systems, new DJs and live
        performances each week.  $3, 21+, 60 Sixth Street.  info 415.sols666 
Dakota - 1015 Folsom, 21+, $10 - 415.431.1200
Zendada - basement of 1015 Folsom - 12am-7am
Kuba - acid jazz w/DJs Charlotte, Josh, Dos Rexx - 1190 Folsom, SF.
Soul'd Out - acid-jazz party @ F/X, San Jose.  DJs Julius Papp & guests

---------------------------- S a t u r d a y --------------------------------

Dorothy's Tribe - Rick Preston, Nobel, James & guests
	6am-6pm at the EndUp, 401 6th @ Harrison.  415.543.7700

Funky Buddha - presented by Spundae - 520 4th St
        Head on House DJs: Simon, Henrik, Ernie, Jay-J, Mic, Eric Lacy, Josh.
        House of Funk & Killa Grooves: Bam Bam, Miquel, Melvin J, John Howard
        21+, $8 before midnite.  415.764.2922
Contact! - various guest DJs. $5, 18+, 2721 Broadway, Sacramento.  916.484.5661
Free Fall - Trance, Techno, Space - 60 6th St @ Market. 21+, 10-2, $3 after 11
        415.281.know

------------------------------ S u n d a y ----------------------------------

Sunday School - Tommy Roger, Aaron O, Swing Kid, Smile-E.  6am-?
        free before 2, $2 after.  the EndUp (6th & Harrison).  415.543.7700
Sunset - 2pm-sunset. Free! - 415.985.5264

Bulletproof boat party - 5-9pm pier 40 (one Sunday of each month) 
        Tickets and info at Bulletproof 629 Haight (255.7168)
Spundae - various guest DJs - 9pm-5am, 21+, $5 b4 12 - 55 Natoma. 415.974.9389
Family Affair - DJs Blackstone, Smile-E & guests. the EndUp (6th & Harrison)
        9pm-2am. 415.979.4502

------------------------------ M o n d a y ----------------------------------

Mushroom Jazz (Jazid Up)- acid jazz w/Mark Farina, Thomas, Ammon, Is,
	Alex, Kevin, Bob Taylor and/or Julius Papp.
	$5, 10pm-4am.  1190 Folsom St, 21+. 415-905-8811
FreeLife - Rick Preston, Harry Who? & guests 551 W.Julian @ Montgomery, SJ.
Pepper - various djs - 510 larkin @ turk  (Deco), 21+, $3, 10pm-2am
Noc Noc - ambient techno, 557 Haight St.  21+.  (every other Monday)
Call In Sick - monday mornings 6am-noon - DJs Nobel, Rick Preston,
        Neon Leon, Alex C & guests.  The EndUp, 6th & Harrison.  415.543.7700

----------------------------- T u e s d a y ---------------------------------

Together/Happiness - 21+, $5, 1015 Folsom - 10pm-3:30am - 415-979-8825
Body and Soul - Larry Blakes, Berkeley 10pm-2am, acid jazz and funk $3
Butterfly - Casanova, 527 Valencia, 861.4657.
        DJs Charlotte (the Baroness) & guests
Terbo Tuesday - live tecno - at Kalera, 60 6th St, SF.  10pm-2am, 21+.

--------------------------- W e d n e s d a y -------------------------------

Motion - 400 S 1st St, SJ (side entrance of F/X). 21+.  408-236-3732
Stone Groove - acid jazz n' cosmic funk.  presented by Bulletproof.
        $3, 21+, 9pm-2am.  Miss Pearl's, 601 Eddy @ Larkin.  415.255.7168.
Recycle - every other Weds w/Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests. 415.468.6970
Come/Unity - Simon, Jeno, Garth - usually first Weds each month - 415.241.8815

        Club Oasis, 278 11th St.  415.262.3953

        the End Up, 6th & Harrison.  415.303.6279

Elmo - 415-884-ABCD

Clubline - 415.979.8686
Fatline - 415.207.3668

---------------------------- Radio/TV Shows ---------------------------------
Sunday mornings 1-3:30am - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

to get all the info every week.

The only way I know to isolate sound at all effectively is by having 
double walls that are not connected to one another (except at top and 
bottom, I suppose)
About ten years ago, some friends of mine were putting together a movie 
theatre in Santa Cruz on Front St., and I remember discussing this with 
them. I will see if I can locate them and get more details.

Maui

Subject: Re: What is ambience? (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407211740.A14478-0100000@sutro>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

this is just and idea...but i wanted to see how people felt about it...i 
have more  of a background in the visual arts....and i love chillout 
spaces...

so i was thinking...what if we added another element to chillout spaces...
kinda group exploration/art project...i love to build or make things 
while concentrating on music...it is both calming and inspiring...i 
always loved those murals on butcher paper that glowed in the dark that 
people drew on at big parties...

i was thinking some sorta group collage effort....or some computer 
graphics that can be manipulated by different people...i guess i would 
have to think about its direction and exacution a little bit more...

anyone interested? any ideas? susie(:

This is an *excellent* idea. One many of us have had and maybe done, but 
it's time to do it here! A good way to do this would be have an "Art 
Party"-- have some music, munchies, and whatnot, with paper, fabric, 
paints, pens, etc. that everyone can just go wild with. I just got some 
more fabric, in fact-- bannertime...

Anyone else?

Maui

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I haven't heard much
> about Universal Groove or Better Living thru Chemistry, so somebody
> check them out and give us a report!

Oh, hey, I went to a Better Living Thru Chemistry!  Lessee...it was a few
weeks ago.  I don't remember that much, specifically, but I really liked
it.  The crowd seemed to be pretty fun and diverse; there was little
clubbiness or stuck-up-ness.  It was pretty crowded but not TOO much, and
the space was neither too big nor too small.  The dance space was ample and
dark, there were trippy paintings with black light, a big screen for
visuals, a laser...all kinds of stuff.  I don't recall being blown away by
the music or the sound system, but I was pleased.  There is a bar there,
which is a bit of a detriment, but there are also lots of chairs and tables,
a pool table or two, and a small balcony on which you could get some fresh
air and look out over the city (my understanding is that Chemistry is in the
same venue every week, a club around the corner from the Palladium where
there usually is, I think, salsa music).  And, bonus, it's only $5 with a
can of food. 

3.5 stars.  Joe Bob says check it out.  Sorry this isn't more detailed; our
friend Rocky was there as well that night, perhaps he has something to
add?...

stevie

can't imagine that it hasn't been thought of before.

different buildings. Admission to one would be good for the other -
maybe hand stamps with the same design.

	Hi to the list...

	This is an introduction of sorts. Even though I've made the 
	occasional posting to the list, my contribution had been far
	from frequent. On and off I've been subscribed since this
	thing was created.

	I'm Gary, I live in Ayr, Scotland (For the moment)

	One of the reasons I'm not more of the familiar face around 
	here, is that I've felt fairly disconnected from a lot of 
	the goings-on I've been priviliged to read every day. After
	all, I am 6000 miles away - its not like I've the opportunity 
	to attend all the parties I hear you rave about.

	Well, thats about to change, In six or seven or eight weeks 
	time I'll be making my way to San Francisco. This is a large
	moment in my life. You see, its not just for a visit, its 
	permanent, I'll be living, working and playing in a city I 
	consider one of the most beautifull places I've ever been 
	lucky enough to experience.

	As you can tell, I'm pleased about the whole thing.

	Why ? How ? Well, my wife (Leigh Ann), I'm three months married, 
	is an American, and we've decided there's more over in America for
	us than over here. Initially I'll be staying in Montara, a 
	little place about 22 miles from San Francisco proper - just
	down the road from Half Moon bay. 

	So the point of this ? Well, I'd like to get to know some of
	you. I'd like to have some people I can call, go out with, a 
	few folks that know the scene. I'd like to make a few friends.

	Now I doubt I'll be out and about every night of every weekend,	
	its likely to more of an occasional thing. When I first get out
	I'm going to be more concerned with getting myself a job, and 
	then somewhere to live than the weekend scene. What I'm thinking 
	is that it would be nice to get to know a couple of people through
	mail - people I could get in touch with once I've made the
	move...

	Guess I'd better wind up, I've rambled away enough. If you feel
	you could introduce a Scot to the San Francisco scene, or would
	like to get to know me a bit better - feel free to reply, I'll 
	talk to the list as a whole, or individually in e-mail...

	Thanks, 
	Gary

Date: Fri, 22 Jul 94 01:16:48 -0700
Subject: AMBIENT I LUV
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I like my ambient music slow and memorable, like stuffed with the occasional
weird sample or catchy melodic hook.  I don't dig TRUE ambient much, as in
music you're not really supposed to listen to, for if that were the case, then
why make music at all?  There should be something to the music that would make
someone remember it or even just maybe wanna dance or hum along.

I've caught on to the Orb, but can anyone recommend any other ambient bands (or
record compilations, for that matter) in this vein?

Any monkey can twiddle around with a synth tone for half an hour, but it takes
a CREATIVE monkey to think of throwing in samples from the Sesame Street
episode sponsored by the letter 'L'.

Ahem.

What with the recent discussion of bleedthrough and "ambient" rooms,
I was discussing the topic with a friend last night.  He observed that
the issue may be one of expectation...if it's called "ambient" or "chill",
some folks may expect a pristine soundscape; said soundscape may not be
possible.  

In light of the recent suggestions for art projects done to "ambient"
music, might I suggest renaming the area to "Multimedia Lounge"?
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

susie wrote..

>this is just and idea...but i wanted to see how people felt about it...i 
>have more  of a background in the visual arts....and i love chillout 
>spaces...
>
>so i was thinking...what if we added another element to chillout spaces...
>kinda group exploration/art project...i love to build or make things 
>while concentrating on music...it is both calming and inspiring...i 
>always loved those murals on butcher paper that glowed in the dark that 
>people drew on at big parties...
>
>i was thinking some sorta group collage effort....or some computer 
>graphics that can be manipulated by different people...i guess i would 
>have to think about its direction and exacution a little bit more...

thanks susie, i agree.

i also love the chill spaces, i think they are *essential*.  I like the idea
of a group exploration/art project and chill areas would in my opinion be a
good environment, provided there is enough space (not the narrow hall at
Komotion). For some strange reason:) i am usually infused with positive
energy and creating/making things in a collective way could be a very fun and
interesting outlet.

i think some collective collage or even individual stuff that could be
included/mixed in with the projections in the chill or main areas might be
interesting (although there are already some excellent collective visuals out
there).

i would be glad to help, with materials or in any other way...

peace
marty

   Excursions in Ambience - a collection....

Subject: Ambient/Chill Rooms

(((I tried to post this message 2 days ago from my new address on crl and it
never got here.  More problems...if this posting gets here twice don't blame
me...call crl.   So here goes)))


Well after reading all the postings concerning this topic, it occurs to me
that we may be talking about 2 different things here:
1) Chill-out rooms vs 2) Ambient performances.
This is also probably due to my original vague statement: "I think any
ambient dj would agree that the purpose of a chill out room is to create an
atmosphere where the music transport you into another world where the dream
is not interupted by annoying sounds."

Like Will Penna probably would say,"Lets get back to basics" and I would say:
"Lets take a step back here!"

1)CHILL OUT ROOMS. A few years ago when chill-out rooms started to get
popular, the places I used to hang out at had ambient music on a tape or CD
player only.  This music or set-up was definitely intended to be used as
background music.  Fine environment but it did not matter if you listened to
the music or not.  I saw it's use mainly as a "crash and burn" type
environment after 4:00 AM post dancing type thing.  (I'm sure it's still used
that way too).   

2)AMBIENT PERFORMANCE. Enters the much improved version, The era of A.
Paterson (Orb) phenomena craze, of bringing ambient music as a stand alone
serious music form to the night life.  Today it is common to hear "live" djs
spending an entire evening spinning records or in this case, playing
instruments to create and enhance the mood in the "chill-out" rooms.  I see
this as a totally different thing, this is now closer to an art form. 

Getting back to last Saturday, one detail I did not put in my posting was the
fact that I was informed that "resonate" (Steve) was going to P-E-R-F-O-R-M
and to get upstairs so not to miss anything. So again my observations are
only that it disapoints me that one can't fully enjoy the artists performance
(vision) without additional sound transfer in this venue.  

Is there a solution?  I think everyone's comments (Steve, Will, Bryce, Ethan,
Matthew....) are all very valid.  I guess to simply enjoy the music in the
present chill rooms (while understanding the shortfalls) or better yet, also
attending their special performances as named in previous postings.  

Just a little footnote here.  It is interresting to read the feelings and the
views of the actual performers about their music.  Enlightening and
surprising at the same time.......but keep on striving to achieve those
dreams and keep on performing to enrich the soul of us music lovers...like
me.

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com (or jeffsharp@aol.com)


P.S.: Ethan, Bryce...I'll try to make myself available if you need help
setting up future events. (But probably not tearing it down 'cause it's
usualy way past my bed time.)

The problem is that majordomo here is set up so that if someone who's listed
as being on SFRaves tries to post to it, it gets forwarded to me and then 
I can judge whether to forward it along or not.  The volume of posts from
people with different addresses has surged recently for some reason, so 
PLEASE PLEASE before posting make sure you're posting from the same 
address you receive mail at, if at all possible.  If this is impossible 
let me know and I can add you to a list of approved addresses, but this
is an administrative nightmare I'd rather not do.  Thanks, and sorry about
the rant...

Date: Fri, 22 Jul 1994 13:43:08 -0700 (MST)
From: harmonious efflorescence <devonc@bigdog.engr.arizona.edu>
Subject: introductions...

	Howdy everyone.  I've been lurking about for a long time now, and 
seem to have been able to do so without really posting much.  SOOO... like
Gary from Scotland, I'm introducing myself!
	One of the great things about this list is the diversity it seems 
to incorporate, much like the music we all share a common interest in.  
We have such a broad spectrum of entities converging here, that it's 
really a beautiful thing.  Obviously, may of you know each other first-hand,
but I, being trapped in this desert they call Arizona, do not.  Being a 
"outsider" of sorts, I'm free to look in on our conversations through 
unbiased eyes.  With few exceptions, everyone seems to respect 
each other, and a environment of good "vibes" ( I hate that word ) and 
energy radiates from my screen.
	I s*bscribed to maybe get the lowdown on some music I haven't got 
my grubby little hands yet, and maybe get some ideas for more musical 
excursions.  I've got my own radio show on our college radio 
station (exposing the masses to my ambient stylings), so I wanted to see if I 
could find something new to add to my collection. But what I found I like the 
most is the way everyone interacts and talks about the raves.  We've got an 
okay rave "scene" out here, but nothing in respect to what you have.  Consider 
yourselves lucky, you've got a great thing.   	
	Actually, I have similar intentions as Gary, as I too will be in 
the area shortly, and would love to meet a few of you some night.  I 
want to experience SF raves, so I can further my explorations of sound 
by adding a new element to it...  GOOD raves, not our wanna-be raves.
	I'll be there next weekend (July 30-Aug. 1) for a little Family
Reunion thang.  I'm looking for some brave soul in the San Jose area that 
would be willing to pick me up and drag me around for a night,
probably Sat. (31st), and get me back that morning.  I'm flying up to 
Montana on Sunday morning with "the cool uncle" in his Cessna.  That is 
assuming I can get away from all the Aunts and Uncles gasping @ how much 
I've grown in the last 20-some years... comprende?

Any takers?

					MELTING IN THE SUN
				       	  ((( DevoN )))

From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 22 18:36:17 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA07610; Fri, 22 Jul 1994 18:36:17 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA07604; Fri, 22 Jul 1994 18:36:11 -0700
Received: from sybex.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id SAA07030; Fri, 22 Jul 1994 18:36:28 -0700
Received: by sybex.com Fri, 22 Jul 94 18:34:35 PDT
Message-ID: <D709302E8136C7D1@sybex.com>
Date:  Fri, 22 Jul 94 18:34:35 PDT
From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject:  re: art projects {long}
X-Mailer: UGate [Ver. 1.69]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> i was thinking some sorta group collage effort....or some computer 
> graphics that can be manipulated by different people...i guess i would 
> have to think about its direction and exacution a little bit more...
> 
> anyone interested? any ideas? susie(:

I too have a strong background in the visual arts. I've actually done 
a lot of collaborative work with people, both for serious art 
projects and just for fun. I've had several collaborative painting 
parties which have all resulted in great artworks.

I've found that acrylics work best for painting in these these kinds 
of situations because they dry quickly and are easy to work with in 
terms of clean-up (water soluable) and toxicity. Acrylics are also 
toxic, but not nearly so much as oil paints which require solvents 
for clean up and thinning.

A few problems I've encountered with collaborative works: people tend 
to get VERY protective AND VERY sensitive when it comes to creating 
things, especially if they are not used to doing this professionally. 
They usually have problems with it if someone comes along and adds 
to, obliterates, or otherwise monkeys with whatever they've done. At 
my painting parties, before we begin painting it is made clear to 
everyone present that they should not become attached to whatever 
they do. Still, people get bent out of shape. Then there is usually 
somebody there that MUST obliterate everything that anyone else does, 
consciously or not. The only way to deal with that is to let that 
person know what you see going on and hopefully they will calm down 
and stop trying to enforce their aesthetic. I've never tried to say 
"leave everything as the artist lays it down". I don't think it 
really works to produce a finished piece that way, but if you're not 
looking for a solid finished piece of art then I don't see why it 
would not work to have a rule about people not mucking around with 
other people's creations. Though I think it would result in a 
visually "choppy" piece that way, and rules, well.... After art 
parties at my house the people involved are much closer. We go 
through a lot of stuff staying up all night painting and figuring out 
ways to work together while maintaining a sense of individual 
aesthetic.

Yes, I'm ALWAYS interested in art parties! A chill room art scene 
would probably be somewhat different than these things that I've 
hosted before. I could see painting getting a little messy or out of 
hand...maybe. Collage, yes! I can see piles and piles of old 
magazines, scissors and lots of white glue on huge pieces of butcher 
paper. Add crayons and markers to that. I'm sure people would bring 
things to add (jewelry and plant matter, etc.). Hang a roll of 6 ft. 
wide paper on the wall and just roll it off onto the floor as 
needed...

Alissa

A group of young people who have formed an alternative community in 
Sheffield, England will be producing the Rave Mass. They have developed 
Rave Masses and other community services which include the use of the 
rave & and multimedia idioms.

Matthew Fox was a Catholic priest but got booted out a year or two ago 
but has been taken in by the more liberal Episcopal Church.

Matt Fox is a recognized author and the founder of the Institute For 
Creation Spirituality at Holy Names College in Oakland.

I happened to attend a couple of talks at The ICS summer workshop last 
week which were quite stimulating. One was from the Seneca-Iriquois 
teacher Jose Hobady who spoke on native spirituality, ritual & dance and 
the other I attened was from cosmologist and ecological advocate Brian 
Swimme. He is the Director of the Center For the Story of the Universe @ 
the Calif Inst.. of Intergral Studies and quite an inspiring thinker.

Matthew Fox will be partaking in dialogue with noted biologist and 
philospher Rupert Sheldrake Aug. 25, 7:30 PM at Grace Cathedral. The talk 
is entitled "Ritual , Resonance & the Return of the Angels". Should be 
quite interesting, the only draw back is that admission is a bit pricey 
($18), maybe the promoters of this talk should arrange some kind of 
slideing scale.

That's what I know at the moment.

Ronan

From: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Reply-To: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Subject: Rave Mass
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9407222046.A27055-0100000@netcom15>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am going to post a short excerpt from an interview with a defrocked 
priest who is taking a different, more constructive approach to religion 
& spirituality than the Catholic church.

Anyone who is offended by my posting something involving religion can 
flame the hell out of me-- I see this guy as healing a breach.

(the following has been excerpted, without permission, from San Francisco 
Focus magazine's interview with Fr. Matthew Fox)

SFFocus: Is there room in the Episcopal Church for your kind of spirituality?

Fox: I think so. I'll give you an example-- it's the main thing that's 
drawing me there. Last August, I had just finished writing "The 
Reinvention of Work'. The last chapter was on ritual, how we need rituals 
to create community support. We were doing a summer program in Seattle, 
and four people flew in from Sheffield, England. The oldest was a 33 year 
old Anglican priest, and their story was they have a community there of 
200 people, in their 20's reinventing the form of the Mass. The result is 
they have some 500 or so people coming to this Mass; average age 27. This 
is mind-blowing-- it's a miracle. There probably aren't 7 people in their 
20's going to church anywhere else in England on Sunday. These are 
blue-collar people. Sheffield is the Youngstown, Ohio of England, the 
birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, and it's in a total depression 
now. These young people come out of abusive situations-- economic, 
political, drugs, alcohol, all of it. They're plugged into the Rave 
culture there, and in the Mass they use Rave music and dancing and media.

SFFocus: Did you get an opportunity to see it firsthand?

Fox: I went over in November to experience it. It's held in the basement 
of a sports complex, a round room, and they have 42 television sets, 12 
videos, and projections all over the walls: galaxies dancing, to atoms, 
DNA, and so forth. The altar is a big, round white table with projections 
on it from above, colors and forms that change throughout the service, 
and they create the videos every other week for the Mass. There's also 
live television happening during the Mass, but the reading of the 
Scripture is on all the television sets and video screens simultaneously. 
   
The first response I had was that this is a very friendly experience for 
a generation raised on television. The second response I had was that 
these people are taking television away from the broadcasters. They're 
doing it live. Where? At the heart of a community. That's why it was so 
interesting and powerful. And yet it is the Mass-- you can recognize the 
form of the Mass within it.

I came back and talked with Bishop Swing in San Francisco, and we're 
planning such a Rave Mass in the basement of Grace Cathedral in October. The 
Sheffield Community is going to send ten people over, their best artists 
and techno artists, for a 2 year commitment to get the community going 
here in America, here in the Bay Area.

SFFocus: So this will be ongoing?

Fox: Yes. Eventually, we hope to coordinate the Mass with a conference 
for Silicon Valley on spirituality and TechnoArt. Technology is promising 
us 500 video channels and an information superhighway. But is that 
highway going to take us faster and deeper into the hell of consumerism, 
or can the new technology being born right here lead us to the next level 
of human evolution, which has to have something to do with spirituality? 
That's the challenge we want to give to Silicon Valley.

FORWARDED FROM ALT.RAVE without permission

I thought this guy's experience would add an additional perspective on
the recent Wicked...

Ken

included message follows:
==========================================================================

>
>Last night I went to my first "rave", from a listing on sfraves-calendar,
>clan of Wicked in SF.  I was shocked!
>
>1. There was no variety to the music at all!  The only change was that
>the baseline would occasional stop and start again.
>2. There were no trippy, colorful clothes - most everyone looked like they
>were trying to emulate boring mainstream fashion ala grunge and jeans.
>3. There were no interesting drugs - the drug of choice was clearly
>nicotine and I got a whole carton of second-hand smoke.
>4. It was predominantly couples dancing together (it IS the 90's, but..)
>5. The music had absolutely no positive social content - the only
>discernable spoken sample was a voice saying "Annihilate Intruders" - it
>felt really creepy like the military-industrial complex was sponsoring it.
>6. It was expensive ($15 for a few hours of generic dance beat???)
>
>Somebody please tell me that there are Raves not like this!?  Somewhere
>with interesting and conscious music and people, less fricking cigarette
>smoke, and maybe a single person or two?
>
>Ben Discoe
>    "I do VR for a living"

Will writes:
>In the list of "Signs and Symptoms of Inner
>Peace" I would exclude just one:
>
>
>6.  Loss of interest in conflict.
>
>because the spiritual leaders with inner
>peace that I admire had a *lot* of interest
>in conflict:
>
>Gautama Buddha
>
>Jesus the Christ
>
>Mohandas K. Gandhi
>
>Etc.

Actually none of those people had any *interest* in conflict.

Their only interest was the love inside themselves and everyone else.

However, they did not *shun* conflict if it became necessary to
accomplish their mission.   To shun or exclude anything is to give it
importance...

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id FAA14306; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:10:25 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id FAA14301; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:10:19 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id FAA17681; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:06:49 -0700
Received: by tigerteam.org (WILDUUCP! v1.10d)
        Fri, 15 Jul 1994 02:53:00 GMT
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <F29232D1@tigerteam.org>
Subject: Her Karma Ran Over His
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 1994 02:53:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Will writes:
>I disagree with the general tenor of the
>11 "Signs & Symptoms," however, in that for me they
>don't jibe with my own sense of the feng shuy of
>higher spirituality.  They definitely come from that
>current school of thought that separates inner peace
>from activism,

Well, this "current school of thought" is not really current, in fact it
is the oldest recorded thought, period.

The basic problem of activism is that it comes from the ego of "I know
what is best for everyone".

"Higher spirituality" consists of removing yourself from the limited,
closed-in perspective of your own ego, so that you can resume the
natural state of a higher perspective.

The "signs and symptoms" are simply a sign post of how you are doing in
that endeavor.

Christ, Buddha and Gandhi were all coming from that non-ego/self-less
perspective, and what they did was in the best interests of everyone.

Note that Christ refused to take part in any revolution against the
Romans, despite the oppression going on.  Not exactly an activist.

Buddha renounced his position as crown prince - a very influential
position - in order to seek enlightenment.

>moral indignation

requires an "us" and "them" perspective.

>and creating the new
>dualism of bliss/blitz vs. nonviolent resistance. I'll happily choose
>the latter every time if (as the list makes clear) and when I see the
>former.

I don't see any inconsistency between bliss and nonviolent resistance,
especially when you consider that Gandhi did both.

If someone really feels there is an inconsistency, that would mean that
they come to raves, which are generally blissful and non-political, only
to distribute flyers and/or recruit people for causes...

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

From sfraves-owner  Sat Jul 23 05:16:30 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id FAA14404; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:16:30 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id FAA14381; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:16:18 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id FAA17906; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:10:50 -0700
Received: by tigerteam.org (WILDUUCP! v1.10d)
        Fri, 15 Jul 1994 06:07:00 GMT
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <3F16079A@tigerteam.org>
Subject: There IS No Contradicti
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 1994 06:07:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Will writes:
>Ken sez--
>
>>Well, this "current school of thought" is not really current, in fact it
>is the oldest recorded thought, period.
>
>It's *one* thing to demonstrate that something is true,
>Ken, and another to just baldly state it as you do here.
>If you're interested I'd like you to relate these 11
>Signs and Symptoms to "the oldest recorded thought"
>somehow.  I doubt tHat you can.

It comes froms the Vedas, estimated to have been written roughly about
10,000 years ago.

It would take some hours of research to rigorously demostrate this. I'll
seen what I can dig up that might be less rigorous...

>Both Jesus and Gandhi (and possibly Buddha) were
>killed because they *were* activists, real threats
>to the political status quo of their times.  Check
>*your* sources on that!

No, I just mentioned in the last message that Jesus refused to be an
activist.  In fact, that was why he was killed.  As long as everyone is
distracted by the Judaea vs. Rome, Clinton vs. Bush, etc. then the
status quo is NOT threatened.  What is threatening to the status quo is
that Jesus and Gandhi asked people not to be selfish, to love/help your
neighbor.  Gandhi was killed AFTER his non-violent campaign caused the
British to give India its independance.  He was killed because he THEN
started advocating that Hindus and Moslems love each other and get along.

The whole idea of being ego-less and self-less is very threatening to
both individuals and the status quo.

>
>Going to raves, indeed, frequently *is* a very
>spiritual experience of the highest order.  It
>can be demonstrated from some of the truly giving,
>ego-less moments we'vw all shared there and on sfraves
>as well!  But it's not the kind of mindless bliss
>that that list suggests, rather it's a truly mindful
>state.

Okay, could you list what on the list strikes you as "mindless"?
This could be semantics, really.  In order to be truly mindful, ie in
the sense of aware, you have to turn off your "mind", ie the chatterbox
in your head...

>
>And my point was, in fact, that bliss and n-v resistance are
>a unitary state--but I saw nothing in the list that suggested
>that the conflict that n-v resistance engages is is okay, in
>fact it says just the opposite!

I re-read the list after reading this point and, really, the only one
that refers to this whole discussion is that same one:

6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

Whereas Tony posted that the problem is in the term here "conflict", I
think that the crucial word is "interest".

In the ego-less state one has no interest in conflict.  If, however,
circumstances dictate that conflict is the necessary and proper course
of action, then conflict is not shied away from.  To shy away from
something, is actually to be interested in it, in that one is interested
in avoiding it.  If one neither embraces nor avoids something, one is
not interested in it.

Indeed, someone who was interested in conflict would have no reason to
resort to "non-violence".

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

From sfraves-owner  Sat Jul 23 12:00:33 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA00108; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 12:00:33 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id FAA14672; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:45:58 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id FAA19682; Sat, 23 Jul 1994 05:40:34 -0700
Received: by tigerteam.org (WILDUUCP! v1.10d)
        Sat, 16 Jul 1994 02:54:00 GMT
From: KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org (KEN STUART)
Message-Id: <793743FC@tigerteam.org>
Subject: Re: Some Signs & Sympto
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 1994 02:54:00 GMT
Organization: Tiger Team Information Network (510) 268-0102
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

>Ken sez--
>
>It will take him "hours of research to rigorously demonstrate"
>that the Signs & Symptoms list comes from the Vedas!
>
>THIS I'll gladly wait to see! As a student of the Vedas myself,
>it's hard for me to see how things like #5, 6, 7 and 11 come
>from the Vedas.

I don't yet have the time to find my Upanishads to rigorously document
this, so I'll just go from general memory.

>5.  Loss of interest in interpreting actions. [of others]

What others do is irrelevant, everything of value is within yourself, so
all that you need to do is focus on the love within yourself (atman).

All actions of others are due to karma [perhaps messages on
hyperreal.com are due to hyperkarma :-) :-)].  Their karma, in turn, is
due to their actions.  Escaping this vicious circle is only through
focusing on the love within yourself.

>6.  Loss of interest in conflict.

Same answer as for 5.

>7.  Loss of ability to worry.  (this is a very serious symptom)

When you are focused on the love within yourself, what possibly could
there be to worry about?  If you say "but what if" or "but what about",
then that consists of a lack of focus.

11.  Increasing tendency to let things happen rather than make them
happen.

This is the more esoteric one (perhaps that is why it is at the end).
The mystics all describe that when they let go of their own petty
desires, and aligned themselves with the love within, then things happen
of their own accord, without their own puny intervention.  When they
aligned themselves with the love within (atman), they automatically
aligned themselves with the world (brahman, Gaia) and being aligned with
the world, things in the world happened in alignment with them in return.

>
>Then he says that "Jesus was killed because he refused to be
>an activist...(to be) distracted by the Judaea vs. Rome" thing.
>
>Wrong!  Remember when he said "Render unto Caesar the things that
>are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's"? THIS really
>set the (then P.C.) Herod-Pontius Pilate crowd off because they
>could see how these kinds of teachings were a real threat to their
>status quo collusion of the religious leadership in Judaea with
>the Roman colonial government.  When given the chance to kill
>Jesus or the most heinous criminal, it's not surprising they had
>Jesus the "rabble-rouser" killed!

Yes.  This paragraph is more evidence in support of my position :-).  I
was going to put in this paragraph, but I didn't want to make the post
too long.

>Remember when he said "Render unto Caesar the things that
>are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's"?

The previous sentence is "Whose face is on this coin?" "Caesar's".

The meaning of this is (in the context of the taxation without
representation of 2000 years ago) that there is no point in contesting
worthless material things.  The "things that are God's" are the
spiritual things - Peace, Love, Unity, Respect.  Elsewhere Jesus says
"my two commandments are Love God and Love Your Neighbor".  So, it's
PLUR for God and PLUR for your "neighbor".  (How you interpret "God" is
your own personal choice.)

The other jews were upset that he refused to lead a activist rebellion
against Rome, so when the high-priests (jewish establishment) made the
Romans arrest him, no one came to his aid other than his disciples.

Then Pontius Pilate asked him "Are you the King of Jews", he answered in
such a seemingly vague way that, after some further questions, Pilate
announced that he could find no crime.

>Ken also asks if I "could list on the list what strikes you as
>'mindless'?"
>
>I did that in my first post responding to this list.  Let me say
>again that the discussion about how the "ego-less state one has no
>interest in conflict" has become so convoluted and dualistic that
>it has lost any meaning. Conflict is an integral part of life, of
>growth, spiritual, mental, physical or any other kind I can think of.
>
>Finally, Ken lists Clinton and Smeal his idea of who the P.C. ones
>are.  Well, P.C. is relative to your point of view.

NOT!  Whereas you definitely COULD use P.C. to describe those things
that right-wing republicans automatically assume are true, it just isn't
done.  Useage in the 90's refers to left-wing liberal rigidity and lack
of a sense of humor about their objectives; it especially refers to
where institutions try to prevent speech that says anything about a
specific group of people (cf the concurrent 'stereotyping' thread on
sfraves :-) :-) ).

>In New Age circles I've seen lists like this list held up before
>as guides for right livelihood, not people like the
>two above!

NOT!  Please excuse the stereotyping :-) but New Age overwhelming
consists of people who have the same PC speech taboos described above
and are VERY MUCH in favor of activism for left-wing liberal causes.

The Signs and Symptoms is very much at odds with the New Age - which is
one reason why it fits raving so well :-) :-).

New Agers are ALWAYS interpeting EVERYTHING :-).  They're ALWAYS
WORRYING :-).  They're ALWAYS acting due to fears based on past
experiences.   And they're ALWAYS judging their self. :-)

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Laura writes:
>Ken writes:
>>Will writes:
>>>
>>>P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?
>>
>>This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes to
>>on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.
>
>But what does this have to do with going raving?  Will SPECIFICALLY
>asked if you ever go raving, and you didn't answer his question even
>though you claim that talking over email is so much less prone to errors
>than other forms.  If so, then how can it be when you've completely missed
>his simple and direct yes or no question? :-)

Because this is such a ridiculous question that the only result of the
question can be the thought -- why did this person ask this question?

(Can you imagine posting to someone on alt.cult-movies "Do you ever go
to see movies?" or to someone on alt.soccer "Do you ever watch soccer?")

The only plausible reason has to do with:

>Here in SF, too, I've seen similar things on a smaller scale. I distinctly
>recall a lot of bickery email going around before the Friends and Family
>party at Komotion.  Two of the three combatants (and you were the third)
>met in person at the party.  I made sure they got introduced.  The result
>was smiles and hugs and declarations of new-found feelings of friendship.

But you see there is a BIG problem with this.  All that has happened is
that you've moved someone from within the "them" circle to the "us"
circle.  What we need is to do this with EVERYONE - ie eliminate the
"them" circle.  As I mentioned to you in private e-mail (I hope you
received that), what set me off was that the supposed "narc" was treated
with prejudice as "them".  What was stupid on my part was to treat the
person who did that, as "them" :-).

The idea that we're supposed to be introduced and then never take
exception to false statements :-) :-) seems pretty silly to me.

>>So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with a
>>specific e-mail address :-) ?
>
>Direct human contact with those whom we endlessly debate often gives
>rise to greater understanding.

Greater understanding of what?  I have friends I see every week (as a
group) and I know less about them than I know of many people I converse
with on e-mail - because of what I said before about the usual
meandering nature of conversations.

> It also allows you to meet people
>with whom you'd otherwise not exchange email and in that way extend
>your connections with the community.

Ah, but this is the opposite of my question.  If I go to a rave, meet
someone, and say "How can I contact you later?", that person might say
"Do you have e-mail?".  This has nothing to do with meeting people we
know on e-mail previously.

> I then decided to throw a big party at
>my house before a big rave so that the "email addresses" from the
>list could meet face to face.  The result was phenomenal.  ne-raves
>was transformed from a lot of sterile semantic debate into a huge
>love-fest.  To this day ne-ravers
>go out of their way for each other to offer rides to parties, to
>offer crash space after parties, to cooperate to have picnics,
>dinner parties, nights out in cafes or restaraunts, and to even throw
>raves.

But again, this also works in reverse, otherwise there would be no rave
scene at all.  Someone throws a rave, people discover that there are
other people like them who are willing to take a chance in order to
experience the love vibe, they exchange phone numbers (and/or e-mail
addresses), meet at cafes or for lunch, etc.

>Nothing beats first-hand experience, be it of music, of that ephermeral
>quality known as "vibe," or of another person.

But this is just what I said in the part of my post that you deleted in
your response.

And we all do all of those things.  But I feel that we should interact
with EVERYONE on e-mail (or elsewhere) as if they were a close friend.
I'm unlikely to ever rave with Tony in Miami or Sigi in Australia or
Chrome in Amsterdam -- should I treat them differently??

Interestingly, the question at the top came at the end of a thread where
the OTHER person was advocating the place of "conflict" and THEN feels
the need to meet in person because we've been having this e-mail conflict.
:-) amazingly ironic :-).

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

PS Anyone know the exact time of the full moon this week?

Precedence: bulk

Will writes:
>
>P.S. Ken--do you go raving as well as posting on sfr?

This touches on the larger question of meeting people that one writes to
on the net.  My viewpoint is that I don't see a need to.

I find e-mail a superior verbal communication to either the telephone or
in person.  E-mail allows you to sit down when YOU have time to
comfortably think about what you are reading.  On the phone or in
person, two things happen:

(1) I can't fully relate all that I'd like to say about the topic
because it takes a moment or two to collect my thoughts.
(2) I find that in 80% of cases, the conversation veers into a different
direction before an interesting aspect is discussed.

Now, there is, of course, the non-verbal aspects which are very much
enhanced in person.  But, I'm married :-) and I find that the other
non-verbal aspects, ie raving, happen just being in the room with
everyone.

So, what is the advantage of associating a specific physical body with a
specific e-mail address :-) ?

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

In addition to the "ambient I love" things
that others have mentioned, one by Steve Hilage
that I've had for 15 years:

Rainbow Dome Musick
Virgin Records VR 1
with Steve Hillage, Miquette Giroudy, and Rupert Atwill
compositions are "Garden of Paradise" by Miquette Giroudy
on side one and "FourEver Rainbow" by Steve Hillage on side
two.

This is post-Gong Hillage and sounds  (to me) even more
Orb-y than the future work Hillage would do with System 7.

Has it ever appeared on CD? Are there other Hillage things
like this from this time (1979)?

My copy is  still in excellent shape if anyone would like
a taped copy (I have no idea if it's rare or not).

ciao,
Will

Well, welcome home Patrick!

>Are there any decent Rave style spots up there?

The house community up here is generally a here and there, every or 
every-other weekend warehouse-party scene with a few club weeklies 
thrown in for good measure.  There are a lot of smaller, more private 
house parties cropping up here and there, more free outdoor events and 
generally smaller things happening as of late.  As you'll see below, 
there are also things happening in other nearby cities that supply a 
bit of everything for everyone.  Still, it could use a little more of 
everything too, that wouldn't hurt.  At least _I_ wouldn't mind...

>I remember the main stream house clubs-blaaaaaaa!
...some things never change...

>I'm looking for a place a little more sexually mixed.
Well...I don't exactly know what you mean by that.  Other than sheer 
numbers, that could mean a lot of things.  But I'd hazard a guess that 
it's not going to be like what you're used to down there.  More often 
than not, people play it down up here, and it works.  Whatever.  To 
paraphrase an old idiom, "let whomever do whatever their thing is..."

Here's the haps in Seattle.

EVENTS

Sat, Jul 23 	Planet Funk 2. (sea)  $10
		Buck (last US gig before he moves to the UK),
		Markem X, Donald, Kip, Shon, Ryan, Mike Manahan,
		Dervish, ATOI/Matt Corwine, After Dark Production Crew

Sat, Jul 30	Eternal Summer (van) 604.669.8185
		Czech, Minitmaid, Noah, Quickfix, live: soul control

Sat, Aug 6	Summer Of Love (van) (604) 268-9574 (whistler)
		wooooo... waay too many to list:)

Sat, Aug 13	X-citing (van) 473.6166 $10 at odyssey, bassix
		DJ Midnite, DMJ, T-bone, special guest
		Tix $10 advance at Odyssey, Zulu, Bassix

Sat, Aug 27	Eternal Summer pt2 (van) 604.669.8185
		Dr.Trance, Czech, Donald G., Noah, Cyber, ursula,
		live: soul control


sept. 9		Haven's 18th (magical rave age)! (sea)
		6pm to 3am, 6-11 dance, 11-3 ambeint


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 24 12:35:24 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA11346; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 12:35:24 -0700
Received: from mail02.prod.aol.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA11338; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 12:35:18 -0700
From: ZIMMERMANJ@aol.com
Received: by mail02.prod.aol.net
	(1.38.193.5/16.2) id AA20318; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 15:34:49 -0400
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9407241534.tn104022@aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 94 15:34:47 EDT
Subject: VIVID PRONOIA-What the F@CK HAPPENED!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night my friends and I drove down to Santa Cruz from the City to attend
Vivid Pronoia. I must say it was a rather disappointing event! Although it
started out quite well, ( the visuals and music at the school were above par)
it rapidly disintigrated.
Problems:
1.) Moving a party a 11:00 at night is a really stupid idea when no mass
trans. is provided, i.e. a bus! While leaving I saw a LOT of people driving
really fucked up on a number of drugs. Very uncool! This is supposed to be a
healthy movement, not a stupid one, we don't need a car load of Ravers
smeared across the road, with the potential of killing other drivers.
2.) The directions to the after party where rather vague. My friends and I
drove up and down the coast for an hour trying to find that spot. I wasted a
lot of gas :-(  not good for the environment.
3.) Upon finding the spot 1 1/2 hours after leaving the first party none of
the promoters had showed up yet! The people who were there were wondering
what was going on..
4.) Who invited the guys in the big suburban and their friends? They were
definitely not part of the family! my friends and I asked if they would play
a Garth tape on their monster car stereo, to be told that "we don't like
House music"! Pardon me, but who the hell invited you, and WHY do you WANT to
be here?
I must say at this point that I do not look down on other peoples tastes in
lifestyles( variety is the spice of life), but there are times when people
with different agendas just should not mix.

last one:
5.) What the hell happened down in the lower parking lot?
I was sitting in my car, and  heard the sound of someones windshield being
smashed in, turning around I saw some guy (definitedly not part of the
FAMILY!) going apeshit on the hood of someones car ( a white GOLF or Jetta I
think_) who was trying to get out of the lot. A minute later this same fine
gentleman is kicking in the window of a green nova completely in a rage. I
could not believe my eyes! A few moments later he's kicking the shit out of
some young kid! I would like to applaud who ever it was who reached in and
grabbed the kid at that point, I hope he was taken to get medical help and is
O.K.!
 I was rather dissapointed with myself and others that no one stepped in to
stop this asshole, but somehow I can feel that we can be forgiven seeing that
we are not an arms carring bunch, I hope! I think I was afraid that he would
pull a gun or one of his friends would. 
Those are my gripes about last night. I must say that that was definetly the
last out door rave I go to where there is no security (with the exception of
the full moon, and Sunset)
 I've been reading all this mail with people whinning about the cost of some
of these partys,To tell you the truth, I really have NO problem paying $15 to
be in a SAFE environment.
Having jumped in and out of the Rave scene over the past four years (was at
floppy's when that was still going, been to parties in L.A. with several
thousand people in attendence) Never have I experienced what I did last
night. It really made me sad, and the long car ride home was rather glum. ( I
don't think I've ever used that word before, funny sounding word, GLUM, GLUM,
GLUM... Sorry just felt I needed to get that out of my system).
ON A MORE UPBEAT NOTE:
I must say that I did have a blast at last weekends COME UNITY, as well as
the Full Moon Party. I'd like to thank the cops  for being smart (how
unusual!) and letting us stay friday morning. Or should I thank the person
who talked them into letting us stay, since we were all too messed up to
drive. Besides dancing is healthy and doesn't hurt anyone. I've been drinking
milk, and some day I'm going to be as good as John Travolta.
Peace, Love, Groovyness, and all that other mushy crap...
Jon Zimmerman
ZIMMERMANJ@AOL.COM

P.S. If anyone else saw what I did last night and would like to discuss it,
please don't hesitate to write me!



From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 24 16:12:38 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA13597; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 16:12:38 -0700
Received: from nak.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA13592; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 16:12:32 -0700
Received: from cafe.berkeley.edu.noname by nak.berkeley.edu (8.6.8.1/1.40)
	id QAA23810; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 16:12:33 -0700
Received: by cafe.berkeley.edu.noname (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA19124; Sun, 24 Jul 94 16:12:33 PDT
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 94 16:12:33 PDT
From: stevec@cafe.berkeley.edu (Steve Collins)
Message-Id: <9407242312.AA19124@cafe.berkeley.edu.noname>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: MESS! : a review of sorts.
Cc: laurel@plague.berkeley.edu
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Although I've known about Mother Earth Sound System for some time, I've never
been to one of their parties for more than a few minutes, until Friday's
shindig in Berkeley.  Was I impressed!

First let me tell you a bit about the venue.  It was a vegetarian co-operative
(mostly) student household called Lothlorien.  Throughout the years it has
had many laid-back and happy people pass through its doors and leave their
concentrated vibes on its walls, much as a pipe collects resin.  Needless
to say, it's a great place to have a rave.  I had had the idea myself of
having a party there when I was living there, but I didn't think it would
happen because it is, after all, a house where people live and sleep.  But
the MESS crowd somehow talked them into it.  (As i understand it, people
there are more accepting of ravers than in the past.  I'm told I was the
first person to play techno on the house stereo, but these days it's a
fairly common occurrence.  Good to know I left my legacy behind.)

At any rate, the party definitely deliverd its promise.  Who was spinning
around 10:30, 10:45, and what would you call that kind of music?  It sounded
a lot like commercial techno in some ways, but with a low cheesiness
factor.  Great stuff, and that quality was upheld throughout the night.

The crowd was really lively and friendly.  My favorite article of clothing
was a young woman's T-shirt which, due to a vaguely formed "l" and "o",
said equally "love" and "Rave".  I suppose that most of the crowd were
Berkeley students, given the proximity to the University, and if so, that
opened my eyes.  For some bizarre reason I dont know _that_ many Berkeley
student ravers, and I never cease to be amazed at the sheer numbers of
them.  (I even spotted one or two people I hadn't seen at a rave in ages --
remember Sheryl, Brian?)  We ought to have a Berkeley Student Raver lunch or
picnic!  The point is, the vibe was magnificient.

A couple of people were incredulous at the fact that I was wearing earplugs,
and I took a moment to explain to a few of them the Gospel According to
Lerner, of which (at least with regards to hearing protection) I am now a
devoted disciple.  I think you can actually hear things BETTER through
earplugs; everything's quieter, but sharper, and different sounds don't
bleed into each other, forming aural mush.

Best of all, I got my good friend Laurel to come, who is a woman of such
great intelligence, intensity, spirituality, and beauty that her continued
presence on the scene could not but help.  SHe had a blast.  I think she's
still a little shy about really letting loose and contributing to the vibe,
but I'm sure she'll improve with repeated exposure.

Unfortunately, I had to leave rather early as I've been sick (sniffle) the
last couple days and I don't have very much energy.  But I was definitely
glad I went, if nothing else to soak up the healing powers of house.  (And
how I could pass up a free party 2 blocks from my apartment?)

Peace,
stevie


From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 24 18:49:24 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA15114; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 18:49:24 -0700
Received: from netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA15109; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 18:49:17 -0700

	id SAA00583; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 18:49:42 -0700
From: meclay@netcom.com (Michael E. Clay)
Message-Id: <199407250149.SAA00583@netcom5.netcom.com>
Subject: What happened - one story
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 1994 18:49:41 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2971      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Yesterday's Vivid Pronoia at the Mountain school started well enough 
 (although I didn't arrive until 7 or so). Then as Laura was saying later
 "It was weird". At one point people were going to "talk". The music was
 stopped - strange stuff was affoot with the DJ's - lack of communication
 and planning happened (apparently no leadership). Pinkus? the "road warrior
 dude" took over the mic and became F. Clark "by definition". What was he
 talking about? F. Clark took over the mic - began got lost, began got lost
 began got lost... Is this the spokesperson for nationally famous Zippies?
 The talks became diffuse.. the music became diffuse - not DJ's fault. 
 Finally, a bit later the flow started back ...
 Good music, good visuals - some of the best computer visuals I've seen of
 late! so as darkness fell - the party was on. Ethan was spinning a good
 set and then -- here come the police. Close down time - at least this was
 expected since it had been announced. It had also been announced that a
 renegade was "planned" for the later evening...

 OK. the road warrior gave out directions to what turned out to be a GREAT
 site. Is it usable? Don't trash it. By telling us to go to Ano nuevo and
 how many miles past the deed was done properly. I watched my odometer -
 and sure enough we were there! But where was the music? We waited, and
 waited... there had been no planning for the sound system. DJ's with tunes
 were plentiful but no system. I was talking with Aaron(sp?) from SPAZ and
 at one point we agreed the site was big enough for two major sound systems.
 Unfortunately, no body had one. Keep this site in mind. Now for that 
 previous post.  As Crunch and I were walking in we came upon a group of
 "gentlemen" - I previously started a flame war describing the type -
 Sean uses "testosterone types" I believe and this will do... They asked
 Crunch and me "Are you ravers?" - loaded question. Crunch handled himself
 well - they joked about a "slightly used shotgun and a knife to cut my
 hair" - Crunch and I moved on.. This vibe was not at the Mountain school
 so how did it show up at the renegade? Later I went to a party with a guy
 who was beaten up by someone at the site - Could this have been the one
 observed in the previous post? Some people at the site watch too much MTV
 and had the "gangsta attitude" down to a stereotype... avoid, avoid...

 Crunch found another renegade so off down the coast to below Moss Landing
 we went. A small group of cars in the middle of a nice field. Deaks was
 one of the DJ's - these folks had gotten together a system on short notice
 set up in about 30 minutes, DJ tables on the trunk of a car, small but 
 adequate sound system and about 40-50 people were off dancing and hanging
 out until well after sun rise - good vibe guys. Now if only the Vivid 
 people had planned as well!  

 There sure are adventures out there in the land of renegade raving but
 danger seems to lurk as well....

  Are the various governmental "protection services" - police, park Etc.
  watching for rave (or other?) activities along the Santa Cruz coast ?
  Perhaps as as aftermath of Boony Dune ?

  I ask because as we were going up the coast looking for the rave site
  Cap'n Crunch was driving behind me and I was following a string of cars
  lead by a slow "white bus". The bus pulled into a parking lot as did the
  string of cars - we hadn't reached "the described site" yet so I continued
  slowly but Crunch flashed and turned into the lot also. I U'ed back into
  the lot. The self described "hippies in the bus" said we're no party we
  just stopped to get some sleep. As I got back in my truck I noticed a
  ranger truck had already arrived ( in about 3 minutes ).   

  Later at the site Laura commented on seeing the "white bus" go by so I
  will assume that the rangers told the bus to "be on its way" which 
  would be totally unfair since I had noticed many camper and RV type
  vehicles parked along the road - presumably to "get some sleep also" and
  I assume they were not systematically asked to "move on". 

  Once at the site which was in San Mateo Co. no authorities showed up (so
  far as I know) during the several hours I was there. I'm interpreting
  this fact as - authorities in Santa Cruz being "on alert". Is this a
  reasonable assumption? If it is planners might want to keep this in mind.
  (We did have a nice small gathering with Deaks et. al. later but this
   was way south of Santa Cruz and inland - not on a beach.) No trouble there
  either...

 
  Keep music going strong,
  Mike Clay

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 24 20:27:07 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id UAA16160; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 20:27:07 -0700
Received: from netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA16152; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 20:26:58 -0700
Received: by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id UAA12714; Sun, 24 Jul 1994 20:27:21 -0700
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 1994 20:27:21 -0700
From: resonate@netcom.com (resonate)
Message-Id: <199407250327.UAA12714@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: some santa cruz notes
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I will never understand the endless fascination with having
	parties in Santa Cruz. I lived there for 4 years during the
	ascent of the rave scene and heres some info for you.

	Santa Cruz is a tourist/resort town. The police there are
	*specialsts* in the artform of busting people who are camped/
	partying/etc...  on beaches/forests/ranches etc. They *know*
	every site up and down the coast and in the forest.

	The Santa Cruz police are recruited locally and from the very close
	relationship the SCPD has with the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk Security
	force- who are most often on a career path towards SCPD. They are
	not sophisticated urban police who "have better things to do with their
	time than bust a bunch of suburban kids out dancing." This is exactly
	what SCPD are there for. To bust people who are partying out of bounds
	in this tourist/resort town.

	Santa Cruz sites are 100% dead ends. There are easy to box in by
	police and rangers.

	Why are people so bent on going down there? If they want a non-urban
	spot they should go *north* out of the city and away from the major
	population centers like Silicon Valley.

	If you want to have a party in santa cruz and enjoy the natural
	landscape the best bet is to simply get in touch with a student at
	UCSC and plan a daytime dance party in any number of the UCSC
	amazing viewpoint/gathering areas.



From sfraves-owner  Sun Jul 24 21:41:26 1994

On Sun, 24 Jul 1994, resonate wrote:
> 	Why are people so bent on going down there? If they want a non-urban
> 	spot they should go *north* out of the city and away from the major
> 	population centers like Silicon Valley.

The police up north can be even worse sometimes, not to mention that many 
of the residents are unfriendly to our using their (in the collective 
sense) land. At least many of the beaches are far enough that it poses a 
problem for any serious "law" enforcement, but I've known of a couple 
occasions where residents along the roads out there have called in a 
"suspicious group of cars heading west." I know of very few people who 
have pulled something off anywhere inland in Marin.

But where there's a will, there's always a way, I guess (and hope).

jmar!

Will writes:
>In addition to the "ambient I love" things
>that others have mentioned, one by Steve Hilage
>that I've had for 15 years:
>
>Rainbow Dome Musick
>Virgin Records VR 1
>with Steve Hillage, Miquette Giroudy, and Rupert Atwill
>compositions are "Garden of Paradise" by Miquette Giroudy
>on side one and "FourEver Rainbow" by Steve Hillage on side two.
>
>This is post-Gong Hillage and sounds  (to me) even more
>Orb-y than the future work Hillage would do with System 7.

Yes, and this appears in Dr. Alex Patterson's top 12 ambient albums list.

>Has it ever appeared on CD? Are there other Hillage things
>like this from this time (1979)?

It has appeared on CD.

No, there really isn't any other Hillage albums that are similar to this
one.   Most of the rest of his work is hippie/trancey/jazzy, similar to
Gong, but less exoticly weird.   His best is "Live Herald" with some of
my favorite rock guitar work ever.

The whole System 7 thing is interesting, because in England, the words
"Hillage" and "hippie" are entirely synonymous (even more so than
"Grateful Dead" and "hippie" here).

I also second the recommendation for Michael Stearns' "Planetary
Unfolding"; most of his albums are good ambient ("Plunge" is jazz, though).

>Everything and everyone in your life is there by your choice.

Hence nothing to worry about...

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

Subject: Security
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was talking to a friend this weekend who said there was a shooting at the
Moonlight Mass (Massive?) rave this weekend in LA.  MM is supposed to be LA's
equivalent of our FMR.  This was a free outdoors party where you're on your
honor not to bring guns or your bad vibe to the scene.  Unfortunately this
was not the case.  

This event brought up a good point about security.  Yes, we have to wait an
extra 1/2 hour or longer sometimes to get in because security wants to search
EVERYTHING.  Don't you think this is a fair trade off to keep us safe?

I know we're not LA and I certainly am not comparing - I just hope we never
have anything like this happen at our FMR, Sunset or equivalent free outside
event where there is no security - it sure would blow the vibe for future
raves of that kind. 

So next time you are being searched and are frustrated just remember what
happened that night in LA.  And remember to bring your PEACE and not your
PIECE!

Peace and positivity,

Cindy and Greg
House Archives

P.S. Thanks to guys with Mother Earth Sound System for yesterday at the
marina.  Did anyone see us flying our green and purple kite?

This first part is from Joe Rice, followed by a less descriptive 
and more preaching news article:

> A friend who saw the shooting gave this description:
> 
> The 20 yr old was held up at gunpoint for a quantity of X and acid. The
> guys that held him up immediately fled the scene in their car. The 20 yr
> old become extremely distraught, angry, and aggressive. It's not known if
> he was on any drugs (speed, perhaps?) but my friend had met him before and
> said he was normally a nice guy. However, he went back to his car where he
> had a shotgun and he began loading it. The two 15 year olds were evidently
> staring at him as he did this. He shot them. They had no connection to the
> drug robbery.
> 
> The local news reported raves as parties full of underage drinking and $3
> nitrous ballons at the door.

San Diego Union-Tribune
Sunday, July 24, 1994
page B1

Shots ring out; 2 teen-age revelers die

by Cheryl Clark and Pauline Repard
Staff Writer

  For months, two National City mothers fought separate battles with 
their 15-year-old sons, trying to keep them away from all-night rave 
parties.
  But Gustavo Maldonado and his best friend, Jorge Alberto Villarino Jr., 
didn't listen to their mothers.  They went to the parties anyway.  One in 
particular on Friday nights along the railroad tracks of Old Town was 
rumored to be a smash.
  Today, both are dead from shotgun blasts, fired at them as they 
congregated with about 250 other partygoers near Taylor and Juan streets 
about 4 a.m. yesterday.
  An anonymous tip led police to a 20-year-old Paradise Hills man who 
sat in a pickup that was boxed in by other cars parked in a nearby lot.  
The suspect, Mark Jonathan Morales, was arrested and booked into the 
county jail on suspicion of two counts of murder.  A loaded shotgun was 
confiscated from the cab of the pickup, police said.
  Jorge was found dead with a shotgun blast to his head underneath 
Interstate 5, near where a band had performed earlier.	Gustavo was 
taken to UCSD Medical Center, where he died several hours later.
  Both mothers said they were shocked and baffled by the killings.  They 
said they were told by police and friends that the gunman fired at their 
sons by mistake, and they denied that their sons had any connection to 
gangs.
  "We were told this guy went over there and started shooting like a 
madman," said Gustavo's mother, Patricia.
  Rave parties, a '90s phenomenon, feature live or recorded music 
popular with teen-agers, such as hyperfast techno or hip-hop styles.  
They are often publicized through pamphlets or by word of mouth and have 
an admission of $10 per person or less.
  They are publicized with leaflets listing a phone number that can be 
called that evening for the location, which is usually in a remote 
outdoor area or an abandoned building.
  But the so-called rave parties also are known for the availability of 
alcoholic beverages and illegal mood-altering drugs such as MDMA, 
methylene dioxyamphetamie, also called Ecstasy, or "X."
  Maldonado's mother said she had long suspected that alcohol and drugs 
were available at these events.

See Mourn on Page B-4

MOURN
2 teen-agers are slain at Old Town 'rave' party

  "These parties go on in the middle of the street, with all the wrong 
crowd," she said.
  "You should tell whoever is organizing them that they're taking 
advantage of our kids and hurting innocent people," said Villarino's 
mother, Rosa, who lives a few blocks from Maldonado.
  Police Lt. Jim Collins declined comment on statements by the victim's 
families that the gunman hit the wrong targets.  He said the fatal shots 
were fired deliberately at each youth, just seconds apart.
  But he said the two homicides are the first to occur at a local rave 
party, which are not known for violence.
  "These are new to me," he said.  "One thing we will be checking on is 
what information our department has on rave parties."
  Collins said illegal drugs are sometimes available at such parties, 
but rave events are not usually associated with gang activity.
  "To my knowledge, rave parties are usually in a more isolated area, 
often a vacant warehouse," he said.  "I hope this (incident) lets kids 
know these parties are not a good place to be."
  Officers questioned those at the scene but said that only 10 saw or 
knew anything about the slayings and that they offered contradicting 
theories about the gunman's motive.
  Maldonado said her son was a loving, caring person who enjoyed camping 
and had a lot of friends.  But then he started in with a bad crowd, 
"just went in a different direction, like he was going through a stage 
where he was harder to get along with," she said.  "Everything was so 
out of control with these teen-agers today.  They do everything so hush 
hush and don't talk about anything."
  She said her son had admitted using drugs in the past, mainly smoking 
marijuana.
  "He said he didn't do it regularly, that it wasn't what he wanted to 
do with his life," she said.  "He wanted to be a civil engineer when he 
grew up."
  Maldonado said that her son had stopped going to the parties in recent 
weeks and that he spend Friday afternoon weeding and raking the front 
garden and cleaning up the yard.
  "He didn't deserve to die," said Maldonado's girlfriend, Tonya 
Marquez, 15, She said she thought he was going out with another friend 
that night because she had plans to go to the movies.
  Villarino's mother said Jorge wanted very badly to be a party disc 
jockey.  She said he practiced his banter as he washed the dishes, 
cleaned the house and threw out the trash Friday afternoon before he 
went out.
  "It isn't fair," she said, in tears.  "Suddenly to lose your son for 
nothing."

Staff writer Jeff Ristine contributed to this report.

 ,
dana

    his car to fishtail while driving on a winding dirt road.

This message is along similar lines as several recent postings

My name is Amanda and two friends and I are picking up and moving
from the east bay to Europe (we're not sure exactly where,yet).

a place in the scene in London and Paris....

to Europe and have developed roots there--or if anyone knows another

This is the biggest move of our lives and it would be incredible to
feel welcomed in these strange new places:)
