From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul 25 12:15:37 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA24554; Mon, 25 Jul 1994 12:15:37 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qSVUp-0003V8C; Mon, 25 Jul 94 12:15 PDT
Message-Id: <m0qSVUp-0003V8C@taz.hyperreal.com>
From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 1994 12:15:31 PST
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Adventures in Zippieland
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I got to the site (the playground of a private elementary school) around
6:00 pm.  There were about 100 people there, sort of hanging out.  A
nice sound system was set up and a DJ was spinning some deep diva house.

About 10 people were dancing and the rest just hung out enjoying the
afternoon.  As time went on more people arrived, I guess there were between 
150 and 200 overall.  A bit before 8:00 Bryce was asked to start an
ambient set that would back up Frazier Clarke's talk.  So, the dance
beats stopped, the more mellow stuff started.  I sat down to listen
but was not watching who was speaking.  Andrew, the head of the people
in Santa Cruz who put on the party, made a little speech and a little
introduction.  Then things got REALLY weird.

Frazier Clark was supposed to speak, but Zippy Pinkus (the one who
wears body armor and carries a staff at all times) upsurped the microphone.
Now, I wasn't watching so I thought it was Frazier Clark speaking all 
the time, and many people who don't know Frazier Clark from John Doe
were probably confused too.  Anyway, Pinkus started talking some really
bizzarre wacked out stuff, he was saying "By definition, this party
is hijacked.  By definition, I am Frazier Clark, I have lied to people 
throughout this tour and promised them things that I have had no intention 
of delivering, I have promised money and then when asked to pay have not 
paid . . .  " it went on like this for a minute or two, and then the voice 
(Pinkus) was saying things like "this being, Frazier Clark by definition, 
declares himself no longer a voice of the Zippy Pronoia Tour to US."  The 
last bit of major confusion was when the voice (Pinkus) said "and now we 
must vector to the dance floor and dance" and at that point Planet-6 started 
playing some hard acid techno.  So some people jumped up and started dancing.

The music went on for a minute or two.  The music stopped.  Some people 
started screaming "what are we really here for?  To listen to some old guy 
go on and on with his tired rap?  Let's dance."  The music started.  The 
music stopped.  I got scared of the whole thing and sat on a blanket on the 
edge of the playground to watch this all play out.

The music continued while some people remained in the area where 
Frazier Clark/whoever were speaking.

After a while things calmed down.  Drew from Santa Cruz played a very
bouncey house set that got people relaxing and dancing again.  Then
Ethan from San Francisco started a wonderful trance techno set.  (Ethan,
I danced so hard that I pulled the muscles in my calves, and I still hurt!)
Shortly thereafter (around 10:00 pm) 5 policemen arrived to close down
the party due to multiple noise complaints.

Word was spread (through Pinkus) that we were to move to a location
in the fields north of Santa Cruz.  The music would start up back there
around 1 am.  Supposedly somewhere in all this the Santa Cruz people
who had planned, set up, and paid for the entire party (one of the 
Santa Cruz organizers told me the Zippies didn't even arrive until
after the party had started) threw up their hands and said they had no
idea what was going on and didn't know if they felt like going any further
with the evening.  So, I had serious doubts about any sound ever arriving,
but Brian, Jeannie, Jules, and I went to the new site.  We waited until 
3:00 am and drove back to San Francisco because no one from the Zippies or 
from the Santa Cruz planning group or with a sound system arrived and the
mood was getting ugly.  Some local high school kids got in a fight and
were trying to beat each other up.

I had doubts about this all along, and these doubts were magnified on
last Monday night when 4 of the roughly dozen Zippies who are currently
in the US came over to Brian's and my apartment to talk with him about
using hypereal to put up pictures, articles, and digitized video.  
Throughout their time here I had no idea as to what their mission or
message was or if they really even had one.  Pinkus even suggested that
they print up 50,000 flyers advertising a party at Alcatraz and then just
not have it.  Someone talked a bit about manipulating the media and
getting on the cover of something like Newsweek.  Their seeming American
voice, John (Cubensis) went on about how he went to some little rave in 
Iowa or something and how bad it was because the kids were drinking beer
and how the Zippies have to show people how it really should be done (at
which point I asked "What right do you think you have to tell people how
to go about having fun.?")  [Not that I'm into lotsabeer + rave, but if
that is what the local people like then who am I to tell them what to do?
As M. pointed out, the important thing was that these kids actually had
the idea and gumption to throw a party.]

But anyway, I figured they'd been travelling a lot and were probably stressed 
out, and when I saw them twice subsequently they were industriously scanning 
material and uploading it to the net.  So I figured what the hell, going to 
Santa Cruz would be fun and maybe then I'd get to see what they were really
all about.

I really don't know what the whole story is, or even if there is one.

Laura

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 94 08:03:15 PDT
From: mwinton@cod.nosc.mil (Michael Winton)
Subject: Re:  Security

There were two shootings.  Two 15 year old boys were killed.  One
died at the scene, one died at the UCSD hospital a few hours later.
The suspect was arrested at the scene with a loaded shotgun and all
the ravers were detained until morning for questioning.

Apparantly a dealer was held up at gunpoint for his supply of 
E and acid.  Being quite distraught (and possibly on speed) he went
out to his truck and loaded his shotgun.  He then shot two innocent
bystanders (had no connection with the robbery); the robbers had
already fled...

Newspaper articles are basically blaming the rave scene...


mike / SoCal Raves

--I am not a witness, but am only relaying the story as discussed on
the SoCal Raves list.  Please do not quote me as an accurate source:)


P.S.  Hello to SF Raves, I'll be back up north in about a month.
Definitely miss the scene up there:)

Regarding the weirdness with the Zippies, the "false" Frazier Clark speech
(really Zippy Pinkus), and Frazier Clark... a friend of mine has it from
Andrew, head of the Santa Cruz folks throwing the party, and who introduced
the Zippies... that what basically happened is that the Zippies self
destructed at that event.  Zippy Pinkus had joined them somewhat recently
in their tour, and somehow been turned into treasurer for the group within
a short period of time.  Apparently he decided to break from the Zippies,
but since he was in control of their money, no one knew what would happen
next.

As anyone knows who bothered to listen to him, the *real* Frazier Clark was
almost incoherent when he finally was able to speak.  The same source says
that normally he's much more coherent, but that he was very upset by these
unfolding events at the party.

Doug




From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul 25 16:36:47 1994

In-Reply-To: laura@hyperreal.com -- 07/25/94 12:31

hi folx,
here's what happened with m and i at the zippy thing.
after some tribulations - the directions to the party were bad; appearently
epic people in sc lost an earlier, better site so they had to improvise
the mountain hi thing - we get there around 8 pm. saw  andrew from epic
productions who was putting on the party and he told us to talk with
randy who was doing the ambient thing at the time. andrew told us
that itwas not cleara if there was going  to be an afterparty. anyway,
m and i wanted at  least an hour to do the spoken word ambient set.
now randy started this sob story how he took many hours to set up his
set and that he usually  does six hour sets (!) anyway, he had been playin
for about an hour -this was around 9 pm - so we said, ok, why don't
you play for two hours , till 10 pm, and m and i do the last hour.
well, randy said that he could 'give' us 15-30 minutes ! that seemed
really selfish to us. plus, there was no way we could do our performance
for just 30 minutes. so  we ended up NOT doing it. so sorry to the folx
who came to hear the quantum physics/spirituality thing ; we could not
make it happen. hopefully we will do it at friends &family iii.
i have to say that the vibe at this time seemed really weird, as laura
said. couldn't really put my finger on it, but it just seemd really 'me me me'
and non-cooperative. i had a difficulty getting into the party after this,
and just talked with laura and bryce and brian for a bit. since
andrew told me that he was NOT continuing, i decided to skip the possible
afterparty, &  i just stayed  in sc for the night and
spent sunday hanging around sc.
take care/shalom
ovid


From sfraves-owner  Mon Jul 25 16:46:58 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA28435; Mon, 25 Jul 1994 16:46:58 -0700
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA28430; Mon, 25 Jul 1994 16:46:51 -0700
Received: by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.8.1/Netcom)
	id QAA03253; Mon, 25 Jul 1994 16:46:50 -0700
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 1994 16:46:50 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199407252346.QAA03253@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weak end rave report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WeakEnd rave report
===================

Well,   I have to admit it was a really strange weekend for us.   
First off,   I never got the word about the Full Moon event until way
after 5 am,   and by that time,  I had already nestled in for the evening
and didn't want to trek out to Contra Costa.    

A few things...  I think we might want to try and organize our phone
tree a bit better.    Almost always,   I start getting lots of phone calls
"Where the FMR tonight",   but most cases,   I'm just as "In the dark"
as most of those that call.     Is there one anymore?    I suspect so,
because I eventually got called,   and after that,   I put the info
number on my "Outgoing message machine" for those that still tried to
phone me,  so they can get the info.

I also don't mind being an "Information node" or using my 800 number
as an information nexus,   but sure can use some help in paying for the
800 number use (Which really don't cost that much).   Nuff complaints,
if you even call them that...   Lets get on the real gest....

The Santa Cuz Pronoia thingie was really strange,  as we all probably
know from all those reports that have already come through the SFRaves
mailing list.    

Re: the Zippies,  apparently  sometime between Wyoming and California,
possibly earlier,  there was some sort of "Falling out" or dis-association
between Frazer and the main Zippy possee.    I don't really know that
much about it,   and want to stay neutral in this.    This fragmentation
apparently was evident in ths Santa Cruz bash.   And could have been better
organized between the music and talks.   For instance,  the school grounds 
were sufficiently large enough to have BOTH music and talking going on,
but the area set up for the talk was in much too close proximity to the
main dancing area.

There was also a nice chill area set down the hill a ways and just beyond
that spot,   would have been a much better place for Frazer to give his
talk to those that might want to listen to him.

Although I was rather "tweaked" at the time,  and my mood was into dancing,
I had thought that Pinkus's talk was sort of a crude introduction to Frazer
in a somewhat twisted humerous way.   But lets not forget that the UK is
over 7000 miles away,  and British humor can be somewhat different than
ours.   Nuff said...

When the music finally did go back on,   it was really GREAT,  and Ethan's
set literally put my mind into a wonderful blissful state that made me forget
all the other stuff that happened.    Naturally,  the PIGS had other thoughts
about this,   and the music regrettably stopped about an hour short of the
expected finished time.

There was a tad bit of confusion when the music finally stopped,   and a mad
scramble for the location to the alternate area sortof ended a good mind
trip.

Mike and myself stopped by a restaurant for some food and to wait for the sound
truck to get to the alternate site.     After about an hour later,   we started
heading out to the site.

Luckily,  I'm familiar with the geography of the coastal region and didn't
have much problem interpreting Pinkus's directions,   but again,  good planning
could have been implemented,   by getting the info out to more people.
At least the SC shariffs lit up the place and made it easier to locate
my friends and clear out.

As mike pointed out in his report,    I ran into a caravan of about 4 or 5 cars
ahead of me that suddenly made a left turn into a parking area along the coast,
so I pulled in because I thought this was the place.   At least I got to talk
to some others about the location.

So we all pull in,   talked a while,  and just as the ranger pulled in,   me and
Mike left the parking lot,  and headed back north.    We find Ano Nuevo park
and proceed exactly as told and sure enough,   about 50 folks had already arrived.

I was somewhat concerned that the location was a bit too close to the Elephant
seal population at Ano Nuevo,  but later learned it was nowhere near there.

Because we were just across the county line,   I often wondered if that Santa
Cruz pig would actually go to the effort to notify the San Mateo county officials
about the rave.    But we discovered that the site was really GREAT...   Lots of
trees,   but people were yelling and in general making a lot of noise and I
had second thoughts about the possibility of the pigs arriving.    They didn't,
at least not while I was there...

I park in an authorized area,  carefully checking to see of there were any
parking restrictions.    At that point,  I walk into the crove of trees to
find an ideal spot.    At that time,  people were arriving at the alternate
site in droves,   and as I walked around,   I saw some raudy types,  and
one approached me and asked "Are you ravers?".    I didn't say anything,
just smiled and walked along a small roadway leading out to a cow pasture.

Mike and I sat down and talked a while,  then Brian, Laura,  and their
Dutch friend Joules showed up and Laura told me about the spat back at the
school about the sound system.    I was tripping pretty hard at that time,
so just hung out,  visited old friends and didn't much care about whether
or not the sound system arrived.    A few tents were set up,  and it sorta
reminded me of the rainbow gathering.

I was no where near where that fight broke out,  and Aaron was crashed out in
my car,   but I enjoyed chatting with Mike about a bunch of things in general,
and schmoozed around.

Later on,  a few Monterey dudes handed me a flyer to a renigade party they
had planned near Monterey,  and I took down the directions.    Everyone
was crowding around me,  eagerly wanting to know the location.    I let the
"Food,  not bombs" crew take down the directions and info number,  and
slowly made my way back to the car.    Eventually,  I ran into the Rowdy
folks again,  and they said "Are you a raver?",   I then replied "Raver?
Whats a raver?",  a few people laughed,   and some other ravers I had met at
other parties approached me and said "Just ignore those guys!",   I then
motioned for them to come with me so I could give them the directions to
the other party without the raudy people nearby.     As I approached the
road,   I saw more people I recognized and told them about the Monterey party, 
and they all eagerly followed me back to the hiway.

I gave everyone the Monterey party info number,  and headed back to the
car.    Without waking Aaron,   I carefully head out to the hiway,  with Mike
following and head south.   I noticed a few other cars following me.

About 45 minutes later,   I find the turnoff,  and head out to the party site.
The party site was a huge field of grass and stickers,   and I just arrive
as the sound system arrived and after some confusion,  we jostled the cars
around and in about 15 minutes,   the generator,  and mixer was set up on
the back of a car,  the music began,   and I was in my natural element
once again.

It turns out that the place we were raving at was on Ft Ord property, and
I silently thanked the US Government for providing such a nice site and
condemmed the local Santa Cruz authorites for being so much against the
idea of having a good time dancing and schmoozing.

I don't know who was spinning at first,   but he played some excellent acid
Techno,  then followed by another person who was a lot more fragmented in
keeping up a beat,  but I was ready to chill anyway.    Eventually Deaks
went on the turntables.    I had met Deaks earlier,   at the earlier
site,   and got to hear him spin.

He played a mixture of trancey acid stuff,   lost the beat a few times,
but spun some pretty good stuff.

All in all,  the after party was pretty good,   I would say about 20 or
so people eventually made it there.    

As the sun was coming up,   I could see this very straight line of cirrus
clowds in a perfect straight line to the East,  which was very appropriate
for the name of the party "Cirrus".    I had a GREAT time,  talking with
the young folks there,  as they were glad to have me attend their party.

One dude walked up to me and said,   "Could I have my picture taken with
you?",   I said "Sure!" and we talked for a while.    It turns out that he
had heard of me being in the rave scene and was surprised to see me.

I said "I always like the smaller renigade raves!"....    All in all,
I had a great time,  dispite the strangeness....

A few things the Monterey dudes should have considered... They should have
tried to keep the party at the first location instead of monterey....
Instead they should have spread the word out that an effort was being
made to go and get the sound equipment.  I know it would have taken another
1 1/2 hours to get back from monterey,   but I would have stayed...

Eventually,  around 9 or 10 am,   everyone packed up,  and I headed back
to Santa Cruz with Leo,   and visited him and a few friends at the beach
before heading back to SF.   I eventually had Aaron drop me off at the EndUp
and hung out there (Haven't been there in over a month),  and re-established
contacts with that crowd,  and took a nice leasurly bus ride back to
Mill valley.

The bus ride was very enjoyable and I enjoyed watching the multitude of
wind surfers out in the bay,   was treated to a spectacular view of SF
and when the bus pulled into downtoen Mill Valley,  I had stepped out
into a completly different world that the one I left.   It was 20 degrees
warmer,  and an incredably pleasant change from the socked in fog in
the past few weeks.

So,  dispite the strangeness,  I would have to give it an overall
8 on a one to 10 scale.... Looking forward to Tribal Funk next weekend,
as I was assured it was to be an outside location....  See U all there
next weekend...

Peace
Cap'n Crunch

        Ambient suggestions in another vein.  If you're into Aphex Twin
_Selected Ambient Works II_,  you might also want to check out Zoviet
France  (I believe they've split and half of the group is now Horizon 222).
 I've got _Mohnomishe_, which bears a strinking resemblance to some tracks
on _Selected Ambient Works II_  (the other way around, more likely...). 
Also worth checking out (now this is stretching it a bit), are albums by
Halfler Trio.  His stuff tends to be a bit spotty, and on the industrial
noise side of things, but the some of the albums I have have some really
beautiful moments.

/steve

   On Sun, 24 Jul 1994, resonate wrote:

> 
> 	I will never understand the endless fascination with having
> 	parties in Santa Cruz. I lived there for 4 years during the
> 	ascent of the rave scene and heres some info for you.
> 
> 	Santa Cruz is a tourist/resort town. The police there are
> 	*specialsts* in the artform of busting people who are camped/
> 	partying/etc...  on beaches/forests/ranches etc. They *know*
> 	every site up and down the coast and in the forest.
> 
 > 	The Santa Cruz police are recruited locally and from the very close
> 	relationship the SCPD has with the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk Security
> 	force- who are most often on a career path towards SCPD. They are
> 	not sophisticated urban police who "have better things to do with their
> 	time than bust a bunch of suburban kids out dancing." This is exactly
> 	what SCPD are there for. To bust people who are partying out of bounds
> 	in this tourist/resort town.
> 
> 	Santa Cruz sites are 100% dead ends. There are easy to box in by
> 	police and rangers.
> 
> 	Why are people so bent on going down there? If they want a non-urban
> 	spot they should go *north* out of the city and away from the major
> 	population centers like Silicon Valley.
> 
> 	If you want to have a party in santa cruz and enjoy the natural
> 	landscape the best bet is to simply get in touch with a student at
  
> 	UCSC and plan a daytime dance party in any number of the UCSC
> 	amazing viewpoint/gathering areas.
> 
> 
      Hello, i think a daytime party on the beautiful campus of UCSC is a 
fabulous idea... the quarry in the center of campus is a very large outdoor 
amphitheatre with great accoustics. It is surrounded by redwoods and is far 
from other campus buildings.  AND/or we could venture into the ever 
popular "elfland" which is the redwood mountains behind campus. Elfland 
has two meadows that are a fairly short walk from the adjacent parking 
lot.
	I think this would be a great way to express some summer-love 
energy...so if anyone is interested in organizing please mail me.

Jason D.
(408) 479-4327
Phun is a better way to run a planet!

        This was a very long weekend.  It started on Friday with a very
good small renegade that I threw together in about half an hour to an hour.
I was very happy to finally throw a party I've been trting for a year now.
Deaks and Tim spun and played us some wicked music!  We went from about
12:30 till 4:30 and then went to a friends house. The best was whe npoeple
fromk Santa Barbara showed up with notice from sfraves!!!  Thanks for
coming guys you made our day brighter!  So this is an up.

        I go to work after five hours sleep and then at midnight saturday
leave for the zippy/pronoia/vivid thing.  We head north to the site and I
meet friends as we arrive.  I'm in a good mood as I raved here a couple of
weeks ago.  The mention of guns and the rumor of a stabbing get me a little
nervous.  Someone driving a car too fast and near people said, "you don't
think I'll fucking run you over..." as I get closer to leaving.  Apparently
a lot of sketchy dealings were going on and there were some very rude
people there.  Quikly I organized my friends into a mobile unit and we
headed down to Monterey for renegade number two.  As I was leaving (after
giving Crunch directions :)) I saw someone violently smashing the
windshield of a car and my friend Clint stopped near the car and the
'smasher' was apcing back and forth in the way of exiting cars and then ran
headbutted thecar and then my friend quickly left as fast as possible.
Down.

        We got to my house about four and then got to the site a few
minutes later.  Sound up and running by four thirty with about fifty people
I was very pleased to have turned the evening around in a positive way.
The CAp'n was in attendance to deem our first official rave!  Thanks to the
Food Not Bombs people for the OJ and bagels!! Everyone was positve and I
was glad to have everyone come down to Monterey.  Crunch asked me what the
Monterey scene was like well that was it!  He asks if there are many
renegades answer as far as I know this was the second, the first was the
night before! :)  We ended at about 8:00 as friend with speakers needed to
go get sleep.  Thanks to K-go and Deaks for spinning both spun great sets.
Up.

Two guys were there from Richmond Virginia my friend Clint let them hang at
his house later into the day.  Unfortunately they stole his wallet from his
house and used his credit cards to get cash after they left.  They might
still be in the area so be wary.   They drive a black Suzuki Samurai and
told us their names were Ian and Graham.  They are average size both with
black hair and wearing biking shirts.  If you find them tell them they need
to work on their manners and respect, but I have faith their karma will
catch up with them.  Down.

Hopefully next weekend.  Up

The Cloud Factory
Our People Make the Difference

From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul 26 11:47:28 1994

Message-Id: <9407261441.tn195211@aol.com>

Date: Tue, 26 Jul 94 14:41:25 EDT
Subject: STABBING AT VIVID
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



The trouble makers were local Santa Cruz gang members. We were standing
around
watching the guy with the giant bubbles when I noticed some activity going on
by my car. I walked up to see what was going on and 2 guys had a very young
girl pinned down on the hood of my car. They had a knife to her side and were
going through her pockets. They told me to "step off" and that they were
"doing a rip-off".
I decided to watch from a safer distance when several other of their friends
srounded the people I was with before they could get away and tryed to pick a
fight 
with them. One of them pushed my friend down and my other friend grabbed him
and threw him down so they could try to get away. The guy got back up and
pulled out
a knife and stabbed my friend in the face and hand while about 8 others
kicked
him while he was down on the ground. We got my friend in someone's car who
tok him
to the hospital and waited for the gansters to move away from my car so we
could leave.
It seemed that the gangsters (there were about 15 of them) were going up to
people and asking them either if they had any drugs for sale or if they
wanted
to buy any and then riping them off.
After we left some other friends of mine were parked in the lot closest to
hwy 1
sitting in their car when one of the gansters walked up and punched the
driver in the face and grabbed my friend's backpack. He then jumped up on the
hood and started to smash in the windshield. 

I just moved to Santa Cruz last week and we wanted to do outdoor parties here
but
the whole incident really turned me off. It's really too bad that instead of
worring
about getting busted by the cops we now have to worry about our safety. In
all my years in the house/rave scene in San Francisco I've never seen
anything like what happened last weekend. 

I'm too upset from the whole thing to say anymore......



-Sean
SeanC43@aol.com
Freak Out! & The Shake Your Booty Sound System 415 485-6597




From sfraves-owner  Tue Jul 26 12:08:23 1994

	id aa10972; Tue, 26 Jul 94 12:08:43 PDT
From: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>
X-Mailer: SCO System V Mail (version 3.2)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: another perspective on the Zippies in Santa Cruz
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 94 12:03:33 PDT
Message-ID:  <9407261203.aa18389@moscow.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	After reading some of the messages here expressing disappointment
with the vivid event, I'd like to let everybody know that some of the Zippies
did have at least a few good times in SC.  I was fortunate enough to spend
some of those times with them, and miss vivid and especially the "afterparty"
debacle.

	One thing I havent seen mentioned here is that the pronoia tour seems
to be made up of three or four groups.  This is my own observation -- please
forgive me if I've misunderstood.  Anyway, I saw the following:

	- the band, Universal Sound, and their friends
	- Pinkus (Pingus?) and Angus, who met up with Universal in NYC
	- various people helping with driving/logistics
	- Frazier Clark

	I got involved because my friend Craig set up some studio time
for Universal friday night.  They arrived around midnight, with Pinkus and
Angus but without Clark (whom I never did meet).  We went to the studio,
and spent a very enjoyable 6-8 hours partying and recording music, while the
drivers slept.  It was one of the band-members' (Dan's) birthday, which added
to the festivities.

	The Zippy caravan left my house (where I was entertaining part
of the party while others tore down the equipment) around 8am, and
I didn't get to sleep till after noon.  That, and other obligations by
Craig (who was going to provide video for the after party) caused us to
get to the vivid venue as the last of the people were being dispersed.
Apparently earlier plans for a more suitable (closer) location for the
after party had fallen through, and the eucalyptus grove sounded too
far away and not particularly real/likely, so we went home to see what had
happened.

	At this point we found out that things had gone a bit awry, and
that the after-party probably wouldnt have power for the projector.  Also,
the band wanted to mix the stuff they'd recorded and make some copies.
So, we all went back to the studio, where many people slept and the rest
of us listened to music...  another nice morning.

	I watched the Wharf-to-Wharf afterwards and slept, and the last
I heard Universal and Pinkus and Angus had left for San Diego, but Frazier
Clark was still in Felton -- and thinking about staying.  I just hope the
recent murders in SD don't bring things down too much there... we'll see.

	As an aside, I think there were two things, outside Epic's control,
which may have contributed to the dis-harmony:

	- a spot in a column in the Wednesday Sentinel (local SC paper),
mentioning the Zippies' planning a "massive two day party" in SC, and giving
a number for the location.  Not the kind of publicity the cops like to see...

	- a huge gathering of Seventh Day Adventist camp people -- some kind
of national convention -- just down the street from the party.  Many people
probably saw the security at the crosswalk, with flares etc.  So the cops
were already nearby...

Andrew

PS If anyone's interested in Universal, let me know and I'll try and get
	your message to them.  Angus is interested in selling tapes, but
	I don't know what his distribution plans are.  Its sort of a
	trance-dance blend...  maybe I can put some up on the net...
AK

   If anyone south of San Luis Obispo is going to Anthem of the 
Sun on the 30th and is able to give a fellow raver a ride up to SF and back,
please let me know.  I will pay for part of gas.  I haven't been up
to SF since April, so such a favor will be greatly appreciated.

-Peace and Respect

Omar

Forwarded message:
Subj:    Stabbing
Date:    94-07-26 16:58:55 EDT
From:    datherton@ea.com
To:      SeanC43

Hi- sorry to hear about what happened to you and your friends. Something very

simular happened to me in October of this year at a party near Candlestick. 
About four gang members asked my friend for drugs and then they just attacked

him. They had him on the ground and were just kicking away at him. Nobody was

doing anything but just watching. I couldn't take it so I tried to stop them 
at first I got in between them and then they starting hitting me so I fought 
back. My friend got away at this point and two of the guys went after him. 

These people fought like pigs they would scratch and come at me two at a 
time. I tried to run from them and instead run into to more of them. This 
time around about six of them. They all attacked me one had a board and beat 
me over the head and back with it. I had my ear slashed with a knife and a 
gun placed to my head. Eventually one of the guys held me up and said he was 
going to kill me but then he said he didn't want to go down for that. He told

me that I should say I am sorry for what I did. I couldn't really see 
anything at this point cause there was so much blood in my eyes and I was 
pretty close to buying it. So I said sure I'm sorry I even left my house this

evening and he dropped my on the ground head first and they left. 

Five people ended up in the hospital that night one was a girl who they put 
in a concussion. When they were attacking me they were also getting other 
people too, it was almost like they had this planned in a weird way. 

Anyways I know how you must feel-and it's fucked that there is people like 
this in the world. I wish that there is something that can be done to keep 
them away from the house scene but in the last couple of years we seem to be 
on a collision course with them. I hope you and your friends still go out 
and can put this behind you. I have and am having a good time again on the 
dance floor with my friends. Although some of the trust and over all free 
feeling has been left behind.

Take Care
DA

Just a brief note to all and sundry:

i am posting this message because i have received a few messages, and
read a post or two on SFR wondering where a sound system might be
obtained.

if you didn't know, i own a smallish sound system that is available
for parties.  i usually work with it for free or cost.  it has formerly
been known as MetroVision, after the other  sound system that i work 
with, Sound Vision, and because it fits in my Geo Metro.  however, 
after talking with a lot of folks who were less familiar with it's 
history and parentage, they have usually referred to it as "the 
Liquid sound system."  i can tell a good thing when i hear it (jingle 
hound that i am), so i've decided we should formally name it the 
Liquid sound system.

if you or someone you know would like me to bring Liquid to a party, 
please feel free to contact me at the address below, or phone 415.642.9791.
if you'd like to see it, talk with me in person, or hear it in real time, 
please call my voice mail for it's next workout: 415.985.5244.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

I am interested in taking a survey of what people's favorite dj's are in 
the Bay Area.  They do not have to be from the Bay Area, but I would 
prefer them to be someone who at least plays around here once in a 
while.  If you are interested in taking part in this ANONYMOUS survey, 
this is what you need to do.  

1) email me, deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu.  DO NOT POST IT TO SFRAVES!

2) in your subject header, please write "DJ Survey Response"

3) please post your response no later than Sunday, July 31.  

4) only one response per person, please.

i think this will be fun for everyone, and i hope you all take the time 
to take part in this survey.  if I get a good enough response, I will run 
more surveys (complete with percentages! :) )

thanks!
little particles of water that look like clouds but hang low to the 
ground that is deep (the clouds)



From sfraves-owner  Wed Jul 27 13:33:27 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA11999; Wed, 27 Jul 1994 13:33:17 -0700

	id AA27449; Wed, 27 Jul 94 13:33:11 PDT
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 94 13:33:11 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9407272033.AA27449@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: kinetic
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



I went to Kinetic at 1190 Folsom last night.

It was a buck - the front bar was doing its own offbeat jazz
Tuesday night lounge deal (quite pleasant).  The back room was 
dancing that stayed reasonably active during the evening.

The sound was good (got a little loud later).  The music was 
coherent and well mixed.   Of what I heard, I thought that 
the beginning of Monty's set was the strongest.  I am a bit
clueless when it comes to techno - but this stuff has a funkier
fusion feel.  You can certainly get down to a non-outerspace 
vibe.

There were a few aggressive young men trying to boogie their way
into people's lives.  This wasn't any real problem - mostly amusing.
They were the exception to a nice crowd.   I met several friendly
people.

I would think SF techno fans could get really into this
place as a weekly.

Dave

Begin quote:>>>>

Gosh, I missed the original post of this thread, but it sounds terrible. I'd
gotten jumped at a party once in LA 'cause some guy thought I was hitting on
his girlfriend...

My injuries were basically just scratches and pulled hair, but the experience
stayed with me for a long time.  Until it happens to you, I'd say one doesn't
really know the sad emptiness victimization causes.  Its really hard to shake
off too, especially when its so senseless.

To whoever got victimized, I hope you bounce back soon, OK?  Life is good,
even if some people aren't

j a k e

Hi everybody!  Here's what's up on what the biggest _OUTDOOR_ NW party
this year. Beautiful mountains, tranquil forests, cool clear waters,
sandy beaches...and some of the _best_ performance and vinyl on this
side of the country...

                                                 brings to us

Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/1.33(web)-oc4)
	id RAA07306; Wed, 27 Jul 1994 17:45:30 -0700
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 1994 17:45:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Whitsitt Goodson <whitsitt@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: vivid
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9407271726.A19329-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm getting really sick of thugs.  Went to the vivid pronoia party with 
the rest of the MESS crew and had a (mostly) great time.  Liberated a US 
flag from a gas station to make the "United States of Free Love" banner,
 and missed the conflict between Mr. Road Warrior and whatever...Gave 
Frazier back copies of the Mess zine and met Steven, who traded 
his zine for ours and showed us wonderful hospitality 
at his place while waiting for the second half of the party (thanks for 
the vitamins and spiritualina).
So as we arive at the renegade site, I'm feeling particularly 
(naturally) high and open and friendly.  I see lots of familiar bodies 
from the Mt. School, so I don't pay enough attention to my intuition when 
this thug steps to us offering treats. End result: a lesson in applied 
socialism with a blunt object and now I'm missing parts of two teeth and 
my wallet.
I spent a night in SF General hospital last fall waiting to see if my 
sister would survive the beating she recieved from several locals who 
showed up at the party we threw at Candlestick park. ( not to metion the 
other four people who suffered the same fate.)  In the hospital a cop 
tried to blame me (and the rave scene) for what happened.  Our discusion 
proved less than productive.  Two weekends ago a cop who broke up a house 
party we threw in our coop told me he would charge me with felony 
contributing to the delinquency of a minor so that i would "go to prison 
and get buttfucked" (btw- I like anal sex, but homophobic remarks from 
cops make me rilly rilly rilly angry, like "bricks to the head" angry.)
I'm trying to be peace and love, but I fucking hate cops.  I want to get 
over it, but I feel trapped between two groups of thugs-one with a 
uniform.  I remember Jane's Addiction's song "1%" "the gang and the 
government are no different"
sorry for venting on you all
all in all, loosing my wallet was a liberating experience (no money, no 
id, no responsibility!) Sunset was, as always, amazing. We got to 
hear Spun play deep house.  Hooray for stoner disco. The east bay can 
finally claim a decent "scene," thanks to several wonderful groups.
  On top of this, I'm also falling deeply in love with a wonderful woman, 
which has nothing to do with raves except it's all about love...

heaps of peace to every being (especially thugs),
whitsitt

	0   mother earth s.s.	 0
	+(respect yo mama, baby!)+

p.s. karma happens

I'm writing a paper on ambient music for a "popular music and society" 
mass comm. seminar i'm taking at Cal.  Since y'all are the most 
knowledgeable folks on this subject, would anyone with an opinion please 
e-mail me with it.
I especially would like to hear from DJ's, musicians/performers, and 
ambient promotors, as well as "audience" types.
I'm kinda working an angle along the lines of "the evolution of dance 
culture;post-rave dance/club culture"
I'm leaving this intentionally vague(rather than putting up a bunch of 
leading questions), but basically I want to know: your involvement 
with ambient music.
 how do you use this music?
 what does it mean to you? 
 where does ambient fit into the house nation?

I've got my own experience to draw from, but since this is a research 
paper, I want to hear from you, too.
btw, please hurry, I've got a deadline to meet:)

love,
whitsitt

Hi, ravers!

As you may recall, myself and at least a few others from the SFR crew are
taking Liquid, ourselves, and whatnot to this year's Burning Man in Nevada.
I would like to produce a 'zine to handout at the event, called "Flaming
Dud[e][tte]" (PC, and a multiple read and entendre all wrapped into one,
as well as a joke...phew!).  This zine, hereafter referred to as Flaming,
will include at least who SFR is, how to get in touch with the regional
lists, access informatin for the more well known service providers, what
the house "movement" is about (as we understand it) and the like.

If you'd like to write something up (anything!) for inclusion, please
send it to me at the address below.  I need to get things together fairly
quickly so i can gather up everything, get it laid out, copied, etc. 
Therefore, the submission deadline is Saturday, August 20th, at midnight.
We won't have very much space available...i'd like to save trees and my
sanity by copying it on a single sheet of two-sided paper, folded.  So,
space is limited, and my judgement of what to include is, alas, final.
I will consider *any* material for inclusion, though it would be nice if
the material could be copied onto paper.  If you'd like to give us something
to take along to the Burning Man, we'll do that, too.

thanks muchly!  i'll be putting up the file somewhere on the net for your
perusal once i get it all done, as well as copying off a few extra hardcopies
to hand out around town after we come back.
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

hello, i was thinking about the rave scene at last weeks 
sunset...like...what is different  etc. there is a theme of sf's scene 
this summer, but i have not pinpointed what i think it is. well i was 
thinkin of what it is like and what is popular and whatever so here...

	IN				OUT
***************************************************************
dj's spinning for free			dj's getting paid
dj's spinning at free parties		dj's spinning at smoky indoors
berkeley marina				bonny doon
violence				safety
goons as doorpeople			fabulous drag queens as doorpeople
marijuana				nitrous
water					beer
earplugs				speaker-worshipping
daytime parties				all night raves
komotion				haze theatre
dancing					sitting
bisexuality				heterosexuality
techno					house
new dj's				traditional popular dj shamans
ambient clubs				speed klubbs
living in santa cruz			raving in santa cruz
love					confusion


well those are all of things that i can think of. the theme of my 
personal summer is either "the summer of love" and/or "the best time of 
my life". 

My love goes out to everyone    (even the thugs at vivid/pronia)
Jason d.

p.s. DO IT NOW!

Here's the relevant part of the Mercury-News article.  Someone
at my work actually saw my name in it and brought it in...


San Jose Mercury News, Saturday, July 23, 1994.

David Plotnikoff, "Modem Driver", excerpted from 
"It's a beautiful day in the cyberhood"

[intro about travelling and big city life and lack of meaningful
interaction with people] 

...I think of the home-brew bulletin-board
services and the small Internet mail-groups out on the edge of the
electronic wilderness as the places where real communities are being
built.

Forget video-on-demand and real-time stock quotes -- there's your real
"killer application."  I believe that small on-line neighborhoods will
be what finally sells cyberspace to a mass audience.  They offer the
things that are so sorely missing from real, streets-and-sidewalks
neighborhoods today: a sense of belonging.  A shared set of values.
Knowledge that -- for better or for worse -- we all have a stake in a
larger whole.  And someone to help with a barn-raising or a ride to
the dance.  Above all, small virtual settelements afford us a chance
to know each other as whole, multi-dimentsional people.  There are
thousands of small trives out there beyond the big mainstream services
and networds.  Here are two local Internet e-mail groups that
exemplify all that is good about small-town life.

To my ears, the musical terms "techno" and "house" are synonymous
with headache-in-a-can synthesized dance music.  Yet with that said,
I've had a tremendously enriching six months lurking on the SF RAVES
mail group.  The rave scene is still largely an underground phenomena
(sic).  This high-volume mail group (it regularly carries more than 25
messages a day) has been my window into the subculture.  On one hand,
it's very chatty and clubby - wiith a heavy dose of provincial
attitude, insider gossip and petty bickering.  Conversley, it can also
be very global in outlook.  These mostly college-age party-hounds are
the Beats of their generation - spontaneous, hedonistic and more loyal
to each other than they are to any cause.

The richest SF RAVES read lately was a long, hilariously detailed
travelogue on the Rainbow Family hippie convocation penned by the
legendary on-line wag John "Cap'n Crunch" Draper.  The list is also
the only place I've been able to find advance notice of the "Burning
Man" community-art project slated to go down in Nevada's Black Rock
Desert over Labor Day weekend.  (Yeppers - those zany kids really do
plan to torch a three-story human icon).

In between the gems you'll currently find long threads of discussion
about concert-related hearing loss, the drug Ecstasy and the recent
arrival of Zippies (nomadic British ravers) to the Bay Area.  There
are also semi-regular notices offering ride-pools to events, picnic
lunch gatherings in the park and the like.  Derek Chung's [that's me]
weekly rave guide, posted each Thursday, is dry-yet-essential reading.

The post-rave reviews, many of them quite poetic, are the real heart
of the community.  A recent dispatch from Will Penna, in which he
describes a group of ravers picking berries in the fog as dawn breaks
along a coastal ridge, is one of the sweetest pieces of writing I've
encountered on-line.  To svbscribe to the SF RAVES group, send e-mail
to majordomo@hyperreal.com with this in the body of the message:
svbscribe sfraves.

[goes on to describe the "nerdnosh" digest]

And one caveat, cybersurfer: If you visit these communities, please
respect the rules and conventions they've created.  I don't want to
see any reader of mine playing the gauche tourist in paradise.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

[David Plotnikoff is plotnikoff@aol.com]

Robert presented us with his list of in/out, which i think is cool, but
one problem with one of them...

> 
> 	IN				OUT
> ***************************************************************
> dj's spinning for free			dj's getting paid

now i realize we've all heard this point of view before...but really - i 
mean, i will never turn down a party because it isn't paying me to dj. in
fact, i almost NEVER get paid to dj - i do it because i love it and it's a lot
of fun and i like to share music with people. BUT...records are expensive and
not everyone is as fortunate as i am (both in getting free records and in 
having enough money to stay alive) and can really use some cash to help
out. a great preponderance of djs will spin for free if the party seems genuine
but to have the attitude that djs should not be paid imho isn't right.


*off soapbox*



Tamara Palmer * trance@netcom.com * izzyzi5@mvs.oac.ucla.edu *

To the person I sent the original message to about the Candlestick party. I 
sent that message to your address not the lists. I don't really care that you 
forwarded it- I think that's fine. But in the future when someone sends you 
something you might want to ask them before you post it..

Hay David- it broke my heart to see your sister in the hospital. I could not 
believe what they did to her. I did not see what happened to her because she 
was not around me when they were after me. I never really heard the whole 
story  I just heard that she was hit real hard by one of them. 

I hope that she has been able to put this whole thing behind her and can go 
out and enjoy your parties. I know how you feel about the cops too. They 
just stared at me that night as I was choking and they didn't even offer me 
any thing to drink I had to beg them for one. And at one point I just fell to 
the ground and they just left me there until the ambulance came.

Glad to hear that you have found LOVE- cherish it..
DA

 passes thru majordomo's filter)

  This should be a nice outdoor event for those of you in the SC/Monterey 
area or those of you who want to get out of the city...

	id AA02093; Thu, 28 Jul 94 20:45:00 PDT

Message-Id: <940728204554.24007a43@sonoma.edu>
Subject: re: vivid pronoia from EPIC
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi all,  James here... Andrew Morin from santa cruz is going to 
post through my account to respond about the vivid "pronoia" 
thing->

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
From: Andrew Morin of EPIC Productions in Santa Cruz, (408) 
423-7923.

The 4 PM to 10 PM Vivid/Pronoia was a pretty fantastic event 
though as you'll read below the "stars" had trouble ahead written on 
them. The school up Old San Jose road provided a beautiful site 
with redwood covered mountains in the backgorund and Soquel 
Creek in the canyon bottom. We had two sound systems, the fat one 
up by the school and the ambient by Dionysus Dreams down  in a 
field. As the day turned into night the crowd grw to about 500 
people who enjoyed spectacular visuals by Synergy, a great set spun 
by DJs Drew and Ethan, more visuals down in the field with 
projected images on the forests, a guy juggling florescent balls and 
flags, and a guy making huge bubbles in the lights. A huge falling 
star streaked across the sky and the moon began to rise on the event. 
Too bad we couldn't have gone longer as it was reaching epic...

It was very very sad what happened up the coast after our earlier 
event. In a major way, what putting on an event, of the sort that 
EPIC/Vivid did on Saturday, involves is creating a bascically 
anarchistic situation in which mostly anything can (and does) 
happen. Its not about creating a controlled and scripted event (like at 
rock concerts where people are assigned seats and told not to stand 
up). At a free event there is no security other than all of us working 
together to keep the negative energy at bay. Usually it works, often 
it doesn't.  I completely agree with what Whit from MESS said- that 
the cops are just thugs in uniforms. They killed our earlier event on 
Saturday just as it had reached critical mass- knowing that we were 
only going to go just one more hour (to eleven- by contract with the 
school).  They were extra-abrasive and rigid-  perfectly fulfilling 
every negative stereotype about police. 

There had been a bunch of confrontations at our day/evening event 
as the Dog Day of Sirus and the Full Moon played havoc with 
emotions. The zippies break between Fraser Clark and the 
Pincus/Angus group went public as Pincus pushed me aside as I 
was introducing Fraser and "hijacked" the event with such negativity 
that it had our DJ in tears. It was only DJ Drew's and Ethan's 
spinning that brought the event back together again for the final few 
hours. But the negativity had been unleashed... and the 
Pincus/Angus group were all over me about the fact they weren't 
going to be making any money from the now free event (at 
which they didn't participate at all except to try and sabatoge it.)  
Also, some of the Santa Cruz "Family" members also expressed 
their displeasure about the event, ie, the attempt to do something 
slightly different than simply have DJs spinning records.  After the 
cops broke up the event the zippies and the santa cruz "family" just 
got up and took off leaving only Drew, James, and myself to clean 
up and move the sound and generators. Three hours later wefinished 
cleaning up and had no way to transport the sound up the coast and 
back.   

The zippies are hype, and while Fraser Clark and the three Univeral 
Sound Band members are cool people, the rest of the group are 
useless groupies looking for a free tour of the US. With no real 
purpose except to ride the hype of the Wired Magazine article the 
group has been aimlessly wandering around the US hoping to hitch 
a ride on the back of existing rave communities. It hasn't been 
working very well. Fraser Clark is a true philosopher and 
visionary, and the three Universal Sound band members play some 
hot hard core euro-techno. But nothing has really come together and 
the tour is now in shambles. Now minus Clark, the group is 
scrounging for money to stay afloat. 

so thats the scoop... if anyone wants to respond- any questions, 
comments, concerns you can reply or call us at (408) 423.7923

peace and love to you all,

Andrew

Well I wonder if big brother bothered to read the San Jose Mercury News.
This ain't unda ground no more.  Ahh, above ground now.  Well the sun is 
shining and I can see the sun or the moon.  Oh and over there are those pesky
guys who like to wear blue uniforms (why?) and dislike the fact that other
people besides themselves are enjoying life.  Are we paying their salaries by
any remote chance?  Hey there's more people around
here.  Look they've come to learn about unity.  Isn't that exhilarating?  But
with more exposure comes greater responsibility and more risks.  Are we in
the Soviet Union of Amerikkka yet?  I see a few signs that seem to be similar,
but good, I'd prefer not have to look over my shoulder when I take a pee 
behind a tree.....

Anyways, I'm going to nap.  Have a fantastic fantasy dream reality every-one, 
if you're already there.  While you're at it how about looking at one day's 
worth of waking life as a dream reality.  Wait a second here..... Me remembers
going to sleep and in my dream I'm tapping on a keyboard while I nod off yet
again in that dream to find myself tapping on another keyboard in that dream.
Now am I dreaming or am I awake or am I awake but actually my life from birth
till death is within another short dream and I'm really just a dream segment
of a much larger, more all-encompassing creat-ure that is dreaming?

Playing the work game, the rent game, the green paper play-money game, the
survival game, the crew-member of spaceship Earth game, to name a few.......

Love and respect and tolerance and forgiveness and unity to ya ahlll,
Spanky

I've always thought that it would be great if the authorities *really read*
sfr; they'd be the first to realise how totally harmless we are :) 

That our only real threat (and this IMO is *the* most important aspect of
"what we are doing*) is in subverting the dominant paradigm by engaging in
peace, by engaging in positivity, by engaging in and bulding community is,
I think, well beyond the ken of the average officer. Too bad that their
lack of a conscious cognizance of this dynamic seems not to interfere with
their baseline dislike of people having fun.

Unfortunately and, as recently evidenced, the world is full of *real*
criminals. That, seen in this light, 'civilization' seems to require police
is the unforunate consequence of a culture weened and perpetually
malnourished on alcohol, violence and a total lack of paths leading towards
meaningful existence in the (lack of) community. 

"..protect me? who'll protect me from you, the likes of you, the nerve of
you..." 
             Gil Scott Heron (approximately +)

Funny to think that twenty years later the all too bitter irony is that the
revolution *will* be televised; this, however, will make little difference,
as the the very nature of the approaching involution will be nothing if not
the wholesale consumption of physical materialism by itself. Those that
stay behind to watch it will be, by then, so far gone as to find the next
level totally incomprehensible. Inside the mind, that's where it's goin... 

Now how's that for topic drift +)

take it easy
ethan

ZIPPY NEWS FLASH
================

   Hi,   I just talked with Frazer Clark,   where he has sort of made me
a spokesperson in this area,   where he is planning to set up a permenent
office here in N.  California.   We are currently establishing our own
identity here in the Scene.    This includes myself,   Aaron Namaste,
and Radion Matrix TestData (Who has now come back to us,   after a long 
absence from the scene).

>From Frazer Clark...

    PHASE 1 OF THE ZIPPY INVASION IS NOW COMPLETE
    
   As planned,  I have now reached California where I have gone underground
with the Zippies here,  and with others joining me here from London,   including
Cap'n Crunch.

   We are working on the Grand Canyon Maga-rave (whose venue will be announced
this Monday) and also on opening a very large Megatripolis club in San Francisco 
in September.

   As with Megatripolus in London,  it will combine the best of Rave Culture,
Festival,  New Age,  Supertech,  and Internet-weaving etc.   Which will
facilitate the scene meeting itself.

PLEASE NOTE:

   The Pronoia tour was the hypodermic syringe to inject the new cultural virus
deep into Americas psychic body.

   This stage has now been completed and,  although the booster rocket continues
to orbit under its own momentum,  it is no longer connected IN ANY WAY to the
nroader Zipy invasion as it disperses deeper into the US Culture.

I REPEAT:  The Zippy Pronoia Tour to US is no longer connected to me (Frazer
Clark) IN ANY WAY AT ALL.

						Signed:
						Frazer Clark
						"Zippy Invasion HQ - California"

----- end ------

John D - There you have it from the horses mouth,   and we (John Draper,
Aaron Getting,  and Radion) will have more information as it comes together.

Subject: A great party last night
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

   Well everyone...  Last night has convinced me that the underground Rave
scene is flowering back into something of the likes I haven't seen since the
ToonTown days.

   I'm sure you all remember the Survival Research venue this last June,  where
they did theoir awsome show.    WELL,   this venue has yet again served a super
scene last night to an awsome rave where about 300 young folks danced to the
awsome tunes of Carlos,  Dutch and others in an incredably energetic and
wonderful vibe that exceeded all my expectations.

   Everyone there was on their best behavior,  and Carlos got on the Mic and
made an announcement that NO Alcoholic beverages were allowed.    I am happy
to report that I saw nobody indulging in said substances.    Instead,  everyone
had a killer time....  no police showed up,   and as I approaced the venue,
I was efficiently guided into the large dirt parking area,  where the cars
were neatly parked in an efficient manner.

   The party was FREE,  dispite the killer sound system that made for some
very heady spacey sounds when bopping around the dance area.

   I also want to remond folks that Tribal Funk is happening tonight (Friday)
and I will be there,  and encourage others to make plans to go,  either after
the last SPAZ party,   or both.    This venue is to be an outside venue,  on
private property,  and is reputed to be bust free,  and last well into the
morning.   Call (415) 905-4476 for venue location after leaving SPAZ or
sometime after about 8 - 9 pm.    See Ya all there...

Crunch
Namaste
Radion Test Data



From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 29 15:11:42 1994

In-Reply-To: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
        "An important note from Frazer Clark" (Jul 29,  2:26pm)
References: <199407292126.OAA12116@netcom7.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: An important note from Frazer Clark
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wish Frazer Clark well, but quite frankly, his note (kindly provided
through Crunch) is an admission of the hollowness of the whole Zippy
Pronoia affair.  In a scene saturated with hype, I'll give the Zippies
credit for rising above the fray to a new higher level of hype.  Coming
to the States and glomming on to local scenes all over and taking
advantage of the good intentions and hard work and positive vibes of
event organizers and attendees alike, without providing all that much
of substance in return, strikes me as more an exercise in ego than
a doorway to the transformational future.  I'm thankful that we're
nearly done with the self-congratulatory, self-referential phase of
this particular trip.  

Sorry to be so down on this, but I'm one who is always more impressed
with results than pronouncements.

All the same, we do need to hear from articulate, visionary folks who
can crystallize some of those feelings we all have, I think, about the
*need* for a transformational approach to life on this planet.  But
we hardly have a corner on that particular font of truth.  I just happen
to think non-commercial dance-oriented house-based music is one hell of
a great gateway to the future that I want, a reuniting of mind, body,
spirit with our earth, with each other.  I've heard some interesting
thoughts along those lines from Frazer Clark and I hope to hear more.

Who knows where this journey leads?  I'm not leaving my place in this
theatre until I see the final credits!

> Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
> Date: Fri, 29 Jul 1994 16:06:40 -0800
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
> Subject: Drowning in Hype
> Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Precedence: bulk
> 
> >    PHASE 1 OF THE ZIPPY INVASION IS NOW COMPLETE
> >    
> >   As planned,  I have now reached California where I have gone underground
> >with the Zippies here,  and with others joining me here from London,  
> >including
> >Cap'n Crunch.
> 
> This whole mess is really getting hopelessly pathetic. Never have I seen
> such totally vacuous, substancless, blathering, self-agrandizing hype;
> yuch.
> 
> (Talk)-(Action)=0
> 
> >   The Pronoia tour was the hypodermic syringe to inject the new cultural
> >virus deep into Americas psychic body.
> 
> Blah, blah, blah...
> 
> >From what I've seen of this 'virus' I wish they'd kept it on the other side
> of the pond. 
 
  Well, in some support for the Zippies (but not much), They brought some 
realy wicked DJ's over and all the guys in Universal Sound are cool too.  
But this whole "Wired Inspired" event is just terrible.  I realy have no 
clue as to what they are trying to accomplish, and whatever it is, they 
aren't having much success at it..

  Believe me, I am all for a cultural and psychological change, but I 
have the sneaking suspission that the zippies are making people help them 
and behind their backs aren't doing diddly squat.. (err.. ok.. whatever :)

  Frazer Clark has an intriguing writing style and the zippie propaganda 
and philosiphy is interesting.. But try reading something like "The 
Celestine Prophecy" by James Redfield.  He talks all about major changes 
in humankind in an interesting and down to earth way.  Not in a 
psychedelic, technological mind opening way...

  ::sigh:: 'Frankly, I don't give a damn..' but they have invaded our 
scene and left a not so sweet taste in our mouths (see: VIVID PRONOIA) 
and the idea of them staying here.. well.. I just dont know.. What are 
they going to do, get some people to work hard and open a club for them 
and run it for them?? 
 
  And finally, if there had never been the story in Wired (which I never 
read, but saw the cover..) would they even be here now??

 Peace out.. Keep the vibe strong!

Frazier Clark writes:
 > As with Megatripolus in London, it will combine the best of Rave
 > Culture, Festival, New Age, Supertech, and Internet-weaving etc.

Don't forget jugglers, tilt-a-whirls, gravitrons, and clowns.

Hey, it's Cool World!

John, here's a suggestion for Mr. Clark: Instead of bigger and better
mega this and mega that, why not just spend some time with us? Find
out what we love about the scene...why we pour our hearts into it. Go
to some small events.  Have him come to the next NMR. Not by storm,
though, but with humility.  Have him talk to some of those smiling
faces, and ask them what they like about the scene and what they don't
like. Ask them about their favorite parties and why. Ask them what
it's done for them, and why they think it happened.

Have him read the spirit files in the rave archives.

I think he's going to get a really empty feeling from all this unless
he gets in touch with the people and what's on their minds.

Sean

On Fri, 29 Jul 1994, Fred Heutte wrote:

> I wish Frazer Clark well, but quite frankly, his note (kindly provided
> through Crunch) is an admission of the hollowness of the whole Zippy
> Pronoia affair.  In a scene saturated with hype, I'll give the Zippies
> credit for rising above the fray to a new higher level of hype.  Coming
> to the States and glomming on to local scenes all over and taking
> advantage of the good intentions and hard work and positive vibes of
> event organizers and attendees alike, without providing all that much
> of substance in return, strikes me as more an exercise in ego than
> a doorway to the transformational future.  I'm thankful that we're
> nearly done with the self-congratulatory, self-referential phase of
> this particular trip.  
> 
> Sorry to be so down on this, but I'm one who is always more impressed
> with results than pronouncements.
> 
> All the same, we do need to hear from articulate, visionary folks who
> can crystallize some of those feelings we all have, I think, about the
> *need* for a transformational approach to life on this planet.  But
> we hardly have a corner on that particular font of truth.  I just happen
> to think non-commercial dance-oriented house-based music is one hell of
> a great gateway to the future that I want, a reuniting of mind, body,
> spirit with our earth, with each other.  I've heard some interesting
> thoughts along those lines from Frazer Clark and I hope to hear more.
> 
> Who knows where this journey leads?  I'm not leaving my place in this
> theatre until I see the final credits!
> 
                   no leaders needed,thank you!!!!!!

	This mail is from Ran at Dionysus Dreams...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: Ran@ Dionysus Dreams
Subject: Vivid/Pronoia

These are some of my personal observations concerning Vivid/Pronoia.

First- My heart felt apologies and sympathies to those hurt at the
(so-called) after-party for Vivid/Pronoia.  I would be happy to meet
anyone who was hurt or sustained property damage in order to convey my
apologies personally.

Second- No one at Epic Productions or anyone with the Santa Cruz Family
ever informed about an after-party.  It was discussed earlier in the
week, but I never heard any concrete plans.  At the Mountain School
party, I was asked by several people as to the location of the
after-party, but replied that while there may be one, I did not know of
it.  During the party, someone (oh I wish I knew who) told me of the
eucalyptus grove scene, so I passed on the info thinking it reliable.  I
feel really awful that people were hurt at the grove and that I had even
so little to do with it.

Third- I've been hearing grumblings (still?!?) about how I handled the
ambient space I helped to bring about, with mother earths benevelonce,
as part of Dionysus Dreams's performance at Vivid/Pronoia.  Specifically
Ovid and his companion (m) are claiming that I would not let them perform
or made the situation for them so difficult that they would not want to
perform.  I would like to respond:

1- I never promised anyone anything, except Vivid- and that being that I
would provide the sound, lighting, technical personal for the ambient
space as well as a juggler, an ambient set from me and times for other
ambient performers to express themselves (using my equipment and the
energy time it took me to set up).

2- I was told by the promoters that I was ultimately in charge of the
scheduling for the ambient performers and given a tentative schedule to
work with.

3- On that schedule (which I still have) Onid was scheduled for a half
hour.

4- Back at Vivid/Pronoia I offered Ovid and m 15 to 30 minutes to
perform their material.  I offered to st up a very exspensive microphone
and the use of my CD players.

5- m raised her nose and huffed that only an hour was good enough and
Ovid quietly agreed.

6- It was 9pm, I had been playing for about a half hour, no help me set
my equipment (about 3 hours of work), and I wanted to play for a while
longer and establish a groove in that beautiful setting.  We were
scheduled to stop at 11pm.  As it was we were stopped at 10pm by the
police.  I'm happy with my decision since if I had given in to the
demands of Ovid and m I would have omly a half hour to show for about 6
hours of work (load in and load out) that I agreed to do for free.

7- Only those who own portable sound and lighting equipment, create
sculptures, hire talent for shows, and have a spiritual (for lack of a
better word) approach to their art can understand the work and Love I
put into that ambient space for others to enjoy.  If this attitude is
not good enough for others- tooooo bad!

I really appreciated the chance to create a chill space for everyone!!!!!
I can be reached @ (408)462-0849, look for my e-mail slot at Cabrillo
College (Dionysus Dreams).

Increase the peace,-Ran



From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 29 19:06:55 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id TAA25362; Fri, 29 Jul 1994 19:06:55 -0700
Received: from quack.kfu.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id TAA25357; Fri, 29 Jul 1994 19:06:46 -0700
Received: by quack.kfu.com id AA06271
  (5.65c8/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Fri, 29 Jul 1994 19:06:33 -0700
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 1994 19:06:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: Motion...the Final Frontier...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9407291804.A5826-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Final Motion at F/X in San Jose was PACKED!
I don't just mean people
I'm talking fun.
Even when I could find a decent square foot to get in motion, (so many 
happy people) I could hardly keep up with the trance breaking into what 
very much reminded me of hardcore LA techno/rave all layered with 
jungle/tribal beats from the live drummers going off in the corner!
By the way, thanks Larry for showing me the "sweet spot" between all the 
drummers.  It was like a massage of the soul to be completely surrounded 
by "booonga-booonga" reverberations through the body, all the while 
surrounded by hundreds of people dancing like MAD!
Thanks to WIll Penna for introducing yourself to me.  You seemed right at 
home grooving with the jester's cap and a big smile!

I don't think many more people could have fit into that converted 
theater.  It reminded me very much of the last Wicked event, because the 
whole crowd would FEEL the energy coming from the DJ.  And when it was 
time to bring it up a notch, everyone would respond with whoops and 
cheers when they felt the surge.  It was fantastic.

The visuals were good as well.  Multi-layered slides mixed with film 
clips (what was that clip of the tin man from Oz in the desert?) At 
first, I didn't dig the smoke machine, but as I sat in the corner and 
looked across the sea of moving bodies during a trance-type set, I could 
see the effect someone was going for.. the light mist filled the room and 
gave it an ethereal feeling combined with the space-like sounds and 
suddenly I felt like we were all on a cloud... . .

					. . ..in the jungle.. . 
					(the booonga boooonga drummers)

		. . ..on a slight incline.
			(the movie theater)

I liked it.  Too bad that was the Final Motion.
I hope to see more vibe in San Jose..
walrus@quack.kfu.com



From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 29 19:29:45 1994

Date: Fri, 29 Jul 94 22:29:13 -0400
From: Bob Ramstad <boccibob@media.mit.edu>
Message-Id: <9407300229.AA11404@media.mit.edu>
To: andrewk@sco.COM
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: Andrew Knutsen's message of Fri, 29 Jul 94 18:41:12 PDT <9407291841.aa17537@moscow.sco.com>
Subject: mail re Vivid from Dionysus Dreams
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


if you can forward things to Ran, please forward this to him.

i was not there, but as someone who has been similar situations, it
sucks both ways.  a little planning, though, and a little
communication go a long way.  if anyone had informed Ovid or M of the
situation, that they could only expect to have 15 to 30 minutes, they
would have been able to make the decision one way or the other and
there wouldn't have been any hard feelings.

another comment on this is that there are dozens of people on this
list who have spent hours and hours preparing for parties where they
don't perform.  the party itself is the payoff, not the performance.

finally, the system is self adjusting.  if you make it clear to people
that you would rather spin than have others spin, that's fine and
people can deal with that.  if you make it clear that it's
collaborative, then you'll get people joining in.  it is totally fine
to say "i took six hours to set up so i want to spin the majority of
time" but this also means that it's unlikely that people are going to
leap to help you set up the next time.

the most important thing is to throw the events... but it does make
everyone a whole lot happier if they know what the deal is.

just a bit of blather,
Bob

On Thu, 28 Jul 1994 BUEHRING@sonoma.edu wrote:
> -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> From: Andrew Morin of EPIC Productions in Santa Cruz, (408) 
> 423-7923.
>
> It was very very sad what happened up the coast after our earlier 
> event. In a major way, what putting on an event, of the sort that 
> EPIC/Vivid did on Saturday, involves is creating a bascically 
> anarchistic situation in which mostly anything can (and does) 
> happen. Its not about creating a controlled and scripted event (like at 
> rock concerts where people are assigned seats and told not to stand 
> up). At a free event there is no security other than all of us working 
> together to keep the negative energy at bay. Usually it works, often 
> it doesn't.  

I disagree.  What caused the mess last Saturday was lack of structure
itself - which is the darker side of the whole pronoia concept, i.e.
"having the sneaking suspician that others will take care of the details
and handle responsibility for you".  Andrew, from what I could tell you did 
everything you could to keep structure and form there, but when the event
was sabotaged the control was lost, and that's where the negative energy
comes from (I know Jump in the River will flame me on that one :)  HAD a
sound system shown up at the second location, even with gang members there
I don't think anyone would have been attacked or hurt.  I guess I just come
from the school of thought that chaos is a highly inefficient method of 
getting something done.

I don't blame you for not having been able to get a sound system to the
second site, though it would have been very nice to have sent someone up
there to let others know that it wasn't happening.

> The zippies are hype, and while Fraser Clark and the three Univeral 
> Sound Band members are cool people, the rest of the group are 
> useless groupies looking for a free tour of the US. With no real 
> purpose except to ride the hype of the Wired Magazine article the 
> group has been aimlessly wandering around the US hoping to hitch 
> a ride on the back of existing rave communities. 

They're an embarrasment to the magazine, frankly.  I spent all last
weekend with the author of that article, Jules Marshall, as he's
come out here to follow them (as well as write some other stories).
He had never met Pincus or John Bagby or Angus when researching the
article back in November of last year.  One can debate whether or
not the story merited being on the front page of Wired in April,
but I think that decision was made for photogenic reasons more than
anything else.  Wired is offering NO support for the Zippies on this
tour, firstly because they didn't ask, and secondly because we've never
felt a responsibility for them.  It was just a story, we didn't make
it up, we might run a part 2 or we might not.  

> It hasn't been 
> working very well. Fraser Clark is a true philosopher and 
> visionary, and the three Universal Sound band members play some 
> hot hard core euro-techno. But nothing has really come together and 
> the tour is now in shambles. Now minus Clark, the group is 
> scrounging for money to stay afloat. 

They simply don't have any competent people managing the tour, and
they're frittering away the publicity they have which could have possibly 
been put to much better use to really educate people.  

	Brian
