For your enjoyment....

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 1994 19:35:59 -0700
From: John Bagby <cubensis@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: Zippy Pronoia Tour to US '94 

The Zippies Are A Movement
The Movement Has No Leaders
There is an official Zippy Pronoia Tour To US '94
consisting at this moment of 12 simply real individuals
whose feet are on tour
There is an untold number of Zippies around the universe, 
the world, and in cyberspace,
transponding the Zippy Pronoia Vibe

The specific individual Fraser Clark is manifesting his 
life poem in San Francisco as an entity seperate from the
Zippy Pronoia Tour to US '94

And now, on with the show:

tonight, July 29, 1994, the Zippy Tour was invited to host
the Ambient Room at ELEVATE, in Tijuana, Mexico with music by 
the Zippy Tour Live Techno Band: Universal Sound (UK)
and ambient architecture provided by the Zippy Tour Artists.

Border realities between the US and Mexico being what they be, 
we could all have gone down to Tijuana with the equipment, yet 
not all would be allowed back across the border.  Thus, there
will be a Zippy Tour presence manifested at ELEVATE of a core
group of Zippies to keep the vibe alive.
Unfortunately, no equipment other than DAT and audio recordings
will accompany them

The only real Zippy Pronoia Tour Events are those we are 
communicating to you officially, with the next ones as follows:

Zippy Rave at The Works, Pheonix Arizona, August 16, 1994

YAY!! We're on the bill!  NARNIA, Vector Outbound San Diego
                                  August 20, 1994
>From which we will all transpond to the big one:

Zippy Rave in the Grand Canyon Area August 21-28
Further Details Forthcoming From US to YOU in a 
responsible fashion

Then, officially, at the Grand Canyon Area Event, 
the Zippy Pronoia Tour will be distributing vouchers
for $5 off the ticket price for the
Burning Man Festival, Black Rock Desert, Nevada
Sept 2 - 5
So that whomever so desires comes along parallel to the 
Zippy Pronoia Tour to US '94
Vector Outbound To Burning Man

Vector Transponder Information Throughput
endcom.zippies.07.29.94

Forwarded message:
> From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
> Subject: Motion...the Final Frontier...
> 
> ...rave (music) all layered with 
> jungle/tribal beats from the live drummers going off in the corner!
> By the way, thanks Larry for showing me the "sweet spot" between all the 
> drummers.  It was like a massage of the soul to be completely surrounded 
> by "booonga-booonga" reverberations through the body, all the while 
> surrounded by hundreds of people dancing like MAD!

 One of my favorite MOTION memories will be the percusionists that were
allowed to bring their congas in and play ( as long as they weren't too
close to the DJ ) . I brought claves once , and one gal had a tambourine
this Wednesday. 
 Having a DJ playing the "endless groove" with live drummers that 
know what they're doing is always a potent combination with me!
It should happen more often.
 
>

> clips (what was that clip of the tin man from Oz in the desert?)

From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 29 21:50:40 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id VAA27172; Fri, 29 Jul 1994 21:50:40 -0700
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA27166; Fri, 29 Jul 1994 21:50:33 -0700

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <9407292150.ZM12947@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 1994 21:50:27 -0700
In-Reply-To: tazzleberry <tess@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
        "Re: An important note from Frazer Clark" (Jul 29,  5:41pm)
References: <Pine.3.89.9407291743.A3401-0100000@locusts.berkeley.edu>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: tazzleberry <tess@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Re: An important note from Frazer Clark
Cc: John Draper <crunch@netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I agree, I'm not interested in self-proclaimed 'leaders'.  I prefer to
work with those who lead by action and intention.

If this crew can pull off something to equal the original Megatripolis,
more props to 'em, SF could use a boost.  But unless the same folks who
organize MegaT come over and do it here too, I doubt the result will be
as good.  SF doesn't have a *single* weekly event of the Megatripolis
type, which of course is a niche to fill but also indicates how difficult
it is to get something that substantial going.  I also tend to think
that the more episodic efforts like Wicked, Gathering, etc. have been
more successful in this environment despite the many problems, because
of specific characteristics of the SF scene.  For one thing, as major
as it is, the club/going-out-for-music scene even in SF isn't anywhere
near the size and visibility it has in the UK right now.  Megatripolis
is just one little corner of a massive upsurge in club culture.  Another
point: in the UK, it's generally not possible any more to *do* the kind
of one-off, warehouse or outdoor events which still happen fairly often
here.  This makes it more like the scene in the east, particularly New
York, which is pretty much limited to clubs (aside from underground
one-offs which are not really in the realm Megatripolis occupies anyway).

Finally, I wonder what the established club/event promoters are going to
think of yet another set of out-of-towners trying to establish something
in SF.  The crew that came over from the UK in 1990-91 adapted very well
to local conditions, but quite frankly the lack of cultural awareness
and "scene sensitivity" from the various missives and pronouncements of
the Zippies don't lead me to anticipate big success.  As I've said before,
better to take the DIY approach, blend in with the natives, figure out
what you can add to the scene where it needs it and you can do it.

But we don't need any damn leaders, thank you very much!


From sfraves-owner  Fri Jul 29 21:55:33 1994

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199407300340.UAA20112@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sunset at the Marina
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I guess it's a little late for a reveiw, but here goes:

We arrived at the Marina around 3:30 and Solar was spinning some very
funky grooves.  There were already lots of people dancing, but the
crowd lacked the critical mass at that point to really get off just yet.
But we could tell that 	SOMETHING was going to happen there that day.

First of all, it was beautiful!  The weather was perfect - sunny, with
just enough breeze to cool you down.  There were maybe over a hundred
people sitting on the gentle slope up from the dance area in front of
the decks and people were laughing, talking, passing around paper bags
of plums...the trees are dropping them by the dozens around here it seems!

Soon after we got there, the MESS crew (mostly people who live at Chateau,
a student co-op at UC Berkeley) arrived and planted a flag at the top
of the hill where everyone was sitting.  On one of the white stripes they
had printed "United States of Free Love."  I guess it's official!

Then they passed out a sheet for all the various soundsystems and parties
to fill out...mostly a fact sheet asking for rental info, soundsystem
& party contacts, voicemail info, etc...that they are going to compile into
a phone list of sorts to give out to people who want it.  (Hmm..maybe
they should have had a category of: places NOT to throw a party, considering
recent events...)

By then, Galen was starting his set.  The crowd was loving it!  There were
 a lot more people dancing and you could feel a definite vibe emanating
from dancers.  A lot of the people there were "regulars" that i've seen
there pretty much every weekend & it seemed like everyone was thinking:
"this is the best sunset party yet!"

Also in the park that day was another soundsystem that was set up at the
other end of a pathway that runs along the water and then into the park.
I checked it out: John (Jon?) was playing some progressive house with a lot
of energy, but there were only a few people there.  I got the impression
it wasn't a flyered party...does anyone know who they were?

Spun went on after Galen and he played well beyond the sunset....the crowd
wouldn't let him go and shouted for more when tried to quick when it got
dark, and so he kept on giving the people what they want.  You could see
the lights of the city coming on from across the bay...it was such a 
beautiful sight to see that and also so many people together experiencing
musical nirvana.  *sigh*

Oh, I forgot to mention all the kites!! And the woman walking her Doberman
who jumped in and started dancing!  (You should have seen her poor dog..
he was so confused!  But then he got into it & went around everywhere 
checking people out...) And the guy jumping off the hill with a parachute!
(no kidding...)

Unfortunately, there will be no sunset party this weekend, due to a kite
festival/contest that will be held there.  At least, this is what i heard
last sunday.  But maybe he'll change his mind and do it anyway?  Call the
info line & see!

-anthrax

Precedence: bulk


> Andrew, from what I could tell you did 
> everything you could to keep structure and form there, but when the event
> was sabotaged the control was lost, and that's where the negative energy
> comes from (I know Jump in the River will flame me on that one :) 

Nope; you answered the question yourself in the next sentence.

> HAD a
> sound system shown up at the second location, even with gang members there
> I don't think anyone would have been attacked or hurt.

You're probably right.

> I guess I just come
> from the school of thought that chaos is a highly inefficient method of 
> getting something done.

The important distinction here is that the event needed a focus (the
sound system), which usually causes the structure to form naturally.
I think this is a better way than imposing the structure from outside
based on what you _think_ will happen -- because you might not be
right, and then you have conflict.  This is the problem of authority
-- it tries to enforce the future.

It sounds like the afterparty had the opposite problem, which is that the
expected future never came, so the energy people brought was spent against
each other in the absence of a focus (music), and the spontaneous order
never emerged.

I don't believe everything should be chaos, or that everything
_should_ be anything at all other than what it is.  I believe that
most people deny that chaos exists at all, or maintain that it is a
bad thing that can and should be stomped out.  I prefer to surf the
edge of chaos, and if I sometimes get dunked, well, that's life, and
if I sometimes hit ordered land harder than I'd like, well, that's
life too.  It's the people who try to pave the sea that scare me.

// g

--- warning: self-promotion follows.  skip if such offends. ---

PS: Hey, I'm 100% done with the arcade game I've been working on for the
past (almost) two years!  If you see a T-MEK at yer local arcade, check it
out.  It's just starting to ship but many places around here are beta test
sites for us.  If not, ask.  It's easy to find; just follow the sound of
loud explosions.  I promise my next game will have techno in it; I wasn't
in charge of this one...

PPS: I finally dumped all my music-to-date to DAT, so Bryce, Steve,
and other interested folks should get to hear some of it soon.
Mysterious beautiful ambience, head-splitting power electronics,
bouncy electro-jazz damage, intense lights-off head trips, and more
not-very-classifiable stuff.  If you thought Richard James' ambient
was experimental this'll expand your mind.  If I generate enough interest
I'll probably press a CD...we'll see.  My bit on the Mind/Body CD was
about the harshest you can expect, but the sense of mystery (what _is_ that?)
remains...

--- end self-promotion ---

Unfortunately, the bottom half of my message was chopped off somewhere
along the line (you'll notice there was no .sig ).

I'm referring to style or sub-genre of music this DJ spins, ie
"progressive house", "acid trance", "gabber", and so forth.

The idea is that if you see a notice for an event, you at least have an
idea in advance what sort of music there will be.

As has been mentioned here before, very little information is provided
by promoters in advance.  [For example, for "Anthem of the Sun" last
night, there was no information other than a list of the DJs (in this
case, well known ones) and the location.  No age limit, cost, intended
starting or ending time, availability of water, exit priveleges, etc.]

Perhaps you thought I meant something like "flamboyant", "repressed",
"boring", "exciting"? :-) :-)

respect,

    Ken
    Ken.Stuart@tigerteam.org

require everyone on sfraves to submit a blood test indicating positive
presence of psychoactive substances? :-) :-)

Well, not quite Uncle Sam, but I want you - hyperreal has been up for
several weeks now and seems quite stable (needs to be rebooted
every couple of days, but I'm working on that) so I've been giving
out accounts to people willing to do projects here or help maintain
the mailing lists or archives.  I want to make hyperreal a real
community machine.  In exchange you get an account here, with
mail and news and all the usual Unix features, as well as a reliable
site for any other infomation-providing projects you might want to
work on.

If you are interested in helping out in sfraves-related projects here,
let me know.  Here's a sample of what I'd like to delegate:

1) Management of the sfraves list - basically someone to manage
bounces and the odd subscription request that didn't get automatically 
handled.  Approximately 20 minutes/day, but it needs to be done regularly.

2) Creation of and management of the SFRaves home page including
the pictures, flyers, and mailing list archives (possibly a couple
of people to work together on this)

3) Management of the Spirit and HoldYourOwn archives - putting these
documents into HTML and creating a nice interface to them, as well as 
updating them with other related documents lying around that belong
there. (possibly a couple of people here, too)

4) There are other projects I'm thinking about too... if you have
your own idea for something you think belongs here, let me know.

I have registered sfraves.org for this machine, and I'll be setting 
up the DNS for that soon.  If you're kinda in the dark about
what exactly we're all about, check out http://hyperreal.com/
or more specifically http://hyperreal.com/info/hyperreal/
for an idea.  If you don't have access to a web browser, telnet
to hyperreal.com and log in as "lynx" and it'll give you a text-
based hypertext browser.

Thanks in advance!

	Brian

References: <9407310331.aa22896@cruzio.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: William Penna <wpenna@cruzio.com>, KEN STUART <KEN.STUART@tigerteam.org>
Subject: Re: DJ identification: Say What?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm not the "Fred" on the list and I have NO idea who Joe and Gluph are :)

But if I were, I don't know if I want to be type-cast as far as DJ style.
While DJs have distinctive "styles" it's awfully hard to categorize beyond
the very broadest generalities.  You could say, for example, that Ethan
and Laura are both "techno-trance" DJs but they play very different styles
to my ears anyway.  If Jeno is a "house" DJ, then where do you make the
distinction with Markie, Digit, Neon Leon, Jan Cooley and Tony, all of
whom can fairly be described as "house" DJs but have totally different
styles.

It's hard to figure how I would fit into a typology, since my whole approach
to DJing is grounded in the house environment but reaches out to dub,
techno and trance of various types, '70s funk and some ambient stuff.

To some degree we need labels, shorthand handles for a much more complex
reality.  But it's all too easy to cross the line into fixation with
labeling.  The map is NOT the territory!

After a few dance steps at the so called new club "Universe", same old
thing (177 Townsend), I taxied over to Ultraviolet around 12:30 - 1:00 last
night and I thought the atmosphere was great.

Now talk about a positive change.  Right away the music dragged me
immediatly to the dance floor.  The music was really good with hard techno
trance.  Now correct me if I'm wrong but I think the djs' name was Craig.
Wonderful stuff.

After awhile I made my way to the ambient room.  Very cool space. I ran
into Alex (Gaia Mantra) and he pointed me to Steve (resonate).  It was nice
to meet him in person after having a few words with him here on sfraves.
-"He reminded me that he (WBL) will be playing live at Gaia Mantra on Sat.
August 6th at 2:00pm.  If I'm not mistaken I think he also mentioned that
he will be playing the ambient room at F&FIII".

This was my first time in that location, 788 Minna (at ninth street).  I
thought the space was layed out quite nice.  Both rooms were of fair size
and well ventilated.  For the somewhat short time that I was there I
thought the energy was real good.  I would go back for sure.  Did not see
too many familiar sfravers so if anybody else were there I would love to
hear your comments.

Denis, ravnbird@crl.com

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: tribal funk (horse)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Tribal Funk for $3 in a super secret San Francisco location
was on Friday night.  This party somehow just landed in 
my lap.  Special thanks to Mr Crunch for his sfr post.

To preface my review, I must admit my overwhelming desire 
for dancing that evening - I was giddy with anticipation.
A school girl

Around 1:00 or so I was directed into a secured parking area.
Near the water with pavement and gravel and rocks.
I would guess several hundred very beautiful people
Extremely Beautiful
Gorgeous, Frantic, Bubbly, Wild and Funky
not a sweaty pit
but Getting Down with an Urgency
a Fix
give it to me
all of it
Now

They moved around both sides of a dj/speaker area with some tents
and small fires off to the inland side.  A few decorated cars made
a loose semi-circle around this sortof designated chill area.

Within minutes (hours?) I was Bombarded with cookies, stickers,
flashing lights, nutty sounds, water, hugs and smiles
I had space to move - all around
Cool air to breathe (and smoke in)  
The sound was the Best  - dozens of sweet spots 
Decorations were minimal  
A low key underground
a Neo-Classical Rave Revivalist Movement

Simon, Christophe, Buck, Josh, Tracy is what I scratched onto
my directions.  I don't know who is what.  Tribal House with
liberal horns moved into Deeper House - busting out with the
Fusion references and some insane classic Jams.

By dawn there was a good crowd  
I could sense a Cast and Crew who knew their jobs
Worked me like a dog - and, overall, were as Cute as a Button
High Marks for the gratuitous Gogo dancing

I met almost no one - beyond the casual water/cigarette exchange
I wore a Red Hat and thought this was a Wonderful Party 

Dave

	id AA02992; Sun, 31 Jul 94 19:59:30 PDT

From: stevec@cafe.berkeley.edu (Steve Collins)
Message-Id: <9408010259.AA02992@cafe.berkeley.edu.noname>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Designing Society
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Early Tuesday morning I will be getting on a plane to spend a week at the
Summer School for Designing Society, which I'm including a description of
below.  I'll be joing up with the regular Summer School students who have
already been there for 4 weeks.  These people seem to be on the same track
as a lot of us are, so I thought some of you might be interested to know
about it.  If you have any questions or comments you'd like me to bring
along on your behalf, feel free to mail me before I leave (no email in South
Dakota, it seems).  I'll try to take good notes and bring back a full
report.

peace,
stevie

SUMMER SCHOOL FOR DESIGNING SOCIETY, a five-week seummer school in Sioux
Falls, South Dakota, is a project of composers, performers, teachers and
engineers working with students to build a desirable society.

Rather than orienting participants to find a "comfy" spot within the current
social system, this summer school offers time, ambiance, and tools with
which people can energetically imagine, discuss, and begin to design, a
system they would prefer.

The Summer School zigzags between social concerns and artistic concerns:

1.  Participants will explore the question "What would I consider a
desirable society?"  In addition to being asked to consult their wishes and
desires, students will be given conceptual tools from the areas of
cybernetics, information theory, and composition.

2.  Participants will consider the question "Can I learn to use my
imagination to write prose, music and theater that would have desirable
consequences on society?"  Skills for composing (music, prose, and theater)
will be taught, and time will be set aside for writing, rehearsing, and
performing.
